Publication.Essay:
The Akaroa Mail’s first bi-weekly issue was published on July 21 1876. It was begun by the peripatetic ‘rag-planter’ Joseph Ivess who began nearly 30 newspapers in clusters of small towns around New Zealand for three decades from the early 1870s. Ivess sold the Akaroa Mail a year later and there were several owners before, in 1881, the paper was bought by Howard C Jacobson. The Jacobson family was to own and run the newspaper for 71 years.

H C Jacobson, from Devon and educated at King’s College, London, was a school teacher before becoming, with Joseph Ivess, a part-owner of the Ashburton Mail, begun in 1877. Sale of his interest in the Ashburton paper helped fund his purchase of the Akaroa Mail. He was to run the newspaper until his death in 1910.

His daughter Ethel May Jacobson, the seventh of 14 children, excelled at Christchurch Girls’ High School and subsequently gained BA and MA degrees in English and French from Canterbury College. She was teaching in Nelson when, in 1903, her father became ill and called her home to help run the Akaroa Mail. She soon became editor and took full control from 1907, three years before her father died. She was then the legal owner, manager and editor. For almost 50 years, certainly a record, Ethel Jacobson was to remain the Akaroa Mail editor. Later, her younger brother, William took care of the business side of the paper. In time, there were four staff in the printing department.

Possibly Ethel Jacobson’s greatest achievement was her growing acceptance as a pioneering women editor at a time when the role was considered a male preserve. She was to become a familiar figure, with wide-brimmed hat and hobnailed boots, riding side-saddle over Banks Peninsula’s hilly terrain to report meetings and events. There were also launch trips to Pigeon Bay and Port Levy to ensure the detailed coverage that makes the newspaper an invaluable record of Banks Peninsula life. The newspaper was also, during her long editorship, widely respected for the standard of its journalism and high quality printing.

Ethel Jacobson, who never married, retired in 1952 and died, 88 years old, in 1965. The year she retired the Akaroa Mail was sold to George R Dobbie, who had worked for the Christchurch Star-Sun, and subsequently edited the newspaper for a number of years. In the early 1980s there was a decline in editorial standards and stock photographs were used frequently and often inappropriately.

Publication, continuous since 1876, was interrupted for two months in 1985 before publisher-editor Michael de Hamel took over, restored the previously high standards and substantially increased the paper’s circulation.

Nō te 21 o Hūrae 1876 i whakaputaina te putanga tuatahi o te Akaroa Mail, he mea whakaputa ia rua wiki. Nā te manu takiwhenua, te ‘rag-planter’ a Joseph Ivess, i tīmata, nāna hoki ngā niupepa 30 i tīmata i ngā kāhui taone iti puta noa i Aotearoa mō ngā tau 30 mai i te ekenga o ngā tau 1870. Kotahi tau i muri mai i hokona atu e Ivess te Akaroa Mail, ā, he āhua maha tonu ngā kaipupuri i mua i te hokotanga o te pepa e Howard C Jacobson i te tau 1881. Mō ngā tau 71 i puritia, i whakahaerehia te niupepa e te whānau Jacobson.

Nō Devon a H C Jacobson, i kuraina ki King’s College, Rānana, he kaiako kura a ia i mua i te hokotanga o te Ashburton Mail e rāua ko Joseph Ivess, i tīmata rā i te tau 1877. Nō te hokotanga atu o tāna wāhanga o te niupepa i whai pūtea āwhina a ia ki te hoko i te Akaroa Mail. Ka whakahaeretia e ia te niupepa tae noa ki tōna matenga i te tau 1910.

I tino puta te ihu o tāna tamāhine o Ethel May Jacobson, te tuawhitu o ngā tamariki 14, i te Kura Tuarua o Christchurch Girls’, ā, nō muri mai i whiwhi a ia i ana tohu Paetahi, Paerua hoki i te reo Ingarihi me te reo Wīwī mai i te Kāreti o Waitaha. He kaiako ia i Whakatū i 1903, ka pāngia tōna matua e te mate ka karangahia a ia kia hoki mai ki te kāinga hei ringa āwhina ki te whakahaere i te Akaroa Mail. Kāore i roa i piki a ia ki te tūranga o te ētita, ā, nō te tau 1907 i riro i a ia te mana whakahaere, e toru tau tērā i mua i te matenga o tōna pāpā. Nā konā ka noho a ia hei kaipupuri ā-ture, kaiwhakahaere, ētita hoki. I tata ki te 50 tau i noho tonu a Ethel Jacobson hei ētita o te Akaroa Mail kāore e kore he tino rongomau tērā. Nō muri mai ka riro i a William, tōna tungāne, te taha pakihi o te niupepa. I roto i te wā ka piki ngā kaimahi o te tari tā ki te whā.

Tērā pea ko te tino mahi i tutuki i a Ethel Jacobson ko te whakaaetanga ki tāna mahi hei wahine pakari, hei ētita, i tētahi wā e whakaaro nuitia ana he tūranga kē tērā mā te tāne anake. Ka āhua rongonui haere a ia, tana pōtae pārua-whānui me ana pūtu hopineira, e eke taha-tera ana i te hoiho i runga i ngā puke o Akaroa ki te hopu kōrero mō ngā huihuinga me ngā takahanga. I tua atu hoki ko ngā haereere mā runga waka ki Whakaroa (Pigeon Bay), ki Koukourarata (Port Levy) hoki, hei āta whakarite i te horanga āmiki, nā runga i tērā kua noho te niupepa hei puna kōrero kāmehameha mō te rohe o Akaroa. I te roanga atu o tōna wā roa hei ētita i mihia te niupepa mō te paerewa o āna mahi rīpoata, me te kounga nui hoki o ana mahi tā.

Kāore a Ethel Jacobson i mārena, ā, i mutu a ia i te tau 1952, nō te tau 1965 a ia i mate, 88 tau te pakeke. I te tau i mutu ai tana mahi i hokona te Akaroa Mail ki a George R Dobbie, he kaimahi nā te Christchurch Star-Sun, nāna te niupepa i ētita mō ētahi tau. I ngā tau tuatahi o 1980 i heke ko ngā paerewa ētita, ā, i whakamahia auautia ngā whakaahua puna, i ētahi wā anō kāore i tika te whakamahinga.

Tūmau ana te whakaputa mai i te tau 1876, engari i kotia mō te rua marama i te tau 1985 i mua i te taenga mai o te kaiwhakaputa-ētita a Michael de Hamel, nā konā i piki anō ai ki ngā paerewa teitei o mua, ā, i piki anō hoki te tokomaha o ngā kaipānui.

Publication.Title: Albertland Gazette
Publication.Description: The first issue of the Albertland Gazette appeared on 14 June 1862, on board the ‘Matilda Wattenbach’, a ship bringing settlers to found a nonconformist community on the Kaipara Harbour. Samuel Johnson (1827-1905) had been engaged as printer and editor. He managed to produce a second shipboard issue despite problems preventing his cases of type from being upset.

I tāia te putanga tuatahi o te Albertland Gazette i te 14 o Hune 1862, i runga i te kaipuke ‘Matilda Wattenbach’, he kaipuke tēnei i mau mai i ngā kainohonoho whakapono whakahē ki te Kaipara. Kua oti kē a Samuel Johnson (1827-1905) te tohu hei kaitā, hei ētita hoki. I tāia hoki e ia tētahi putanga tuarua i runga kaipuke ahakoa te āwangawanga kei huripokina ana pouaka reta.
Publication.Essay:
The first issue of the Albertland Gazette appeared on 14 June 1862, on board the ‘Matilda Wattenbach’, a ship bringing settlers to found a nonconformist community on the Kaipara Harbour. Samuel Johnson (1827-1905) had been engaged as printer and editor. He managed to produce a second shipboard issue despite problems preventing his cases of type from being upset.

Although the ship arrived in Auckland in September 1862, after a disagreement with settlement leader William Rawson Brame, Johnson spent time in Auckland and Dunedin, and did not arrive in Port Albert until March 1863.

He produced the third issue, and the first to be printed on land, on 1 August 1863, and the Albertland Gazette continued to appear on a monthly basis, until the last issue on 19 June 1864.

Exhausted by his role as publisher, editor, reporter and compositor, not to mention local postmaster, Johnson quit Port Albert, and later went on to establish the Marlborough Express in Blenheim.

I tāia te putanga tuatahi o te Albertland Gazette i te 14 o Hune 1862, i runga i te kaipuke ‘Matilda Wattenbach’, he kaipuke tēnei i mau mai i ngā kainohonoho whakapono whakahē ki te Kaipara. Kua oti kē a Samuel Johnson (1827-1905) te tohu hei kaitā, hei ētita hoki. I tāia hoki e ia tētahi putanga tuarua i runga kaipuke ahakoa te āwangawanga kei huripokina ana pouaka reta.

Ahakoa i tae atu te kaipuke ki Tāmaki-makau-rau i te marama o te Hepetema 1862, nā ngā tautohetohe ki te kaiārahi o te heke ki a William Rawson Brame, ka noho rawa a Johnson ki Tāmaki, me Ōtepoti mō tētahi wā, ā, nō te marama o Māehe 1863 kātahi anō ia ka tae atu ki Port Albert.

Ka tāia e ia te putanga tuatoru, ko te mea tuatahi tēnei kia tāia ki uta, i te 1 o Ākuhata 1863, ā, ka puta haere tonu te Albertland Gazette ia marama, ia marama, taea noatia te putanga whakamutunga i te 19 o Hune 1864.

Kua tino pau tana hau hei whakawhakaputa, hei ētita, hei kaikawe kōrero, hei kaitā hoki, tae atu hoki ki tana noho hei kaitiaki poutapeta, ā, ka wehe atu a Johnson i Port Albert, haere atu ana ki te whakatū i te Marlborough Express ki te Wairau.

Publication.Title: Ashburton Guardian
Publication.Description: The 1870s and 1880s saw a flurry of newspaper publishing in Ashburton. First there was the Ashburton Mail, established in 1877 by Joseph Ivess, a prolific publisher of country newspapers. This was followed by the Evening Echo in 1878. The next year Ivess published the Evening News to help him in his bid for the Ashburton mayoralty. Charles Dixon and Horace Weeks, the owners of the Echo, now called the Ashburton Herald, started the Ashburton Guardian to oppose Ivess’s ambitions. Ivess narrowly lost the election although it’s not clear what, if any, effect the Guardian had on this.

Nō ngā 1870 me ngā 1880 ka kitea ai te tini o te tā nūpepa i Ashburton. Tuatahi ko te Ashburton Mail, nō te 1877 ka tūria ai e Joseph Ivess, tētahi tino pū mō te tā i te tini o te nūpepa o tuawhenua. Nō te 1878 ka whai mai ai ko te Evening Echo. Nō te tau o muri mai, ka tāngia e Ivess te Evening News hei āwhina i tāna whai i te tūranga o te Mea o Ashburton. Nā Charles Dixon rāua ko Horace Weeks, ngā rangatira o te Echo, ko tōna ingoa hōu ko te Ashburton Herald, ka tāngia ai te Ashburton Guardian hei tohe i ngā wawata a Ivess. Ka hinga kau a Ivess, ēngari kāore i te mārama he aha te pānga mai o te Guardian ki taua hinganga nei.
Publication.Essay:
The 1870s and 1880s saw a flurry of newspaper publishing in Ashburton. First there was the Ashburton Mail, established in 1877 by Joseph Ivess, a prolific publisher of country newspapers. This was followed by the Evening Echo in 1878. The next year Ivess published the Evening News to help him in his bid for the Ashburton mayoralty. Charles Dixon and Horace Weeks, the owners of the Echo, now called the Ashburton Herald, started the Ashburton Guardian to oppose Ivess’s ambitions. Ivess narrowly lost the election although it’s not clear what, if any, effect the Guardian had on this.

The town couldn’t support four newspapers so in 1880 Edward George Wright and Hugo Friedlander, the new owners of the Herald and Guardian, merged their two papers under the title of the Ashburton Guardian. In 1884 the Mail was sold to William Jules Steward. Steward had worked on various papers in Canterbury and Otago and represented the area in local and national politics. In 1885 Steward acquired the Guardian as well.

Steward’s political commitments (he was a Member of the House of Representatives from 1881 to 1911), made it difficult for him to devote enough time to his papers and in the 1890s he leased them to Henry Willis, eventually selling them to Robert Bell in 1900.

Robert Bell had worked on newspapers in Australia and Timaru before coming to Ashburton. He would become Managing Director of the Lyttelton Times in 1917 and Chairman of the Timaru Post in 1922. Bell closed the Mail in 1932 and died in 1937. His son W.B. Bell succeeded him as manager.

The Guardian is still published by the Bell family, making it one of the few independently-owned daily newspapers left in New Zealand.

Nō ngā 1870 me ngā 1880 ka kitea ai te tini o te tā nūpepa i Ashburton. Tuatahi ko te Ashburton Mail, nō te 1877 ka tūria ai e Joseph Ivess, tētahi tino pū mō te tā i te tini o te nūpepa o tuawhenua. Nō te 1878 ka whai mai ai ko te Evening Echo. Nō te tau o muri mai, ka tāngia e Ivess te Evening News hei āwhina i tāna whai i te tūranga o te Mea o Ashburton. Nā Charles Dixon rāua ko Horace Weeks, ngā rangatira o te Echo, ko tōna ingoa hōu ko te Ashburton Herald, ka tāngia ai te Ashburton Guardian hei tohe i ngā wawata a Ivess. Ka hinga kau a Ivess, ēngari kāore i te mārama he aha te pānga mai o te Guardian ki taua hinganga nei.

Kāore i taea e te taone te tautoko i ngā nūpepa e whā, nō reira ka honoa e Edward George Wright rāua ko Hugo Friedlander, ngā rangatira hōu o te Herald me te Guardian, aua pepa e rua tahi nei ki te ingoa The Ashburton Guardian. Nō te 1844 ka hokona ai te Mail ki a William Jules Steward. Ko tā Steward he mahi ki ētahi tūmomo nūpepa i Waitaha me Otākou, ko ia hoki te māngai o taua takiwā ki te kāwanatanga ā-rohe, ā-motu hoki. Nō te 1885, ka riro i a Steward te Guardian rā anō hoki.

Nā ngā herenga tōrangapū a Steward (he Mema Paremata ia mai i te 1881 ki te 1911), ka uaua kē te whai taima mō āna nūpepa, nō ngā 1890 ka rīhingia ki a Henry Willis, te mutunga iho, ka hokona atu ki a Robert Bell i te tau 1900.

Ko tā Robert Bell he mahi nūpepa ki Ahitereiria me Timaru nō mua noa o tana taenga ki Ashburton. Ko ia te Kaiwhakahaere Matua o te Lyttelton Times i te 1917, te Hiamana hoki o te Timaru Post i te 1922. Ka katia e Bell te Mail i te 1932, ka mate i te 1937. Nō muri mai i a ia ko tāna tama ko W.B. Bell te kaiwhakahaere.

Kei te tāngia tonungia te Guardian e te whānau Bell, ko ia tētahi o ngā nūpepa ruarua noa o Aotearoa, ngā mea whai rangatira motuhake.

Publication.Essay:
The Evening Star first appeared in Auckland in January 1870 more by accident than careful design. With ambitions beyond his clerkship at one of Auckland’s morning dailies, the Southern Cross, William Ferrar placed an advertisement seeking a partner in a publishing venture. A former Presbyterian minister, the Rev George McCullagh Reed, responded while passing through Auckland on his way back to Australia from the West Coast goldfields, and the two men met. Despite having little capital, no influential friends and minimal experience, they quickly agreed to begin an afternoon paper, of more liberal persuasion, in opposition to the Evening News. Julius Vogel, manager of the Southern Cross, agreed to print copies of the four page paper, with Reed, who had some writing ability, the editor and Ferrar selling advertisements.

However, Reed unwisely pushed his temperance views in a town with a proliferation of pubs and taverns; more wisely he sought the advice of the New Zealand Herald’s £5 a week waterfront reporter Henry Brett. Advising that the lack of hard news was the problem, Brett took a third interest in the paper and was soon in charge with a young friend, Thomson Wilson Leys, formerly sub-editor of the Southern Cross, joining him. George Reed continued as editor until 1875, when Leys took over the role.

Brett became sole proprietor of the newspaper which was renamed the Auckland Evening Star in 1879 and Auckland Star in 1887. Brett and Leys subsequently formed a commercial partnership and successive generations of both families continued to play leading roles. The Brett Printing and Publishing Co. Ltd. became a public company in 1920. In 1929, following the purchase of the Lyttelton Times and Christchurch Star, the company became New Zealand Newspapers Ltd.

The newspaper’s growing success through the last decades of the nineteenth century was largely due to Brett’s commitment to providing as up-to-the moment news as possible. Before Auckland was linked to the telegraph, staff boarded arriving ships at the harbour entrance in specially-built boats to pick up English and Australian newspapers. Brett also used a dozen pigeons, from a Tasmanian breeder, to carry daily news from the Thames goldfields and from Tauranga where the telegraph line from Wellington ended in the early 1870s.

It was claimed that the Evening Star had a circulation of 2,700 copies in 1872, rising to 4,700 three years later. In 1884, now the Auckland Evening Star, the paper’s circulation had reached 10,000. In 1898, Brett claimed the Auckland Star had the country’s largest afternoon circulation – 15,000 copies a day.

The Star was one of the first newspapers in New Zealand to replace hand setting of type with linotype machines. It was also one of the first dailies to make regular use of photographs; the separate weekly magazine, the New Zealand Graphic, begun by Henry Brett in 1890, was illustrated from the beginning.

The Auckland Star was a major, innovative metropolitan daily until the early 1960s. Weakened, as most afternoon papers were, by the introduction of television, the Star, and NZ Newspapers Ltd., fell prey to a corporate raider, and ceased publication in 1991.

I puta tuatahi mai te Evening Star i Tāmaki-makaurau i te marama o Hānuere 1870, ā, he puta pokerehū tonu, kāore i āta whānau mārire mai ki te ao. Kei kō noa atu ngā moemoeā o William Ferrar e rere ana, tētahi o ngā karaka i tētahi o ngā niupepa o te ata o Tāmaki-makaurau te Southern Cross, i tāna mahi o ia rā. Ka whakaputaina e ia he pānui e rapu ana i tētahi hoa mō tētahi kōkiri whakaputa niupepa hōu. Ka whakautua tāna pānui e tētahi Minita nō te Hāhi Perehipitīriana i mua, e George McCullagh Reed, i a ia e hoki atu ana ki Ahitereiria mai i ngā keringa kōura o Te Tai Poutini, nā, ka tūtaki tēnei tokorua. Ahakoa he iti noa iho ngā moni punga, kāore he hoa whai mana nui, he iti noa iho hoki ngā akoranga o mua mō te mahi nei, tere tonu tā rāua whakaoti tikanga kia tīmataria he niupepa o te ahiahi, he āhua mākohakoha kē atu te titiro, arā, hei tauwhāinga ki te Evening News. I whakaae a Julius Vogel, te kaiwhakahaere o te Southern Cross, ki te tā i ētahi kape o te pepa, he whā whārangi te roa, ā, ko Reed, he tangata āhua matatau ki te tuhi, hei etita. Ko tā Ferrar mahi he hokohoko pānui hoko.

Ahakoa tērā, kāore i tino tika ngā mahi a Reed i tāna kauwhau i ōna whakaaro puru rīpene (whakamutu i te hoko waipiro) i tētahi tāone he tini ōna hōtera, wāhi inu hoki; nō muri mai ka kimi i ngā tohutohu a te kairīpoata o ngā wāpu o te New Zealand Herald, a Henry Brett, mō te £5 i te wiki, me te nui o ngā hua o taua whakaaro. Nā Brett ia i tohutohu ko te korenga o te rongo kōrero hou te tino mate, ā, ka hoko pānga a Brett ki te niupepa. Taro kau iho ka eke ia hei kaiwhakahaere o te niupepa, me tōna hoa taitamariki a Thomson Wilson Leys, te etita o raro o te Southern Cross i mua. I haere tonu te etita nei a George Reed hei etita, taea noatia te tau 1875 i eke atu a Leys ki taua tūranga.

Ka eke a Brett hei rangatira takitahi o te niupepa, ā, ka whakaingoatia anō ko te Auckland Evening Star i te tau 1879 me te Auckland Star i te tau 1887. I uru tonu a Brett rāua ko Leys ki tētahi mahi tahitanga arumoni i muri, ā, i noho anō ngā whakatupuranga o ngā whānau e rua ki te kawe i ngā tūranga maha. Ka huri te Brett Printing and Publishing Co. Ltd. hei kamupene tūmatanui i te tau 1920. Nō te tau 1929, nō muri i tāna hoko i te Lyttelton Times me te Christchurch Star, ka huri te kamupene hei New Zealand Newspapers Ltd.

Ko te take i whanake ai te niupepa i roto i ngā tekau tau whakamutunga o te rau tau tekau mā iwa, ko te ū o Brett ki te hora i ngā rongo kōrero tino mohoa nei. I mua i te hononga o Tāmaki-makaurau ki te tarikarāwhe, i haere atu ngā kaimahi ki ngā kaipuke i ngā putanga ki te pūau o Tāmaki mā runga i ngā poti i āta hangaia mārire, ki te tiki atu i ngā niupepa tino hou o Ingarangi me Ahitereiria. I whakamahia hoki ētahi kūkupa kawe kōrero tekau mā rua e Brett, mai i tētahi kaiwhakatupu kūkupa nō Tahimānia, hei kawe i ngā rongo kōrero mai i ngā keringa kōura o Hauraki me Tauranga, te wāhi i mutu atu ai te waea tarikarāwhe i Pōneke i ngā tau tuatahi mai o 1870.

E kīia ana i taua wā tata ki te 2,700 niupepa te tohanga o te Evening Star i te tau 1872, ā, kua piki ki te 4,700 e toru tau i muri mai. Nō te tau 1884, i raro i te ingoa te Auckland Evening Star, kua piki te tohanga o te niupepa ki te 10,000. I te tau 1898, ka puta te kōrero a Brett kua kake te tohanga o te Auckland Star kia noho koia te tino niupepa ahiahi awatea he nui rawa te tohanga o te motu katoa – 15,000 ngā kape ia rā.

Ko te Star tētahi o ngā niupepa tuatahi o Aotearoa ki te whakakapi i te tāpae ā-ringa i ngā momotuhi, ki ngā mīhini linotype. Koia hoki tētahi o ngā niupepa ā-rā tuatahi ki te whakamahi auau i te whakaahua; inā hoki i puta haere tonu he whakaahua i te maheni ā-wiki, te New Zealand Graphic. Nā Henry Brett tēnei i tīmata i te tau 1890.

He tino niupepa ā-rā, ā-tāone hoki te Auckland Star, nā, he niupepa nui, auaha hoki taea noatia ngā tau tuatahi mai o 1960. He mea whakangoikore te niupepa, pēnei i te nuinga o ngā niupepa o te ahiahi o taua wā, e te pouaka whakaata. Ka raru te Star, me NZ Newspapers Ltd, ā, ka riro i tētahi kamupene horomi kamupene kē, nā, ka mutu noa iho tōna putanga mai i te tau 1991.

Publication.Title: Bush Advocate
Publication.Title-alternate: Takapau, Ormondville, Norsewood, Makotuku, Danevirke, and Wainui District Advertiser; Dannevirke Advocate
Publication.Description: James Clayton established the Bush Advocate in Dannevirke (in Hawke's Bay) on 8 May 1888. It started as a tri-weekly newspaper published on Tuesdays, Thursday and Saturdays. The paper intended to be the voice of a large geographic area, which was clear from its subtitle: the Takapau, Ormondville, Norsewood, Makotuhu, Dannevirke and Wainui District Advertiser.

Nā James Clayton te Bush Advocate i whakatū ki Tāmaki-nui-ā-Rua (Dannevirke) i te rohe o Hawkes Bay i te 8 o Haratua 1888. I te tīmatanga e toru ngā putanga ki te wiki, arā, ka whakaputaina i te Tūrei, te Tāite, me te Rāhoroi. Ko tāna, he reo mō te rohe whānui, koia rā tōna taitara-iti: "The Takapau, Ormondville, Norsewood, Makotuhu, Dannevirke and Wainui District Advertiser".
Publication.Essay:
James Clayton established the Bush Advocate in Dannevirke (in the Manawatu) on 8 May 1888. The paper intended to cover a wide area, which can be seen from its rather long subtitle: 'the Takapau, Ormondville, Norsewood, Makotuhu, Dannevirke and Wainui District Advertiser.'

Clayton had installed a quality press and the Bush Advocate was well produced from the start. It did not aim to represent any factional views but sought to serve the business needs of the communities in which it circulated and to report local news faithfully.

The paper began life as a tri-weekly, published on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. In 1893 Clayton sold it to David Curle, who had had extensive experience with Havelock and Wellington newspapers. New owners took over in 1901 and renamed the paper the Dannevirke Advocate.

They in turn sold it to Thomas Lindsay Buick and John Ruffell Russell, in 1903. The paper flourished under their control and became a daily, expanding its news gathering service deep into the Hawke's Bay back country.

Buick had been a Member of Parliament for Wairau, was an accomplished orator and journalist and the author of many books on New Zealand history (including a comprehensive survey of the early history of Marlborough). His interest in the Advocate continued until 1912 when the paper was sold and merged with the Dannevirke Evening News.

Nā James Clayton te Bush Advocate i whakatū ki Tāmaki-nui-ā-Rua (Dannevirke) i te rohe o Hawkes Bay i te 8 o Haratua 1888. Ko tāna mahi, he reo mō te rohe whānui, koia rā mai i te roa o tōna taitara-iti: "The Takapau, Ormondville, Norsewood, Makotuhu, Dannevirke and Wainui District Advertiser".

He huarangi te painga o te perehi a Clayton, ā, he pērā anō te whakaputanga o te Bush Advocate mai tōna tīmatanga. Kāore ōna whiunga kōaro, he hāngai tonu ki ngā hiahia pakihi o ana hapori, ā, i rīpoata tikangia ai ngā kōrero o te rohe.

I te tīmatanga e toru ngā putanga ia wiki, arā, ka whakaputaina i ngā Tūrei, ngā Taite, me ngā Rāhoroi. I te tau 1893 ka hokona te nūpepa e Clayton ki a David Curle, he tautōhito ki ngā nūpepa o Havelock me Pōneke. I te tau 1901, he rangatira hou anō ōna, nā rātou i tapa ki te ingoa hou, ko te Dannevirke Advocate.

Kātahi ka hokona e rātou ki a Thomas Lindsay Buick rāua ko John Ruffell Russell i te tau 1903. Ka kaha te tupu i raro i a rāua, ka huri hei nūpepa o ia rā, me te whakawhānui ake i āna kohi kōrero ki roto rā anō i ngā wāhi taratahi o te rohe o Te Matau-a-Māui (Hawke's Bay).

He Mema Pāremata a Buick mō Wairau, he pukenga ki te whaikōrero, ki te tuhi kōrero hoki, he maha hoki āna pukapuka e pā ana ki te kōrero o nehe o Aotearoa (me tētahi tirohanga whānui o te tāhuhu kōrero o te rohe o Wairau (Marlborough). Ka haere tonu tāna whaiwāhi i te Advocate tae noa ki te tau 1912, te wā i hokona ai te nūpepa, ā, i hanumia ai ki te Dannevirke Evening News.

Publication.Title: Bruce Herald
Publication.Description: The Bruce Herald was published at Milton from 1864 to 1971. It was one of New Zealand’s longest running country newspapers. The Herald was established by Joseph Mackay, a stationer and publisher from Dunedin. The Herald was one of a chain of newspapers that Mackay ran in Otago in the 1860s and 70s. Other papers in the chain included the Mataura Ensign at Gore and the Clutha Times at Balclutha.

I tāngia te Bruce Herald i Milton mai i te tau 1864 ki 1971. Koia tētahi o ngā nūpepa taiwhenua i tino roa ai te tānga. Nā Joseph Mackay te Herald i whakaū arā, he kaihoko pānga pukapuka, he kaitā nūpepa hoki ia nō Ōtepoti. Ko te Herald tētahi o te mekameka nūpepa i whakahaeretia e Mackay i Ōtākou i waenganui i te huinga tau mai i 1860 ki te 1880. Ko ētahi atu nūpepa i whakauru ki taua mekameka ko Te Mataura Ensign i Gore, ko te Clutha Times i Balclutha.
Publication.Essay:
The Bruce Herald was published at Milton from 1864 to 1971. It was one of New Zealand’s longest running country newspapers.

The Herald was established by Joseph Mackay, a stationer and publisher from Dunedin. The Herald was one of a chain of newspapers that Mackay ran in Otago in the 1860s and 70s. Other papers in the chain included the Mataura Ensign at Gore and the Clutha Times at Balclutha.

Financial difficulties in the late 1870s forced Mackay out of newspaper publishing and in 1879 he sold the Herald to Francis Grant & Co. The paper changed hands several more times over the next fifty years. Reginald Augustus Pyke was probably the most significant of the later owners. Pyke ran and edited the paper several times between 1896 and 1915. His editorial policy was unashamedly parochial as he used the Herald to advance the economic interests of Milton and Bruce County. His lobbying, through the pages of the Herald, was instrumental in attracting a woollen mill to the town. The mill was for many years one of the main employers in Milton.

The Bruce Herald had a number of rivals in Milton between 1866 and 1910. The most notable were the Bruce Independent (1866-1867) and the Milton Mirror (1905-1910). The Independent provided some real competition for the short time it ran. Under Edward T. Gillon the paper gained much attention locally for its strong anti-provincial editorial policy. The impact of the Independent was such that the Herald increased the size of its issues from 4 to 8 pages. However Gallon’s views were too strong or at least too vigorously expressed for the directors of the Independent and the paper was wound up in 1867. The Milton Mirror was published by Charles Lewis Grant, a former employee of the Herald. The Mirror met with some success but was taken over by the Herald after a fire destroyed the Mirror’s office in 1910.

The Herald ceased publication on 7 October 1971.

I tāngia te Bruce Herald i Milton mai i te tau 1864 ki 1971. Koia tētahi o ngā nūpepa taiwhenua i tino roa ai te tānga.

Nā Joseph Mackay te Herald i whakaū arā, he kaihoko pānga pukapuka, he kaitā nūpepa hoki ia nō Ōtepoti. Ko te Herald tētahi o te mekameka nūpepa i whakahaeretia e Mackay i Ōtākou i waenganui i te huinga tau mai i 1860 ki te 1880. Ko ētahi atu nūpepa i whakauru ki taua mekameka ko Te Mataura Ensign i Gore, ko te Clutha Times i Balclutha.

Nā ngā raruraru pūtea i āki i a Mackay kia mahue i a ia te mahi whakatā nūpepa i ngā tau whakamutunga o te tekau tau mai i 1870, ā, i te tau 1879 ka hokona e ia te Herald ki te kamupene o Francis Grant & Co. He nui anō ngā ringa i whakawhitihia ai te nūpepa i roto i ngā tau e rima tekau i muri mai. Ko Reginald Augustus Pyke pea te tino tangata hira o ngā kaihoko tōmuri. He nui tonu ngā wā nā Pyke te nūpepa i whakahaere, i whakatikatika hoki i waenganui i ngā tau 1896 me 1915. He mea māia tonu te titiro whāiti o tōna kaupapa whakapuaki, i tāna whakamahi hoki i te Herald hei āki whakamua i ngā painga ohaoha o Milton me te takiwā o Bruce. Nā āna whakahau, rā ngā whārangi o te Herald, i āwhina kia kukume ai tētahi mira mahi wūru ki te tāone. He maha tonu ngā tau i noho ai ko taua mira tētahi o ngä kaiwhakawhiwhi mahi matua i Milton.

He nui tonu ngā nūpepa tāwhai o te Bruce Herald i Milton i waenganui i ngā tau 1866 me 1910. Ko ngā mea nui rawa ko te Bruce Independent (1866-1867) rāua ko te Milton Mirror (1905-1910). Nā te Independent te tino tauwhāinga mō te wā poto i haere ai ia. I raro i a Edward T. Gillon i riro i taua nūpepa te āro nui o te iwi kāinga mō te tū ārai ki ngā porowini o tōna kaupapa whakapuaki. Anō te pänga o te Independent, i whakarahia e te Herald te tau o ana whārangi mai i te whā ki te waru. Heoi anō he pakari rawa nō ngā whakaaro o Gillon, he kaha rawa rānei nō te whakapuakitanga, ina rā ki te titiro a ngā kaihautū o te Independent, ā, ka katia te nūpepa i te tau 1867. Nā Charles Lewis Grant te Milton Mirror i whakatā, he kaimahi nā te Herald i mua. I angitu pai ai te Mirror ēngari i taumanutia e te Herald i te weratanga o te tari o te Mirror i te ahi i te tau 1910.

Mutu rawa te tānga o te Herald i te 7 o Whiringa-ā-nuku 1971

Publication.Title: Bay of Plenty Times
Publication.Description: The Bay of Plenty Times first appeared on 4 September 1872, as a bi-weekly, tabloid sized newspaper. Although the paper experienced some difficult times in its first 40 years, it continued to be published and has prospered to now become one of New Zealand's largest daily newspapers.

Ko te Bay of Plenty Times he nūpepa hīnohi i tāngia tuatahitia i te 4 o Mahuru 1872, ā, e rua ngā putanga ki te wiki kotahi. Ahakoa ngā uaua o ngā tau tīmatanga e 40, tāngia tonungia ana, kua puāwai, ā, i tēnei wā koia tētahi o ngā nūpepa nui o Aotearoa e whakaputa atu ana ia rā.
Publication.Essay:
The Bay of Plenty Times is currently one of the New Zealand's largest daily newspapers but for many years its existence was precarious and it came close to folding on a number of occasions.

It was first produced on 4 September 1872 as a bi-weekly publication. It consisted of four pages in tabloid size and cost three pence per issue. The founder and editor was WB Langbridge.

Ownership of the Times changed many times over the next 40 years, including several times through mortgagee sales. Despite the hardships the Times issued a Christmas supplement in 1897, which featured one of the earliest use of photographs in New Zealand newspapers.

From 1913 the paper enjoyed stability after the Gifford and Cross families took over. Both families were associated with the paper until it was sold to Wilson and Horton in 1992. Ownership changed again in 1996 when Independent Newspapers PC from Dublin acquired a controlling interest in Wilson and Horton.

In 1976 a fire destroyed the newspaper's entire collection of back issues. Fortunately the publisher had kept copies on microfilm and these are now held by the Alexander Turnbull Library.

The Times has prospered in the last 50 years and appears secure. Its progress has been linked with that of the Bay of Plenty, which has grown rapidly and continuously since Mt Maunganui became an export port in the early 1950s.

Ko te Bay of Plenty Times i tēnei wā tētahi o ngā tino nūpepa o Aotearoa e whakaputa atu ana ia rā, engari mō ngā tau maha i nui ngā raruraru, ā, ka maha ngā wā ka tata rā anō te kati.

I tāngia tuatahitia i te 4 o Mahuru 1872, ā, e rua ngā putanga ki te wiki. E whā ōna whārangi, he nūpepa hīnohi, ā, e toru kapa te utu. Ko tōna kaihanga, tōna ētitaētita hoki, ko W.B. Langbridge.

Ki roto i ngā tau e 40 o muri mai, he maha ngā hokonga i te Times, ā, ko ētahi anō, he hoko ā-mokete. Ahakoa ngā pōrarurarutanga nō te tau 1897 ka tāngia ai e te Times tētahi āpititanga Kirihimete me te whakaatu whakaahua, arā, he mea hōu ki roto i ngā nūpepa o te wā i Aotearoa.

Mai i te tau 1883, mai i te hokonga e ngā whānau Gifford, Cross hoki ka āhua tatū te puehu. Ko aua whānau tonu ōna rangatira tae noa ki te hokonga ki te kamupene Wilson me Horton i te tau 1992. Ka hokona anō i te tau 1996, nō te rironga i a Independent Newspapers PC o Tapurini (Dublin) te nuinga o ngā hea o Wilson and Horton.

I te tau 1976 ka kāinga e te ahi te katoa o ōna putanga tawhito. He waimarie nō te pupurutanga e te kaitā he kape ki runga kiriata mōkito, e tiakina ana i tēnei wā i te Whare Pukapuka a Alexander Turnbull.

Kua puāwai te Times i ngā tau e 50 kua taha nei, tēnā pea kua tū kaha. Ko tōna whakawhanaketanga he mea haere tahi ki tō te rohe o Te Waiariki, me te tere o tāna tupu mai i te whakatūnga a Maunganui hei whanga hokotai i te tīmatanga o te tekau tau atu i 1950.

Publication.Title: Bay of Plenty Beacon
Publication.Description: From the 1840s there was a good early relationship between the Ngati Awa tribe and the slowly growing number of Europeans living in the Whakatane area. This had changed by the mid-1860s. There was widespread Maori adoption of the new Pai Maire religion and the teachings of prophet Te Ua Haumene were peaceful, but the murder of Europeans in the Bay of Plenty by Hau Hau followers resulted in the confiscation of Ngati Awa’s lands. Following Te Kooti’s raid on Whakatane in 1869, there was a determined effort by European settlers and local Maori to re-establish community and economic life in the township.

Mai i te ngahurutanga tau 1840-1850 he pai tonu te wairua o te noho tahi o te iwi o Ngāti Awa me te tokopae āta tupu o te hunga Pākehā e noho ana i te rohe o Whakatāne. Te taenga ki waenganui i te ngahurutanga 1860-1870, kua puta kē te āhua. Kua tīmata te huri a te tini o ngāi Māori ki te whakapono Pai Mārire. He rangimārie ngā akoranga a te poropiti a Te Ua Haumene, engari nā te kōhurutanga i ngā Pākehā i te Moana a Toi e ngā Hau Hau, ka murua ngā whenua o Ngāti Awa. I muri i te whakaekenga a Te Kooti ki Whakatāne i te tau 1869, ka tīmata anō te kōkiri a ngā kainohonoho Pākehā, me ngā Māori ki te waihanga i te oranga ohaoha, oranga hapori hoki i te tāone.

Ka āhei koe ki te tārua i ngā rawa whai-manatārua o tēnei nūpepa mō ngā take arumoni-kore i raro i tētahi raihana Creative Commons New Zealand BY-NC-SA . Publication.Essay:
From the 1840s there was a good early relationship between the Ngati Awa tribe and the slowly growing number of Europeans living in the Whakatane area. This had changed by the mid-1860s. There was widespread Maori adoption of the new Pai Maire religion and the teachings of prophet Te Ua Haumene were peaceful, but the murder of Europeans in the Bay of Plenty by Hau Hau followers resulted in the confiscation of Ngati Awa’s lands. Following Te Kooti’s raid on Whakatane in 1869, there was a determined effort by European settlers and local Maori to re-establish community and economic life in the township.

Whakatane had a population of a little over 200 when the first attempt was made to establish a newspaper. The Whakatane Times and Opouriao Advocate began its short life in 1899 but there were not sufficient readers or advertisers for it to survive beyond its first two months. The paper edited by H G Walmsley, was backed by Daniel McGarvey, a one-time compositor on Auckland’s Southern Cross.

In 1901 there were 781 Europeans and between 3-4,000 Maori in Whakatane County. The township’s population had risen sufficiently by 1907 for the Whakatane County Press, using the Times plant, to have more sustained success. The owner, Charles Gibbs Beckett, was well-known for starting newspapers.

According to the Thames Star in January 1907: ‘Mr C G Beckett bids fair to rival the fame of Mr Joseph Ivess as a newspaper ‘planter’. He is the proprietor of the Northern Wairoa Times, the Whangarei Morning Press and the Waihi Times, and he is now establishing a fourth at Whakatane, to be known as the Whakatane County Press. Years ago Mr Beckett established several papers in the Wairarapa district, and for some time he owned the Inglewood Record.’

Following the paper’s first issue on 14 January Wellington’s Evening Post reported that it ‘is a double-demy sheet, and claims to be the first penny paper in the Bay of Plenty. As befits a county paper, it gives full prominence to local news and local requirements.’ It appeared three times a week and was published in the morning. It may have been a daily for a time in 1916.

One newspaper, at least, was less welcoming. In December 1907 the Bay of Plenty Times commented: ‘We notice that the Whakatane County Press makes very free with the articles in this paper by publishing them in its leading columns as original matter. We have no objection to incompetent papers copying our articles, provided they acknowledge their source instead of stealing them.’

During the period 1916-1921 Whakatane was the fastest growing town in New Zealand, contributing factors being the congenial climate, fertile alluvial plains and lower hill country and the increasing importance of the port at Whakatane. Forestry, fishing, and dairying were all important.

In 1919 the Whakatane County Press was bought by the Bay of Plenty Printing Company and in 1923 changed back to evening publication. In 1935, it absorbed the East Coast Guardian from Opotiki and the paper’s title was changed to Bay of Plenty Press. The Bay of Plenty Press stopped publication at the beginning of 1939 and two months later F J Reynolds formed the Beacon Printing and Publishing Company and took over the Press’s machinery. The first issue of the Bay of Plenty Beacon, a tri-weekly, appeared in April 1939.

The Whakatane Beacon, as the paper is now called, is a broadsheet publication printed three times a week, on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and on Fridays. It has a circulation of about 8,400. The Beacon Printing and Publishing Company also publishes the Bay Weekend, a tabloid newspaper delivered free every Saturday to every home in the greater Eastern Bay area.

Mai i te ngahurutanga tau 1840-1850 he pai tonu te wairua o te noho tahi o te iwi o Ngāti Awa me te tokopae āta tupu o te hunga Pākehā e noho ana i te rohe o Whakatāne. Te taenga ki waenganui i te ngahurutanga 1860-1870, kua puta kē te āhua. Kua tīmata te huri a te tini o ngāi Māori ki te whakapono Pai Mārire. He rangimārie ngā akoranga a te poropiti a Te Ua Haumene, engari nā te kōhurutanga i ngā Pākehā i te Moana a Toi e ngā Hau Hau, ka murua ngā whenua o Ngāti Awa. I muri i te whakaekenga a Te Kooti ki Whakatāne i te tau 1869, ka tīmata anō te kōkiri a ngā kainohonoho Pākehā, me ngā Māori ki te waihanga i te oranga ohaoha, oranga hapori hoki i te tāone.

Kei te 200 tāngata te taupori o Whakatane, i te tīmatanga tuatahitanga rawa o ngā mahi whakatū niupepa. I tīmata te oranga poto o te Whakatane Times and Opouriao Advocate i te tau 1899, engari kāore i rahi ngā kaipānui, te hunga whakatairanga hokohoko rānei e ora ai ia, i tua atu i ōna marama tuatahi e rua. He mea ētita te niupepa e H G Walmsley, ā, he mea tautoko e Daniel McGarvey, tētahi o ngā kairaweke tā i te Southern Cross o Tāmaki-makau-rau.

I te tau 1901 e 781 ngā Pākehā, i waenga hoki i te 3-4,000 ngā Maori i te takiwā o Whakatāne. Nō te taenga ki te tau 1907 kua piki te taupori o te tāone, i āhei ai te Whakatane County Press te whanake, te tū. I whakamahia e ia ngā mīhini o te Times. He rongonui te ingoa o te rangatira a Charles Gibbs Beckett, mō te whakarewa i tēnei mea te niupepa huri noa.

E ai ki te Thames Star i te marama o Hānuere 1907: ‘E kore pea e kore ka rite te rongo o Mr C G Beckett ki tōna hoa tauwhāinga ki a Mr Joseph Ivess hei 'kaiwhakatō' niupepa. Koia te rangatira o te Northern Wairoa Times, o te Whangarei Morning Press me te Waihi Times, ā, i tēnei wā kei te whakatū ia i tētahi mea tuawhā ki Whakatāne, e mōhiotia ai ko te Whakatane County Press. I ngā tau o mua ka whakatūria e Mr Beckett ētahi niupepa i te takiwā o Wairarapa, ā, koia hoki te rangatira o te Inglewood Record mō tētahi wā.’

I muri i te putanga tuatahi o te niupepa i te 14 o Hānuere, ka puta te pūrongo a te Evening Post, i Pōneke, 'he rau double-demy, ā, e mea ana rātou koia te pepa kapa-tahi tuatahi ki te Moana a Toi'. Kia tika ai te kī he pepa ā-takiwā, e kī katoa ana i ngā rongorongo ā-rohe, me ngā kaupapa ā-takiwā.' E toru ōna putanga ia wiki, ā, ka whakaputaina i ngā ata. He niupepa ā-rā mō te wā poto i te tau 1916.

Kotahi te niupepa kāore i kaha rawa te tautoko i tōna whānautanga mai. Nō te marama o Tīhema 1907 ka puta te kōrero a te Bay of Plenty Times: 'E kite ana mātou kei te ngana te Whakatāne County Press ki te tāhae i ngā tuhinga rongo kōrero o tēnei niupepa me te pānui anō i aua tuhinga, ānō nei nāna i tito, i tuhi. Kāore kau mātou e whakahē i ngā niupepa kaha-kore e tārua nei i ā mātou tuhinga, engari me whakaingoa i te puna i kitea ai, kaua e haere mai ki te tāhae i aua tuhinga.'

I waenga i ngā tau 1916-1921 ko Whakatāne tētahi o ngā tāone hohoro rawa ki te tupu i Aotearoa. Ko te take ko te tū o te rangi, he huarere tino mahana, te mōmona o te oneone o ngā raorao, o ngā pārae, ngā hiwi o raro, me te pikinga ake o te mana o te wahapū i Whakatane. He mea tino nui anō hoki te tope rākau, te hī ika, me te mahi kūtētē kau.

Nō te tau 1919 ka hokona te Whakatane County Press e te Bay of Plenty Printing Company, ā, nō te tau 1923 ka hoki anō hei putanga ā-ahiahi. I te tau 1935, ka horomia e ia te East Coast Guardian o Ōpōtiki, ka hurihia te taitara ki te Bay of Plenty Press. I mutu te putanga o te Bay of Plenty Press i te tīmatanga o 1939. E rua marama i muri mai nā F J Reynolds i whakatū te Beacon Printing and Publishing Company, ā, ka riro i a ia ngā mīhini o te Press. I puta mai te putanga tuatahi o te Bay of Plenty Beacon, he toru putanga ia wiki, i te marama o te Āperira 1939.

E kīa ana ināianei ko te Whakatane Beacon. He putanga whārangi whānui ia, ā, e toru ōna putanga ia wiki i te Tūrei, i te Wenerei, me te Paraire hoki. E 8,400 ōna kape ka hokona. Kei te whakaputa te Beacon Printing and Publishing Company i te Bay Weekend, he niupepa ā-papa, ki ia kāinga i te rohe whānui o te Moana ā-Toi ki te Rāwhiti.

Publication.Title: Charleston Argus
Publication.Description: Charleston and its newspaper appeared as the direct and immediate result of a major gold discovery in 1867, about 30km south of Westport on the West Coast. Gold was also discovered at Brighton, 10 miles to the south, the same year. The 1867 census showed that the fields at Charleston and Brighton had a combined population of about 11,000. There were also 53 hotels at Brighton or nearby and a further 37 at Charleston.

I tupu tōtika mai te tāone o Charleston me tōna nūpepa i runga i te kitenga o te taonga nei te kōura i te tau 1867, tata ki te 30 km ki te tonga o Westport i te Tai Poutini. I kitea hoki te kōura i Brighton, 10 māero ki te tonga, i taua tau anō. I te tau 1867 kua eke te taupori katoa o ngā keringa kōura i Charleston me Brighton ki te takiwā o 11,000. Kua eke ki te 53 ngā hōtēra i Brighton i kō tata atu rānei, me tōna 37 hōtēra anō ki Charleston.
Publication.Essay:
Charleston and its newspaper appeared as the direct and immediate result of a major gold discovery in 1867, about 30km south of Westport on the West Coast. Gold was also discovered at Brighton, 10 miles to the south, the same year. The 1867 census showed that the fields at Charleston and Brighton had a combined population of about 11,000. There were also 53 hotels at Brighton or nearby and a further 37 at Charleston.

After John Tyrrell had begun the Westport Times in 1866 he opportunistically added Charleston Argus to the title and briefly moved his plant to the new settlement. The Brighton Times and Pakihi Reporter had appeared earlier but was absorbed into the stand-alone Charleston Argus after it was launched in March 1867. Tyrrell dropped the ‘Charleston Argus’ add-on from his Westport paper’s masthead in 1869.

Wellington’s Evening Post reported on 9 March: ‘Judging from the manner in which the Press is supported in gold fields districts, we may safely prognosticate for our contemporary a lucrative existence until the rich country of the Buller is worked out. The management are experienced journalists, and will probably bring out the new journal in such a manner as to ensure for it a cordial reception.’

In its first issue the Charleston Argus was bullish about prospects: ‘On the middle flat fortune is variable, but on the whole the fickle goddess is favourable to the miners. Water is greatly needed, however, and if this is got there is from two to three years' work before the claimholders. Fuller and party have been at work about three months here. They have cut a water race, and are now ground sluicing, and average from £10 to £14 per man per week.’ (From about $1,000 to nearly $1,500 today.)

The well-produced bi-weekly was subsequently renamed Charleston Herald and Mining Reporter by Charles Mirfin, who later became editor of the Inangahua Herald. A further change came when the latter part of the name was dropped in favour of Brighton Times.

John Tyrrell, an Irishman, emigrated to the United States after finishing his apprenticeship and worked there for some years. He arrived in Australia in 1859-1860 and was compositor on the Melbourne Chronicle and Ballarat Times before moving to New Zealand. After a period on The Press in Christchurch he moved to Hokitika, beginning the Hokitika Chronicle as well as the Westport Times and Charleston Argus.

In 1886, Thomas Dolman, proprietor for some years, sold the paper to Irish journalist Patrick Kittson, who had served his apprenticeship as a printer on the Melbourne Argus. When he died in 1893 his widow and children continued the business. First, Norah Kittson’s two sons, aged 12 and 10, largely ran the paper and, following their early deaths from TB in 1902, she and her daughters continued to publish, firstly as a weekly and then more irregularly, until 1911. By this time Charleston Riding’s population had dwindled to 264.

I tupu tōtika mai te tāone o Charleston me tōna nūpepa i runga i te kitenga o te taonga nei te kōura i te tau 1867, tata ki te 30 km ki te tonga o Westport i te Tai Poutini. I kitea hoki te kōura i Brighton, 10 māero ki te tonga, i taua tau anō. I te tau 1867 kua eke te taupori katoa o ngā keringa kōura i Charleston me Brighton ki te takiwā o 11,000. Kua eke ki te 53 ngā hōtēra i Brighton i kō tata atu rānei, me tōna 37 hōtēra anō ki Charleston.

I muri i te tīmatanga a John Tyrrell i te Westport Times i te tau 1866 ka tāpiritia e ia te Charleston Argus ki te taitara ā, ka nekehia e ia ana mīhini ki te kāinga hou. Kua puta kē noa atu te Brighton Times and Pakihi Reporter engari i whakahanumitia ki roto i te nūpepa tū motuhake o te Charleston Argus i muri i tōna whakarewanga i te marama o Māehe i te tau 1867. I whakarērea e Tyrrell te tāpiritanga o te Charleston Argus i te pane kōrero o tana nūpepa i Westport i te tau 1869.

E ai ki te pūrongo a te Evening Post o Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara i te 9 Māehe: ‘Ina tiro tātou ki ngā tini tautoko a te iwi i tēnei mea te Nūpepa i ngā rohe keri kōura, tēnei mātou te matapae nei tērā e puta he oranga nui mā tō tātou hoa nūpepa, kia pau rā anō ngā keringa kōura mōmona o te Kawatiri. He mātanga katoa ngā kaiwhakahaere, ā, he mōhio rātou ki te whakaputa i te nūpepa hou kia ātaahua ki te hunga pānui, e tino paingia ai e te iwi katoa.’

I tōna putanga tuatahi i te hīkaka katoa ngā kōrero o te Charleston Argus ki te takahi i te huarahi ki te ora mō ngā kaikeri o te rohe: ‘I te pārae o waenganui he āhua pai ngā whiwhinga, engari mō te nuinga e atawhaitia ana ngā kaikeri kōura e ngā atua wāhine o te whenua. E tino hiahiatia ana he wai, ā, ki te taea tēnei taonga te wai ka haere pea te kerēme mō te rua ki te toru tau. Kua toru marama a Fuller mā e mahi ana i konei. Kua tapahia e rātou he rerenga wai, kei te horohoroi i te kirikiri, ā, tōna toharite mai i te £10 ki te £14 te hua mā ia tangata i te wiki.’ (Mai i te $1,000 ki te $1,500 i ngā moni o nāianei.)

I whakaingoatia anō te nūpepa rua putanga i te wiki, he nūpepa tino pai hoki, ko te Charleston Herald and Mining Reporter e Charles Mirfin. Nō muri ka eke ia hei etita mō te Inangahua Herald. Ka puta hoki tētahi rerekētanga mō te ingoa tuarua o te ingoa i te hurihanga ki te Brighton Times.

Ka wehe atu a John Tyrrell, tētahi tangata Airihi ki Amerika i muri i te otinga o ana tau akoako, ā, ka mahi i reira mō ētahi tau. Ka tae atu ia ki Ahitereiria i te tau 1859-1860 ā, koia te kaitā i te Melbourne Chronicle me te Ballarat Times i mua i tana nukuhanga mai ki Aotearoa. I muri i tētahi wā i The Press i Ōtautahi ka nuku ia ki Hokitika, tīmata i Hokitika Chronicle tae atu hoki ki te Westport Times me te Charleston Argus.

I te tau 1886, nā Thomas Dolman, te kaihautū mō ētahi tau i hoko te nūpepa ki te kaituhi Airihi ki a Patrick Kittson. I ako a Patrick i tana mahi tuatahi, te mahi kaitā i te Melbourne Argus. I tōna matenga i te tau 1893 ka kawea haeretia e tōna pouaru me āna tamariki te umanga. I te tuatahi nā ngā tama e rua a Norah Kittson, 12 me te 10 tau te pakeke, i whakahaere te nūpepa, me kī te nuinga rā, ā, i muri i tō rātou matenga i te mate kohi i te tau 1902, nā rātou ko ana tamāhine i whakaputa te nūpepa, i te tuatahi hei nūpepa ā-wiki, ā, he āhua tīmutumutu i muri, taea noatia te tau 1911. I te taenga ki tērā wā kua iti haere te taupori o Charleston Riding ki te 264.

Publication.Title: Press
Publication.Description: The Press published its first weekly issue on 25 May 1861 – a six page paper every Saturday costing 6d – a decade after the Lyttelton Times made its appearance as Canterbury’s first newspaper. But it did have the distinction, in March 1863, of being the province’s first daily – 5,000 copies of the four-page paper were printed, selling for 3d a copy. Shortly afterwards, advertisements replaced articles on the front page.

I whakaputaina e te Press tana putanga ā-wiki tuatahi i te 25 o May 1861 – he pepa e ono ngā whārangi ia Rāhoroi 6d te utu – tekau tau tēnei i muri i te putanga o te Lyttelton Times te niupepa tutahi o Waitaha. Heoi anō i whai ingoa ai te pepa nō te mea i te marama o Maehe 1863, koia te pepa tuatahi o taua rohe kia whakaputaina ā-rā – 5,000 ngā kape o te pepa e whā ana whārangi i tāngia, i hokona ia kape mō te 3d. Nō muri tata mai, i whakakapia ngā tuhinga i te whārangi tuatahi ki ngā pānui.

Publication.Essay:
The Press published its first weekly issue on 25 May 1861 – a six page paper every Saturday costing 6d – a decade after the Lyttelton Times made its appearance as Canterbury’s first newspaper. But it did have the distinction, in March 1863, of being the province’s first daily – 5,000 copies of the four-page paper were printed, selling for 3d a copy. Shortly afterwards, advertisements replaced articles on the front page.

In 1861, the principal backer was James Edward FitzGerald, Canterbury’s first superintendent and MP for Lyttelton – and also the Lyttelton Times’ first editor. FitzGerald, returning to Canterbury after an extended period back in England, disapproved of the extravagant and ambitious plans – including a Lyttelton rail tunnel – of his successor William Moorhouse. As the Lyttelton Times supported Moorhouse’s expensive schemes, FitzGerald, and like-minded settlers, put up the capital to underwrite a rival publication with a different vision for Christchurch. In the beginning, with FitzGerald writing most of the first few issues, there were violent attacks on Moorhouse and his policies but before long the paper adopted the sober, sensible standards that, over the following decades, established The Press’s reputation as New Zealand’s principal ‘journal of record’. An early contributor was Samuel Butler who wrote articles for The Press that were later woven into his famous book Erewhon.

James FitzGerald was nominally sole owner of The Press for several years, although financially indebted to two leading Canterbury businessmen. His association with The Press diminished and later ended following his acceptance of a government appointment in Wellington in 1867.

Technical innovation became a speciality of the private companies that owned The Press, with differing shareholdings, for the next century. In 1893, the Weekly Press, which began in 1865 as a news digest for country districts, produced its Christmas number with a full-colour lithographed art cover and, for the first time, half-tone blocks illustrated the articles. In 1917, Mona McKay became one of the first ‘lady reporters’ in the country to work in a general reporters’ room, long a male preserve.

Prominent staff members included Guy Scholefield, who was associate editor of The Press (1903-04), London correspondent of the NZ Associated Press (1908-19) and later, for 22 years, Parliamentary Librarian at the General Assembly Library. While Oliver Duff was editor from 1929-1932 well-known contributors included Ngaio Marsh, Monte Holcroft and D’Arcy Cresswell. Duff resigned over editorial policy differences with the board involving a tramway strike; in 1939 he became the founding editor of the NZ Listener.

In 1970 the Christchurch Press Co. Ltd. listed on the NZ Stock Exchange; in 1987 Independent Newspapers Ltd took control; and in 2003 ownership passed to the Fairfax Group.

I whakaputaina e te Press tana putanga ā-wiki tuatahi i te 25 o May 1861 – he pepa e ono ngā whārangi ia Rāhoroi 6d te utu – tekau tau tēnei i muri i te putanga o te Lyttelton Times te niupepa tutahi o Waitaha. Heoi anō i whai ingoa ai te pepa nō te mea i te marama o Maehe 1863, koia te pepa tuatahi o taua rohe kia whakaputaina ā-rā – 5,000 ngā kape o te pepa e whā ana whārangi i tāngia, i hokona ia kape mō te 3d. Nō muri tata mai, i whakakapia ngā tuhinga i te whārangi tuatahi ki ngā pānui.

I te tau 1861, ko te kaitautoko matua ko James Edward FitzGerald, he kaiwhakahaere tuatahi mō Waitaha, he MP hoki mō Lyttelton – ko ia hoki te ētita tuatahi o te Lyttelton Times. I tana hokinga mai ki Waitaha i muri i te wā roa ki Ingarangi i whakahēngia e FitzGerald ngā kaupapa tōtōā, whakaaro nui hoki o tana kaiwhakakapi a William Moorhouse – tae atu ki te arapoka tereina o Lyttleton. Nā runga i te mea e tautokohia ngā kaupapa nui te utu a Moorhouse e te Lyttleton Times, i huri a FitzGerald me ētahi atu tāngata he ōrite ngā whakaaro ki te whakarite pūtea hei tīmata i tētahi niupepa kē e whakahau ana i tētahi kaupapa matakite kē mō Ōtautahi. I te tīmatatanga, i runga i te mea ko FitzGerald te kaituhi o ngā putanga tuatahi, he kaha tana whakahē i a Moorhouse me ana kaupapahere, heoi anō kāore i roa i tīmata te whakamahinga o ngā paerewa mārama, whai tikanga hoki e te niupepa, nō konā, i ngā tau whai muri mai hoki, i whakatūria te ingoa o te Press hei 'pūrongo tika pū' matua ki Aotearoa. Ko tētahi o ngā kaitakoha tuatahi ko Samuel Butler, nāna ētahi tuhinga i tito mō te Press, ā, i muri mai i tuituia atu ki roto i tana pukapuka rongonui Erewhon.

Me kī ko James FitzGerald te kaipupuri tūtahi o te Press mō ētahi tau, ahakoa i te noho nama ia ki ngā kaipakihi matua e rua o Waitaha. I pōturi haere ka mutu hoki ana pānga ki te Press i muri i tana whiwhinga o tētahi tūranga kāwanatanga ki Pōneke i te tau 1867.

Ko te whai i ngā āhuatanga hou te tino whai a ngā kamupene tūmataiti e whakahaere ana i te Press, i runga i ngā pupuritanga-hea rerekē, mō te rau tau whai muri mai. I te tau 1893 i whakaputaina e te Weekly Press, he mea i tīmatangia i te tau 1865 hei pānui pitopito kōrero ki ngā rohe kōraha, tana nama Kirihimete ki tētahi ūwhi toi kua tāngia ki ngā tae-katoa, ā, ko te wā tuatahi hoki i tātuhitia ngā tuhinga ki ngā paraka tae-haurua. I te tau 1917, i tīmata a Mona McKay ki te mahi i te rūma kairīpoata whānui, tētahi o ngā 'wahine kairīpoata' tuatahi i te motu ki te mahi i reira, kua roa tērā he wāhi mā te tāne anake.

Ko ētahi o ngā kaimahi rongonui ko Guy Scholefield, he ētita tuarua o te Press (1903-04), he kaituhi ki Rānana mō te NZ Associated Press (1908-19), ā, i muri i tērā, mō ngā tau 22, ko ia hoki te Parliamentary Librarian ki te General Assembly Library. Ko Oliver Duff te ētita mai i te 1929-1932, ko ētahi o ngā kaitakoha rongonui ko Ngaio Marsh, ko Monte Holcroft me D'Arcy Cresswell. I heke a Duff i tana tūranga i runga i ngā tohenga kaupapahere ētita ki te poari e pā ana ki tētahi taraiki o ngā terēme, i 1939 ko ia te ētita tuatahi o te NZ Listener.

I 1970 i whakarārangihia te Christchurch Press Co. Ltd ki te NZ Stock Exchange, i 1987 i riro te mana whakahaere i te Independent Newspapers Ltd, ā, i 2003 i whakawhitia te kaipupuritanga ki te Fairfax Group.

Publication.Title: Clutha Leader
Publication.Description: The Clutha Leader was first published, weekly, in 1874. It was the first newspaper in Balcutha to be established that has lasted over time. It is still published on a weekly basis today by South Otago Newspapers.
I tāngia tuatahitia te Clutha Leader ia wiki i te tau 1874. Koia te nūpepa tuatahi o Balclutha kia mauroa te tū. E whakaputa tonungia ana ia wiki i tēnei wā e te kamupene South Otago Newspapers.
Publication.Essay:
The Clutha Leader was first published, weekly, in 1874 and was the first newspaper in Balcutha to be established that has lasted over time.

While other newspapers were published in Balclutha, the only serious competition came from the Free Press (1891-1926). The Free Press supported the Liberal Party of Ballance, Seddon and Ward while the Clutha Leader backed Massey's conservative Reform Party.

The Leader eventually proved too strong for its rival and absorbed the Free Press in 1927. Very few issues of the Free Press have survived while the Leader is still published.

The National Library recently microfilmed the Clutha Leader from 1874 to 1975.

Ko te 'Clutha Leader' i tāngia tuatahitia ia wiki i te tau 1874, ā, koia te nūpepa tuatahi o Balclutha kia mauroa te tū.

Waihoki i whakaputa rā anōtia ētahi atu nūpepa i Balclutha, kotahi anake te mea kaha ki te whakataetae, ko te Free Press (1891 - 1926). Tautokona ai e te Free Press te Rōpū Rīpera (Liberal Party) o Paranahi (Ballance), Te Hetana (Seddon) me Te Waari (Ward), inā rā ko tā te Clutha Leader ko te Rōpū Rīwhoma (Reform Party) o Te Maahi (Massey).

Nāwai rā he kaha rawa te Leader mō tōna hoa whakataetae, horomia ana e ia te Free Press i te tau 1927. He korekore noa ngā putanga tawhito o te Free Press i tēnei wā, ā, kei te ora tonu te Leader.

Nō nākuanei kua whakatakotoria te Clutha Leader o ngā tau 1874 - 1975 ki runga kiriata mōkito e te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa.
