Publication.Essay:
The Hutt News is one of New Zealand’s earliest and longest running community newspapers. It was established by Walter Harold Smith in 1927. Smith, a retired farmer, thought the time was right for Lower Hutt to have its own paper. The neighbouring borough of Petone had managed to sustain a newspaper, the Hutt and Petone Chronicle, since 1887. By the 1920s Lower Hutt’s population was approaching that of Petone’s.

The Hutt News was first issued in April 1927 under the auspices of the local Businessmen’s Association with 2500 copies posted to households and businesses in Lower Hutt. In 1928 Smith was joined by James and William Kerr from the Petone Chronicle. Together they formed the Hutt Printing and Publishing Company to produce a new version of the Hutt News. Smith remained as manager with William Kerr assisting him while his brother stayed with the Chronicle.

The Kerr family had long been involved with newspapers. The father, James Kerr (1834-1901), had worked on papers in Scotland, Australia and Otago before establishing the Grey River Argus in Greymouth in 1865. James, his son, managed the Argus before buying the Petone Chronicle in 1912. William had worked on the Argus and the New Zealand Times.

The paper thrived as the population of the area grew rapidly in the 1940s and 1950s although production was threatened during the War due to staff shortages. The Hutt News had to rely on printers from the Trentham Military Camp to keep the paper going. In 1948 William Kerr became the Managing Director after the death of Walter Smith.

In 1953 the Hutt Printing and Publishing Company took over the Petone Chronicle and continued to publish that paper until 1967. In 1961 William Kerr died and his son Ted succeeded him as Managing Director. In 1963 the paper was sold to Blundell Brothers, publishers of the Evening Post. The Hutt News became part of Independent Newspapers Limited (INL) in 1972 after they bought the Blundell’s company. Ownership changed again in 2003 when Fairfax bought INL.

Ko te Hutt News tētahi o ngā niupepa ā-rohe tuatahi, roa rawa hoki tana puta mai ki te ao, i Aotearoa katoa. Nā Walter Harold Smith te niupepa i whakatū i te tau 1927. He kaipāmu o mua a Smith, ā, ki ōna whakaaro kua tae ki te wā e tika ana kia whakaputa a Lower Hutt i tōna ake niupepa. I kaha anō a Pitoone ki te kawe i tōna niupepa ake, ko te Hutt and Petone Chronicle, mai i te tau 1887. Nō te taenga ki te tekau tau mai i 1920 kua tata atu te taupori o Lower Hutt ki tō Pitoone.

I puta te Hutt News tuatahi i te marama o Āperira 1927 i raro i te maru o te rōpū o te Businessmen’s Association o te takiwā, ā, i tukuna ētahi kape 2500 ki ngā kāinga me ngā umanga katoa o Lower Hutt. Nō te tau 1928 ka uru mai a James rāua ko William Kerr mai i te Petone Chronicle hei hoa mō Smith. I mahi tahi rātou ki te whakatū i te Hutt Printing and Publishing Company ā, ka puta i a ia tētahi putanga hōu o te Hutt News. Ka noho tonu a Smith hei kaiwhakahaere, ko William Kerr te kaiāwhina i a ia, ā, ka noho tonu tana tuakana i te Chronicle.

He roa tonu te mahi a te whānau Kerr i te ao niupepa. I mahi tana matua, a James Kerr (1834-1901), ki ētahi niupepa i Kotirani, i Ahitereiria me Ōtākou i mua i tana whakatūnga i te Grey River Argus i Māwhera i te tau 1865. Nā tana tama, ko James hoki tana ingoa, i whakahaere te Argus i mua i tana hoko i te Petone Chronicle i 1912. I te mahi a William i te Argus me te New Zealand Times.

I tino tuawhiti tonu te tupu o te niupepa i te whanaketanga o te takiwā i te tekau tau mai i 1940 me 1950 ahakoa i mōrearea tonu te putanga tonutanga i te Pakanga, nā te kore kaimahi. I riro nā te āwhina o ngā kaitā pukapuka i te Puni Hōia i Trentham i puta tonu ai te Hutt News. Nō te tau 1948 ka eke a William Kerr ki te tūranga Kaihautū Whakahaere i muri i te matenga o Walter Smith.

Nō te tau 1953 ka riro i te Hutt Printing and Publishing Company te Petone Chronicle, ā, nāna Te Petone Chronicle i whakaputa tonu, taea noatia te tau 1967. Nō te tau 1961 ka mate a William Kerr ka piki ko tana tama a Ted ki tana tūranga Kaihautū Whakahaere. Nō te tau 1963 ka hokona te niupepa ki Blundell Brothers, ngā kaiwhakaputa o te Evening Post. Ka huri te Hutt News hei wāhi o Independent Newspapers Limited (INL) i te tau 1972, ā, nō muri mai ka hokona e ia te kamupene o ngā Blundell. Ka huri anō te mana pupuri i te tau 2003 i te hokonga o INL e Fairfax.

Publication.Title: Hawera & Normanby Star
Publication.Description: The Hawera & Normanby Star was founded in 1880 by Patrick Galvin, Joseph Innes and J.C. Yorke. Southern Taranaki was being opened up at this time and they saw an opportunity to establish a paper there. All three had worked together on the New Zealand Times in Wellington and their partnership was forged there.

I tīmatahia te Hāwera & Normanby Star i te tau 1880 e Patrick Galvin, rātau ko Joseph Innes me J.C. Yorke. I te huaki haerehia te Tonga o Taranaki i taua wā, me tā rātau kite ake i tētahi wāhanga i reira hei whakatū nūpepa. Kua mahia ngātahitia te tokotoru nei i mua i te New Zealand Times i Whanganui-a-Tara, ā, i whakapūmautia tō rātou whakahoatanga i reira.
Publication.Essay:
The Hawera & Normanby Star was founded in 1880 by Patrick Galvin, Joseph Innes and J.C. Yorke. Southern Taranaki was being opened up at this time and they saw an opportunity to establish a paper there. All three had worked together on the New Zealand Times in Wellington and their partnership was forged there.

The first issue appeared on 10 April 1880 and the paper was published twice a week. In 1881 Galvin retired due to ill health and his place was taken by Joseph Armit. However Galvin continued to be involved with newspapers for the rest of his life, founding the short-lived Hawera Morning Post in 1894 and contributing to the New Zealand Times.

The Star saw off a challenge early on from Joseph Ivess, publisher of the nearby Patea Mail. Ivess had been publishing the Patea Mail since 1875 and had ambitions to establish a chain of papers in Taranaki. He tried to persuade Galvin not to set up in Hawera. When Galvin persisted, he opened an office in Hawera, from which he briefly published the Hawera Times. However the residents of Hawera preferred the Star and Ivess abandoned his new paper after two issues.

The Star progressed steadily in its first two decades. In 1882 a new press was installed and the paper began daily publication. In 1885 it started the Egmont Star, a weekly compendium of items from the parent paper for distribution to the backblocks of Taranaki. The Egmont Star ceased in 1914. In 1895 the Hawera Star survived a fire that destroyed the paper's premises and plant.

In 1889 Yorke became sole proprietor; in 1893 he sold the Star to the paper's editor, William Alfred Parkinson. Parkinson ran the paper until his death in 1920. Ownership changed several more times through the 20th century. The paper ceased daily publication in 1977 and became a community paper the following year. It is still published in that form today.

I tīmatahia te Hāwera & Normanby Star i te tau 1880 e Patrick Galvin, rātau ko Joseph Innes me J.C. Yorke. I te huaki haerehia te Tonga o Taranaki i taua wā, me tā rātau kite ake i tētahi wāhanga i reira hei whakatū nūpepa. Kua mahia ngātahitia te tokotoru nei i mua i te New Zealand Times i Whanganui-a-Tara, ā, i whakapūmautia tō rātou whakahoatanga i reira.

Nō te 10 o Paenga-whāwhā 1880 te putanga tuatahi, ā, e rua ōna tānga i te wiki. I te tau 1881 ka whakatāngia a Galvin nā tana pāngia e te mate, ā, ka riro tōna tūranga i a Joseph Armit. Engari i noho tonu a Galvin ki roto i ngā whakarite o ngā nūpepa mō te roanga atu o tōna oranga, ā, nāna i tīmata te nūpepa Hāwera Morning Post i te tau 1894, ahakoa poto noa iho te wā ki tēnei pepa, me te whai wāhi anō ki te New Zealand Times.

I te tīmatanga i parea atu e te Star te wero a Joseph Ivess, te kaitā i te nūpepa tata mai, te Patea Mail. E tāhia ana e Ivess te Patea Mail i te tau 1875 me tana hiahia ki te whakatū i ētahi nūpepa ki roto o Taranaki. I whakamātau ia ki te aukati i a Galvin mai i Hāwera. Nā te ngana haere tonu o Galvin, ka whakatūhia e ia he tari ki Hāwera, i reira ka tāhia te Hāwera Times mō te wā poto. Engari i hiahia kē ngā tāngata o Hāwera ki te Star, ā, e rua ngā putanga o tēnei nūpepa ka mutu.

Pai tonu te haere o te Star i ngā tau rua tekau mai i tōna tīmatanga. I te tau 1882 ka whakauruhia he mīhini tā hou, ā, ka tāhia te nūpepa nei ia rangi. I te tau 1885 ka tīmatahia te Egmont Star, ā, puta ai tēnei nūpepa ia wiki me ngā pitopito kōrero mai i te nūpepa matua hei tohatoha atu ki ngā wāhi tuawhenua o Taranaki. I katia te Egmont Star i te tau 1914. I te tau 1895 i ora noa te Hawera Star i tētahi kāpura i turakina ai te wāhi me ngā rawa o te nūpepa.

I te tau 1889 ka noho ko Yorke te rangatira ake; i te tau 1893 ka hokona atu e ia te Star ki tōna kaietita, a William Alfred Parkinson. Whakahaerehia e Parkinson te pepa nei tae noa ki tōna matenga i te tau 1920. He maha tonu ngā whakawhititanga o te pepa nei i roto i ngā tau o te rautau 20. Whakamutuhia te tānga ia rangi o tēnei nūpepa i te tau 1977, ā, ka huri hei pepa hapori i te tau o muri mai. Tāhia tonutia hei pepa hapori i ēnei rā.

Publication.Title: Hutt Valley Independent
Publication.Description: The Hutt Valley Independent was started by Angus McCurdy in 1911. McCurdy was a significant figure in the development of Upper Hutt, both socially and politically. To him can be attributed the first Town Board in 1907, the first cinema, the debate for gas lighting within Upper Hutt and the first newspaper, the Hutt Valley Independent. McCurdy went on to become the first Mayor of Upper Hutt in 1926.

I tīmataria te Hutt Valley Independent e Angus McCurdy i te tau 1911. He tangata rongonui a McCurdy i roto i te whanaketanga o Whakatiki, i te taha pāpori me te taha tōrangapū. Nāna te Poari Tāone tuatahi i whakatū i te tau 1907, tae atu ki te whare pikitia tuatahi, nāna ngā tohe kia whakaurua mai ngā raiti haukapuni i roto i Whakatiki, nāna hoki i whakatū te Hutt Valley Independent. I ngā tau o muri mai ka piki a McCurdy hei Koromatua tuatahi mō Whakatiki i te tau 1926.
Publication.Essay:
The Hutt Valley Independent was started by Angus McCurdy in 1911. McCurdy was a significant figure in the development of Upper Hutt, both socially and politically. To him can be attributed the first Town Board in 1907, the first cinema, the debate for gas lighting within Upper Hutt and the first newspaper, the Hutt Valley Independent. McCurdy went on to become the first Mayor of Upper Hutt in 1926.

The Hutt Valley Independent documents the radical changes happening in Upper Hutt during the period 1911-1933; public services such as gas lighting and the establishment of a borough council being two examples. As it was the only community newspaper available at that time, it is a key resource for researchers and genealogists.

I tīmataria te Hutt Valley Independent e Angus McCurdy i te tau 1911. He tangata rongonui a McCurdy i roto i te whanaketanga o Whakatiki, i te taha pāpori me te taha tōrangapū. Nāna te Poari Tāone tuatahi i whakatū i te tau 1907, tae atu ki te whare pikitia tuatahi, nāna ngā tohe kia whakaurua mai ngā raiti haukapuni i roto i Whakatiki, nāna hoki i whakatū te Hutt Valley Independent. I ngā tau o muri mai ka piki a McCurdy hei Koromatua tuatahi mō Whakatiki i te tau 1926.

I tuhia ki te Hutt Valley Independent ētahi o ngā tino huringa nunui i pā ki Whakatiki i roto i te wā 1911-1933; inā ētahi tauira e rua ko ngā raiti haukapuni me te whakatūranga o te kaunihera ā-rohe. Kua noho tēnei pepa ināianei hei tino puna mō ngā kairangahau me te hunga whai whakapapa, nā te mea koia anake te niupepa o te hapori i puta i taua wā.

E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki nga Upper Hutt City Library , nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Inangahua Times
Publication.Title-alternate: Reefton Courier and Inangahua Advertiser, Reefton Guardian, Inangahua Herald
Publication.Description: The Inangahua Times was published in Reefton from 1875 until it ceased publication in 1942 under pressure of wartime restrictions. Initially it was issued three times a week, by 1891 it came out daily. By 1888 there were three daily newspapers in Reefton although the town had a population of only 2,000.

Ka tāngia te Inangahua Times i Reefton mai te tau 1875 tae noa ki tana katinga i te tau 1942 i raro i ngā pēhitanga o te wā pakanga. I te tīmatanga e toru ōna putanga ia wiki, nō te tau 1891, ka puta ai ia rā. Nō te tau 1988 e toru ngā nūpepa ia-rā i Reefton, he ahakoa te tokomaha o te tangata he 2,000 noa.
Publication.Essay:
The Inangahua Times was published in Reefton from 1875 until it ceased publication in 1942. Initially it was issued three times a week, but by 1891 it came out daily.

The Times was started by William Joseph Potts. Potts had been involved with other newspapers on the West Coast. In 1873 he had edited Grey Valley Times at Ahaura. In 1874 he started the Reefton Courier but this didn't last out the year. Potts owned the Times until his death in 1901. His wife ran the paper after his death.

The Times had to compete with several other newspapers in Reefton. The main rival was the Inangahua Herald which had begun three years before the Times in 1872. The Times eventually absorbed the Herald in 1936.

In 1888 Reefton got a third daily newspaper, the Reefton Guardian. Reefton's population at this time was about 2,000 which was not enough to support three newspapers. The Guardian was the first to go under, probably in 1894.

It's not clear why a small town like Reefton had three daily newspapers. Certainly the 1890s was a flourishing time for newspaper publishing in New Zealand (newspaper publication peaked about 1910). Also it's likely that Reefton was seen as a town with prospects. Reefton was known as the "Gateway to the Coast" because most land traffic in and out of the West Coast passed through it. It had been a boom town in the 1860s and 1870s. In 1887 Reefton became the first place in New Zealand to have its own public electricity supply and in 1892 it was connected by rail to Greymouth.

The Times, like many other small town newspapers in New Zealand, could not cope with the restrictions and shortages that the Second World War brought and it published its last issue on 6 June 1942.

The Times was revived as a weekly in 1946 under the title Inangahua-Murchison Times. This paper ceased in 1956.

Ka tāngia te Inangahua Times i Reefton mai te tau 1875 tae noa ki tana katinga i te tau 1942. I te tīmatanga e toru ōna putanga ia wiki, nō te tau 1891, ka puta ai ia rā.

Nā William Joseph Potts te Times i tīmata. He pānga anō o Potts ki ētahi atu o ngā nūpepa o Te Tai Poutini. Koia te ētita o te Grey Valley Times i Ahaura i te tau 1873. I te tau 1874 nāna te Reefton Courier i tīmata, engari kāore i pau noa te tau ka katia ai. Ko Potts te rangatira o te Times tae noa ki tana mate i te tau 1901. Nō muri mai nā tana wahine i whakahaere.

He tāwhainga nō te Times i ētahi atu nūpepa maha i Reefton. Ko te tāwhainga matua nō te Inangahua Herald ko tōna tīmatanga e toru tau nō mua noa o te Times i te tau 1872. Ka horomia rawatia te Herald e te Times i te tau 1936.

Nō te tau 1888, ka puta ai te tuatoru o ngā nūpepa ia rā o Reefton, te Reefton Guardian. Ko te tokomaha i Reefton i taua wā he 2,000 pea, kāore i taea te tautoko i ngā nūpepa e toru. Ko te Guardian te tuatahi kia taka, i te tau 1894 pea.

Kāore i te mārama he aha i toru ai ngā nūpepa i te tāone pēnei me Reefton. Ko te tekau tau atu i 1890 he wā makuru mō te tā nūpepa i Niu Tīreni (ko tōna taumata i te tau 1910 pea). Tērā pea i tūmanakotia ko Reefton tētahi tāone tōnui. I mōhiotia whānuitia hei 'Kūaha ki Te Tai Poutini' i te mea mā reira te nuinga o ngā haerenga mai me ngā haerenga atu o Te Tai Poutini. He tāone tuputere i ngā tau mai i 1860 ki te 1880. I te tau 1887 ko Reefton te wāhi tuatahi o Niu Tīreni kia whiwhi ki tōna ake whakaratonga hiko ki te iwi whānui, ā, nō te tau 1892 ka honoa ai ki Māwhera (Greymouth) mā te rerewē.

Ka rite te Times ki te maha noa o ngā nūpepa o ngā tāone iti o te motu, kāore i ora mai i ngā haukotinga me ngā kōpaka o te Pakanga Tuarua o te Ao, ā, ko tōna putanga whakamutunga i te 6 o Hune o te tau 1942.

I whakaoratia mai anō te Times hei nūpepa ia-wiki i te tau 1946, ko te ingoa ko te Inangahua-Murchison Times. Nō te tau 1956 ka katia ai.

Publication.Title: King Country Chronicle
Publication.Description: It has been claimed that, at the beginning of the 20th century, there were 134 Europeans in Te Kuiti but the completion of the rail link brought in more settlers, the beginning of pastoral farming and cutting down of dense forests. The weekly King Country Chronicle was launched in Te Kuiti in 1906 by Arthur Hayward and Norman Matthews. The Poverty Bay Herald announced in its 2 November issue that the new paper ‘is excellently got up and has a substantial look’. Hayward left shortly afterwards, and edited the New Zealand Farmer in Auckland until his death in 1914. Matthews continued to run the paper for a number of years.

E ai ki ngā kōrero a ētahi, i te tīmatanga o te rau tau 20, 134 ngā Pākehā i te noho i Te Kuiti ā, nō te otinga o te hononga rerewē i piki ake ai te maha o ngā tāngata nohonoho i reira, i tīmata ai hoki te whāngai kararehe, me te tuatua i Te Wao nui a Tāne. I whakarewaina te nūpepa ā-wiki nei te King Country Chronicle i Te Kuiti i te tau 1906 e Arthur Hayward rāua ko Norman Matthews. E ai ki ngā kōrero a te Poverty Bay Herald i tōna putanga o te 2 Nōema ko te nūpepa hou ‘he ātaahua te takoto, he whai kiko ki te titiro atu’. Kāore i roa i muri mai ka wehe atu a Hayward ka haere hei kaiwhakatika i te New Zealand Farmer i Tāmaki-makau-rau taea noatia tōna matenga i te tau 1914. I whakahaere a Matthews i te nūpepa mō ētahi tau i muri mai.
Publication.Essay:
Because European occupation and development of the King Country came much later than most other parts of New Zealand, newspapers also came relatively late to the area. The King Country was the heart of the Maori King movement, in parts still strongly antagonistic to European settlement, so it was not until the main truck railway line pushed through the area that towns developed. The railway from Auckland reached Te Kuiti, a Maori village, in 1887. European settlement dates from that year, when a railway construction camp was established, including an iron foundry to make girders for the Waiteti Viaduct. The main trunk line slowly extended south, reaching Taumarunui in 1901.

It has been claimed that, at the beginning of the 20th century, there were 134 Europeans in Te Kuiti but the completion of the rail link brought in more settlers, the beginning of pastoral farming and cutting down of dense forests. The weekly King Country Chronicle was launched in Te Kuiti in 1906 by Arthur Hayward and Norman Matthews. The Poverty Bay Herald announced in its 2 November issue that the new paper ‘is excellently got up and has a substantial look’. Hayward left shortly afterwards, and edited the New Zealand Farmer in Auckland until his death in 1914. Matthews continued to run the paper for a number of years.

In the early years of settlements, newspapers saw ‘boosterism’ – the boosting and often exaggerated promotion of their communities as a key role. When Te Kuiti became a borough in 1910, the King Country Chronicle published this doggerel:

‘Ho, Te Kuiti has a Mayor
Say the word and hold your breath
From the Waipa right to Taupo
She’s the greatest and the best
From the great majestic river
That all nations flock to see
Westward to the rolling hills
Te Kuiti is the town to be.’

By 1911, the European population of the King Country was just over 15,000. Te Kuiti and Taumarunui were the largest towns, each with about 1,000 Europeans.

In May 1918, the New Zealand Herald announced that the Waikato Times Publishing Company and Mr W Thomas, proprietor of the Taumarunui Press, had joined interests and taken over the King Country Chronicle. ‘The business of the three papers will be run in the name of the Waikato and King Country Press’. The agreement was either very short-lived or never finalised because the next year Matthews sold the King Country Chronicle to John Hamill. His ownership was not without its difficulties. In December 1921 Hamill was the defendant in a Hamilton Supreme Court case, sued for £4,000 by the clerk of the Waitomo County Council, who alleged libel. It was decided the statements published in the King Country Chronicle were defamatory and £50 damages were awarded. The next year the paper was sold again, this time to Samuel Craig, member of an Invercargill printing and publishing family that part-owned the Southland News.

The King Country Chronicle was subsequently a bi-weekly run in conjunction with the Otorohanga Times (1912), which was begun by ‘rag-planter’ J H Claridge and later purchased by the Craigs. In 1980 the King Country Chronicle and Otorohanga Times were merged. The Waitomo News, as the resulting newspaper was named, was sold to the Spring family in 2002. The free tabloid, delivered on Tuesdays and Thursdays, is part of the Spring’s privately-owned group which includes the Whakatane Beacon, Bay Weekender and Opotiki News.

Nā runga i te tōmuri o te tae mai a te iwi Pākehā me ōna āhuatanga whanake ki te Rohe Pōtae, i tōmuri ai te tae mai o ngā nūpepa Pākehā ki tēnei o ngā rohe. Ko te Rohe Pōtae te pūtahi o te Kīngitanga, ā, i ētahi takiwā ōna kāore rawa atu ōna hapū i rata ki te Pākehā kia nohonoho i reira. Nō te taenga mai o te rerewē kātahi anō ka tae mai te ararino, ka tupu mai ai ko ngā tāone a te Pākehā i te taha. Ka tae te rerewē mai i Tāmaki-makau-rau ki Te Kuiti, tētehi kāinga Maori, i te tau 1887. I tīmata te nohonoho mai a te Pākehā i taua tau i te whakatūnga o tētehi puni hanga rerewē, tae atu ki tētahi whare whakarewa rino hanga tāhuhu mō te piriti o te Waitetī. Ka toro whaka-te-tonga te ararino matua o te motu, tae rawa atu ki Taumarunui i te tau 1901.

E ai ki ngā kōrero a ētahi, i te tīmatanga o te rau tau 20, 134 ngā Pākehā i te noho i Te Kuiti ā, nō te otinga o te hononga rerewē i piki ake ai te maha o ngā tāngata nohonoho i reira, i tīmata ai hoki te whāngai kararehe, me te tuatua i Te Wao nui a Tāne. I whakarewaina te nūpepa ā-wiki nei te King Country Chronicle i Te Kuiti i te tau 1906 e Arthur Hayward rāua ko Norman Matthews. E ai ki ngā kōrero a te Poverty Bay Herald i tōna putanga o te 2 Nōema ko te nūpepa hou ‘he ātaahua te takoto, he whai kiko ki te titiro atu’. Kāore i roa i muri mai ka wehe atu a Hayward ka haere hei kaiwhakatika i te New Zealand Farmer i Tāmaki-makau-rau taea noatia tōna matenga i te tau 1914. I whakahaere a Matthews i te nūpepa mō ētahi tau i muri mai.

I ngā tau tuatahi o ngā tāone hou ko te ‘whakarawe’ – arā, te whakarawe me te whakapai i ngā āhuatanga o ō rātou tāone tētahi whāinga nui mā ngā nūpepa o aua tāone. Nō te ekenga o Te Kuiti hei takiwā 'borough' i te tau 1910, ka whakaputaina e te King Country Chronicle tēnei ruriruri:

‘E, he koromatua tō Te Kuiti
Whakapuakina te kupu takina te manawa
Mai i Waipā tae noa ki Taupō
Koia anō te mea rahi rawa, te mea hira rawa
Mai i te awa rongonui
Te mīharotanga a ngā whenua o te ao
Ahu whaka-te-uru ki ngā pīnanakitanga
Ko Te Kuiti ia te tāone ka manakohia.’

Nō te taenga ki te tau 1911, kua piki iti ake te taupori o te Rohe Pōtae i te 15,000. Ko Te Kuiti me Taumarunui ngā tāone nunui rawa, 1,000 nga Pākehā o tētehi, o tētehi.

I te marama o Mei 1918, ka whakapuakina e te New Zealand Herald kua tūhono te Waikato Times Publishing Company rāua ko W Thomas, te rangatira o te Taumarunui Press, i ō rātou hea, ā, kua noho tahi hei rangatira mō te King Country Chronicle. ‘Ka whakahaeretia ngā kaipakihi o ngā nūpepa e toru i raro i te ingoa te Waikato and King Country Press’. Heoi anō, he poto noa iho te wā o te kirimana, kāore i oti mārire rānei, inā hoki, i te tau i muri ka hokona te King Country Chronicle ki a John Hamill. Ehara i te mea kāore he raruraru o tōna wā i te nūpepa. Nō te marama o Tīhema 1921 ko Hamill te tangata e whakapaetia ana i tētahi take ki te Kōti Teitei o Kirikiriroa mō te £4,000 he mea whakapae e te Waitomo County Council, mō te hāhani. Ka whakatauria, āe, he hāhani tonu ngā kupu i puta i te King Country Chronicle me te whakawhiwhi i ngā moni kāpeneheihana £50. I te tau i muri mai ka hokona anō te nūpepa, ki Samuel Craig, he mema nō tētahi whānau tā-nūpepa, tā-pukapuka nō Te Waihōpai, nō rātou tētahi wāhi o te Southland News.

I muri i tērā, e rua ngā putanga o te King Country Chronicle i te wiki, i te taha o te Otorohanga Times (1912), nā tētehi ‘rag-planter’ nā J H Claridge i tīmata, ā, i hokona i muri e te whānau Craig. I te tau 1980 ka whakakotahitia te King Country Chronicle me te Otorohanga Times. Ko te nūpepa i hua ake ka whakaingoatia ko te Waitomo News, ā, ka hokona ki te whānau Spring i te tau 2002. He nūpepa whāiti kore-utu tēnei i tohangia i ngā Tūrei me ngā Tāite. He wāhi tēnei nō te huinga nūpepa tūmataiti a Spring kei roto nei te Whakatane Beacon, Bay Weekender me Opotiki News.

Publication.Title: Kai Tiaki : the journal of the nurses of New Zealand
Publication.Description: Kai Tiaki - the Journal of the Nurses of New Zealand, as it was originally titled, was founded by the indomitable nursing visionary Hester Maclean, who came to New Zealand from Australia in 1906 to take up the government role of Assistant Inspector of Hospitals. In this role, she had oversight of all nursing matters. Using her own funds and working in her own time, she established Kai Tiaki, first published in January 1908.

Kai Tiaki – arā, ko the Journal of the Nurses of New Zealand tōna ingoa tuatahi, he mea whakaū e te matakite, māia hoki o Hester Maclean, i haere mai ki Aotearoa i Ahitereiria i te 1906 hei Kaiwhakawā Tautoko o ngā Hōhipera, he tūranga kāwanatanga. Nā tēnei tūranga ko tāna he mātai i ngā take nēhi. Mai i tāna ake pūtea, he mea mahi i tōna ake wā hoki, nāna te Kai Tiaki i whakatū, ko te tānga tuatahi i te Hānuere o 1908.

You will need to get their consent to reproduce in-copyright material from this journal. For advice on reproduction of out-of-copyright material from this journal, please refer to the Copyright guide .

Ko te Rōpū o ngā Nēhi o Aotearoa te kaipupuri i te manatārua mō Kaitiaki: te hautaka o ngā nēhi o Aotearoa. Me mātua kimi tō rātou whakaae kia tāruatia ngā rawa whai-manatārua i tēnei nūpepa. Mō ētahi tohutohu mō ngā rawa kua puta i te manatārua mai i tēnei nūpepa, tēnā titiro ki te Puka mō te Manatārua .
Publication.Essay:
Kai Tiaki - the Journal of the Nurses of New Zealand, as it was originally titled, was founded by the indomitable nursing visionary Hester Maclean, who came to New Zealand from Australia in 1906 to take up the government role of Assistant Inspector of Hospitals. In this role, she had oversight of all nursing matters. Using her own funds and working in her own time, she established Kai Tiaki, first published in January 1908. The quarterly publication cost the princely sum of four shillings a year. In her inaugural editorial on the purposes of the journal, Maclean said she wanted it to be ‘. . . a bond of union, a common interest, a means of communication, a mutual help, and a road to improvement in their professional work and knowledge, to all nurses of the Dominion . . .’

Maclean chose the title, wanting it to be distinctive and suggestive of the journal’s country of origin. It was suggested to her by a Government interpreter, in response to a request from Maclean. Kai tiaki, in Māori, contains meanings associated with guardianship and protection. The journal has undergone a number of name changes but, despite its official titles, it has always been referred to by the profession at large, as simply Kai Tiaki.

It was first registered as a magazine in 1912.

Maclean maintained ownership of the journal, which reported extensively on nurses’ involvement in World War 1 and on the influenza epidemic of 1918, in which more than 8000 New Zealanders, including some 30 nurses, died. In 1919 a complete set of journals covering the period of the First World War, 1914-1918, was deposited in the British War Museum in London.

In 1923, the New Zealand Trained Nurses’ Association (NZTNA), founded in 1909, bought Kai Tiaki from Maclean, who remained as editor. The journal subscription increased to six shillings a year. The following year the first sub-editor was appointed, and in 1930 Kai Tiaki expanded to become a bi-monthly publication. That year also saw a name change to New Zealand Nursing Journal (Kai Tiaki).

In 1932 Maclean, the journal’s founder and editor for 24 years, died.

From 1939 to 1947 Kai Tiaki was published monthly but in 1942 wartime regulations controlling the use of newsprint saw the number of pages in each issue reduced to 28, then 24. From 1947 to 1959, Kai Tiaki was published two monthly, returning to monthly publication at the dawn of the new decade. 1957 was literally a red letter day for the journal, when it used colour on its cover for the first time and 1958 saw the publication of a Golden Jubilee issue. Kai Tiaki continued to be published monthly until 1988, when publication was reduced to 11 times a year, with a combined December/January issue.

Kai Tiaki – arā, ko the Journal of the Nurses of New Zealand tōna ingoa tuatahi, he mea whakaū e te matakite, māia hoki o Hester Maclean, i haere mai ki Aotearoa i Ahitereiria i te 1906 hei Kaiwhakawā Tautoko o ngā Hōhipera, he tūranga kāwanatanga. Nā tēnei tūranga ko tāna he mātai i ngā take nēhi. Mai i tāna ake pūtea, he mea mahi i tōna ake wā hoki, nāna te Kai Tiaki i whakatū, ko te tānga tuatahi i te Hānuere o 1908. Ko te utu nanakia o te tānga ia toru marama he whā hereni i te tau. I tāna etitatanga tuatahi mō ngā kaupapa o te hautaka, ko tā Mackean he hiahia nōna ko te hautaka ‘ … hei pou here i ngā nēhi katoa o te Tōminiona, hei hurahi whakawhitiwhitinga whakaaro ngātahi, ka whakapakarihia ai te ngaio o ā rātou mahi, mātauranga hoki ...’

Nā Maclean te ingoa, ko tāna hiahia ki te ingoa motuhake, he mea whai hoki i te whenua taketake. Nā tētahi kaiwhakamāori Kāwanatanga i tūtohu mai, hei whai i tā Maclean tono. Ko te Kai tiaki he mea pā ki te mānaakitanga me te poipoitanga. Kua whakarerekēhia te ingoa i roto i te wā ēngari, ahakoa ōna ingoa ōkawa, ko tōna ingoa ōpaki tonu ki tōna hunga ngaio, ko te Kai Tiaki noa.

He mea rehita hei puka maheni i te 1912.

Ka mau tonu i a Maclean te rangatiratanga o te hautaka, he pūrongo nui o te whai wāhi a te hunga nēhi i te Pakanga Tuatahi, me te tahumāero whurū o te 1918, otirā te matenga o te neke atu i te 8000 tāngata o Aotearoa, tae atu ki te 30 nēhi hoki. I te 1919, ka takohatia tētahi huinga katoa o te hautaka o te 1914-1918, te Pakanga Tuatahi, ki te British War Museum i Rānana.

I te 1923 nā te New Zealand Trained Nurses’ Association (NZTNA), he mea whakaū i te 1909, te Kai Tiaki i hoko mai i a Maclean, me tāna noho tonu hei etita. Ka rahi ake te utu ki te ono hereni i te tau. Nō te tau o muri mai ka whakatūria tōna etita-tautoko tuatahi. I te 1930, ka tāngia rua-maramatia. I taua tau anō ka huria te ingoa ki te New Zealand Nursing Journal (Kai Tiaki).

Nō te 1932, ka mate ai a Maclean, tōna kaiwhakaū, tōna etita mō te 24 tau.

Mai i te 1939 ki te 1947 he mea tā ia marama te Kai Tiaki, ēngari nā ngā ture pakanga o te whakamahi pepa ka iti iho ia tānga ki te 28 whārangi, kātahi ki te 24. Mai i te 1947 ki te 1959, ka tāngia ia rua-marama, ka hoki ki te tānga ia marama i te pūaotanga o te tekautau hōu. He ‘rā reta-whero’ tūturu te 1957 mōna, kātahi rā ka kitea tuatahitia ngā tae ki tōna uwhi. Nō te 1958, ko te whakaputanga o tōna tānga Rima Tekau Tau. Ka tāngia tonungia te Kai Tikai ia marama tae noa ki te tau 1988, ka whakaitia iho hoki ki te 11 ia tau, he hononga te putanga Tīhema/Hānuere.

Publication.Title: Kaipara and Waitemata Echo
Publication.Description: In 1905, Charles de La Roche started the weekly Kaipara Advertiser and Waitemata Chronicle in Helensville. He launched his first newspaper, the Tauranga Herald, in 1899, but the bi-weekly survived for only a few months. His next venture, the Rodney and Otamatea Times, based in Warkworth, was to prove much more successful. Late in 1903 he sold the newspaper, moved his real estate business to Helensville and established his third newspaper.

Nō te 1905, nā Charles de La Roche i tīmata te wikiri nei te Kaipara Advertiser and Waitemata Chronicle i Helensville. Ka whakarewaina e ia tana niupepa tuatahi, te Tauranga Herald, i te tau 1899, engari i ora mai te niupepa rua-putanga-i-te-wiki mō ētahi marama noa iho. Otiia ko tana umanga o muri mai, te Rodney and Otamatea Times, i puta rā i Warkworth, tērā noa ake te painga i puta. No ngā marama whakamutunga o 1903 ka hokona e ia te niupepa, ka nekehia e ia tana umanga hoko whenua, hoko kāinga ki Helensville, ka whakatūria hoki e ia tana niupepa tuatoru.
Publication.Essay:
In 1905, Charles de La Roche started the weekly Kaipara Advertiser and Waitemata Chronicle in Helensville.

A 41-year-old entrepreneur, de La Roche was born and grew up in New South Wales. At 21 he was an officer in the Australian Imperial Forces and served in the Sudan War in 1885. Several years later he resigned his commission and moved to New Zealand. Already an experienced journalist, he contributed to a number of South Auckland newspapers while establishing a real estate business at Pukekohe.

He launched his first newspaper, the Tauranga Herald, in 1899, but the bi-weekly survived for only a few months. His next venture, the Rodney and Otamatea Times, based in Warkworth, was to prove much more successful. Late in 1903 he sold the newspaper, moved his real estate business to Helensville and established his third newspaper.

Helensville had been settled in 1863 by Scottish timber millers and kauri milling underwrote the town’s early development, with dairy farming of increasing importance by the beginning of the 20th century.

The Kaipara Advertiser and Waitemata Chronicle had several more owners before Francis Mackenzie absorbed the paper into his Kaipara and Waitemata Echo in 1914. The Echo began publishing in 1907 and the new weekly was soon outperforming its competitor. Mackenzie, a colourful newspaperman who started several Northland newspapers, had worked for the Government Printer in Sydney and was an overseer at Auckland’s Southern Cross before founding his most successful publication, the Northern Luminary, in Kawakawa in 1879. He sold this paper in 1913. Known for the robustness of his journalism he was taken to court for libel and was once attacked in the street by someone claiming he had been defamed. Son Frank took over the Echo when his father died in 1917 and ran it until he retired. C J Claridge, junior, owned the paper until 1927 and then sold to Hilton Venables. The Echo was subsequently incorporated into the Rodney and Otamatea Courier.

Nō te 1905, nā Charles de La Roche i tīmata te wikiri nei te Kaipara Advertiser and Waitemata Chronicle i Helensville.

He tangata tīmata pakihi a de La Roche, 41 ōna tau, i whānau mai, i tupu ake hoki i New South Wales. 21 ōna tau ka eke hei āpiha i te Ope Taua o Ahitereiria, ka haere ki te Pakanga i Sudan i te tau 1885. Ētahi tau i muri mai ka tukua e ia tana kōmihana ka nuku mai ki Aotearoa. Kua tautōhito kē ia ki ngā mahi kawe kōrero, ā, i riro nāna i tuhi kōrero mō ētahi o ngā niupepa o Manukau, o Pukekohe i a ia e whakatū ana i tētahi umanga hoko kāinga hoko whenua i Pukekohe.

Ka whakarewaina e ia tana niupepa tuatahi, te Tauranga Herald, i te tau 1899, engari i ora mai te niupepa rua-putanga-i-te-wiki mō ētahi marama noa iho. Otiia ko tana umanga o muri mai, te Rodney and Otamatea Times, i puta rā i Warkworth, tērā noa ake te painga i puta. No ngā marama whakamutunga o 1903 ka hokona e ia te niupepa, ka nekehia e ia tana umanga hoko whenua, hoko kāinga ki Helensville, ka whakatūria hoki e ia tana niupepa tuatoru.

Kua whakanohonoho mai ngā kaituatua rākau, kaimira kauri mai i Kotirani ki Helensvillei te tau 1863, nā rātou anō i punga te whanaketanga o te tāone i aua tau tuatahi, ā, i te takanga o ngā tau ka piki hoki te hua o te mahi pāmu kau kūtētē kia tae ki te tīmatanga o te rau tau 20.

Arā anō ngā rangatira o te Kaipara Advertiser and Waitemata Chronicle i mua i te rironga o te niupepa i a Francis Mackenzie ki roto i tāna Kaipara and Waitemata Echo i te tau 1914. I tīmata te puta o te Echo i te tau 1907, ā, kāore i roa i muri mai ka kaha ake tāna mahi i tōna hoa tauwhāinga. He kaihautū niupepa ingoa-nui a Mackenzie, i riro nāna i tīmata ētahi niupepa o Te Tai Tokerau. I mahi ia mō te Kaitā Kāwanatanga i Poihākena, ā, he kaiārahi ia i te Southern Cross o Tāmaki-makaurau i mua i tāna whakatūranga i tōna niupepa tino whai painga rawa, te Northern Luminary, i Kawakawa i 1879. Ka hokona e ia tēnei niupepa i te tau 1913. I mōhio nuitia mō te hāngai o āna tuhinga kōrero, ā, ka whakapaetia ia i mua i te Kōti e tētahi tangata kē atu mō te whakahahani i a ia. Nā tana tama a Frank i kawe te Echo i muri i te matenga o tōna matua i te tau 1917, ka haere tonu taea noatia te tukunga i tana tūranga. I riro nā C J Claridge, tama, i whakahaere te niupepa tae noa ki te tau 1927 kātahi ka hokona e ia ki Hilton Venables. Nō muri mai ka hanumitia te Echo ki roto i te Rodney and Otamatea Courier.

Publication.Title: Lyttelton Times
Publication.Description: Even before the arrival of the first colonists in Canterbury, they had highlighted the need for a newspaper: a “Prospectus of Newspaper to be established in the Canterbury Settlement” proposed the publication of a weekly newspaper to be called the Lyttelton Times.

I mua rā anō i te taenga mai o ngā Pākehā tuatahi ki te nohonoho i Waitaha, kua puta mai te hiahia ki tētahi niupepa mā rātou: nā tētahi “Prospectus of Newspaper to be established in the Canterbury Settlement” i whakarewa te whakaaro kia whakaputaina tētahi niupepa ā-wiki, ka kīia ko te Lyttelton Times.
Publication.Essay:
Even before the arrival of the first colonists in Canterbury, they had highlighted the need for a newspaper: a “Prospectus of Newspaper to be established in the Canterbury Settlement” proposed the publication of a weekly newspaper to be called the Lyttelton Times.

The plant arrived in Lyttelton on 16 December 1850 on the Charlotte Jane, one of the first four ships. The first issue was published on the 11 January 1851, under the editorship of James Edward Fitzgerald.

The Lyttelton Times began to appear twice a week in 1854, then in 1863 this increased to three times a week. At this time, publication also moved to Christchurch, already home to The Press newspaper, founded in 1861.

The publishers of the Lyttelton Times started the weekly Canterbury Times in 1865, and then The Star, an evening edition of the Lyttelton Times, appeared on 14 May 1868.

In 1929 the Lyttelton Times became the Christchurch Times, the final issue of which appeared on 29 June 1935.

I mua rā anō i te taenga mai o ngā Pākehā tuatahi ki te nohonoho i Waitaha, kua puta mai te hiahia ki tētahi niupepa mā rātou: nā tētahi “Prospectus of Newspaper to be established in the Canterbury Settlement” i whakarewa te whakaaro kia whakaputaina tētahi niupepa ā-wiki, ka kīia ko te Lyttelton Times.

I tae mai ngā mīhini tā ki Lyttleton i te 16 o ngā rā o Tīhema 1850 i runga i te Charlotte Jane, tētahi o ngā kaipuke tuatahi e whā. Ka hokona te putanga tuatahi i te 11 o ngā rā o Hānuere 1851, ko te etita ko James Edward Fitzgerald.

E rua ngā putanga o ngā Lyttelton Times mai i te tau 1854, ā, nō te tau 1863 ka piki ki te toru putanga i te wiki. I taua wā ka neke te niupepa ki Ōtautahi, koirā hoki te kāinga o te niupepa e kīia nei The Press, nō te tau 1861 i tīmata ai.

Nā ngā kaiwhakaputa o te Lyttelton Times te Canterbury Times i whakarewa i te tau 1865, ka whai i muri ko The Star, he putanga ahiahi tēnei o te Lyttelton Times, i te 14 o ngā rā o Mei 1868.

Nō te tau 1929 ka huri te Lyttelton Times hei Christchurch Times, ā, ka hokona tōna putanga whakamutunga i te 29 o ngā rā o Hune 1935.

Publication.Title: Lyell Times and Central Buller Gazette
Publication.Description: Lyell, in the South Island’s Buller district, was a major producer of gold and the centre of considerable quartz mining activity in the surrounding hills until the mid 1890s. Gold was first discovered in the area by Maori prospectors in the early 1860s. As word spread of their finds, miners arrived from other fields and overseas. The only access was by canoe on the Buller River with its many rapids and it was some years before a road was built along the banks of the Buller Gorge.

Ko te tāone o Lyell, i te riu o te Kawatiri i te Waipounamu tētahi wāhi kaha tāna whakaputa kōura, ā, koia te pūtahi o ngā mahi keri kiripaka i ngā hiwi i te taha taea noatia ngā tau i takiwā o 1894-1896. I kitea tuatahitia te kōura e ngā kairapurapu Māori i ngā tau tuatahi o te tekau tau mai i 1860. Ka poia te rongo o tā rātou i kite ai ki ngā wāhi o te ao, me te waipuke mai o ngā kaikeri mai i ētahi atu rohe me tāwāhi anō hoki. Heoi anō nei te urunga mai he hoehoe waka mā te awa o Kawatiri me ōna tini tāheke, ā, nō ngā tau maha i muri mai kātahi anō ka hangaia he rori i te kūititanga o te Awahuri.
Publication.Essay:
Lyell, in the South Island’s Buller district, was a major producer of gold and the centre of considerable quartz mining activity in the surrounding hills until the mid 1890s.

Gold was first discovered in the area by Maori prospectors in the early 1860s. As word spread of their finds, miners arrived from other fields and overseas. The only access was by canoe on the Buller River with its many rapids and it was some years before a road was built along the banks of the Buller Gorge. Cliff Street, Lyell’s only street, where its banks, hotels and newspaper were located, was constructed in the 1870s. By then, the wives and families of miners had arrived, tents along Lyell Creek were replaced by houses around Cliff Street and a more settled community flourished until it had a population of more than 2,000 in the late 1880s.

The first newspaper, the Lyell Argus and Matakitaki Advertiser, launched in 1873, was published weekly, and for a time twice weekly. Its four pages carried international and local news, particularly mining developments and advertisements for the growing number of retailers along Cliff Street. It was run by James Graham Niven and later by Thomas John Metcalfe. It closed in 1882, very likely because of the arrival of a competitor.

The Lyell Times and Central Buller Gazette was begun in 1881 by Edward Percy Smyrk. He had served an apprenticeship under John Tyrrell, then owner of the Westport Times, before working on the Inangahua Times in Reefton. After Smyrk sold the Lyell Times to Walter Atkin in 1888 he worked on the Westport Times again. Later, as proprietor of the short-lived Gisborne newspaper the New Zealand Standard, he filed for bankruptcy in 1892, with liabilities of £349, more than three times his available assets. Interestingly, among his debtors were two well-known newspapermen, Henry Brett and William G Geddis. He subsequently worked on Hawke’s Bay newspapers.

Walter Atkin, originally from Ireland, had managed the Inangahua Times before taking over the Lyell Times. In 1896, the paper’s Cliff Street office was victim of a major fire that also destroyed the National Bank, three hotels and a number of other buildings. Few of the businesses were insured, but Atkin was covered for £200. With the township badly affected by the fire, Atkin closed the Lyell Times a couple of years later and purchased the Westport News, a morning daily. Unlike many early newspaper proprietors he left a sizeable estate – £2,326 – on his death in 1911. (About $375,000 today.)

Lyell recovered to some degree from the 1896 fire, but the closure of the area’s largest mine a decade later led to a major exodus of residents. A number of surviving buildings were destroyed by another fire in 1926 and most of those still living there left after the 1929 Murchison earthquake. Today the cemetery and a picnic ground with display boards outlining the area’s history are all that remain.

Ko te tāone o Lyell, i te riu o te Kawatiri i te Waipounamu tētahi wāhi kaha tāna whakaputa kōura, ā, koia te pūtahi o ngā mahi keri kiripaka i ngā hiwi i te taha taea noatia ngā tau i takiwā o 1894-1896.

I kitea tuatahitia te kōura e ngā kairapurapu Māori i ngā tau tuatahi o te tekau tau mai i 1860. Ka poia te rongo o tā rātou i kite ai ki ngā wāhi o te ao, me te waipuke mai o ngā kaikeri mai i ētahi atu rohe me tāwāhi anō hoki. Heoi anō nei te urunga mai he hoehoe waka mā te awa o Kawatiri me ōna tini tāheke, ā, nō ngā tau maha i muri mai kātahi anō ka hangaia he rori i te kūititanga o te Awahuri. I hangaia tōna tiriti kotahi anake, te tiriti o Cliff , Lyell i te tekau tau mai i 1870. I reira ngā pēke, ngā hōtēra me te tari nūpepa o te tāone. Nō te taenga ki tērā wā, kua taetae mai ngā wāhine me ngā whānau o ngā kaikeri, ā, kua ngaro ngā tēneti i te taha o Lyell Creek, me te tū mai o ngā whare i te Tiriti o Cliff. Ka tupu mai he hapori āhua toitū, ā, ka piki te taupori kia neke atu i te 2,000 i ngā tau mai i 1886 ki 1890.

I whakarewaina te nūpepa tuatahi, te Lyell Argus and Matakitaki Advertiser, i te tau 1873, ā, kotahi putanga i te wiki, ā, i muri e rua ngā putanga i te wiki mō tētahi wā. I roto i ōna whārangi e whā ngā pitopito kōrero o te ao, o te takiwā, otirā ngā āhuatanga keri kōura katoa, ngā pānui mai i ngā toa hokohoko huri noa i te Tiriti o Cliff. He mea whakahaere e James Graham Niven ā, i ngā tau ki muri nā Thomas John Metcalfe. I katia i te tau 1882, te āhua nei nā te taenga mai o tētahi hoa tauwhāinga.

I tīmataria te Lyell Times and Central Buller Gazette i te tau 1881 e Edward Percy Smyrk. I akoako ia i raro i a John Tyrrell, te rangatira i taua wā o te Westport Times, i mua i tana mahi i te Inangahua Times i Rīwhitana. I muri i te hokonga a Smyrk i te Lyell Times ki a Walter Atkin i te tau 1888 i mahi anō ia i teWestport Times. Nō muri mai, hei rangatira o te nūpepa o Tūranga nui a Kiwa e mōhiotia ko te New Zealand Standard ka tono ia ki te kōti pēkerapu i te tau 1892. Ko ngā nama i eke ki te £349, e toru whakareanga tēnei o āna rawa. He mea anō, i waenga i ōna hoa noho nama ki a ia tokorua ngā kaimahi nūpepa, a Henry Brett rāua ko William G Geddis. Nō muri ka mahi ia i ētahi nūpepa i te Matau a Māui.

Kua whakahaeretia e Walter Atkin, mai i Airani i mua, te Inangahua Times i mua i tana whakahaere i te Lyell Times. I te tau 1896, ka wera te tari o te nūpepa i te Tiriti o Cliff i te ahi, nāna hoki i kai te Pēke National, ngā hōtēra e toru me ētahi atu whare. He iti noa ngā umanga i inihuatia engari i te inihuatia a Atkin mō te £200. I tino kino te raru o te tāone i te ahi, ā, ka kati a Atkin i te Lyell Times ā, e rua tau ki muri ka huri ki te hoko i teWestport News, he nūpepa ata ā-rā. Kāore i rite ki ētahi atu rangatira nūpepa o aua tau tuatahi, arā, ka waiho e ia ētahi moni nui ki ana uri - £2,326 – i tōna matenga i te tau 1911. (tata ki te $375,000 i ngā moni o nāianei.)

I hoki mai anō tōna ora ki Lyell, me kī tōna ora nei, i muri i te ahi o 1896 , engari nā te katinga o te keringa nui rawa i muri ka tino mimiti katoa atu te nui o ōna tāngata. Tērā ētahi atu whare i ngaro i te ahi i te tau 1926 ā, ka wehe atu te nuinga o te hunga i te noho tonu i reira i muri i te rū nui o Murchison i te tau 1929. Heoi anō nei ngā tohu o te tāone kei reira tonu ināianei he urupā, he wāhi pikiniki, me ōna papa whakaaturanga ūā ana nei.

E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki Lyall Adamson, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Lake Wakatip Mail
Publication.Description: Following the discovery of gold on the banks of the Shotover River in November 1862, the town of Queenstown appeared almost overnight and the first issue of the Lake Wakatip Mail followed soon after on 2 May 1863. The Otago Daily Times of 18 May 1863 commented about the Mail that ‘it seems difficult to realise ... that such a paper should be published in Queenstown, a place which six months ago was the head station of a runholder, and nothing more’.

I muri i te kitenga i te kōura i ngā tahataha o te awa o te Kimi-ākau o te marama o Nōema 1862, ka tū wawe tonu te tāone o Queenstown i te rā kotahi, te āhua nei, ā, i puta hoki te putanga tuatahi o te Lake Wakatip Mail i muri tata tonu iho i te 2 Mei 1863. I puta te kī a te Otago Daily Times i te 18 Mei 1863 mō te Mail, pēnei "he uaua hopu a te hinengaro ... i tēnei āhua, kia tū he nūpepa pēnei i Queenstown, he takiwā tēnei he teihana pāmu matua noa iho nā tētahi kaipupuru whenua, kāore kau atu i reira e ono marama ki muri’.
Publication.Essay:
Following the discovery of gold on the banks of the Shotover River in November 1862, the town of Queenstown appeared almost overnight and the first issue of the Lake Wakatip Mail followed soon after on 2 May 1863. The Otago Daily Times of 18 May 1863 commented about the Mail that ‘it seems difficult to realise ... that such a paper should be published in Queenstown, a place which six months ago was the head station of a runholder, and nothing more’.

James Bradshaw, who later achieved prominence as a Member of Parliament and as an important early advocate of labour law reform, worked as an editor of the Mail. However, the key figure in the early life of the paper was William Warren, who became part owner of the paper in 1864 and sole owner in 1867.

When gold was discovered on the West Coast, many miners moved on, and the Mail struggled to survive in the severe slump that followed. In April 1867 the Mail announced it would cease publication but was revived after missing only one issue. In its early years, flood and fire also added to the Mail’s difficulties. In 1878 the lower part of Queenstown was flooded and the Mail’s stock damaged; worse was to follow in 1879 when two of Warren’s children lit some paper and the Mail’s office was completely destroyed by fire, along with a supply of new type and materials that had only been received from Melbourne the previous day.

In 1883 Warren found himself in legal strife after the Mail published a scathing article about a public address by J T Marryat Hornsby of the neighbouring Arrowtown newspaper, the Lake County Press. Hornsby sued for damages for libel and succeeded when the jury held that the Mail had implied that Hornsby was a convict by saying he came from Tasmania.

After William Warren died the Warren family continued to be involved with the Mail for many years. During the First World War, Margaret (Daisy) Warren took over management of the paper when her brother enlisted for service, despite prejudice and doubt over her suitability for the role. Daisy proved to be highly successful in her new position and after the war continued to have a prominent role in the running of the Mail.

In 1928 the Lake Wakatip Mail absorbed the Lake County Press and continued to be published until 6 February 1947.

I muri i te kitenga i te kōura i ngā tahataha o te awa o te Kimi-ākau o te marama o Nōema 1862, ka tū wawe tonu te tāone o Queenstown i te rā kotahi, te āhua nei, ā, i puta hoki te putanga tuatahi o te Lake Wakatip Mail i muri tata tonu iho i te 2 Mei 1863. I puta te kī a te Otago Daily Times i te 18 Mei 1863 mō te Mail, pēnei "he uaua hopu a te hinengaro ... i tēnei āhua, kia tū he nūpepa pēnei i Queenstown, he takiwā tēnei he teihana pāmu matua noa iho nā tētahi kaipupuru whenua, kāore kau atu i reira e ono marama ki muri’.

I mahi a James Bradshaw, hei etita mō te Mail. He tangata tēnei i hau te rongo hei Mema Pāremata, hei kaikauwhau tuatahi mō te whakatikatika i ngā ture mō te hunga mahi i ōna rā. Ahakoa, ko te tino kaihautū matua i ngā tau tuatahi ko William Warren, i eke rā hei rangatira mō ētahi o ngā hea o te nūpepa i te tau 1864 ā, ka noho hoki hei kaipupuru hea takitahi i te tau 1867.

Nō te kitenga i te taonga nei i te kōura i te Tai Poutini ka hūnuku atu te tini o ngā kaikeri, ā, ka uaua tonu te haere o te Mail i ngā tāpokopokotanga whai i muri. I te marama o Āperira 1867 ka puta te kī a te Mail ka mutu tāna puta ki te ao engari i whakaorangia mai anō i muri i te hapanga kotahi. I ōna tau tuatahi, nā te waipuke, nā te kānga hoki o te ahi i haupū ai he uauatanga mō te Mail. I te tau 1878 ka waipuketia te wāhanga o raro o Queenstown me te raru anō o ngā rawa o te Mail; engari he kino kē atu te aitua i whai i muri i te tau 1879. Nā ētahi tamariki tokorua a Warren i tahu pepa, ā, ka toro te ahi, kainga katoatia ana te tari o te Mail e te ahi, tae atu ki ngā pūranga poraka tā me ngā rawa kātahi anō ka tae mai i Poipiripi i te rā o mua atu.

I te tau 1883 ka taka a Warren ki tētahi raruraru ā-ture i tāna whakaputanga i tētahi tuhinga whiu kōrero i te Mail mō tētahi kauwhau tūmatanui nā J T Marryat Hornsby nō te nūpepa o te tāonga tūtata o Arrowtown nō te Lake County Press. I hāmene a Hornsby i a ia mō ngā tūkinotanga i te tuhinga, ā i eke tana whakapae i te kitenga a te tekau mā rua nā te Mail i whakairi te whakaaro he mauhere a Hornsby nā te mea i ahu mai ia i Tasmania.

I muri i te matenga o William Warren i haere tonu te mahi tahitanga a te whānau Warren ki ngā mahi te Mail mō ngā tau maha rawa. I roto i te Pakanga Tuatahi o Te Ao nā te tuahine o Warren nā Margaret (Daisy) Warren i whakahaere te nūpepa i te urunga o tana tungāne ki ngā ope hōia, ahakoa ngā whakaaro kino me ngā āwangawanga mō tana tōtika mō te tūnga. Ka tino eke ngā mahi katoa o te nūpepa i a Daisy ā, i muri i te pakanga i haere tonu tana mahi ki te whakahaere i te Mail.

I te tau 1928 ka horomia e te Lake Wakatip Mail te Lake County Press ā, i puta haere tonu taea noatia te 6 Pēpuere 1947.
