I whakamamatitia tēnei niupepa i runga anō i te āwhina mai o ngā Central Lakes Trust .

Publication.Title: Maoriland Worker
Publication.Description: The Maoriland Worker is widely considered the most important publication of the New Zealand labour movement. Early in the 20th century the labour movement had two main strands – those wanting revolution and those working for reform and both had publications reflecting their views. Militant trade unionists did not fit easily into either camp. The Shearers’ Union in Christchurch felt the full weight of press condemnation after a 1910 wage dispute and decided to begin their own paper, The Maoriland Worker, as a monthly.

E whakaarotia whānuitia ana he putanga hiranga nui te Maoriland Worker ki te kaupapa reipa o Aotearoa. I te tīmatatanga o te rautau rua tekau e rua ngā peka o te kaupapa reipa – ko te hunga e whai ana i te pāhoro, me te hunga e whai ana kia whakahoutia ngā tikanga, i whakaritea hoki e ia rōpū he putanga hei whakaata, hei whakaputa hoki i ō rātou tirohanga ki te ao. Kāore i uru pai ngā kaiuniana kaitaua ki raro i ia o aua karangatanga. Nā te kaha pēhi, whakahē hoki o ngā niupepa i a rātou i muri i tētahi tautohe utu i te tau 1910, i whakatauhia e te Shearers' Union i Ōtautahi kia tīmata i tā rātou ake pepa, Te Maoriland Worker hei putanga ā-marama.
Publication.Essay:
The Maoriland Worker is widely considered the most important publication of the New Zealand labour movement. Early in the 20th century the labour movement had two main strands – those wanting revolution and those working for reform and both had publications reflecting their views. Militant trade unionists did not fit easily into either camp. The Shearers’ Union in Christchurch felt the full weight of press condemnation after a 1910 wage dispute and decided to begin their own paper, The Maoriland Worker, as a monthly. The newspaper was produced in Christchurch for a short period, with Ettie Rout and Alexander Wildey prominent. When the shearers’ and miners’ unions combined forces, the paper now represented the ‘Red’ Federation of Labour and, early in 1911, moved its publishing office to Wellington.

The paper, now a weekly, grew rapidly in circulation and influence under the editorship of Australian Bob Ross. It had a circulation of 8,500 by 1912 and 10,000 by the beginning of the next year. It was at the centre of the Federation’s push for socialism. Unionists were enthusiastic ‘paper boys’ and there was a network of voluntary correspondents around the country. The Maoriland Worker’s editorial policy was firmly behind industrial unionism, international co-operation among unionists and pacifism.

The Maoriland Worker was produced to a high professional standard and included some of the most penetrating political cartoons of the period. Ross had left by 1913, and his replacement, Harry Holland, was later leader of the Labour Party. Holland was charged with sedition for his coverage of a waterfront dispute that snowballed into a general strike late in 1913. He was sentenced to a year in prison, and served a little over three months. When war broke out shortly afterwards, the Maoriland Worker took an uncompromising international socialist position and Holland editorialised that world revolution was at hand. He left the paper in 1918 when elected to Parliament at a by-election.

The weekly continued to express its radical views through the war years and until the early 1920s. During the First World War it struggled with libel costs, censorship and police harassment. In October 1921 The Maoriland Worker carried two poems by the noted British war poet Siegfried Sassoon. Three lines of ‘Stand to: Good Friday Morning’ attracted the attention of the authorities and the paper’s publisher was charged with ‘blasphemous libel’. John Glover was tried in the Supreme Court in 1922, still the only such case in NZ legal history. The trial was held at a time when any dissent was suppressed wherever possible and politicians were preoccupied with maintaining ‘social order’, religion an important component of this. Glover was cleared of the charge, but the jury added a rider to its acquittal noting that the publication of such material should be discouraged.

In 1924, the publication’s name was changed to the New Zealand Worker. The paper’s sub-title also changed. It went from ‘A journal of industrial unionism, socialism and politics’ to ‘A New Zealand paper for New Zealand people’. Although trade unions still funded its publication, control now rested with the Labour Party. The radicalism softened rapidly and substantially as the Labour Party sought electoral respectability.

E whakaarotia whānuitia ana he putanga hiranga nui te Maoriland Worker ki te kaupapa reipa o Aotearoa. I te tīmatatanga o te rautau rua tekau e rua ngā peka o te kaupapa reipa – ko te hunga e whai ana i te pāhoro, me te hunga e whai ana kia whakahoutia ngā tikanga, i whakaritea hoki e ia rōpū he putanga hei whakaata, hei whakaputa hoki i ō rātou tirohanga ki te ao. Kāore i uru pai ngā kaiuniana kaitaua ki raro i ia o aua karangatanga. Nā te kaha pēhi, whakahē hoki o ngā niupepa i a rātou i muri i tētahi tautohe utu i te tau 1910, i whakatauhia e te Shearers' Union i Ōtautahi kia tīmata i tā rātou ake pepa, Te Maoriland Worker hei putanga ā-marama. I whakaputaina te niupepa i Ōtautahi mō te wā poto, i reira i tino kitea ngā mahi a Ettie Rout me Alexander Wildey. I te whakakotahitanga o te uniana kaikutikuti hipi ki te uniana kaimaina, kua noho te pepa hei kanohi mō te Federation of Labour 'Whero', ā, i te tīmatatanga o 1911, i nekehia tana tari whakaputa ki Te Whanga nui ā-Tara.

I raro i te ētitatanga o Bob Ross nō Ahitereiria, he tere te tipu o te niupepa, he mea whakaputa ā-wiki ināianei, i runga i te nui o ngā kaipānui, i runga hoki i te kaha o tōna awe. I te tau 1912, 8,500 ngā kaipānui, ā, 10,000 i te tīmatatanga o te tau whai muri mai. Me kī ko te pokapū tērā o te Federation mō te akiaki i te mana hapori. E rikarika ana ngā kaiuniana kia tū hei 'paper boy', he whatunga kairīpoata tūao hoki tō rātou puta noa i ngā motu. I te tino taunaki te kaupapahere ētita a te Maoriland Worker i te unianatanga ahumahi, te mahitahitanga a ngā kaiuniana puta noa i te ao, me te whakamārietanga.

I eke ngā tikanga tārei i te Maoriland Worker i runga i tētahi paerewa ngaio teitei tonu, tae atu ki ētahi o ngā pakiwaituhi tōrangapū tīwharawhara hoki o te wā. I wehe atu a Ross i te tau 1913, nō muri mai i whiwhi i tana whakakapi a Harry Holand te tūranga o te kaitātaki o te Labour Party. I hāmenetia a Holland mō te mahi whana kāwanatanga mō tana rīpoata i tētahi tautohenga wāpu i huri hei taraiki whānui i te mutunga o te tau 1913. I whiua a ia ki te kotahi tau i roto whareherehere, engari i mauheretia mō te toru marama noa iho. Nō muri tata i pakaru mai te pakanga, ko te tū a te Maoriland Worker ko te tū a te kaikōkiri mana hapori ā-ao, i puta hoki ngā matapae a Holland i ngā kōrero ētita mō te ekenga o te pāhoro ā-ao. I wehe a ia i te pepa i te tau 1918 i tana pōtitanga ki te Whare Pāremata i tētahi pōtitanga-iti.

He kaha tonu te whakaputa a ngā tirohanga wāwāhi tikanga puta noa i ngā tau o te pakanga tae atu ki ngā tau tuatahi o ngā 1920. I waenga i ngā tau o te pakanga i pēhingia hoki te niupepa e ngā utu kupu whakakino, te aukatinga me te inonotitanga pirihimana. I te tau 1921 i tāngia e te Maoriland Worker ētahi ruri nā te kaitito rongonui Peretania o te pakanga a Siegfried Sassoon. I kitea e ngā mana o te wā ngā raina e toru o 'Stand to: Good Friday Morning’ i hāmenetia te kaiwhakaputa o te pepa mō te 'kupu whakakino kohukohu'. I whakawāhia a John Glover i te Supreme Court i te tau 1922, koira anake te momo kēhi pērā i te hītori ture o Aotearoa. I tū te whakawā i tētahi wā ko te pēhi i te hunga whakararu i ngā wā me ngā wāhi ka taea te mahi, ā, i te aro kē ngā kaitōrangapū ki te pupuritanga o te 'raupapa pāpori', ko te hāhi tētahi wae tino nui o tēnei momo mahi. I wetea a Glover i te whakapae, engari i tāpirihia atu e te tekau mā rua he kōrero ki tana wetenga e kī ana e tika ana kia whakapāhunu i aua momo tuhinga.

I te tau 1924, i hurihia te ingoa o te putanga ki te New Zealand Worker. I huri hoki te taitara-roto. I huri mai i te kōrero 'He hautaka o te unianatanga ahumahi, te mana hapori me te tōrangapū' ki 'He pepa nō Aotearoa mā ngā tāngata o Aotearoa'. Ahakoa i te whai pūtea tonu te putanga i ngā uniana, i te noho tonu te mana whakahaere i te Rōpū Reipa. He tere, he nui hoki te heke o te mahi wāwāhi tikanga i a te Labour Party e whai ana kia tika tō rātou āhua ā-tōrangapū.

Publication.Title: Mataura Ensign
Publication.Description: The Mataura Ensign, named after the Scottish newspaper, the Northern Ensign, was first produced in Gore (in Southland) on the 10 May 1878. The early years of the paper had a strong literary flavour including regular articles from 'Uncle Phil' who encouraged children to write well. The paper is still published daily today as the Ensign.

Ko te Mataura Ensign i puta mai i te tāone o Gore i Murihiku i te 10 o Haratua i te tau 1878. I tapaina taua ingoa mai i te nūpepa o Kotarangi (Scotland) e kīia nei ko te Northern Ensign. I te tīmatanga, he nūpepa tuhituhi mātauranga anake, ā, he nui hoki ngā tuhituhinga o "Uncle Phil". Ko tana mahi he whakakaha i ngā tamariki kia pai rātau ki te tuhituhi. Kei te tū tonu taua nūpepa ēngari ko tana ingoa ināianei ko te Ensign.
Publication.Essay:
The Mataura Ensign began publication in Gore (in Southland) on 10 May 1878 by Joseph Mackay who owned the Bruce Herald in Milton at the time. He ensured that his new venture began soundly by first securing backing from several of the Mataura Valley's prominent businessmen.

The paper's name was suggested by Mackay's business partner George Renner, after the Scottish newspaper the Northern Ensign. Renner and his partner James Sinclair canvassed the district for subscribers and advertisers.

Milton newspaper publisher Alfred Dolamore bought the Ensign in August 1882. Mackay went on to establish the Southern Free Press at Mataura but this paper failed to compete with the Mataura Ensign, as did its later rival, the Gore Standard.

Dolamore had previous experience on the Nelson Evening Mail and Southland Times. The Mataura Ensign expanded rapidly under Dolamore and he took on additional partners including his brother Howard. The paper moved into larger premises and increased the circulation area. Dolamore died in 1895 and after a disastrous fire which destroyed everything except the printing machine, the paper moved to new premises in Mersey Street, Gore. The Ensign became a daily in April 1906.

Under the Dolamore's stewardship the paper retained a strong literary flavour, claiming amongst its staff the noted historian James Herries Beattie (1881-1972). He compiled extensive files on the history of Southland through oral interviews and correspondence. William Gilchrist, headmaster of East Gore School from 1891, wrote as "Uncle Phil" for many years, encouraging children to write well.

In 1920 the Gore Publishing Company was formed and included a number of the paper's employee. The newspaper changed its name to the Ensign in 1973 and is still published daily.

Ka tīmata te puta mai o te Mataura Ensign, mai i te tāone o Gore i Murihiku i te 10 o Haratua i te tau 1878. Ko te tangata nana i tārai ko Joseph Mackay. Nōna anō hoki te nūpepa o Milton e kīia nei ko te Bruce Herald. I āhei ake ia kia tino kaha taua nūpepa, ā, i tēnei nā ka haere ia kia tautokona taua nūpepa e ngā tangata kaipakihi rongonui o te riu o Mataura.

Nā tētahi o ngā hoa kaipakihi o Mackay, arā, ko George Renner, i whakaaro kia tāpaia te ingoa o te nūpepa o Kotarangi (Scotland), arā, te Northern Ensign, hei ingoa mō te nūpepa nei. Ko te mahi a Renner rāua ko tana hoa kaipakihi a James Sinclair, hei whai ake i ngā kaitango koha, i ngā kaipānui hoko rānei mō te nūpepa.

I te marama o Here-turi-kōkā 1882, ka hokona e Alfred Dolamore te Ensign. Ko ia hoki te kaiwhakaputa nūpepa i te tāone o Milton. I ngā tau ki muri i tīmataia e Joseph Mackay te Southern Free Press ki Mataura, ēngari kāore i ora tēnei nūpepa i te taha o te Mataura Ensign, ā, i pērā anō tērā o ngā nūpepa whakataetae, a te Gore Standard.

I mua hoki, i mahi ia i ngā nūpepa e kīia nei ko te Nelson Evening Mail me te Southland Times. Ka tino tere te piki o te kaha o te Mataura Ensign, ā, ka whakaurua e ia he hoa kaipakihi anō, ā, ko tētahi ko tana tungāne a Howard. Ka nuku taua nūpepa ki roto kē i tētahi tari nui kē, ā, ka rahi kē atu anō te rohe e kapi ai. I te tau 1895 ka mate a Dolamore, ā, i muri atu i tētahi ahi nunui nei ka ngaro katoa te tari, ā, ko te mīhini tā nūpepa anake i toe. Ka nuku te nūpepa ki tētahi whare hou i te tiriti o Mersey, i te tāone o Gore. Nō te marama o Paenga-whāwhā i te tau 1906, ka puta mai ia rā taua nūpepa.

I raro i te kaiārahitanga o Dolamore, ka mau tonu te kaupapa whakaputa tuhituhinga mātauranga. I taua wā anō ko tētahi o ngā kaimahi o taua nūpepa nā, ko tētahi tonu o ngā toa mō te tuhituhi kōrero o nehe. Ko James Herries Beattie (1881-1972) tana ingoa. I hangaia e ia ētahi tukunga kōrero e pā ana ki te tāhuhu korero o Murihiku. I hopukina e ia aua kōrero mai i te kōrero ā-kanohi me te tuhi anō hoki ki ētahi atu tāngata. Ko te kaituhi "Uncle Phil" ko William Gilchrist, te tumuaki o te kura o Gore ki te rāwhiti. I tuhi ia mai i te tau 1891, ā, mō ngā tau nui ki muri hoki. Ko tana mahi hei whakakaha i ngā taitamariki kia tino pai ake tā rātau tuhi.

I te tau 1920, ka whakatūria te kamupene whakaputa pukapuka, arā, te Gore Publishing Company, ā, i nui tonu ngā kaimahi o te nūpepa i mahi i taua kamupene nā. I te tau 1973 ka tīnihia te ingoa o te nūpepa rā ki te Ensign, ā, e haere tonu nei i tēnei wā hei nūpepa e tāngia ana ia rā, ia rā.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank the Ensign Office in Gore for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Ensign Office ki roto i Gore, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Marlborough Express
Publication.Title-alternate: The Marlborough Express and Weekly Commercial Reporter.
Publication.Description: The Marlborough Express is the daily newspaper of Blenheim and has been published there since 1866. It became a daily in 1880 and took over its rivals the Marlborough Times in 1895 and the Marlborough Press in 1948. In 1998 it was sold to Independent Newspapers Limited (INL).

Ko te Marlborough Express te nūpepa ā-rangi o Wairau kua pānuitia ki reira mai i te tau 1866. Ka puta ia rā mai i te tau 1880, ā, taumanutia ana e iaōna tāwhai, arā, te Marlborough Times i te tau 1895 me te Marlborough Press i te tau 1948. I te tau 1998 ka hokona ia ki te kamupene Independent Newspapers Limited (INL).
Publication.Essay:
The Marlborough Express is the daily newspaper of Blenheim and has been published there since 1866.

In 1866 the prospects for a new newspaper in Marlborough were not good. The population of the province was small and Marlborough already had two newspapers. A third, the Marlborough Times, had folded the year before after a few months in operation.

The Express was founded by Samuel Johnson. Johnson already had some experience as a journalist in England and New Zealand. He had arrived in 1862 with the Albertians, a band of idealistic settlers who settled in North Auckland. Johnson edited the Albertian newspaper the Albertland Gazette for a short time until he became disillusioned with the settlement. He then worked on newspapers in other parts of the country before settling on Blenheim.

Politics in Marlborough was dominated by rivalry between Blenheim and Picton, and this was reflected in the Marlborough newspapers. Originally the Press was published in Blenheim but had moved to Picton. The publishers tried to placate Blenheim residents by saying that the paper was actually published in both places, but eventually they had to publish a separate Blenheim paper, the Wairau Record. When launching the Express Johnson promised to give Marlborough a paper that would serve the whole province. Perhaps it was this attempt to rise above the squabbling between Blenheim and Picton that helped the Express establish itself and ultimately prevail over its rivals.

In 1879 Johnson sold the Express to Smith Furness and James Boudy. Furness had worked on newspapers in Wellington, Nelson, and Ashburton. The Furness family controlled the Express until 1998 when it was sold to Independent Newspapers Limited (INL). The Express became a daily in 1880 and took over its rivals the Marlborough Times in 1895 and the Marlborough Press in 1948.

Ko te Marlborough Express te nūpepa ā-rangi o Waiharakeke (Blenheim), ā, kua tāngia ki reira mai i te tau 1866.

I te tau 1866 kāhore i pai rawa ngā tūmanakohanga mō tētahi nūpepa hou ki te rohe o Wairau. He iti hoki te nuinga tāngata i te rohe, ā, e rua kē hoki ngā nūpepa i reira. Kua hinga kē hoki te tuatoru, arā, te Marlborough Times, i te tau o mua, i muri mai i ētahi marama noa e whakahaeretia ana.

Nā Samuel Johnson te Express i whakaū. Kua whai mātanga kē a Johnson hei kaituhi nūpepa i Ingarangi, i Aotearoa hoki. I tae mai ia i te tau 1862 i te taha o ngā Albertians, tētahi rōpū tāngata whai, whai whakaaro rangatira tonu, i noho ki te Tai Tokerau. Nā Johnson i whakatika te nūpepa o te rōpū Albertian, arā, te Albertland Gazette, mō tētahi wā poto, puta rawa tōna matekiritanga i tērā nohanga. Ka mahi tonu ia i ētahi nūpepa i wāhi kē o te whenua i mua i tana nohonga ki Waiharakeke.

Ko te tauwhāinga i waenganui i a Waiharakeke me Waitohi (Picton) te whakaawe i te ao tōrangapū ki Wairau, ā, whakaātatia ana tēnei āhuatanga i roto i ngā nūpepa o te rohe. I tāngia tuatahitia te Press i Waiharakeke, ēngari kua neke ki Waitohi. He whakamātauranga nā ngā kaiwhakaputa ki te whakarata i ngā tāngata whenua o Waiharakeke tā rātou meatanga i whakaputaina te nūpepa ki aua wāhi e rua, heoi taro rawa tō rātou tānga i tētahi nūpepa motuhake mō Waiharakeke, arā, te Wairau Record. I te whakawahatanga o te Express ka whai kupu whakaari a Johnson ka hoatu e ia he nūpepa ki a Wairau hei ratonga mō te rohe katoa. Nā tēnei whakamātauranga kia rewa ake i ngā tautohetohe i waenganui i a Waiharakeke me Waitohi, nā konei pea te āwhina i ū ai te Express, ā, i kake rā anō i runga i ōna tāwhai.

I te tau 1879 ka hokona te Express e Johnson ki a Smith Furness rāua ko James Boudy. Kua mahi hoki a Furness i ētahi nūpepa i Pōneke, i Whakatū (Nelson) me Hakatere (Ashburton). Nā te whānau Furness te Express i whakahaere tae ana ki 1998, i tōna hokonga ki te kamupene Independent Newspapers Limited (INL). I tāngia ia rā te Express i te tau 1880, ā, taumanutia ana e ia ōna tāwhai te Marlborough Times i te tau 1895 me te Marlborough Press i te tau 1948.

Publication.Title: Manawatu Herald
Publication.Description: The Manawatu Herald was founded in 1878 and was the first paper published in Foxton. The paper was initially published twice a week then moved to thrice weekly in 1890, back to bi-weekly in 1944 and then to weekly from 1956. In 1955 the title was changed to the Foxton Herald and in 1961 it reverted to the Manawatu Herald. The paper ceased publication in 1997.

I whakaūhia te Manawatu Herald i te tau 1878, ā, koia anō te nūpepa tuatahi i tāngia ki Foxton. E rua ngā rā tānga ia wiki i te tīmatanga, ā, ka nekehia kia toru ngā rā tānga ia wiki i te tau 1890, hoki ana ki te rua rā ia wiki i te tau 1944, kātahi ki te kotahi rā ia wiki i te tau 1956. I whakawhitia te ingoa ki te Foxton Herald i te tau 1955, ā, i hoki anō ia ki te Manawatu Herald i te tau 1961. I mutu te tānga o te nūpepa i te tau 1997.
Publication.Essay:
Newspaper publishing began in the Foxton area in the 1870s when the Manawatu was opened up for European settlement. In this period Foxton’s port was developed and the town was linked by coach and rail to the main centres in the lower North Island.

The Manawatu Herald was founded by brothers George Warren Russell and John Ruffell Russell in 1878. It was the first paper published in Foxton, following unsuccessful attempts in 1873 to publish a newspaper called the Manawatu Guardian. George Russell had worked on newspapers in Invercargill and Wellington and went on to work on others, in particular the Spectator in Christchurch. He was also a prominent Member of the House of Representatives and cabinet minister during the First World War.

George Russell did not stay with the Herald for long. By 1882 he had moved on to the Manawatu Times in Palmerston North leaving his brother with the Foxton paper. The Herald was sold to Ernest Thynne in 1889. During Thynne’s tenure the Herald had a rival paper to contend with, the Foxton Telegraph, which ran for four years from 1896. The local council appear to have encouraged the Telegraph by dividing council advertising between it and the Herald. This was probably because Thynne and the Herald represented the rural lobby in Foxton.

In 1906 Thynne sold the paper to John Knowles Hornblow. Hornblow came from a family of newspapermen; his father wrote for the New Zealand Times, and Hornblow and his brothers worked on various Wairarapa newspapers. Hornblow owned the Wairarapa Standard in Greytown before taking over the Herald.

When Hornblow took over the Herald, Foxton was a town with prospects. There were plans to extend the port and it was hoped that the main trunk line would go through Foxton. Unfortunately within a year or two these prospects were gone. The port development did not go ahead and the railway that was completed in 1908 bypassed Foxton. Despite this Hornblow and his son Robert managed to keep the Herald running, with Robert taking over as proprietor after his father died in 1937. The paper changed hands several more times before ceasing publication in 1997.

The Herald was initially published twice a week then moved to thrice weekly in 1890, back to bi-weekly in 1944 and then weekly from 1956. In 1955 the title was changed to the Foxton Herald and in 1961 it reverted to the Manawatu Herald.

I tīmatahia te tānga nūpepa i te takiwā o Foxton i te tekau tau mai i 1870 i te whakapūaretanga o Manawatu hei nohanga Pākehā. I whakawhanaketia te poi o Foxton i tēnei wā, ā, nā te kōti, nā te tereina hoki i hono ai te tāone ki ngā tāone mātua o te Ūpoko o te Ika a Māui.

Nā te tuakana a George Warren Russell rāua ko te teina a John Ruffell Russell te Manawatu Herald i whakaū i 1878. Koia te nūpepa tuatahi i tāngia ki Foxton, i muri i ngā whakamātauranga huakore ki te whakaputa i tētahi nūpepa i huaina te Manawatu Guardian i te tau 1873. Kua mahi kē a George Russell i ētahi nūpepa i Waihopai (Invercargill) me Pōneke, ā, i haere tonu ki ētahi atu mahi ai pērā i te Spectator i Otautahi. He mema whakarae anō ia o te Whare Pāremata, he minita hoki o te Rūnanga o te Kāwanatanga i te wā o te Pakanga Tuatahi o te Ao

Kāhore tonu i roa te noho a George Russell ki te Herald. Tae ana ki te tau 1882 kua neke kē ia ki te Manawatu Times i Te Papaioea (Palmerston North), mahue ana tana teina i te nūpepa i Foxton. I hokona te Herald ki a Ernest Thynne i te tau 1889. I a Thynne te pupuritanga, he tāwhai tautohenga tō te Herald, arā, te Foxton Telegraph, he nūpepa i haere tonu e whā ngā tau mai 1896. Te āhua nei nā te kaunihera ā-rohe te Telegraph i āki, i tā rātou wāwāhitanga i ngā pānui kaunihera i waenganui i te Telegraph me te Herald. I heipū pea tēnei āhuatanga i te mea hei kanohi a Thynne me te Herald mō te rōpū pōti taiwhenua o Foxton.

I te tau 1906 ka hokona te nūpepa e Thynne ki a John Knowles Hornblow. Nō tētahi whānau kaituhi nūpepa a Hornblow. I tuhi tōna pāpā mō te New Zealand Times, ko Hornblow rātou ko ana teina hoki i mahi mō ētahi nūpepa i te Wairarapa. Nō Hornblow hoki te Wairarapa Standard i mua i tana taumanutanga i te Herald.

I te taumanutanga o Hornblow i te Herald, he tāone whai tūmanako a Foxton. Tēnei ake ngā kaupapa hei whakarahi i te poi, ā, i tūmanakohia ka haere rā Foxton te ararōau matua. He mea whakarapa tonu i ngaro ai ēnei tūmanako i roto i te kotahi tau, rua tau rānei. Kāhore i neke whakamua te whakawhanaketanga o te poi, ā, i karo te rerewē i whakaotia i te tau 1908 i a Foxton. Ahakoa rā, āhei ana i a Hornblow rāua ko tana tama a Rōpata, kia haere tonu te Herald, ko Rōpata anō te taumanu ana hei rangatira i muri i te matenga o tōna pāpā i te tau 1937. He maha tonu ngā whakawhitinga ringaringa i mua o te whakamututanga i te tau 1997.

I te tīmatanga e rua ngā tānga i ia wiki, ā, ka nekehia kia toru ngā tānga i ia wiki i te tau 1890, hoki ana ki te rua rā i ia wiki i te tau 1944, kātahi ki te tānga ā-wiki mai i te tau 1956. I whakawhitia te ingoa ki te Foxton Herald i te tau 1955, ā, i hoki anō ia ki te Manawatu Herald i te tau 1961.

Publication.Title: Manawatu Standard
Publication.Description: Keen to have his own newspaper, Alexander McMinn, editor of the Rangitkei Advocate, established the Manawatu Standard in 1880 as a four page morning daily, the first daily in Palmerston North. The first issue, dated 29 November 1880, contained an editorial written by John Ballance.

Nā Alexander McMinn, te kaiwhakaputa o te Rangitikei Advocate, i whakarewa te Manawatu Standard i te tau 1880 hei nūpepa whā whārangi mō ia rā, i runga i tana hiahia ki te whakatū nūpepa māna ake, ā, koinei hoki te nūpepa tuatahi i Pāmutana. I puta te putanga tuatahi i te 29 o Noema 1880, ā, i reira ētahi tuhinga nā John Ballance.
Publication.Essay:
Keen to have his own newspaper, Alexander McMinn, editor of the Rangitkei Advocate, established the Manawatu Standard in 1880 as a four page morning daily, the first daily in Palmerston North. The first issue, dated 29 November 1880, contained an editorial written by John Ballance.

As circulation increased (estimated at 1,500 in 1881), technology improved, with replacement of the hand-press by a steam-driven printing press, and town and country editions were introduced. Relations with the rival Manawatu Times were disputatious.

Brothers Frederick and David Pirani took it over in 1891 and later changed it to an evening publication. Martha Pirani, wife of Frederick, wrote editorials for the paper. Liberal Independent in politics, it circulated in the Manawatu District, Hawke’s Bay and Taranaki and was recognised for its stock sale advertisements. Frederick won the seat of Palmerston in the election of 1893 and remained in office until his retirement due to poor health in 1902.

The Manawatu Standard was sold to John Coombe and Norman Henry Nash in 1903. The Standard celebrated its Golden Jubilee in 1930, with a special issue. Despite further changes in ownership, it continued to be published into the 21st century.

Nā Alexander McMinn, te kaiwhakaputa o te Rangitikei Advocate, i whakarewa te Manawatu Standard i te tau 1880 hei nūpepa whā whārangi mō ia rā, i runga i tana hiahia ki te whakatū nūpepa māna ake, ā, koinei hoki te nūpepa tuatahi i Pāmutana. I puta te putanga tuatahi i te 29 o Noema 1880, ā, i reira ētahi tuhinga nā John Ballance.

Nō te pikinga ake o ngā tāngata hoko i te nūpepa (i kīia kei te 1,500 i te tau 1881), nō te pakari haeretanga hoki o ngā hangarau, i runga i te whakamahinga o ngā mīhini tā ā-mamaoa, hei whakakapi i ngā mīhini tā ā-ringa, ka tīmataria he putanga mō te tāone, he putanga hoki mō te tuawhenua. Ka nui te tautohetohe o tēnei nūpepa ki tōna hoa tauwhāinga ki te Manawatu Times.

Nā ngā tuākana tēina, a Frederick rāua ko David Pirani i hoko i te tau 1891, ka hurihia hei nūpepa mō te ahiahi. Nā Martha Pirani, te hoawahine o Frederick, i tuhi tāpaetanga whakaaro mō te nūpepa. He āhua Rīpera Motuhake tōna anganga tōrangapū, ā, i tiria ki ngā rohe o Manawatū, o Heretaunga, o Taranaki. Ko tētahi take i painga ai ia, ko ōna pānui hoko kararehe. I wikitōria a Frederick i te tūru o Pāmutana i te pōtitanga o te tau 1893, ā, ka noho i taua tūru taea noatia te tukunga i tōna tūranga i runga i te māuiui i te tau 1902.

I hokona atu te Manawatu Standard ki a John Coombe rāua ko Norman Henry Nash i te tau 1903. I whakanuia e te Standard tōna Tiupiri Kōura i te tau 1930, ki tētahi putanga motuhake. Ahakoa ngā rerekētanga o te hunga pupuri i te nūpepa, ka whakaputaina tonutia taea noatia te rautau 21.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank Palmerston North City Library for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
Kei te whakamoemiti te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Palmerston North City Library mōna i āwhina i te whakamamatitanga o tēnei taitara.

Publication.Title: Manawatu Times
Publication.Description: The first issue of the Manawatu Times was published on 23 October 1875, the first newspaper in Palmerston North. Its founders, partners Joseph Poulter Leary and John Law Kirkbride, had established the Rangitikei Advocate 5 months earlier. It appeared in the evenings twice a week, though it did later become a morning publication, largely to facilitate its distribution in country areas. A weekly edition, the Manawatu Weekly Times, was published for 2 years in 1889-1891.

I puta tuatahi mai te Manawatu Times i te 23 o Oketopa 1875, koia hoki te nūpepa tuatahi o Pāmutana. Nā ōna kaiwhakatū nā Joseph Poulter Leary rāua ko John Law Kirkbride i whakarewa te Rangitikei Advocate e 5 marama ki muri. I puta i ngā ahiahi, he rua ahiahi i te wiki, engari ka huri hei nūpepa o te ata i roto i te wā, i runga i te whakaaro, mā reira e pai ai tōna tiringa ki ngā rohe o te tuawhenua. I puta he putanga ā wiki e kīia nei ko te Manawatu Weekly Times, mō te 2 tau i te tau 1889-1891.
Publication.Essay:
The first issue of the Manawatu Times was published on 23 October 1875, the first newspaper in Palmerston North. Its founders, partners Joseph Poulter Leary and John Law Kirkbride, had established the Rangitikei Advocate 5 months earlier. It appeared in the evenings twice a week, though it did later become a morning publication, largely to facilitate its distribution in country areas. A weekly edition, the Manawatu Weekly Times, was published for 2 years in 1889-1891.

The paper was bought by John Boulger Dungan, who maintained strained relations with the rival Manawatu Standard, to the extent that Standard editor Alexander McMinn brought a libel case against him. He ran it until his death, at which point George Warren Russell took it over from 1882-1884.

Purchased by Mr. W.H. Smith in 1884, he ran it until 1896. The Manawatu Daily Times Company was launched in 1915. Chairman Alfred Seifert had an association of 30 years with the Times until his death in 1945.

Publication continued until 1963.

I puta tuatahi mai te Manawatu Times i te 23 o Oketopa 1875, koia hoki te nūpepa tuatahi o Pāmutana. Nā ōna kaiwhakatū nā Joseph Poulter Leary rāua ko John Law Kirkbride i whakarewa te Rangitikei Advocate e 5 marama ki muri. I puta i ngā ahiahi, he rua ahiahi i te wiki, engari ka huri hei nūpepa o te ata i roto i te wā, i runga i te whakaaro, mā reira e pai ai tōna tiringa ki ngā rohe o te tuawhenua. I puta he putanga ā wiki e kīia nei ko te Manawatu Weekly Times, mō te 2 tau i te tau 1889-1891.

I hokona te nūpepa e John Boulger Dungan, ā, nāna hoki i whakapātari te riri ki te Manawatu Standard, me te aha, ka mauria ia ki te kōti e te ētita o taua nūpepa te Standard, e Alexander McMinn mō te ngautuarā. Ka whakahaeretia e ia taea noatia tōna matenga, ā, nā George Warren Russell i kawe mai i 1882-1884.

He mea hoko mai e Mr.W.H. Smith i te tau 1884, ā, ka whakahaeretia e ia taea noatia te tau 1896 I whakarewaina te Manawatu Daily Times Company i te tau 1915. Ka 30 tekau tau te noho a te timana a Alfred Seifert i roto i te kamupene o te Times taea noatia tōna matenga i te tau 1945.

I puta haere tonu te nūpepa tae noa mai ki te tau 1963.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank Palmerston North City Library for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
Kei te whakamoemiti te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Palmerston North City Library mōna i āwhina i te whakamamatitanga o tēnei taitara.

Publication.Title: Mt Benger Mail
Publication.Description: The Mt Benger Mail was one of a number of newspapers, mostly short-lived, which appeared in Central Otago during the gold rush era in the nineteenth century. John Weatherall began the Mt Benger Mail at Roxburgh in 1880. A brief item in the Bruce Herald of 30 April that year announced that the Mt Benger Mail was about to be published ‘at the low price of 3s per quarter’.

Ko te Mt Benger Mail tētahi o tērā huinga nūpepa i puta i te Awahuri i Ōtākou i te wā keri kōura i te rau tau tekau mā iwa. Ko te nuinga i ora mō te wā poto noa. Nā John Weatherall i whakarewa te Mt Benger Mail i Roxburgh i te tau 1880. I puta tētahi pūrongo poto i te Bruce Herald o te 30 Aperira i taua tau kua tata te puta o te Mt Benger Mail ‘mō te utu iti o te 3 herenga ia koata’.
Publication.Essay:
The Mt Benger Mail was one of a number of newspapers, mostly short-lived, which appeared in Central Otago during the gold rush era in the nineteenth century.

John Weatherall began the Mt Benger Mail at Roxburgh in 1880. A brief item in the Bruce Herald of 30 April that year announced that the Mt Benger Mail was about to be published ‘at the low price of 3s per quarter’. It also mentioned that John Weatherall was ‘for several years in the Tuapeka Times office’.

Gaining a reputation as a ‘rag-planter’ in the region, Weatherall had other forays into newspaper ownership – the Central Otago Leader for one – but was proprietor of the weekly Mt Benger Mail until 1896.

Apparently, Weatherall did not initially own the paper’s press, as the Tuapeka Times reported in November 1883 that John Thompson, auctioneer and Times shareholder, had sold him the plant of the Tuapeka Press (closed in 1869) and Mt Benger Mail for £47 10s (about $8,000 today). The same year Weatherall and journalist James Rowe re-launched the Tuapeka Press as a bi-weekly. It was short-lived, possibly coinciding with Weatherall and Rowe filing for bankruptcy – this remaining in force for about a year. After selling the Mt Benger Mail in 1896, Weatherall began the Tuapeka Recorder (the second paper of that name) in Lawrence and it appears to have survived four years.

After he sold the Mt Benger Mail to P J Dunne and William P Matthews, it was reported in the Otago Witness that the new owners had secured new plant, and proposed to remodel the paper. The paper noted: ‘Mr Dunne was for some time on the literary staff of the Waimea Plains Review, and also of the Tuapeka Times, and is regarded as a clever and capable journalist.’ In about 1900 he joined the West Coast Times as editor. He left in 1909, and, moving to the North Island, he subsequently edited the Levin Chronicle and Ohakune Times before dying, aged 55, in 1920.

William Matthews, who worked on the Otago Daily Times and Australian publications as well as the Tuapeka Times, was proprietor of the Mt Benger Mail when he died in January 1904 and the newspaper was purchased by Mr W Jack of Dunedin. At this time, the weekly, published on Fridays and considered ‘Independent Liberal’ in its politics, contained six, seven-column pages and was circulated widely in Central Otago. The newspaper’s premises contained, as the Cyclopedia of New Zealand reported in 1906: ‘an Albion press, Platen jobbing machine, and a good font of newspaper and jobbing type’.

In 1911 the newspaper was bought by the Tuapeka Times Co and printing shifted to Lawrence. After World War One, in 1919, W A Laloli bought the paper and it was again published in Roxburgh. It became a daily in 1920 for a period. It survived, with reduced frequency, until the early 1940s.

Ko te Mt Benger Mail tētahi o tērā huinga nūpepa i puta i te Awahuri i Ōtākou i te wā keri kōura i te rau tau tekau mā iwa. Ko te nuinga i ora mō te wā poto noa.

Nā John Weatherall i whakarewa te Mt Benger Mail i Roxburgh i te tau 1880. I puta tētahi pūrongo poto i te Bruce Herald o te 30 Aperira i taua tau kua tata te puta o te Mt Benger Mail ‘mō te utu iti o te 3 herenga ia koata’. I kī hoki ia i mahi a John Weatherall mō ētahi tau i te Tuapeka Times ’.

Ka hau tōna ingoa hei ‘rag-planter’ i taua rohe, nā te mea arā atu ngā kōkiri whakatū nūpepa a Weatherall – ko te Central Otago Leader tētahi – engari koia te kaihautū o te Mt Benger Mail taea noatia te tau 1896.

Te āhua nei, i te tuatahi kāore i a Weatherall te rangatiratanga o te perehi o te nūpepa, nā te mea i puta te pūrongo a te Tuapeka Times i te marama o Nōema 1883 nā John Thompson, kaihokohoko, kaipupuru hea hoki nō te Times, i hoko ngā mīhini o te Tuapeka Press (i kati rā i te tau 1869) me te Mt Benger Mail mō te £47 10s (ka rite ki te takiwā o te $8,000 i ngā moni o nāianei). I taua tau anō nā Weatherall rāua ko te kawe kōrero nei nā James Rowe i whakarewa anō te Tuapeka Press hei nūpepa e rua putanga i te wiki. He poto noa te oranga, i te wā tonu tēnei o te tuku o Weatherall rāua ko Rowe ki te kōti pēkerapu –ka whai mana tēnei mō te takiwā o te tau kotahi. I muri i te hoko i te Mt Benger Mail i te tau 1896, nā Weatherall i tīmata te Tuapeka Recorder (te nūpepa tuarua he pērā te ingoa i Lawrence ā, ka ora pea mō te whā tau.

I muri i tana hokonga i te Mt Benger Mail ki a P J Dunne rāua ko William P Matthews, i puta te pūrongo i te Otago Witness kua riro i ngā rangatira hou ētahi mīhini hou, me te whakaaro kia hoahoatia anō te nūpepa. I kī te nūpepa: ‘I mahi a Dunne hei mema o ngā kaituhi o te Waimea Plains Review, me te Tuapeka Times, e whakaarotia ana he kaituhi mātau, pakari hoki.' I te takiwā o te tau 1900 ka tūhono ia ki te West Coast Times hei etita. I wehe atu ia i te tau 1909, ā, i tana nekehanga ki te Ika ā-Māui, ka etitatia e ia te Levin Chronicle me te Ohakune Times i mua i tōna matenga, e 55 te pakeke, i te tau 1920.

Ko William Matthews, tētahi kaimahi i te Otago Daily Times me ētahi nūpepa i Ahitereiria, tae atu ki te Tuapeka Times, te kaihautū o te Mt Benger Mail i tōna matenga i te marama o Hānuere 1904 ā, hokona te nūpepa e W Jack o Ōtepoti. I tēnei wā i puta tēnei nūpepa ā-wiki i ia Paraire. I whakaarotia he ‘Independent Liberal’ ōna āhuatanga tōrangapū, ā, e ono ōna whārangi whitu-kōwae, i tiria whānuitia i Te Awahuri, me Ōtākou. Kei roto i te tari o te nūpepa ēnei āhuatanga, e ai ki te pūrongo o te Cyclopedia of New Zealand i te tau 1906: ‘he mīhini tā Albion, he mīhini hangahanga Platen, tētahi pūranga pepa nūpepa me te tini o ngā pū tā kupu’.

I te tau 1911 i hokona te nūpepa e te Tuapeka Times Co ā, ka nukuhia te tāngata ki Lawrence. I muri i te Pakanga tuatahi o Te Ao, i te tau 1919, nā W A Laloli te nūpepa i hoko, ā, ka puta anō i Roxburgh. Ka huri hei nūpepa ā-rā i te tau 1920 mō tētahi wā. Ka puta te ihu, engari ka āhua tīmutumutu taea noatia ngā tau tuatahi i muri i 1940.
Publication.Acknowledgement: This newspaper was digitised in partnership with the Central Lakes Trust .
I whakamamatitia tēnei niupepa i runga anō i te āwhina mai o ngā Central Lakes Trust .

Publication.Title: Mount Ida Chronicle
Publication.Description: The Mount Ida Chronicle and St Bathans Weekly News was one of the earliest goldfields newspapers to survive for a lengthy period. In May 1863, gold was discovered in the Hogburn Valley, on the Upper Taieri Plain 90 miles north-west of Dunedin, by a party of miners including the Parker brothers. The resulting township had various names – including Parker’s, Hogburn and Mount Ida – before settling on Naseby. The Mount Ida Chronicle was founded there in 1869 by Hugh Wilson who ran the paper with a succession of partners until his retirement in 1919.

Ko te Mount Ida Chronicle and St Bathans Weekly News tētahi o ngā nūpepa tuatahi o ngā keringa kōura kia ora mō te wā roa tonu. Nō te marama o Mei 1863, ka kitea tuatahitia te kōura ki te Hogburn Valley, i te Raorao Whakarunga o Taieri 90 maero ki te raki-mā-uru o Ōtepoti, e tētahi ope kaikeri kōura, tae atu ki ngā tuākana tēina Parker. He maha ngā ingoa rerekē o te tāone i tupu ake i reira – inā rā ko Parker’s, ko Hogburn me Mount Ida – ā, tatū rawa atu ki te ingoa o Naseby. I whakatūria te Mount Ida Chronicle i reira i 1869 e Hugh Wilson nāna i whakahaere te nūpepa me te tini o ngā hoa mahi taea noatia tōna hekenga i tōna tūnga i te tau 1919.
Publication.Essay:
The Mount Ida Chronicle and St Bathans Weekly News was one of the earliest goldfields newspapers to survive for a lengthy period. In May 1863, gold was discovered in the Hogburn Valley, on the Upper Taieri Plain 90 miles north-west of Dunedin, by a party of miners including the Parker brothers. The resulting township had various names – including Parker’s, Hogburn and Mount Ida – before settling on Naseby. The Mount Ida Chronicle was founded there in 1869 by Hugh Wilson who ran the paper with a succession of partners until his retirement in 1919.

The first partner was Henry Hertslet, a considerable landowner, whose involvement lasted only a year. Two years later Cecil de Lautour joined the paper as partner and editor, combining his editorial role with an increasing involvement in politics. In 1874, de Lautour was elected as one of the two members to represent the Mount Ida district on the Otago Provincial Council, remaining on it until its abolition in 1876. The same year he was returned as the member for Mt Ida in the House of Representatives, and won two subsequent elections in 1879 and 1881. Cecil de Lautour’s actual involvement with the newspaper ended when he left the district in 1879 and moved to Poverty Bay.

Wilson’s next partner, from 1883, was Mackay J S (Scobie) Mackenzie. A successful runholder, he was also an aspiring politician. After some years on the Maniototo County Council, Mackenzie stood against de Lautour at the 1881 election, challenging the incumbent’s right to represent Mt Ida when he lived hundreds of kilometres away in the North Island. As the Otago Witness reported in Mackenzie’s September 1901 obituary: ‘The contest which ensued had a sensational termination. Telegraphs were rarer in those days, and on the evening of the election it was concluded, in the absence of one or two outlying returns, that Mr Mackenzie was the member for Mount Ida. He was carried in triumph through the streets of Naseby, while his opponent left the town and travelled through the night to catch train and steamer for the north. Before daylight, however, a block vote for Mr de Lautour came in from the largest of the outlying places, and by a few votes the position was reversed.’

Scobie Mackenzie was elected to the House of Representatives in 1884, while de Lautour contested an Auckland seat unsuccessfully. Mackenzie was an accomplished journalist, writing regularly for the Mount Ida Chronicle and Australian newspapers. He served three terms as MP for Mount Ida and then held, from 1896-1899, a Dunedin seat. In 1896 his shares in the newspaper were sold to a relation-by-marriage, Alfred Dillon Bell, brother of Sir Francis Bell. John Reed took up the Bell interest in 1907 and ran the business following Wilson’s 1919 retirement until the newspaper’s 1926 sale and subsequent demise.

For much of its 57 years, the Mount Ida Chronicle was a weekly. Gold in the area was mined by hydraulic sluicing and the government built several miles of water races in 1875. Following this boost to the local mining industry, the newspaper appeared twice-weekly until 1899. Naseby was the commercial and local government centre of the Maniototo for the last 25 years of the 19th century and by 1880 one of the largest towns in the district, and claiming a population of about 4,000. As well as many hotels, it had the county council chambers, town hall, courthouse, warden’s office, district hospital, several churches and schools, Masonic hall, Athenaeum (library and reading room), and racecourse. However, by the early 1920s, gold mining was finished and, with the Central Otago railway bypassing the town, Ranfurly became the new district centre.

The Mount Ida Chronicle provided informed and contrasting political comment during the period Cecil de Lautour and Scobie Mackenzie were writing for it. Before the parliamentary party era, both were independents, but de Lautour was of a liberal and Mackenzie a more conservative persuasion. The paper also provided a detailed coverage of an important period in the country’s gold mining history and was a conscientious recorder of the social life of the Maniototo.

Ko te Mount Ida Chronicle and St Bathans Weekly News tētahi o ngā nūpepa tuatahi o ngā keringa kōura kia ora mō te wā roa tonu. Nō te marama o Mei 1863, ka kitea tuatahitia te kōura ki te Hogburn Valley, i te Raorao Whakarunga o Taieri 90 maero ki te raki-mā-uru o Ōtepoti, e tētahi ope kaikeri kōura, tae atu ki ngā tuākana tēina Parker. He maha ngā ingoa rerekē o te tāone i tupu ake i reira – inā rā ko Parker’s, ko Hogburn me Mount Ida – ā, tatū rawa atu ki te ingoa o Naseby. I whakatūria te Mount Ida Chronicle i reira i 1869 e Hugh Wilson nāna i whakahaere te nūpepa me te tini o ngā hoa mahi taea noatia tōna hekenga i tōna tūnga i te tau 1919.

Ko te hoa tuatahi ko Henry Hertslet, tētahi kaipupuri whenua nui, i noho ki reira mō te tau kotahi noa iho. E rua tau i muri mai ka tūhono mai a Cecil de Lautour hei hoa, hei kaiwhakatika, arā, ka tuia tahitia āna mahi whakatika ki āna kuhunga ki te ao tōrangapū i aua wā. I te tau 1874, ka pōtitia ko de Lautour hei mema i te taha o te mema tuarua i pōtitia mō te rohe o Mount Ida i te Kaunihera ā-Rohe o Ōtākou, ā, ka noho i reira tae noa ki tōna whakakorenga i 1876. I taua tau anō ka whakahokia ia hei mema mō te Whare Pāremata, ā, ka wikitōria i ngā pōtitanga e rua whai i muri i ngā tau 1879 me 1881. I mutu katoa te mahi a Cecil de Lautour i te nūpepa i tana wehenga atu i te rohe i 1879 me tana nukuhanga atu ki Tūranga-nui-a-Kiwa.

Ko te hoa hou o Wilson mai i 1883, ko Mackay J S (Scobie) Mackenzie. He kaiahuwhenua whai take, ā, he tangata hoki ia i wawata kia uru ki ngā mahi tōrangapū. I muri i ētahi tau i te Kaunihera ā-Rohe o Maniototo, ka tauwhāinga atu a Mackenzie ki a de Lautour i te pōtitanga o 1881 me tana wero ki te tika o te tangata i te tūnga hei kanohi mō Mt Ida, inā hoki, i te noho kē a de Lautour i te Ika-a-Māui e hia kiromita kē ki te tokerau. Tērā ngā pūrongo a te Otago Witness i roto i te poroporoaki ki a Mackenzie i te Hepetema 1901: ‘He whakamīharo te whakataetae i whai i muri. Kāore i tino nui ngā tarikarāwhe i aua tau, ā, i te pō o te rā pōtitanga i maharatia, ahakoa kāore anō kia tae mai ētahi o ngā huinga pōti o te tuawhenua, kua wikitōria a Mackenzie ā, koia te mema hou mō Mount Ida. Ka kawea haeretia ia i runga i te rekareka o ngā hoa, mā roto i ngā tiriti o Naseby, ā, ka wehe atu tana hoa tauwhāinga i te tāone, ka haere i te roanga o te pō kia āhei tana piki ki runga tereina, me te tima hoki, kia tae atu ia ki te Ika-a-Māui. Engari i mua i te awatea o muri mai, ka tae mai tētahi huinga pōti nui mō de Lautour mai i ētahi atu o ngā wāhi tino nui o te tuawhenua, me te aha, kua takahuri anō te kaute, kia eke ko de Lautour hei kanohi.’

I pōtitia a Scobie Mackenzie ki te Whare Pāremata i te tau 1884, ā, i whakataetae a de Lautour i tētahi tūru i Tāmaki-makau-rau, engari kāore i eke. He kaituhi ringa rehe a Mackenzie ā, he auau tonu tāna tuhi mō te Mount Ida Chronicle me ētahi nūpepa i Āhitereiria. E toru ana tūnga hei Mema Pāremata mō Mount Ida, ā, i puritia tētahi tūnga i Ōtepoti i 1896-1899. I te tau 1896 ka hokona ana hea i te nūpepa ki tētahi whanaunga pākūhā ki a Alfred Dillon Bell, hei teina tēnei ki a Sir Francis Bell. Nā John Reed i hāpai ngā hea o te whānau Bell i te tau 1907 me te whakahaere i te umanga i muri i te hekenga a Wilson i tana tūranga i te tau 1919 taea noatia te hokonga me te mutunga o te nūpepa i te tau 1926.

Mō te roanga atu o ōna tau 57 ka noho te Mount Ida Chronicle hei nūpepa ā-wiki. Ko te puhanga wai te tikanga keri kōura i taua rohe, ā, i hangā hoki e te kāwanatanga ētahi maero terenga wai i te tau 1875. I muri i tēnei whakapikinga i te ahumahi keri kōura ā-rohe, e rua rawa ngā putanga o te nūpepa i te wiki, tae noa mai ki 1899. Ko Naseby tonu te pūtahi o ngā mahi arumoni, kāwanatanga hoki o Maniototo i ngā tau whakamutunga 25 o te rau tau 19. Nō te taenga ki te tau 1880 ka eke hei tāone nui i waenga i ngā tāone o te rohe, ko tōna taupori kua piki ki te 4,000. Kua tū ōna hōtēra maha, tōna hōro tāone hoki, ōna tari kaunihera ā-takiwā, he whare kōti, he tari wātene, he hōhipera ā-rohe, ētahi whare karakia, kura hoki, he hōro Masonic, tētahi Athenaeum (he whare pukapuka, me tōna rūma pānui pukapuka) me te papa reihi hōiho. Ahakoa tēnei, kia tae ki ngā tau tuatahi i muri mai i 1920, kua mutu te mahi keri kōura, kua taha te rerewē o Central Otago i te tāone, ā, ka noho ko Ranfurly te pūtahi hou o te rohe.

Nā te nūpepa nei nā te Mount Ida Chronicle i hora ētahi whakapuaki whai whakaaro, whakamere hoki i te wā o āna kaituhi, a Cecil de Lautour rāua ko Scobie Mackenzie. I mua atu tēnei i ngā tau o ngā rōpū tōrangapū, nā reira he tangata tū takitahi tēnei tokorua. Heoi anō, he whakaaro ngāwari a de Lautour ā, he āhua mārō kē atu te tū a Mackenzie. He rawe ngā kohinga kōrero mō ngā āhuatanga o aua tau nunui o te keringa kōura i Aotearoa, ā, he pukumahi hoki te nūpepa ki te āta tuhi haere i ngā mahi, i ngā kōrero, i ngā huihuinga a ngā iwi o te rohe o Maniatoto i ōna rā.

Publication.Title: Northern Advocate
Publication.Title-alternate: Northern Advocate and General Advertiser, Northern Advocate and Whangarei County Gazette, Whangarei Comet and Northern Advertiser
Publication.Description: The Northern Advocate was launched in 1875 by George Edwin Alderton under the title Whangarei Comet and Northern Advertiser and contained a small section printed in Māori. In 1877 the title changed to the Northern Advocate and General Advertiser. The Advocate is still the daily newspaper in Whangarei.

Ka whakamānutia te Northern Advocate i te tau 1875 e George Erwin Alderton, ko tōna ingoa ko te Whangarei Comet and Northern Advertiser, kei roto tētahi wāhanga iti mō te Reo Māori. Nō te tau 1877 ka tīnia te ingoa ki te Northern Advocate and General Advertiser. He nūpepa ia-rā te Advocate ki tēnei rā i Whangārei.
