Ko APN New Zealand te kaipupuri i te manatārua mō te Northern Advocate. Ka āhei koe ki te tārua i ngā rawa whai-manatārua o tēnei nūpepa mō ngā take arumoni-kore i raro i tētahi raihana Creative Commons New Zealand BY-NC-SA . Kāore tēnei nūpepa i te wātea mō ngā take arumoni, mēna kāore anō a APN New Zealand kia whakaae. Mō ētahi tohutohu mō ngā rawa kua puta i te manatārua mai i tēnei nūpepa, tēnā titiro ki te Puka mō te Manatārua .
Publication.Essay:
The Northern Advocate was launched in 1875 by George Edwin Alderton under the title Whangarei Comet and Northern Advertiser. In 1877 the title changed to the Northern Advocate and General Advertiser.

As the title suggests, the Advocate was set up to voice the concerns of Northlanders. Its stated purpose was to redress "the real criminal injustice the northern settlements laboured under from the legislature of the colony".

The Advocate quickly established itself. Initially it was issued weekly. It had 12 pages and carried a small section printed in Māori. It probably started daily publication in 1902 in response to the setting up of another newspaper in Whangarei, the Northern Chronicle.

The Advocate had various rivals over the years. In 1891 there was the Kamo and Hikurangi Gazette which probably only lasted a year. A potentially serious competitor emerged in 1902 - the Northern Chronicle. The publisher of this paper was Francis Mander. Mander, the father of the author Jane Mander, was a local MP and businessman. However before the Chronicle got established, Mander acquired the Advocate and closed the Chronicle. For a short time in the 1900s there were two daily newspapers in Whangarei besides the Advocate. These were the Whangarei County Press (1905-1908?) and the Northern Mail (1908-1914?). Whangarei could not support three newspapers and The Press closed down almost immediately. The Mail and the Advocate enjoyed a lively rivalry until 1914 when the owners of the Mail acquired the Advocate. The new owners formed the Northern Advocate Co. and closed the Mail.

The Advocate is still the daily newspaper in Whangarei.

Ka whakamānutia te Northern Advocate i te tau 1875 e George Erwin Alderton, ko tōna ingoa ko te Whangarei Comet and Northern Advertiser, kei roto tētahi wāhanga iti mō te Reo Māori. Nō te tau 1877 ka tīnia te ingoa ki te Northern Advocate and General Advertiser. He nūpepa ia-rā te Advocate ki tēnei rā i Whangārei.

Ka whakamānutia te Northern Advocate i te tau 1875 e George Erwin Alderton, ko tōna ingoa ko te Whangarei Comet and Northern Advertiser. Nō te tau 1877 ka tīnia te ingoa ki te Northern Advocate and General Advertiser.

Kei te ingoa o te Advocate tōna kaupapa, arā, he reo mō ngā iwi o Te Taitokerau. Ko tōna kaupapa, he whakatika i 'te kino o te hara i te takakino a te rōpū hanga ture o te taiwhenua i ngā nohanga o Te Taitokerau.'

Ka tere te whakaū a te Advocate i a ia anō. I te tīmatanga he tā ia-wiki. 12 ōna whārangi, he wāhanga iti i te Reo Māori. Nō te tau 1902 pea tōna tānga ia-rā hei whakautu i te whakatūranga o tētahi nūpepa anō i Whangārei, te Northern Chronicle.

He tāwhai anō o te Advocate i ngā tau. I te tau 1891, ko te Kamo and Hikurangi Gazette he tau kotahi noa tōna tānga. He tāwhainga tūturu ka puta mai i te tau 1902, arā, te Northern Chronicle. Ko Francis Mander te kaitā o tēnei nūpepa. Ko Mander, te pāpā o te kaituhi Jane Mander, te Mema Pāremata o te rohe, he kaipakihi hoki. Ēngari nō mua noa o te whakaūtanga o te Chronicle, ka riro i a Mander te Advocate, ā, ka katia te Chronicle. Mō tētahi wā poto i ngā tau tuatahi atu i 1900 ka rua ngā nūpepa ia-rā i Whangārei tua atu o te Advocate. Koirā te Whangārei County Press (1905 ki te 1908?) me te Northern Mail (1908 ki te 1914?). Kāore i taea e Whangārei te tautoko i ngā nūpepa e toru, ka katia wawe te Press. He kaha te tāwhainga o te Mail me te Advocate tae noa ki te tau 1914, te wā i riro ai te Advocate i ngā rangatira o te Mail. Ka whakatūria e ngā rangatira hou te Northern Advocate Co., ka katia ai te Mail.

Ko te Advocate te nūpepa ia-rā o Whangārei tae noa ki tēnei wā.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank Whangarei Libraries for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
Kei te whakamoemiti te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Whangarei Libraries mōna i āwhina i te whakamamatitanga o tēnei taitara.

Publication.Title: Nelson Evening Mail
Publication.Description: The Nelson Evening Mail was the first daily newspaper published in Nelson. First published on 5 March 1866, it continues to be published today as the Nelson Mail.
Ko te Nelson Evening Mail te tuatahi o ngā nūpepa o ia rā kia whakaputaina i Whakatū. I tāngia tuatahitia i te 5 o Poutū-te-rangi 1866, kei te puta tonu mai i tēnei rā hei Nelson Mail.
Publication.Essay:
The Nelson Evening Mail was the first daily newspaper published in Nelson. The first issue came out on 5 March 1866. Robert Lucas, a printer who arrived in Nelson in 1859, started the paper. He had previously published two other, short-lived papers - the Nelson Advertiser (1860) and the Nelson Intelligence (1862).

At the time the Mail began publication there were already two existing newspapers in Nelson - the Examiner (1842-1873) and the Colonist (1857-1921). The Mail provided strong competition for them. It first forced the papers to go daily and then eventually observed their demise - the Examiner in 1873 and the Colonist in 1921.

Since then the Mail has been Nelson's only daily newspaper. The Lucas family managed the paper until 1993 when it was sold to INL and its name changed to the Nelson Mail.

Ko te Nelson Evening Mail te tuatahi o ngā nūpepa o ia rā kia tāngia i Whakatū. Ko tōna putanga tuatahi nō te 5 o Poutū-te-rangi 1866. Nā Robert Lucas, he kaitā i tae mai ki Whakatū i te tau 1859, nāna i tīmata. I mua noa ka rua anō āna tānga nūpepa kaore i mauroa, arā, te Nelson Advertiser (1860) me te Nelson Intelligence (1862).

Nō te tīmatatanga o te Mail, ka rua kē ngā nūpepa o Whakatū, arā, te Examiner (1842 -1873) me te Colonist (1857 - 1921). He kaha te whakataetae atu a te Mail. Nāna rāua i whakapōrearea kia puta ia rā, ka mutu ka kitea tō rāua raru - te Examiner i te tau 1873 me te Colonist i te tau 1921.

Mai taua wā ko te Mail anake te nūpepa o ia rā o Whakatū. Nā te whānau Lucas i whakahaere tae noa ki te tau 1993, te wā o te hokonga ki te kamupene INL, te ingoa hou hoki, arā, te Nelson Mail.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank Nelson Public Libraries and the Nelson Provincial Museum for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki Nelson Public Libraries me te Nelson Provincial Museum, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Publication.Description: The Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle was the first newspaper published in the South Island. It was established by Charles Elliott (1811-1876) in 1842, within a few weeks of the New Zealand Company settlers arriving in Nelson.

Ko te Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle te nūpepa tuatahi i tāhia ki roto i Te Waipounamu. I whakatūhia e Charles Elliot (1811-1876) i te tau 1842, i roto i ngā wiki i muri tonu mai i te taenga mai o ngā tāngata whai ki Whakatū.
Publication.Essay:
The Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle was the first newspaper published in the South Island. It was established by Charles Elliott (1811-1876) in 1842, within a few weeks of the New Zealand Company settlers arriving in Nelson.

The Examiner, like its contemporary in Wellington, the New Zealand Gazette, was founded with a loan from the New Zealand Company. And even though the loan was paid back within a few years and despite disavowals from Elliott, the paper was always regarded by many colonists as an organ of the Company. Certainly the Examiner expressed very similar views to the Company, particularly concerning representative government for the settlers and it was an unrelenting critic of the colonial administration in Auckland.

According to Thomas Hocken, the Examiner was “esteemed the best of all early New Zealand newspapers, and had eminent colonists as its editors and contributors”. These contributors included prominent politicians such as Alfred Domett, Francis Dillon Bell, Edward Stafford and William Fox.

Elliott himself was politically active, holding various offices in the provincial government of Nelson in the 1850’s and 1860’s.

Ultimately the Examiner was unable to compete with the two other Nelson papers, the Colonist and the Nelson Evening Mail. The Examiner was too closely aligned with the interests of the large run-holders in the Wairau, who included Charles Elliott and his brother James. The Colonist was established in 1857 to oppose these landed proprietors. The paper lost much of its support when the Wairau was incorporated into the neighbouring province of Marlborough in 1859.

The Examiner tried to compete by moving to daily publication in 1873 and setting up subsidiary publications. These included the Illustrated Examiner (1869), the Weekly Examiner (1873), Wakamarina Intelligencer (1874). None of these publications could be sustained and the paper folded in 1874.

Ko te Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle te nūpepa tuatahi i tāhia ki roto i Te Waipounamu. I whakatūhia e Charles Elliot (1811-1876) i te tau 1842, i roto i ngā wiki i muri tonu mai i te taenga mai o ngā tāngata whai ki Whakatū.

Pērā anō i tērā nūpepa o taua wā o Te Whanganui ā-Tara, te New Zealand Gazette, i tīmatahia mai i tētahi pūtea taurewa mai i te New Zealand Company. Ahakoa i ea te nama i roto i ngā tau tata me ngā whakahē a Galvin ki ō rātau whakaaro, e ai ki te nuinga o ngā tāngata taiwhenua he wāhanga kē te pepa nei nō te Kamupene. Ka mutu he tino ōrite ngā whakaaro o te Examiner ki ō te Kamupene, otirā mō te kāwanatanga ka noho hei māngai mō ngā tāngata whai, me tā rātau whakahē mutukore i ngā whakahaere taiwhenua i Tāmaki Makaurau.

E ai ki a Thomas Hocken, ko te Examiner “te nūpepa pai rawa atu o ngā nūpepa i tā tuatahihia ki roto o Aotearoa, me ngā tāngata taiwhenua tohunga i noho hei kaietita, hei kaituhi hoki”. Ko ētahi o ngā kaituhi nei ko ngā kaitōrangapū rongonui ko Alfred Domett, Francis Dillon Bell, Edward Stafford me William Fox.

He tangata tōrangapū hoki a Elliot, ā, nōhia e ia ngā momo tari i roto i te kāwanatanga ā-rohe o Whakatū i ngā tau 1850 me ngā tau 1860.

Heoi anō, kāre i kaha te Examiner ki te whakataetae atu ki ērā nūpepa e rua o Whakatū, te Colonist me te Nelson Evening Mail. He tata rawa te hono o te Examiner ki ngā hiahia a ngā kaipupuri i ngā rohenga whenua o Wairau, pēnei i a Charles Elliott me tana teina a James. I whakatūhia te Colonist i te tau 1857 hei whakahē i ēnei rangatira pupuri whenua. I haumate haere te tautoko mai i te nūpepa i te whakatōpūtanga o Wairau ki roto i te rohe takiwā o Marlborough i te tau 1859.

I whakahau te Examiner ki te whakataetae atu mā te tā putanga ia rangi i te tau 1873 me te tīmata i ētahi atu pānui i raro i tōna maru. Pēnei i te Illustrated Examiner (1869), me te Weekly Examiner (1873), Wakamarina Intellingencer (1874). Karekau tētahi o ēnei pānui i ora, whāia ka mutu te nūpepa nei i te tau 1874.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank the Nelson Provincial Museum for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Nelson Provincial Museum, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: North Otago Times
Publication.Description: The North Otago Times was first published on 25 February 1864 under the title Oamaru Times and Waitaki Reporter, as a weekly paper. In 1876 it began daily publication which continued until its demise in 1932.

Nō te 25 o Pēpuere o te tau 1864 te tānga tuatahi o te North Otago Times hei Oamaru Times and Waitaki Reporter, hei nūpepa ia-wiki. Nō te tau 1876 ka tīmata ai hei nūpepa ia-rā tae noa ki tōna hemo i te tau 1932.
Publication.Essay:
The North Otago Times was first published on 25 February 1864 under the title Oamaru Times and Waitaki Reporter.

The paper was founded by Frank Pinkerton. In 1870 William Jukes Steward was the registered owner and the title was changed to the North Otago Times. Initially the paper had been issued weekly, but in 1876 it began daily publication. This was in anticipation of the setting up of a rival daily, the Oamaru Mail. The rivalry was real but sporting - the Times printed the first issue of the Mail in 1876 when the Mail's equipment failed.

The Mail was started by William Jukes Steward, the local MP, who had previously owned the Times. Steward and some associates probably started the paper to provide a forum for their political views particularly those concerning the abolition of provincial government in New Zealand. Steward was in favour of abolition even though the Otago MPs tended to favour retention of the provincial system.

Initially the Mail struggled against the Times and the paper soon changed hands. However the Mail was given an unexpected boost in 1877, as a result of the new owner George Jones being tried by the House of Representatives for criminal libel for comments printed in the Mail. This was the first state trial ordered by Parliament. Jones was acquitted and gained a reputation as a champion of freedom of the press. The public showed its appreciation by patronising the Mail. Its circulation and advertising rose. The Mail ultimately triumphed over the Times - it is still published whereas the Times ceased in 1932.

Nō te 25 o Pēpuere o te tau 1864 te tānga tuatahi o te North Otago Times hei Oamaru Times and Waitaki Reporter.

Nā Frank Pinkerton te nūpepa nei i whakaū. Ko William Jukes Stteward te rangatira rēhita i te tau 1870, ā, ka tīnia te ingoa ki te North Otago Times. He tānga ia-wiki i te tuatahi, nō te tau 1876 ka tīmata ai te tānga ia-rā. He mea haukoti i te tūnga o te tāwhainga hou ia-rā, te Oamaru Mail. He tūturu te tāwhainga, engari he ngākaunui - nā te Times te putanga tuatahi o te Mail i tā i te pakarutanga o ngā mīhini tā a te Mail.

Nā William Jukes Steward te Mail i tīmata - nāna te Times i mua. Tērā pea, nā Steward, te Mema Pāremata mō te rohe, me ētahi hoa te pepa nei i whakaū hei whakapāho i ō rātou whakaaro tōrangapū, erangi rawa ia ko ērā whakaaro e pā ana ki te whakakorenga i te kāwanatanga porowini i Niu Tīreni. I te whakaae a Steward i te whakakorenga, he ahakoa te pai ake o ngā mema pāremata o Ōtākou kia noho tonu mai te kaupapa porowini.

I te tīmatanga ka raruraru te Mail i te Times, ā, kāore i roa ka hokona atu. Engari ka hikitia ohoreretia te Mail i te tau 1877, te take ko te hāmenetanga i tōna rangatira hou e te Whare Pāremata, mō te kupu whakakino nō āna whakaaro i tuhia i te Mail. Ko te whakawānga tuatahi tēnei nā te Pāremata i whakarite. I wetea a Jones, ka tupu tōna mana hei reo mō te rangatiratanga o ngā tūmomo nūpepa. Ka kitea te ngākaunui o te iwi whānui ki te hokonga i te Mail. Ka maha atu ngā kape tuku, ka tupu ake te pānuitanga hoko. Nāwai rā, ko te Mail i runga anō o te Times - kei te tāngia tonu, i katia te Times i te tau 1932.

Publication.Title: New Zealand Advertiser and Bay of Islands Gazette
Publication.Description: The New Zealand Advertiser is a significant New Zealand newspaper, which was published in Kororareka from June to December 1840 and ran for twenty-seven issues. It was New Zealand's second earliest newspaper and a forerunner to the Government Gazette. The Advertiser was effectively suppressed by the government for criticising its policy on land.

Ko te New Zealand Advertiser tētahi nūpepa hira tonu o Aotearoa, i tāngia ki Kororāreka mai i Pipiri ki Hakihea 1840, ā, i haere tonu mō ētahi tānga e rua tekau mā whitu. Koia te tuarua o ngā nūpepa o Aotearoa, ā, koia anō te mātārere o te Kāhiti a te Kāwanatanga (Government Gazette). I tāmia te Advertiser e te Kāwanatanga mō ana whakahē ki tōna kaupapa whenua.
Publication.Essay:
The New Zealand Advertiser is a significant New Zealand newspaper. It was New Zealand’s second earliest newspaper. It was a forerunner to the Government Gazette as it was used by the colonial administration to publish official notices. The Advertiser also was effectively suppressed by the government for criticising its policy on land.

The Advertiser was published in Kororareka from June to December 1840 and ran for twenty-seven issues. It was printed by G. A. Eager and edited by the Rev. Barzillai Quaife.

The paper owed its existence to the government who used it as their gazette. While this was its primary function the newspaper also represented settler opinion, particularly concerning land claims. On this issue Quaife was critical of the colonial administration.

The government responded by invoking anti-press laws instituted in New South Wales in 1827 (New Zealand, at this stage was subject to New South Wales law). The cost of complying with these laws was more than the paper could bear and it suspended publication in December 1840. It seems clear that this is what the government intended. The anti-press laws had hardly been enforced and compliance was required only after Quaife started criticising the government.

On 30 December 1840 the Government began publishing its own gazette. In the first issue it was claimed that the Advertiser was no longer being used for government notices because the newspaper had declined to publish them. This was greeted with disbelief by settlers, who found it hard to accept that the newspaper would turn down the very business that sustained it. The government copped much criticism for its actions from the New Zealand Gazette, New Zealand’s other newspaper at the time.

History repeated itself in 1842 when Quaife went on to edit another newspaper, the Bay of Islands Observer. He continued to criticise government policy on land and the government responded by effectively putting him out of business, although this time with threats of libel actions.

Ko te New Zealand Advertiser tētahi nūpepa hira tonu o Aotearoa. Ko ia te tuarua o ngā nūpepa o Aotearoa. Ko ia te mātārere o te Kāhiti a te Kāwanatanga (Government Gazette), i te mea i whakamahia ia e te kāwana hei pānui i āna pānuitanga. I tāmia te Advertiser e te kāwanatanga mō ana whakahē ki ngā kaupapa whenua a te kāwanatanga.

I tāngia te Advertiser ki Kororāreka mai i Pipiri ki Hakihea 1840, ā, i haere tonu mō ētahi tānga e rua tekau mā whitu. Nā G. A. Eager i tā, nā te Rev. Barzillai Quaife i whakatika.

Nā te mahi a te kāwanatanga i ora ai te nūpepa, ko ia tonu te whakamahia hei kāhiti mōna. Ahakoa ko tana mahi matua tēnei, hei kanohi hoki te nūpepa mō ngā whakaaro o ngā tāngata whai, ko te mea nui ngā whakaaro e pā ana ki ngā kerēme whenua. Ko ia anō te take i whakahē ai a Quaife i te kāwanatanga.

Ko te whakautu a te kāwanatanga he whakatara i ngā ture whawhai nūpepa kua whakaritea ki Niu Haute Wēra (New South Wales) i te tau 1827 (i raro tonu i te ture o Niu Haute Wēra a Aotearoa i tēnei wā). He nui atu i tā te nūpepa i āhei ki te waha te utu tautuku ki ēnei ture, ā, ka whakatārewatia te tānga o te nūpepa i Hakihea 1840. Kei te āhua mārama tonu koia tonu te tūmanako o te kāwanatanga. Kāhore noa iho tonu i uruhina ngā ture whawhai nūpepa, ēngari nō muri mai o te whakahēnga o Quaife i te kāwanatanga ka hiahiatia te tautukutanga ki aua ture.

I te 30 o Hakihea 1840 ka tīmatahia e te kāwanatanga te tānga o tōna ake kāhiti. Ka whakapuakina i roto i te tānga tuatahi, he whakakāhoretanga nō te nūpepa ki te pānui i ngā pānuitanga a te kāwanatanga te take kāhore te kāwanatanga i te whakamahi i te Advertiser. Tūtakina ana tēnei kōrero e ngā tāngata whai i runga i te whakaponokore, he uaua tonu tā rātou whakaae ka whakakāhoretia e te nūpepa te mahi nāna rawa ia i toko. He nui tonu te whakahēnga o te New Zealand Gazette, tērā atu nūpepa o Aotearoa i tērā wa, i hopua e te kāwanatanga mō āna mahi.

Tukuruatia te hītori i te tau 1842 i te whanatutanga o Quaife hei ētita mō tētahi atu nūpepa, mō te Bay of Islands Observer. Ka haere tonu āna whakahē i te kāwanatanga mō tana kaupapa whenua, ā, ko te whakautu a te kāwanatanga he katitanga i tana mahi whakaputa nūpepa, ahakoa i tēnei wā i ō rātou whakahaka ka whakapaetia e rātou te nūpepa mō ētahi kupu whakakino.

Publication.Title: New Zealand Colonist and Port Nicholson Advertiser
Publication.Description: The New Zealand Colonist and Port Nicholson Advertiser was first published in Wellington bi-weekly on the 2 August 1842 and continued until the 3 August 1843. The paper was originally produced as a counter to the New Zealand Gazette, which began publication in 1839 and was a staunch advocate of the New Zealand Company.

Ko te New Zealand Colonist and Port Nicholson Advertiser i whakaputa tuatahitia ki Pōneke i ngā rā e rua ia wiki i te 2 o Here-turi-kōkā 1842, ā, ka haere tonu ki te 3 o Here-turi-kōkā 1843. I whakaputahia te nūpepa nei hei whakataetae ki te New Zealand Gazette i tīmata ai te whakaputa i te tau 1839 i tū hoki hei tino kaitautoko o te Kamupene o Niu Tīreni (New Zealand Company).
Publication.Essay:
The New Zealand Colonist and Port Nicholson Advertiser illustrates the factionalism and divergent interests of the early Wellington colonial community. The newspaper was published to counter the New Zealand Company's New Zealand Gazette.

The Gazette had been established in August 1839 by Samuel Revans who was a staunch friend and advocate of the Company. The Gazette's editorial policy was extremely pro-Company. Revans believed that serving the interests of the Company would also serve the interests of the settlement and the settlers. To this end he deliberately censored anti-Company opinions. His championing of the Company became increasingly unpopular as the settlers' and the Company's views and interests diverged.

The Gazette's factional and increasingly anti-settler position eventually led to a group of fifty local merchants and landowners establishing a rival paper, the New Zealand Colonist. It started in August 1842 and was published bi-weekly.

As the Colonist was intended to be opposition for the Gazette it took a strongly anti-Gazette and pro-settler editorial position. However the Colonist struggled financially from the beginning and its position was made more difficult by lack of support from the Company, which was one of the main sources of revenue in the fledgling colony.

The Colonist stopped publication exactly a year after it began, mainly due to poor sales combined with a ruinous fire in its Lambton Quay office. Patrick Day (The Making of the New Zealand Press, 1990) says that "the failure of the small settlement to support a second newspaper against the established Gazette deprived Wellington of an able and largely disinterested voice."

Revans soon fell out with the Company and, growing bored with the venture, closed the New Zealand Gazette in September 1844.

E whakaatu ana te New Zealand Colonist me te Port Nicholson Advertiser i ngā wehewehenga me ngā rerekētanga o te hapori koroni o Pōneke. I whakaputahia te nūpepa hei whakataetae i te New Zealand Gazette, te nūpepa a te Kamupene o Niu Tīreni (New Zealand Company).

I tīmatahia te Gazette i Here-turi-kōkā o te tau 1839 e Samuel Revans, he tino hoa kaitautoko o te Kamupene o Niu Tīreni. He tino tautoko tā te kaupapa ētita ki taua Kamupene. I tino whakapono a Revans mā te whai atu i ngā hiahia a te Kamupene e whai atu ai hoki i ngā hiahia o te tāone hōu me Hōpara i ngā pānuitangata whai. Mai i tēnei ka aukatihia e ia ngā whakaaro whakahē ki te Kamupene. Nā tana tohe ki te whakahau tonu i te Kamupene i piki ai te whakahē mai i te wehenga o ngā whakaaro me ngā hiahia o Hōpara i ngā pānuitangata whai me ērā o te Kamupene.

Nā te wehewehe me te pikinga ake o ngā whakahē ki Hōpara i ngā pānuitangata whai i huri ai tētahi rōpū kaihoko, kaipupuri whenua, rima tekau te tokomaha, ki te whakatū i tētahi nūpepa whakataetae, arā, ko te New Zealand Colonist. I tīmata i Here-turi-kōkā o te tau 1842, ā, i whakaputahia hoki i ngā rā e rua ia wiki.

Nā te mea i whakaritea te Colonist hei nūpepa mautohe ki te Gazette ka huri ki te whakahē i te Gazette me te tautoko i Hōpara i ngā pānuitangata whai. ēngari he uaua te tīmatanga o te wāhanga pūtea o te Colonist, ā, ka tino pakeke ake hoki tōna tūnga nā te mea kāore i tautokohia e te Kamupene. Ko te Kamupene tētahi tino pūtake o ngā pūtea ki roto i te tāone hōu nei.

I mutu ake te whakaputa a te Colonist ki roto i te tau kotahi mai i te tīmatanga nā te koretake o te tauhoko me te toronga o tōna tari i Lambton Quay i te ahi. E kī ana te kaituhi a Patrick Day (The Making of the New Zealand Press, 1990) "nā te kore o te tāone e tautoko i tētahi nūpepa tuarua hei whakataetae atu ki te Gazette i aukatihia ai te tāone o Pōneke i tētahi reo whaikiko, māia hoki".

Kīhai i roa ka wehe mai a Revans i te Kamupene, ā, nā tana hōhā ki tēnei pakihi i katia ai te New Zealand Gazette i Mahuru o te tau 1844.

Publication.Title: New Zealand Spectator and Cook's Strait Guardian
Publication.Description: The New Zealand Spectator was the first Wellington newspaper to last for any length of time. It began weekly publication in October 1844, several weeks after the demise of the New Zealand Gazette, Wellington’s and New Zealand’s first newspaper.

Ko te New Zealand Spectator te nūpepa tuatahi o Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara i āhua roa tōna oranga. I tīmata te tānga ā-wiki i a Whiringa-ā-nuku 1844, i ētahi wiki maha tonu i muri mai o te matenga o te New Zealand Gazette, tō Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara me tō Niu Tireni nūpepa tuatahi.
Publication.Essay:
The New Zealand Spectator was the first Wellington newspaper to last for any length of time. It began weekly publication in October 1844, several weeks after the demise of the New Zealand Gazette, Wellington’s and New Zealand’s first newspaper.

The Spectator was set up by a committee of local settlers to fill the gap left by the Gazette and to provide an alternative to it. The Gazette, a New Zealand company newspaper under the editorship of Samuel Revans, had been so vociferous in its attacks on the colonial administration that many settlers wanted a newspaper that was more temperate. However the Spectator soon found itself embroiled in conflict, when the paper’s printers published an item from Revans that was clearly an attack on local lawyer Daniel Wakefield (younger brother of Edward Gibbon Wakefield). The publishers dismissed the printers who responded by setting up a rival newspaper, the Wellington Independent. The Spectator immediately tried to put the Independent out of business by taking back the printing plant that they were using. The Independent got its own equipment and was back in business four months later. The Spectator and the Independent warred continually for years, advocating for opposing parties in local, provincial and national politics.

From 1845 to 1858 the Spectator was published in Manners Street at the printing works of Robert Stokes (c.1810-80). Stokes was a member of the committee that set up the Spectator. He had originally come to Wellington in 1840 as a New Zealand Company surveyor. He was involved for many years in provincial and national politics, including being a member of Legislative Council from 1862 to 1879.

Stokes was the virtual owner of the paper from about 1850. Under his management the Spectator was the only paper, other than the New Zealander, that supported George Grey and the colonial administration. Many settlers saw Stoke’s support for Grey as grovelling, motivated by a desire to ingratiate himself with the Colonial Office. For this he was described as a "scribbly toady".

The Spectator always struggled to keep afloat and in 1865 it allowed itself to be taken over by its rival the Independent.

Ko te New Zealand Spectator te nūpepa tuatahi o Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara i āhua roa tōna oranga. I tīmata te tānga ā-wiki i a Whiringa-ā-nuku 1844, i ētahi wiki maha tonu i muri mai o te matenga o te New Zealand Gazette, tō Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara me tō Niu Tireni nūpepa tuatahi.

I whakatūria te Spectator e tētahi komiti o te hunga whai whenua, hei whakakapi i te āputa i mahue i te Gazette, hei nūpepa rerekē hoki. Ko te Gazette ia, he nūpepa a te Kamupene o Niu Tireni i raro i te takatānga o Samuel Revans, kua tino keakea rawa āna huaki ki te kāwanatanga tuawhenua, ā, ko te mutunga iho, kua pīrangi kē te maha o te hunga whai whenua i tētahi nūpepa āhua ngāwari kē ake. Heoi, kāore i roa kua puta kē atu te Spectator ki te mura o te ahi, nā te pānuitanga a āna kaiwhakatā i tētahi tuhinga a Revans, he mea i kitea noatia he huaki ki te rōia wā kāinga, ki a Daniel Wakefield (te teina o Edward Gibbon Wakefield). Ka panaia ngā kaiwhakatā e ngā kaiwhakaputa, nā, ko te urupare a ēnei ko te whakatū i tētahi nūpepa tāwhai, te Wellington Independent. I whakamātau wawe tonu te Spectator ki te whakamate i te Independent mā te tangonga i ngā mīhini whakatā i te whakamahia e rātou. Ka hokona e te Independent āna ake mīhini, ā, i te mahi anō e whā marama i muri mai. Ka whawhai tonu te Spectator me te Independent mō ētahi tau maha, me te tautoko i ngā rōpū ātete mō ngā take tōrangapū ā-kāinga, ā-rohe, ā-motu hoki.

Mai i te tau 1845 ki te tau 1858 i whakaputaina te Spectator i te Tiriti o Manners, i te umanga whakatā a Robert Stokes (1810 pea ki te 1880). Ko Stokes tētahi mema o te komiti nāna te Spectator i whakatū. I tae tuatahi mai ia ki Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara i te tau 1840 hei kairūri whenua mō te Kamupene o Niu Tireni. He maha ngā tau i whai wāhi ia ki ngā mahi tōrangapū ā-rohe, ā-motu hoki, tae noa ki tana tūnga hei mema o te Whare Pāremata mai i te tau 1862 ki te tau 1879.

Ko Stokes te rangatira matua o te nūpepa mai i te takiwā o te tau 1850. I raro i tāna whakahaere, ko te Spectator anake te nūpepa, hāunga te New Zealander, i tautoko i a George Grey rātou ko te kāwanatanga tuawhenua. I kitea te tautoko a Stokes e te maha noa o te hunga whai whenua hei koropiko whakapatipati, he mea whakaoho e tana tāwhai kia āta manakohia e te Tari Tuawhenua. Nā reira i whakaahuatia ia hei "kaieneene tuhituhi kōkau".

I ngā wā katoa i ngana te Spectator kia rewa tonu ana mahi, nāwai, i te tau 1865 ka whakaae kia taumanutia e tōna hoa tāwhai, e te Independent.

Publication.Title: Free Lance
Publication.Description: The Free Lance was one of New Zealand’s most popular weekly, pictorial newspapers. It was first published in Wellington in 1900 by Geddis and Blomfield as a spin-off from their successful Auckland weekly, the NZ Observer and Free Lance. The publishers split the title, with the Auckland paper becoming the NZ Observer and the Wellington paper taking the name Free Lance.

Ko te Free Lance tētahi o ō Niu Tireni nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua i tino kaingākautia. I whakaputa tuatahitia e Geddis rāua ko Blomfield i Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara i te tau 1900, hei wāhanga motuhake o tā rāua nūpepa ā-wiki angitu o Tāmaki-makaurau, te NZ Observer and Free Lance. Ka wehea te ingoa e ngā kaiwhakaputa, ko tō te Tāmaki-makaurau nūpepa e noho ana ko te NZ Observer, me tō Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara nūpepa e tango ana i te ingoa o Free Lance.
Publication.Essay:
The Free Lance was one of New Zealand’s most popular weekly, pictorial newspapers. It was first published in Wellington in 1900 by Geddis and Blomfield as a spin-off from their successful Auckland weekly, the NZ Observer and Free Lance. The publishers split the title, with the Auckland paper becoming the NZ Observer and the Wellington paper taking the name Free Lance.

Despite its initial association with the Observer, the Free Lance soon developed as a separate publication with the Geddis family concentrating on the Free Lance and Blomfield the Observer. The editor James McRobert Geddis (1856-1935) later became sole proprietor and in 1920 the Geddis family formed a private company to run the paper. The Geddis family were involved with the management of the Free Lance until it was incorporated into the New Zealand Weekly News in 1960. Its demise left the Weekly News as the last pictorial weekly in New Zealand.

The Free Lance was a typical weekly; conservative and mainstream with much coverage given to royalty, New Zealand scenery, high society and sport. It was noted for its political cartoons. It carried the work of some of the country’s top cartoonists including John Gilmour, Gordon Minhinnick, Tom Ellis (Tom Glover), E.F. Hiscocks and Stuart Peterson. The Free Lance was fortunate to begin publishing at the same time as there was a flowering of local cartooning talent. The Free Lance not only benefited from this but also played a significant role in fostering this talent and pictorial journalism in general.

Ko te Free Lance tētahi o ō Niu Tireni nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua i tino kaingākautia. I whakaputa tuatahitia e Geddis rāua ko Blomfield i Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara i te tau 1900, hei wāhanga motuhake o tā rāua nūpepa ā-wiki angitu o Tāmaki-makaurau, te NZ Observer and Free Lance. Ka wehea te ingoa e ngā kaiwhakaputa, ko tō te Tāmaki-makaurau nūpepa e noho ana ko te NZ Observer, me tō Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara nūpepa e tango ana i te ingoa o Free Lance.

Ahakoa tōna whakahoatanga ki te Observer i te tīmatanga, kāore i roa kua whanake te Free Lance hei pānuitanga wehe kē me te whānau o ngā Geddis e aro kē ana ki te Free Lance, ko Blomfield ia ki te Observer. Nō muri mai ka noho tonu nō tōna takatā, nō James McRobert Geddis (1856-1935) anake te nūpepa, ā, i te tau 1920 ka whakatūria e te whānau o ngā Geddis he kamupene tūmataiti hei whakahaere i te nūpepa. I whai wāhi tonu te whānau o ngā Geddis ki te whakahaerenga o te Free Lance tae noa ki tōna komokomonga ki te New Zealand Weekly News i te tau 1960. I tōna matenga ka noho ko te Weekly News anake te nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua i Aotearoa.

He tānga tikanga noa te nūpepa ā-wiki, te Free Lance; he haratau ana kōrero, he mea rīroa me te nui o āna kōrero e aro atu ana ki ngā ariki taipuru o Ingarangi, ki ngā tirohanga o Niu Tireni, ki te hunga rangatira o te pāpori, ki ngā hākinakina anō hoki. I mōhiotia whānuitia mō āna waituhi whakakata tōrangapū. Whakaatu hoki ai i ngā mahi a ētahi kaitito waituhi whakakata pai rawa o te whenua, tae atu ki a John Gilmour, ki a Gordon Minhinnick, ki a Tom Ellis (Tom Glover), ki a E.F. Hiscocks, me Stuart Peterson. I waimarie tonu te Free Lance ki te tīmata i tana mahi whakaputa i te wā tonu i puāwai mai ai te pūmanawa waituhi whakakata i te wā kāinga. Kīhai te Free Lance i whaihua noa iho i tēnei āhuatanga, engari i hiranga tonu ana mahi whakatairangi i ēnei pūmanawa me te whakatairangi kapikapi i te mahi whakaputa hautaka whai whakaahua.

Publication.Title: New Zealand Gazette and Wellington Spectator
Publication.Title-alternate: New Zealand Gazette, New Zealand Gazette and Britannia Spectator, Wellington Spectator, Britannia Spectator
Publication.Description: The New Zealand Gazette was New Zealand’s first newspaper. The Gazette was first published in London under the auspices of the New Zealand Company on 21 August 1839. A revised edition was issued a fortnight later. The second issue was published on 18 April 1840 in Wellington making it the first newspaper printed in New Zealand.

Ko te New Zealand Gazette te nūpepa tuatahi ki Aotearoa. I tā tuatahitia te Gazette ki Rānana i raro i te mana o te Kamupene o Niu Tīreni i te 21 o Here-turi-kōkā 1839. I whakaputahia he putanga whakahoua rua wiki ki muri. Ko te putanga tuarua i tāhia i te 18 o Paenga-whāwha 1840 ki Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara, ā, koia te nūpepa tuatahi i tāhia ki Aotearoa.
Publication.Essay:
The New Zealand Gazette was New Zealand’s first newspaper. The Gazette was first published in London under the auspices of the New Zealand Company on 21 August 1839. A revised edition was issued a fortnight later. The second issue was published on 18 April 1840 in Wellington, making it the first newspaper printed in New Zealand.

The Gazette changed title several times in 1840. In August it added the words 'and Britannia spectator'; Britannia was the proposed name for Wellington. In November it changed Britannia to Wellington.

The paper was initially owned and edited by Samuel Revans but it was always perceived as the mouthpiece of the New Zealand Company. It supported the Company in its incessant conflict with the colonial administration in Auckland. The vigour with which the Gazette did battle with the enemies of the Company alienated many of the public and in 1842 led settlers in Wellington to start a rival newspaper, the New Zealand Colonist and Port Nicholson Advertiser.

The Gazette expired quietly in September 1844. The printers of the Gazette were employed by the New Zealand Spectator and Cook’s Strait Guardian which began a few weeks later.

Ko te New Zealand Gazette te nūpepa tuatahi ki Aotearoa. I tā tuatahitia te Gazette ki Rānana i raro i te mana o te Kamupene o Niu Tīreni i te 21 o Here-turi-kōkā 1839. I whakaputahia he putanga whakahoua rua wiki ki muri. Ko te putanga tuarua i tāhia i te 18 o Paenga-whāwha 1840 ki Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara, ā, koia te nūpepa tuatahi i tāhia ki Aotearoa.

He maha ngā huringa o te ingoa o te Gazette i te tau 1840. I te marama o Here-turi-kōkā i tāpirihia mai te ingoa ‘and Britannia Spectator’; ko ‘Britannia’ te ingoa i whakaarohia mō Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara. I Whiringa-ā-rangi ka huri te kupu ‘Britannia’ ki ‘Wellington’.

I te tuatahi nā Samuel Revans te nūpepa, ā, ko ia te etita hoki, engari e whakapaehia ana koinei te waha kōrero mō te Kamupene o Niu Tīreni. Nāna i tautoko i te Kamupene i ana raruraru me ngā kaiwhakahaere taiwhenua i Tāmaki-makau-rau. Nā te kaha o tana whawhai me ngā hoariri o te Kamupene, ka whakakairirihia e te iwi whānui, ā, nā tēnei i te tau 1842 ka tīmatahia e ngā tauiwi he nūpepa hou i Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara, arā, te New Zealand Colonist and Port Nicholson Advertiser.

I taumutu te Gazette i te marama o Mahuru 1844. Nō ngā wiki i muri mai i tīmata te New Zealand Spectator and Cook’s Strait Guardian, ā, i whaimahi ai ngā kaitā o te Gazette i tēnei nūpepa hou.

Publication.Description: In 1863, William Chisholm Wilson, an Auckland printer and businessman, withdrew from his partnership in the influential New Zealander to start a rival daily, the New Zealand Herald. The new daily had a clear editorial policy – a more constructive relationship between the North and South Islands and a combative response to what it termed ‘the native rebellion’ – but Wilson’s main motivation was commercial, seeing a business opportunity as Auckland’s population grew rapidly.

He kaitā pukapuka, he tangata kaipakihi a William Chisholm Wilson. Nō te tau 1863 ka wehe atu ia i tōna pātuitanga i te niupepa te New Zealander, tētahi pepa whai mana, kia pai ai tana tīmata i te Hērara o Aotearoa, arā, te New Zealand Herald. He mārama tonu tāna kaupapa-here mō ana tuhituhi - kia paiheretia ngā moutere e rua, Te Ika-a-Māui me te Waipounamu, kia tika ai ngā mahi. Tētahi atu take, kia kaha te pakanga a te taha Pākehā ki te Māori, arā, e ai ki Te Hērara, ko te 'native rebellion’ tērā o tērā wā - engari ko te whāinga matua o Wilson he arumoni kē, ki tāna i matapae ai, tērā te hua o te moni i te pikinga o te taupori o Tāmaki-makau-rau i roto i ngā tau.

Publication.Essay:
In 1863, William Chisholm Wilson, an Auckland printer and businessman, withdrew from his partnership in the influential New Zealander to start a rival daily, the New Zealand Herald. The new daily had a clear editorial policy – a more constructive relationship between the North and South Islands and a combative response to what it termed ‘the native rebellion’ – but Wilson’s main motivation was commercial, seeing a business opportunity as Auckland’s population grew rapidly.

Although the New Zealander closed in 1866, the Daily Southern Cross provided competition for a number of years, and particularly when Julius Vogel acquired a majority shareholding in 1868. In 1876, Alfred Horton, a journalist and printer by training, sold his interest in the Thames Advertiser and bought Vogel’s then-ailing Daily Southern Cross. Shortly afterwards William Wilson died and the next year Horton and Wilson’s two sons merged their interests - the stronger mastheads surviving. The New Zealand Herald absorbed the Daily Southern Cross and its Weekly News incorporated the Weekly Herald.

By the late 1870s the Auckland newspaper scene was dominated by the New Zealand Herald, in the morning, and the Auckland Evening Star (later Auckland Star) at night. The New Zealand Herald was consistently conservative; the Evening Star supported the liberal political movement that was beginning to gain ground.

Alfred Horton’s interest in fast-changing newspaper technology led to Wilson and Horton’s installation of the country’s first rotary press at the New Zealand Herald in 1883. This was followed by a web machine in 1887 and linotypes in 1898. It was also the first local newspaper, in 1909, to run classified advertisements, with products and services sorted in categories.

Horton also played a part in the founding of the NZ Press Association in 1878, which began to share local news among newspaper members and to channel news received from overseas. A year later he assisted in resolving problems with a rival news agency that led to the two joining forces as the United Press Association. The name changed back again to New Zealand Press Association in 1942.

For decades the New Zealand Herald changed little in its appearance and sober, right-of-centre editorial stance; this was epitomised for half a century by the generally conservative cartoons of Gordon Minhinnick. The sobriquet ‘Granny Herald’ was part affection, part frustration.

The New Zealand Herald became a public company in 1925, but a majority shareholding was retained, along with all the directorships, by the Wilson and Horton families. In 1996 the Dublin-based Independent News & Media Group bought the Horton family’s shareholding. The paper is now owned by Australian Provincial Newspapers (APN), a subsidiary of Independent News & Media.

He kaitā pukapuka, he tangata kaipakihi a William Chisholm Wilson. Nō te tau 1863 ka wehe atu ia i tōna pātuitanga i te niupepa te New Zealander, tētahi pepa whai mana, kia pai ai tana tīmata i te Hērara o Aotearoa, arā, te New Zealand Herald. He mārama tonu tāna kaupapa-here mō ana tuhituhi - kia paiheretia ngā moutere e rua, Te Ika-a-Māui me te Waipounamu, kia tika ai ngā mahi. Tētahi atu take, kia kaha te pakanga a te taha Pākehā ki te Māori, arā, e ai ki Te Hērara, ko te 'native rebellion’ tērā o tērā wā - engari ko te whāinga matua o Wilson he arumoni kē, ki tāna i matapae ai, tērā te hua o te moni i te pikinga o te taupori o Tāmaki-makau-rau i roto i ngā tau.

Ahakoa i kati te New Zealander i te tau 1866, ka noho ko te Daily Southern Cross hei hoa whakataetae mō ētahi tau, otirā i tino pērā i te hokonga a Julius Vogel i te nuinga o ngā hea i te tau 1868. Nō te tau 1876, ka hoko a Alfred Horton i ana pānga i te Thames Advertiser. He kaikawe kōrero, he kaitā pukapuka a Horton. I muri ka hokona e ia te Daily Southern Cross a Vogel, i te hē haere ngā pūtea o taua pepa i taua wā. Kāore i roa i muri mai ka mate a William Wilson, ā, nō te tau o muri mai ka haumi ngā tama e rua a Horton rāua ko Wilson i ā rāua pānga - ka puritia kia ora ko ngā upoko niupepa pakari anake. Ka horomia te Daily Southern Cross e te New Zealand Herald, ka horomia te Weekly Herald e te Weekly News.

Nō te mutunga o ngā tau mai i 1870, ka noho ko te niupepa nui ko te New Zealand Herald, i ngā ata, ā, hei ngā ahiahi ko te Auckland Evening Star (nō muri ka kīa ko te Auckland Star). He reo pupuri tikanga i ngā wā katoa te New Zealand Herald, ā, nā te Evening Star i tautoko te kōkiri tōrangapū kia whakangāwaritia ngā take me ngā āhuatanga katoa.

Nā runga i ngā āhuatanga hangarau huri hohoro a Alfred Horton, ka whakaurua te mīhini tā hurihuri tuatahi e Wilson rāua ko Horton i te New Zealand Herald i 1883. Nō muri mai ko te mihini tukutuku o 1887, me te mīhini tā rārangi i te tau 1898. I 1909 koia hoki te niupepa ā-rohe tuatahi kia whakaputa i ngā pānui hokohoko, i wehea ai ngā hua hoko me ngā ratonga, tēnā, tēnā, ki tōna karangatanga, ki tōna karangatanga.

I whai wāhi anō hoki a Horton ki te whakatūranga o te NZ Press Association i te tau 1878, i tīmata ai te tiritiri i ngā rongo kōrero huri noa i ngā mema niupepa, me te whāngai mai i ngā pitopito kōrero mai i tāwāhi. I te tau i muri mai ka āwhina ia ki te whakatau i ngā raruraru ki tētahi tari tauwhāinga, i tūhono ai ngā mahi a ngā whakahaere e rua i raro i te United Press Association. Ka hoki anō te ingoa ki te New Zealand Press Association i te tau 1942.

Kāore i rerekē te āhuatanga o te New Zealand Herald i te takanga o te hia ngahuru tau, mau tonu tōna āhua whakakaumātua, ōna whakaaro tū-ki-matau. Ko te whakatinanatanga o tēnei ko ngā pakiwaituhi pupuri tikanga a Gordon Minhinnick. Ko te ingoa whakawai ko 'Kui Hērara', he mihi tētahi wāhi o taua ingoa, he hōhā tētahi.

Ka huri te New Zealand Herald hei kamupene tūmatanui i te tau 1925, engari i puritia te nuinga o ngā hea e ngā whānau Wilson me Horton, tae atu ki ngā tūru kaiwhakahaere katoa. Nō te tau 1996 ka hokona e te Independent News & Media Group, nō Paraini i Airani, ngā hea o te whānau Horton. Ko te rangatira o nāianei o taua niupepa ko Australian Provincial Newspapers (APN), he pekanga nā Independent News & Media.
