Publication.Title: New Zealand Illustrated Magazine
Publication.Description: The Illustrated Magazine was a monthly, and was published in Auckland from 1899 to 1905. It carried contributions from most of the top New Zealand writers of the day including Apirana Ngata, Jane Mander, James Cowan and Elsdon Best. It featured poetry, short stories and articles and was heavily illustrated by the likes of Frances Hodgkins and Kennaway Henderson.

I whakaputa ā-maramatia ai te Illustrated Magazine i Tāmaki-makaurau mai i te tau 1899 ki te tau 1905. I kawe hoki i ngā takohanga tuhituhi a ngā kaituhi rangatira o Aotearoa o te wā, tae atu ki a Apirana Ngata, ki a Jane Mander, ki a James Cowan me Elsdon Best. I whakaaturia hoki te whiti, te pūrākau poto me te tuhinga whakamārama, ā, i whakaahuatia nuitia e ngā momo tāngata pērā me Frances Hodgkins, me Kennaway Henderson hoki.
Publication.Essay:
In the 1880s and 1890s some New Zealand publishers thought that there was a market for popular periodicals with a strong local focus. A number of titles, including Zealandia (1889), Citizen (1895), Critic (1899), were published in various cities. None of them met with much success or lasted for any length of time. The most significant of these parochial periodicals was the New Zealand Illustrated Magazine.

The Illustrated Magazine was a monthly, and was published in Auckland from 1899 to 1905. It carried contributions from most of the top New Zealand writers of the day including Apirana Ngata, Jane Mander, James Cowan and Elsdon Best. It featured poetry, short stories and articles and was heavily illustrated by the likes of Frances Hodgkins and Kennaway Henderson.

The Illustrated Magazine tried but failed to compete with similar periodicals from overseas such as the Strand and the Bulletin. It is interesting to speculate as to why the New Zealand public preferred the imported varieties to the local. Perhaps the reading public was not as nationalistic as publishers thought they were and found that English and Australian periodicals represented their views as well or better than the indigenous magazines. It is also likely that the New Zealand periodicals suffered from competition with local newspapers, particularly the illustrated weeklies such as the Free Lance and Weekly News. These weekly papers had similar content to periodicals like the Illustrated Magazine and were well established by the late nineteenth century and very popular with the public.

I ngā tekau tau mai i 1880 me 1890 i whakaaro ētahi kaiwhakaputa o Niu Tireni i konei he mākete mō ētahi hautaka e kaingākautia ana e te marea, he kaha te arotahi ki ngā take o te wā kāinga. I tāia ki ngā tāone nui ētahi tānga, tae atu ki Zealandia (1889), ki Citizen (1895), ki Critic (1899). Kīhai te kotahi o ēnei i kake, i āhua tūroa rānei. Ko te mea hiranga tonu o ēnei hautaka ā-rohe ko te New Zealand Illustrated Magazine.

I whakaputa ā-maramatia ai te Illustrated Magazine i Tāmaki-makaurau mai i te tau 1899 ki te tau 1905. I kawe hoki i ngā takohanga tuhituhi a ngā kaituhi rangatira o Aotearoa o te wā, tae atu ki a Apirana Ngata, ki a Jane Mander, ki a James Cowan me Elsdon Best. I whakaaturia hoki te whiti, te pūrākau poto me te tuhinga whakamārama, ā, i whakaahuatia nuitia e ngā momo tāngata pērā me Frances Hodgkins, me Kennaway Henderson hoki.

I whakamātau te Illustrated Magazine ki te whakataetae ki ngā momo hautaka rite nō tāwāhi, pērā i te Strand me te Bulletin, engari kāore i toa. He mea whaitake tonu te whaikupu he aha i kaha kē atu ai te pīrangi o te iwi whānui o Aotearoa ki ngā momo o tāwāhi i ērā o te kāinga. Tērā pea kāore i eke rawa te kotahitanga-ā-iwi o te iwi kōrero pukapuka ki tā ngā kaiwhakaputa i whakaaro ai, ā, tērā anō pea ki a rātou i pai kē atu, i ōrite rānei, te whakapuakanga a ngā hautaka o Ingarangi, o Āhitereiria hoki i ō rātou ake whakaaro i tā ngā hautaka kāinga whakapuakanga. Tērā tonu pea i mate anō hoki ngā hautaka o Niu Tireni i te tauwhāinga atu ki ngā nūpepa kāinga, ina koa ngā tānga ā-wiki whai whakaahua, pērā i te Free Lance me te Weekly News. I āhua rite ngā kōrero o ēnei pepa ā-wiki ki ō ngā hautaka pērā i te Illustrated Magazine, ā, tae rawa ki te mutunga o te rautau tekau mā iwa kua tino ū ēnei pepa, kua tino kaingākautia hoki e te iwi whānui.

Publication.Title: New Zealander
Publication.Description: The New Zealander began publishing weekly in Auckland in June 1845. Under competitive pressure it became a bi-weekly in 1847 and by 1859 it had become the leading daily newspaper in New Zealand. However, its pro-Māori policy led to a decline in circulation and it stopped publication in 1866.

I tīmata te whakaputa i te New Zealander ia wiki i ākarana i te marama o Pipiri 1845. Nā te kaha o te whakataetae ka puta i ngā rā e rua ki te wiki i te tau 1847, ā, nō te tau 1859 koia te tino nūpepa o ia rā i Aotearoa. Heoi anō, nā tana tautoko ki ngā kaupapa Māori ka kore haere te tukutuku, ā, ka mutu te whakaputaina i te tau 1866.
Publication.Essay:
John Williamson started the New Zealander as a weekly newspaper in 1845 and it was the main competitor of the Southern Cross. These were the only two newspapers that became established in Auckland for any significant period of time before the 1860s.

The New Zealander began during the depression following the war against Hone Heke in Northland. The paper aimed to represent the interests of the average settler and Māori. It was the view of the New Zealander that the interests of the larger land claimant groups were already receiving more than enough coverage in the Auckland Times. Ironically the Times closed shortly after the New Zealander began publishing in June 1845.

The Southern Cross was temporarily suspended in 1845 leaving the New Zealander to continue without competition until the Southern Cross was revived in 1847. The New Zealander responded to this by publishing bi-weekly. In 1848 Williamson took William Chisholm Wilson into partnership.

The paper steadily increased its influence. By 1859 it was the leading paper in New Zealand and in 1863 it became a daily. Also in that year the partnership split over the war against the Māori. Williamson was against it while Wilson was for it. Wilson left to set up the New Zealand Herald and Williamson carried on as the sole owner.

The New Zealander incurred some criticism for its comments on the war. In June 1864 fifty men from the HMS Esk threatened to pull down the newspaper office after one of the paper's correspondents suggested that Captain Hamilton's death at Gate Pa was due to his men having deserted. Williamson refused to apologise but did offer to print a rebuttal from the seamen in his paper.

By this time the New Zealander had begun to lose influence and support. The paper's pro-Māori policy was moderated but it was too late. In 1865 it couldn't sustain daily publication and had to revert to bi-weekly. In May 1866 the office burnt down and the paper stopped.

The New Zealander and the Southern Cross are good examples of the way the country's press was politically aligned at the time and this was mirrored in other centres around New Zealand.

Nā John Williamson te New Zealander i tīmata hei nūpepa ā-wiki i te tau 1845, koia rā te nūpepa tino whakataetae i te Southern Cross. Ko ēnei noa iho ngā nūpepa i tū i ākarana mō tētahi wā i mua o te tau 1860.

I tīmata te New Zealander i te wā o te toimahatanga nō muri mai o te pakanga ki a Hone Heke i te Taitokerau. Ko tā te nūpepa he whakaatu i ngā take o te tangata whai pānga iti me te Māori. Ki te New Zealander he kaha tonu te whakapāohotanga o ngā whai pānga a ngā rōpū rapu whenua nui atu e te Auckland Times. Inā te korokē, nō muri tata noa mai o te tīmatanga ki te whakaputa i te New Zealander i te marama o Pipiri 1845, ka katia ai te Times.

Ka whakatārewatia te Southern Cross i te tau 1845, tukua ana te New Zealander kia haere kore whakataetae tae noa ki te tau 1847, arā, te tau o te whakaaranga ake o te Southern Cross. E rua whakaputanga ki te wiki te whakautu a te New Zealander. I te tau 1848, ka tīkina e Williamson ko William Chisholm Wilson hei hoa kaipakihi.

Ka tupu haere te whaimana o te nūpepa. Tae rawa ana ki te tau 1859 koia te tino nūpepa o Aotearoa, ā, i te tau 1863 ka puta ia rā, ia rā. I taua tau anō ka raru te hoa pakihi i te pakanga ki te Māori. Kīhai a Williamson i tautoko, ēngari a Wilson. Ka wehe atu a Wilson ki te whakatū i te New Zealand Herald, ka noho tonu a Williamson anahe hei rangatira.

Ka whakahēngia te New Zealander i āna whakapuakitanga mō te pakanga. I te marama o Pipiri i te tau 1864 ka whakawehia mai e rima tekau o ngā heremana mai i te HMS Esk ki te turaki i te tari o te nūpepa nō muri mai o te puakitanga e tētahi o ngā kairīpoata a te nūpepa nā te whakarerenga o āna hōia i mate ai a Kāpene Hamilton i Pukehinahina. Kīhai a Williamson i whakapāha, ēngari i tukua kia tāngia ki tana nūpepa ētahi kupu tātā mai i ngā heremana.

Ki tēnei wā ka kore haere te tautoko mai me te whaimana o te New Zealander. Ka whakatūpatotia te tauawhi kaupapa Māori, ēngari taea te pēwhea. Tae noa ki te tau 1865 kāore i taea te whakaputa ia rā, ka hoki kē ki ngā putanga e rua ia wiki. I te marama o Haratua i te tau 1866 nō te kānga o te tari i te ahi, ka kore te nūpepa.

He tauira pai te New Zealander me te Southern Cross o te ū a ngā nūpepa o te motu ki te tōrangapū i taua wā, ā, he pērā rā anō ki ētahi atu tāone o Aotearoa.

Publication.Title: New Zealand Tablet
Publication.Description: The Tablet was founded by Patrick Moran, the first Catholic bishop of Dunedin. Moran was an articulate but vitriolic polemicist on behalf of Irish Catholics. His outspoken criticism of the government – over the secularisation of education, which he saw as part of an international conspiracy against the Church, and the failure to fund Catholic schools – attracted national attention but alienated many, including the majority of the press. The Tablet was established to provide him with an alternative means to express his views; Moran often edited the paper and was a regular contributor to it.

Nā Patrick Moran, pīhopa Katorika tuatahi o Ōtepoti, te Tablet i whakaū. He tangata wahapū ia ēngari he kaitautohe pūkawa hoki mō ngā Katorika o Airangi. Nā āna kaha whakahē ā-waha i te kāwanatanga – mō te meatanga a te kāwanatanga i te mātauranga hei mea nō te whai ao, ki tāna titiro he wāhi hoki tēnei o tētahi kara ki te Hāhi huri noa te ao, mō te hinganga hoki a te kāwanatanga hei utu i ngā kura Katorika – i hakahaka ai te whakaaro o te motu, ēngari nāna anō i whakawehe i te nuinga, uru ana hoki te nuinga o te hunga tā nūpepa. I whakaūtia ai te Tablet kia whiwhi ia i tētahi huarahi kē hei whakapuaki i ōna whakaaro; he nui ngā wā nā Moran te nūpepa i whakatikatika, ā, koia anō tētahi o ngā kaituhi auau ki reira.
Publication.Essay:
The NZ Tablet was a Catholic periodical that was published weekly in Dunedin from 1873 to1996. It was set up to represent the interests of Irish Catholics throughout the nation. The Tablet was, particularly in its first fifty years or so, one of the most significant religious and political journals published in New Zealand.

The Tablet was founded by Patrick Moran, the first Catholic bishop of Dunedin. Moran was an articulate but vitriolic polemicist on behalf of Irish Catholics. His outspoken criticism of the government – over the secularisation of education, which he saw as part of an international conspiracy against the Church, and the failure to fund Catholic schools –attracted national attention but alienated many, including the majority of the press. The Tablet was established to provide him with an alternative means to express his views; Moran often edited the paper and was a regular contributor to it.

Moran was a staunch supporter of Irish nationalism and he ensured that the Tablet gave this cause much coverage. In fact there are indications that he sometimes regarded Irish issues as more important than Catholic ones; in the 1880s he criticised the Vatican for not supporting Irish nationalism as strongly as he thought they should.

While Moran had many commendable qualities, his views and the vehemence with which he expressed them were divisive and served to separate Catholics from the wider community.

After Moran’s death in 1895, the Tablet pursued a more moderate line with Henry Cleary as the editor. Cleary, who was in charge from 1898 to 1908, favoured a much more conciliatory approach and he distanced the magazine from the cause of Irish nationalism. In 1918, ten years after leaving the Tablet, Cleary founded the Month, a moderate Catholic journal, to oppose the Tablet, which under James Kelly had returned to the strident approach of Moran.

Kelly became the editor of the Tablet in 1917. He was probably even more outspoken on Irish issues than Moran. Kelly was a supporter of Sinn Fein and used the Tablet to promote their cause. His support for Irish nationalism and the anti-English comments he made in the Tablet during the war offended many New Zealanders. These were a factor in the rise of the Howard Elliott and the Protestant Political Association, a sectarian organisation that enjoyed widespread support throughout NZ during the war and through the 1920s. Kelly’s style became more bitter and fractious as the years went by and he was forced to resign as editor in 1931.

The Tablet continued to be a prominent and often outspoken advocate for Catholic and Irish issues after Kelly but it did this in less strident and provocative ways. The Tablet remained an influential periodical, particularly under the editorship of John Kennedy, editor from 1967 to 1989. He was well known as a political commentator and some believe his support for the Labour party in 1972, expressed through the Tablet, was important in their election as the government that year.

The Tablet wound up in April 1996.

He hautaka Katorika te NZ Tablet i tāngia ia wiki i Ōtepoti, mai i te tau 1873 ki 1996. I whakatūria hei māngai mō ngā pānga o ngā Katorika o Airangi huri noa te motu. Ko te Tablet, motuhake i ōna tau tuatahi e rima tekau pea, tētahi o ngā hautaka karakia, hautaka tōrangapū hoki, tino hira tonu o Aotearoa.

Nā Patrick Moran, pīhopa Katorika tuatahi o Ōtepoti, te Tablet i whakaū. He tangata wahapū ia ēngari he kaitautohe pūkawa hoki mō ngā Katorika o Airangi. Nā āna kaha whakahē ā-waha i te kāwanatanga – mō te meatanga a te kāwanatanga i te mātauranga hei mea nō te whai ao, ki tāna titiro he wāhi hoki tēnei o tētahi kara ki te Hāhi huri noa te ao, mō te hinganga hoki a te kāwanatanga hei utu i ngā kura Katorika – i hakahaka ai te whakaaro o te motu, ēngari nāna anō i whakawehe i te nuinga, uru ana hoki te nuinga o te hunga tā nūpepa. I whakaūtia ai te Tablet kia whiwhi ia i tētahi huarahi kē hei whakapuaki i ōna whakaaro; he nui ngā wā nā Moran te nūpepa i whakatikatika, ā, koia anō tētahi o ngā kaituhi auau ki reira.

He kaitautoko kaha a Moran o te wawao whenua o Airangi, ā, i āta tirohia e ia kia kapia nuitia ai e te Tablet tēnei take. He tika tonu te whakaatu mai, i whakaarohia e ia he mea hira rawa ngā take o Airangi i ō ngā Katorika; i te tekau tau mai i 1880, i whakahēngia e ia te Watikana (Vatican) nōtemea kīhai i kaha tō rātou tautoko i te wawao whenua o Airangi pērā ki tōna i whakaaro ai.

Ahakoa he maha ngā pai o Moran hei whakamihi, he mea whakawehewehe ōna whakaaro me te kaha o tana whakapuaki i aua whakaaro, ā, koia anō te whakawehe atu i ngā Katorika i te hapori whānui.

Nō muri mai i te matenga o Moran i te tau 1895, he āhua ngāwari te huarahi i whaia e te Tablet i a Henry Cleary te takatā. I pai kē a Cleary, nāna hoki i whakahaere mai i te tau 1898 ki 1908, kia āhua tāpore kē te haere, ā, meinga ana e ia kia tawhiti atu te hautaka i te take o te wawao whenua o Airangi. I te tau 1918, arā, tekau tau i muri o tana wehenga atu i te Tablet, i whakaūtia e Cleary te Month, he nūpepa Katorika āhua ngāwari, hei tautohenga ki te Tablet, tērā kua hoki i raro i a James Kelly ki te āhua whakahaere pākinakina o Moran.

I meinga ko Kelly te takatā mō te Tablet i te tau 1917. Tērā pea, he kaha kē ia i a Moran hei waha kōrero mō ngā take o Airangi. Hei kaitautoko a Kelly i a Sinn Fein, ā, i whakamahia e ia te Tablet hei whakatairanga i tō rātou take. Nā tana tautoko i te wawao whenua o Airangi me āna kōrero matakēkē i ngā Ingarihi i roto i te Tablet i waenganui i te Pakanga, nā konei i weriweri ai ētahi tāngata maha o Aotearoa. Ko ēnei hoki tētahi take mō te rewanga o Howard Elliot me te Rōpū Porotehana Tōrangapū, he whakahaerenga rōpū wehe i tautokona whānuitia huri noa Aotearoa i waenganui i ngā tau o te Pakanga me te tekau tau mai i 1920. Ka kaha pūkawa haere, ka kaha whakawehewehe hoki te āhua o Kelly i te haerenga o ngā tau, nā wai ka ākina ia kia tukua te tūru takatā i te tau 1931.

I haere tonu te Tablet hei māngai matua, hei waha kōrero hoki mō ngā take Katorika me ngā take o Airangi i muri i a Kelly, ēngari i āhua ngāwari kē āna mahi, kāore i kaha pākinakina, i taunanawe rānei pērā i mua rā. I noho anō te Tablet hei hautaka whakaawe tonu, motuhake i te wā o John Kennedy, te takatā mai i te tau 1967 ki 1989. I mōhiotia whānuitia ia hei kaikōrero tōrangapū, ā, e whakapono ana ētahi ko āna tautoko mō te Rōpū Reipa i te tau 1972, i whakapuakina i roto i te Tablet, tētahi take nui i tō rātou pōtitanga hei kāwanatanga i tērā tau.

I whakamutua te Tablet i te marama o Paenga-whāwhā 1996.

Publication.Title: NZ Truth
Publication.Description: The NZ Truth was for many years one of the country’s most colourful, controversial and popular newspapers. The Truth was launched, in Wellington, by the Australian newspaper publisher John Norton in June 1905.
Nō ngā tau maha ko te NZ Truth tētahi o ngā tino nūpepa tautohetohe o te motu. Nā te kaitā nūpepa nā John Norton o Ahitereiria te Truth i whakamāunu i Pōneke i te Hune o 1905.
Publication.Essay:
The NZ Truth was for many years one of the country’s most colourful, controversial and popular newspapers. The Truth was launched, in Wellington, by the Australian newspaper publisher John Norton in June 1905.

Norton owned a stable of Truth newspapers in Australia, starting with the Sydney Truth in 1896. The Sydney Truth’s mix of radical politics and muck-raking proved very popular and Norton established similar papers in the other states before crossing the Tasman. In New Zealand he stuck with the same formula and achieved the same results. By 1930 the Truth was selling 100,000s of copies each week.

The Truth stood out from the other New Zealand newspapers because it was overtly political and reported the unseemly aspects of life in immoderate prose. Under Robert Hogg, editor from 1913 to 1922, the paper was strongly socialist. It supported the revolutionary Industrial Workers of the World during the 1913 general strike, opposed conscription during the World War One and published letters from pacifist Archibald Baxter.

The Truth’s politics moved right-wards in the 1920s after John Norton’s son Ezra assumed control. Hogg was dismissed and the paper took a more conservative and populist line from which it never deviated, attacking liberal causes with alacrity. However the commitment to investigative journalism and exposing political corruption remained. The paper was responsible for some major scoops in the next few decades. The Truth grew in popularity although not respectability, circulation reaching about 240,000 copies a week in the 1960s.

Ezra Norton sold the Truth to a consortium of local businessmen in 1951. In 1978 Independent Newspapers acquired the paper and in 1982 they moved it to Auckland. Here the paper went into a sharp decline. Tabloid journalism was now the norm and the paper lost the vitality that being at the centre of politics had given it. Weekly sales were down to 12,500 when the paper was sold in 2007.

Note: no issues are known to exist of the first year of the NZ Truth.

Nō ngā tau maha ko te NZ Truth tētahi o ngā tino nūpepa tautohetohe o te motu. Nā te kaitā nūpepa nā John Norton o Ahitereiria te Truth i whakamāunu i Pōneke i te Hune o 1905.

Nā Norton te huinga nūpepa Truth i Ahitereiria, ko tōna tīmatanga mai i te Sydney Truth i Poihākena i te 1896. Ko tā te Sydney Truth kawe i te tuwhena tōrangapū me te kawe whawhewhawhe he mea ihiihi ki te iwi, ā, ka tūria ai e Norton ētahi nūpepa pērā puta noa ngā wehenga, kātahi ka whakawhiti mai Te Tai o Rehua. Ki Aotearoa ko tāna ko taua tū āhuatanga anō, ko aua hua anō. Tae noa ki te 1930, e hia nei ngā raumano kape o te Truth i te hokona.

He mea rerekē atu te Truth i ētahi anō o ngā nūpepa o Aotearoa, te take he mea whakakite tōrangapū, ka tāngia hoki ngā mea anuanu o te wā ki ngā kupu haere hāngai tonu. I raro i a Robert Hogg, te etita mai i te 1913 ki te 1922, he kaha te ā-pāpori o te nūpepa. He mea tautoko i te rōpū whakawhana o ngā Industrial Workers of the World i te wā o te taraika whānui o te 1913, he mea tohe i te māperetanga o te Pakanga ā-Ao Tuatahi, he mea tā i ngā reta mai i te kairongomau, i a Archibald Baxter.

Ka huri whakatekatau te tōrangapū o te Truth i ngā 1920, nō te rironga o te whakahaeretanga i te tama a John Norton, i a Ezra. Ka panaia atu a Hogg, ka huri, ka mau te nūpepa ki te tūpato, me te manako ā-iwi, ka kaha tonu te tohea o ngā take tōrangapū ngāwari. He oti rā, ka mau tonu tāna here ki te āta rangahau ā-nūpepa me te whakaraerae i te hēnga. Nāna ētahi whakaputanga nui whakaharahara i roto i ngā tekautau o muri mai. Ka tupu, ka tupu te manako ā-iwi, ēngari mō te tirohanga ki te whāia o te tika, ko te hokonga ka eke ki te 240,000 ngā kape i tētahi wiki kotahi i ngā 1960.

Ka hokona te Truth e Ezra Norton ki tētahi rōpū kaipakihi o te takiwā i te 1951. Nō te 1978 ka riro te nūpepa i a Independent Newspapers, ā, nō te 1982, ka nukuhia ai ki Ākarana. Nō konei ka tere heke te nūpepa. Ko ta tānga nūpepa whakaparahako he āhuatanga aunoa, ka ngaro i te nūpepa taua hīkaka o tōna wā i te pokapū o ngā take tōrangapū. Ke heke haere ngā hokonga ki te 12,500 i tōna hokonga i te 2007.

Tēnā: kāore i te kitea tētahi putanga o te tau tuatahi o te NZ Truth.

Publication.Title: Oamaru Mail
Publication.Description: It is thought that the Oamaru Mail (first called the Evening Mail) began in order to express opposing views to those being expounded in the North Otago Times about the abolition of the New Zealand provincial system. William J Steward, who owned the North Otago Times between 1870 and 1897, at times in partnership with others, supported the abolition of the provincial system.

E ai ki ngā mea mōhio i tīmataria te Oamaru Mail (i karangatia ko te Evening Mail i tōna tuatahitanga) hei hoa tauwhāinga ki ngā whakaaro i kauwhautia ai i roto i te North Otago Times mō te whakakorenga i te pūnaha kāwanatanga ā-porowini o Aotearoa. I tautoko a William J Steward i te whakakorenga o te pūnaha kāwanatanga ā-porowini. Koia te tangata nāna te North Otago Times i waenga i ngā tau 1870 me 1897, otirā, arā hoki ana hoa i roto i te nūpepa i ētahi o aua tau.
Publication.Essay:
It is thought that the Oamaru Mail (first called the Evening Mail) began in order to express opposing views to those being expounded in the North Otago Times about the abolition of the New Zealand provincial system. William J Steward, who owned the North Otago Times between 1870 and 1897, at times in partnership with others, supported the abolition of the provincial system.

Steward was a Member of Parliament for the single-seat Waitaki electorate from 1871-1875, but lost the next election to two provincialists in the then, two-seat electorate. He returned to Parliament in 1881 and was Speaker of the House of Representatives from 1891-1893.

Because there was considerable support for the provincial system, particularly in the far south of the country, a group of prominent Oamaru residents decided they would begin a new daily newspaper to promote this, which they did in April 1876. However, the North Otago Times, first as the bi-weekly Oamaru Times and Waitaki Reporter, then as a tri-weekly, became a daily at the beginning of January 1876, pre-empting the new opposition by three months. Further, there was an inauspicious launch for the Evening Mail when its second-hand machinery broke down. As often happened in the early days of newspapering in New Zealand, the North Otago Times obliged by printing its rival’s first issue.

It was doubtful whether Oamaru’s small population could support two dailies. The township had been surveyed as recently as 1860 and it grew slowly as an agricultural/pastoral service centre until, with the construction of a breakwater in the early 1870s, it became a major port for the region. Certainly, the Evening Mail found the going hard and in early 1877, the provincial system now legislated out of existence, the original Evening Mail Company was wound up.

At this point George Jones arrived in Oamaru, following his founding of and brief association with the Evening News in Dunedin, and bought the paper. Born in New Zealand but apprenticed in Australia, Jones was printer of the Auckland Star before launching the Waikato Times in 1872 and the short-lived Echo in Auckland two years later. It took a cause célèbre to put the Evening Mail on a firmer financial footing.

In 1877 the paper accused politician Sir Frederick Whitaker of having a personal interest in native land his planned legislation would make available for sale. Jones was summoned to the bar of the House of Representatives and then prosecuted for criminal libel. He was acquitted, the legislation withdrawn and the Ministry defeated shortly afterwards. The Evening Mail had successfully underscored the ‘freedom of the press’ principle and the attendant publicity provided the paper with a surge of reader and advertiser support.

The Oamaru Mail, as it was now called, could afford to take up, with other evening papers, a special telegraphic service originated by the Dunedin Evening Star and was one of the early papers outside metropolitan areas to install linotype machines. In 1909 the Oamaru Mail business was formed into a private company, at about the same time as George Jones bought the Southland News. He and his sons continued to play a prominent part in the company.

Jones also had a lengthy political career. He briefly represented Waitaki in the House of Representatives in the early 1880s and was a member of the Legislative Council for a quarter century from 1895.

According to the Cyclopedia of New Zealand [Otago & Southland Provincial Districts] in 1905: ‘The first edition of the ‘Mail’ is published daily at 3 p.m., and is timed for despatch by various trains. The journal is a four page paper of twenty-eight columns, and has a daily circulation of 2,100 copies throughout the North Otago and South Canterbury districts. The ‘Oamaru Mail’ office is centrally situated in Tyne Street. It is a two-storey stone building, which was erected for the domicile of the paper. A water motor, supplied from the corporation water works, and a gas engine drive the plant, which consists of a two-feeder double royal Wharfdale machine, two Platen machines, three linotypes, and other up-to-date appliances, besides an ancient machine on which, it is said, the first issue of the ‘Melbourne Age’ was printed and also the first issue of the ‘Otago Daily Times’.’

The Oamaru Mail was owned by descendants of the Jones family until the 1970s when it was bought by NZ News Ltd, a Brierley subsidiary, then by Wilson and Horton which, in turn, was sold to APN NZ Media. In November 2011, the Oamaru Mail became a five-mornings-a-week tabloid paper.

In 2013, the Oamaru Mail was bought by a private, family-owned Christchurch company, Mainland Media Ltd. The company also bought the Christchurch Star and six other community newspapers in the greater Christchurch area previously owned by APN. Charlotte Smulders, co-owner with her husband, is a member of the Smith family which controls Allied Press and the Otago Daily Times. The Oamaru Mail has a paid circulation of about 2,900 copies.

E ai ki ngā mea mōhio i tīmataria te Oamaru Mail (i karangatia ko te Evening Mail i tōna tuatahitanga) hei hoa tauwhāinga ki ngā whakaaro i kauwhautia ai i roto i te North Otago Times mō te whakakorenga i te pūnaha kāwanatanga ā-porowini o Aotearoa. I tautoko a William J Steward i te whakakorenga o te pūnaha kāwanatanga ā-porowini. Koia te tangata nāna te North Otago Times i waenga i ngā tau 1870 me 1897, otirā, arā hoki ana hoa i roto i te nūpepa i ētahi o aua tau.

He mema Pāremata a Steward mō te tūru takitahi o Waitaki mai i 1871-1875, engari i hinga i roto i te pōti whai i muri ki ētahi toa tokorua nō te porowini mō te tūru, kua tūru takirua hoki i taua wā. Ka hoki ia ki te Pāremata i te tau 1881 ā, koia te Kaikōrero i te Whare Pāremata mai i 1891-1893.

Nā te mea he nui te tautoko mō te pūnaha kāwanatanga ā-rohe, otirā ko te rohe tino whaka-te-tonga o Aotearoa te rohe kaha ki te whakaaro pērā, ka whakatau tētahi rōpū tāngata mana-nui i Oamaru ki te tīmata i tētahi nūpepa o ia rā ki te whakatairanga i taua whakaaro, ā, ka pērā anō i te marama o Āperira 1876. Ahakoa rā, ka tīmata wawe te North Otago Times, hei nūpepa o ia rā i te tīmatanga o 1876, e toru marama i mua i te hoa tauwhāinga. I mua he nūpepa e rua ana putanga i te wiki, ko te ingoa ko Oamaru Times and Waitaki Reporter, ā, i muri e toru ana putanga i te wiki, ka huri hei nūpepa o ia rā. I tua atu i tērā, i aituā te whakarewanga o te Evening Mail i te pakarutanga o ana mīhini kua hokona mai i ētahi atu nūpepa. Rite tonu ki te mahi a te tini o ngā nūpepa tuatahi o Aotearoa, i whakaae tana hoa tauwhāinga te North Otago Times ki te tā i te putanga tuatahi o tana hoa tauwhāinga.

Ki te whakaaro ake kāore pea te taupori o Oamaru i rahi kia ora ngā nūpepa e rua. Nō nakua noa nei te tāone i rūritia ai i te tau 1860, ā, i āta tupu hei pūtahi ahuwhenua, taea noatia te hanganga o tētahi kawa wahapū i ngā tau tuatahi mai i 1870, i piki ai te tāone hei wahapū matua mō te rohe. Arā, he uaua te huarahi mā te Evening Mail ā, i te tau 1877 ka whakamutua te Evening Mail Company. Kua whakakorea hoki te pūnaha kāwanatanga ā-porowini i raro i te ture i taua wā.

I konei ka tae mai a George Jones ki Oamaru, i muri i tana whakatūranga i te Evening News i Ōtepoti, me te hoko i te nūpepa. I whānau mai i Aotearoa, engari i ākona ki tana mahi i Āhitereiria. He kaitā a Jones mō te Auckland Star i mua i tana whakarewanga i te Waikato Times i te tau 1872 me te Echo i Tāmaki-makau-rau e rua tau i muri mai. Nā tētahi take nui whakahirahira ngā pūtea o te Evening Mail i whakamōmona.

I te tau 1877 ka whakapae te pepa he pānga tō te kaitōrangapū rongonui a Sir Frederick Whitaker ki ngā whenua Māori meāke ka whakawāteatia mō te hoko i raro i āna ture hou. Ka ngarea a Jones ki te pae whakawā o te Whare Pāremata, kātahi ka hāmenetia mō te hāhani nanakia i te ingoa pai o te tangata. Ka kīia he hara-kore ia, me te aha, ka tangohia te pire, ka hinga hoki te Kāwanatanga i muri tata tonu iho. Kua whakaūngia te mātāpono o te 'noho wātea o te perehi ki te mahi i tana mahi' e te Evening Mail ā, ka piki tōna mana i waenga i te iwi, me te tautoko mai anō hoki o ngā kaipānui me ngā kaiwhakatairanga.

Kua wātea te Oamaru Mail, (tana ingoa hōu), ki te tīmata i tētahi ratonga tarikarāwhe i takea mai i te Dunedin Evening Star ā, koia tētahi o ngā nūpepa tuatahi i waho i ngā tāone nunui kia whakauru mai i ngā mīhini linotype. I te tau 1909 ka whakapūmautia te umanga o te Oamaru Mail hei kamupene tūmataiti, i te wā tonu i hoko a George Jones i te Southland News. I haere tonu ā rātou mahi hihiri ko ana tama i roto i te kamupene.

He roa tonu hoki te wā o Jones i roto i ngā mahi tōrangapū. Ka uru ia hei kanohi mō te Whare Pāremata mō te tūnga o Waitaki i ngā tau tuatahi o te Whare Pāremata o ngā tau tuatahi mai i 1880 ā, he mema hoki nō te Kaunihera Hanga Ture mō te rua tekau tau mai i 1895.

E ai ki te Cyclopedia of New Zealand [Otago & Southland Provincial Districts] i 1905: ‘Puta ai te putanga tuatahi o te ‘Mail’ ia rā, ia rā hei te 3 p.m, ko tōna tikanga ka tukua atu mā runga i ngā tereina e tika ana. E whā ngā whārangi o te nūpepa, e rua tekau mā waru ngā tīwae, ko ngā nūpepa ka hokona ia rā e 2,100 puta noa i ngā rohe o Ōtākou ki te Raki me Waitaki. Ko te tari o te ‘Oamaru Mail’ kei waenga pū i te Tiriti o Tyne. He whare paparanga rua, he mea āta whakatū mārire hei kāinga mō te nūpepa. He pūkaha wai, he pūkahu kapuni hoki ngā mea e pana ana i ōna mīhini, he mea whāngai ki ngā wai o te kāporeihana. Ko aua mīhini he mīhini whāngai-rua Wharfdale pūrua, e rua ngā mīhini Platen, e toru ngā linotype, me tētahi atu mīhini tino hou, me tētahi mīhini tawhito, e kīa ana nāna i tā te putanga tuatahi o te ‘Melbourne Age’ me te putanga tuatahi o te ‘Otago Daily Times’.’

Ko ngā rangatira o te Oamaru Mail he uri nō te whānau Jones taea noatia ngā tau 1970 i hokona mai ai e NZ News Ltd, he pekanga nā Brierley. I muri ka hokona e Wilson and Horton ā, ka hokona hoki tērā ki APN NZ Media. I te marama o Nōema 2011, ka huri te Oamaru Mail he nūpepa rima-ata-i-te-wiki.

I te tau 2013, ka hokona te Oamaru Mail e tētahi kamupena ā-whānau tūmataiti nō Ōtautahi arā, e Mainland Media Ltd. I hokona hoki e te kamupene te Christchurch Star, me ētahi atu nūpepa hapori e ono i te rohe whānui o Ōtautahi, ko APN tō mua rangatira. He kaipupuri hea ngātahi a Charlotte Smulders, me tana tāne, he mema nō te whānau Smith e noho nei hei rangatira mō te Allied Press me te Otago Daily Times. Ko te maha o ngā kaipānui o te Oamaru Mail e utu ana mō te nūpepa kei te 2,900 ngā kape.

Publication.Title: Ohinemuri Gazette
Publication.Description: Based in Paeroa, the first issue of the Ohinemuri Gazette appeared on Saturday, 19 December 1891. It appeared twice a week, on Saturday and Wednesday mornings and was hand-set.

I puta te putanga tuatahi o te Ohinemuri Gazette o Paeroa i te Hātarei, te 19 o ngā rā o Tīhema 1891. E rua rawa ōna putanga ia wiki, i Hātarei, ia Wenerei hoki, i te ata, ā, he mea tā ā-ringa ōna reta.
Publication.Essay:
Based in Paeroa, the first issue of the Ohinemuri Gazette appeared on Saturday, 19 December 1891. It appeared twice a week, on Saturday and Wednesday mornings and was hand-set.

Founder Edwin Edwards arrived in Paeroa in the early 1880s and started off his newspaper career by founding the Gazette with J.H. Moore and H.C. Wick, then in 1896, the Te Aroha Times and Waiorongomai Advocate, with J.W. Parry. He was an amateur geologist who at one time owned part of the Waihi Mine, was active in local affairs and was a writer of ballads, which often appeared in the Ohinemuri Gazette.

Ownership was taken over in 1900 by William Dennis Nicholas and Henry Howard Lyes (retired 1901). Nicholas changed the Gazette to an evening paper, appearing three times a week. Fire swept through the Wharf St office of the Gazette in 1908, but it continued to be published (printed by the owner of Waihi Times). New printing premises were opened in Princes St with an up-to-date press.

The Hauraki Tribune was incorporated into the Ohinemuri Gazette in 1896, with a title change in 1921 to the Hauraki Plains Gazette.

The Hauraki Plains Gazette was incorporated into the Thames Valley Gazette in 1977, with two other local newspapers, and then it became the Paeroa Gazette in 1988. This merged with the Thames Star in 1998 to become the Thames Valley Gazette, but the new publication lasted less than a year.

I puta te putanga tuatahi o te Ohinemuri Gazette o Paeroa i te Hātarei, te 19 o ngā rā o Tīhema 1891. E rua rawa ōna putanga ia wiki, i Hātarei, ia Wenerei hoki, i te ata, ā, he mea tā ā-ringa ōna reta.

I tae mai te kaiwhakatū o te nūpepa a Edwin Edwards ki Paeroa i ngā tau tuatahi mai i 1880, ā, i tīmata tāna mahi nūpepa ki te whakatū i te Gazette i te taha o J.H.Moore me H.C. Wick, ā, nō te tau 1896, ka whakatūria e ia Te Aroha Times and Waiorongomai Advocate, i te taha o J.W. Parry. He kaimātai whenua kore-utu noa ia, ā, tērā anō te wā nōna tētahi wāhi o te keringa nui o Waihī, he tangata i hautū i ngā mahi o te rohe, he tautitotito ruriruri, ā, he maha ōna ruriruri i puta i te Ohinemuri Gazette.

I riro te mana pupuri i a William Dennis Nicholas rāua ko Henry Howard Lyes (i tukua e ia tōna tūranga i te tau 1901). Ka hurihia e Nicholas te āhua o te Gazette hei pepa mō te ahiahi, e toru ōna putanga i te wiki.I kainga ngā tari o te Gazette i Wharf St e te ahi i te tau 1908, heoi anō, ka puta haere tonu (he mea tā e te hunga nō ratou te Waihi Times). Ka whakatuwheratia ētahi whare tā i Princes St, ka whakaurungia he mīhini tā hōu ki roto.

Nō te tau 1896 ka haumitia te Hauraki Tribune ki roto i te Ohinemuri Gazette, ā, nō te tau 1921 ka hurihia te ingoa ki te Hauraki Plains Gazette.

Ka haumitia mai te Hauraki Plains Gazette ki roto i te Thames Valley Gazette i te tau 1977, me ētahi atu nūpepa ā-rohe e rua, ā, ka kīia i muri ko Paeroa Gazette i te tau 1988. Ka haumitia mai tēnei ki te Thames Star i te tau 1998, ka kīia ko Thames Valley Gazette, engari kāore i eke ki te tau te oranga o te nūpepa hou.

Publication.Title: Otago Daily Times
Publication.Description: The discovery of gold in Gabriel’s Gully in 1861 led to a huge increase in the population of Dunedin, going from fewer than 2,000 inhabitants to nearly 15,000 by the end of the 1860s. Julius Vogel (1835-1899) arrived in Dunedin in October 1861 and became editor of the weekly Otago Witness. Together with the Otago Witness publisher William Cutten, Vogel started up the Otago Daily Times. The first issue appeared on 15 November 1861, making it the first daily newspaper in New Zealand, and the one with the longest history of daily publication.

Nā te kitenga o te kōura i Gabriel’s Gully i te tau 1861 ka waipuketia te tāone o Ōtepoti e te tini tauhou, ā, ka piki te tokomaha o te hunga noho i reira i te 2,000 ki te 15,000 i te mutunga o te tekau tau mai i 1860. Nō te marama o Oketopa 1861 ka tae atu a Julius Vogel (1835-1899) ki Ōtepoti, ā, ka noho hei ētita mō te nūpepa ā-wiki e kīia nei ko te Otago Witness. Ka mahi tahi a Vogel me te kaiwhakaputa o te Otago Witness a William Cutten, ki te whakatū i te Otago Daily Times. Ka tāia tāna putanga tuatahi i te 15 o Nōema 1861, i noho ai tēnei nūpepea hei mātāmua mō ngā nūpepa o ia rā i Aotearoa, ko te nūpepa hoki kua roa rawa tōna putanga ia rā ia rā.
Publication.Essay:
The discovery of gold in Gabriel’s Gully in 1861 led to a huge increase in the population of Dunedin, going from fewer than 2,000 inhabitants to nearly 15,000 by the end of the 1860s. Julius Vogel (1835-1899) arrived in Dunedin in October 1861 and became editor of the weekly Otago Witness. Together with the Otago Witness publisher William Cutten, Vogel started up the Otago Daily Times. The first issue appeared on 15 November 1861, making it the first daily newspaper in New Zealand, and the one with the longest history of daily publication.

Vogel’s support for separating the South and North Islands led to his dismissal in 1868, leaving him to concentrate on national politics, whilst always retaining an interest in journalism.

After a merger of the Otago Guardian and the Otago Daily Times, a public company, The Otago Daily Times and Witness Company, was floated in 1878. One of the highlights of the paper’s history is the exposure of working conditions in Dunedin sweatshops in the 1880s by chief reporter Silas Spragg and editor George Fenwick.

Nearly a century later the Otago Daily Times Ltd and the Evening Star Company Ltd merged in 1975, followed within a few years by the transformation of the Evening Star into a community newspaper. This left the Otago Daily Times as the city’s only daily newspaper.

Nā te kitenga o te kōura i Gabriel’s Gully i te tau 1861 ka waipuketia te tāone o Ōtepoti e te tini tauhou, ā, ka piki te tokomaha o te hunga noho i reira i te 2,000 ki te 15,000 i te mutunga o te tekau tau mai i 1860. Nō te marama o Oketopa 1861 ka tae atu a Julius Vogel (1835-1899) ki Ōtepoti, ā, ka noho hei ētita mō te nūpepa ā-wiki e kīia nei ko te Otago Witness. Ka mahi tahi a Vogel me te kaiwhakaputa o te Otago Witness a William Cutten, ki te whakatū i te Otago Daily Times. Ka tāia tāna putanga tuatahi i te 15 o Nōema 1861, i noho ai tēnei nūpepea hei mātāmua mō ngā nūpepa o ia rā i Aotearoa, ko te nūpepa hoki kua roa rawa tōna putanga ia rā ia rā.

Nā te kaha tautoko a Vogel i te kaupapa wehe i Te Ika a Māui me te Waipounamu ka panaia ia i tana tūranga i te tau 1868, ā, nā konei ka wātea ia ki te whai i ngā mahi tōrangapū ā-motu, me te anga tonu anō o ōna whakaaro ki te mahi kawe kōrero i roto i ngā tau.

I muri i te haumitanga o te Otago Guardian me te Otago Daily Times, he kamupene tūmatanui, ka whakatūria te The Otago Daily Times and Witness Company, i te tau 1878. Ko tētahi o ngā mahi tino hira o te nūpepa i roto i ngā tau ko te hura i te kino me te taumaha o ngā āhuatanga mahi i ngā wheketere pēpēhi kaimahi o Ōtepoti, o ngā tekau tau mai i 1880, nā te kaikawe kōrero matua nā Silas Spragg rāua ko te ētita, a George Fenwick, i tuhi.

Tata ki te rautau i muri mai ka haumitia te Otago Daily Times Ltd me te Evening Star Company Ltd i te tau 1975, whai muri i ngā tau tata ko te hurihanga o te Evening Star hei nūpepa ā-hapori. Ka noho mai i konei ko te Otago Daily Times hei nūpepa ā-rā kotahi.

Publication.Title: Oxford Observer
Publication.Title-alternate: Oxford and Cust Observer and Canterbury Liberal; Oxford Observer and Canterbury Democrat
Publication.Description: The Oxford Observer began weekly publication in 1889. The paper was established by Richard Holman Parish, a prominent local businessman. Parish arrived in Oxford in 1870 and set himself up as a draper. He installed a printing press in his shop for general jobbing work. He was active in many areas of life in the community and was a strong advocate for the Oxford area.

Ka tīmata te tānga ia wiki o te Oxford Observer i te 1889. Nā Richard Holman Parish, tētahi kaipakihi rongonui o te rohe, i whakatū. Ka tae mai a Parish ki Oxford i te 1870, ko tāna mahi he hoko whatunga kākahu. Ka tū tāna perehi tā ki tana toa, he mea mahi whānui kau. He whānui anō āna mahi ki tana hapori, he whakapau kaha hoki hei māngai mō te rohe o Oxford.
Publication.Essay:
The Oxford Observer began weekly publication in 1889. The paper was established by Richard Holman Parish, a prominent local businessman. Parish arrived in Oxford in 1870 and set himself up as a draper. He installed a printing press in his shop for general jobbing work. He was active in many areas of life in the community and was a strong advocate for the Oxford area.

In 1894 Parish’s daughter Laurie Annie became proprietor of the paper. She was still running it in 1901. No issues of the paper survive after August of that year. The paper had certainly ceased by 1903. Richard Parish continued to operate a printing office for many years after this.

Only one incomplete set of the newspaper is known to exist.

Ka tīmata te tānga ia wiki o te Oxford Observer i te 1889. Nā Richard Holman Parish, tētahi kaipakihi rongonui o te rohe, i whakatū. Ka tae mai a Parish ki Oxford i te 1870, ko tāna mahi he hoko whatunga kākahu. Ka tū tāna perehi tā ki tana toa, he mea mahi whānui kau. He whānui anō āna mahi ki tana hapori, he whakapau kaha hoki hei māngai mō te rohe o Oxford.

Nō te 1894 ko te tamāhine a Parish ko Laurie Anne te rangatira o te nūpepa, tae noa ki te 1901. Kāore i te kitea he putanga mai i te Ākuhata o taua tau. Nō te 1903, ka kore tūturu ai te nūpepa nei. Mahia tonuhia ai e Richard Parish tētahi tari tā mō ngā tau maha o muri mai.

Kotahi noa te huinga e kitea tonuhia ana, me ētahi wāhanga kei te ngaro.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank Oxford Museum for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Oxford Museum, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Otautau Standard and Wallace County Chronicle
Publication.Description: The Otautau Standard was a weekly newspaper started by Frank Hyde in 1905. Hyde was the owner of another paper in the area, the Winton Record. Hyde sold the Standard to John Fisher the next year. The Fisher family remained in charge until publication ceased in 1946.

He nūpepa o ia wiki te Otautau Standard nā Frank Hyde i tīmata i te 1905. Ko Hyde te rangatira o tētahi atu nūpepa o reira, ko te Winton Record. I te tau o muri mai ka hokona e Hyde te Standard ki a John Fisher. Ka noho tonu ki te whānau Fisher tae noa ki tōna whakakapinga i te 1946.
Publication.Essay:
The Otautau Standard was a weekly newspaper started by Frank Hyde in 1905. Hyde was the owner of another paper in the area, the Winton Record. Hyde sold the Standard to John Fisher the next year. The Fisher family remained in charge until publication ceased in 1946. They gave the high cost of labour and plant as the main reasons for closing.

The Standard had a rival in Otautau for most its life. The Otautau Farmer was started by the publishers of the Western Star in nearby Riverton, and ceased in 1939.

He nūpepa o ia wiki te Otautau Standard nā Frank Hyde i tīmata i te 1905. Ko Hyde te rangatira o tētahi atu nūpepa o reira, ko te Winton Record. I te tau o muri mai ka hokona e Hyde te Standard ki a John Fisher. Ka noho tonu ki te whānau Fisher tae noa ki tōna whakakapinga i te 1946. Ko ngā take i whakakapia ai ko te nui o te utu o ngā kaimahi me te whakanaonga.

He hoa tauwhāinga te Standard me te Otautau mai anō. Nā ngā kaitā o te Western Star te Otautau Farmer i tīmata ki Riverton, ka whakakorehia i te 1939.

Publication.Title: Otago Witness
Publication.Description: The Witness began in Dunedin in January 1851 as a four page, fortnightly newspaper. It became a weekly in August that year. At this time illustrated weekly newspapers were a popular and important form of publication in New Zealand and the paper continued to be published until 1932.

Ka tīmata te Otago Witness i Otepoti i te marama o Kohitātea i te tau 1851, e whā ōna whārangi, he nūpepa o ia rua wiki. I te marama o Here-turi-kōkā i taua tau ka puta ia wiki. I taua wā he mea nui i Aotearoa, i paingia hoki ngā nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua, ā, ka whakaputaina tonutia te Otago Witness tae noa ki te tau 1932.
Publication.Essay:
The Otago Witness was a significant example of the illustrated weekly newspapers that were a popular and important form of publication in New Zealand in the 19th and early 20th centuries. They were particularly popular in isolated rural areas where poor access prevented newspapers being delivered daily. These papers were the main medium for published illustrations and photographs. Others examples include the Weekly News (Auckland) and the New Zealand Free Lance (Wellington).

The Witness began in 1851 as a four page, fortnightly newspaper and started publishing weekly in August that year. The Witness took its title from the Edinburgh Witness, which was a popular journal in Scotland. In its early years the Witness took a high moral stance. However it was actually insulting, vindictive and highly biased in the way that it helped William Cargill (leader of the Otago Association, the branch of the New Zealand Company responsible for the initial settlement of Otago), fight his political opponents. Over time it settled down and became an inoffensive journal that was widely distributed, particularly in the South Island.

At first the Otago Witness struggled to pay its way. In 1855 the paper had only 210 subscribers but by 1864 the paper was printing 4,500 copies a week. The newspaper's fortunes were secured in the 1860s by the influx of people into Otago looking for gold. The Witness also published an edition especially for the goldfields.

During this time the paper's popularity was further improved by introducing illustrations. Initially these were engravings but around 1900 the Witness started using photographs on an insert. The illustrated content increased considerably over time.

Although the Witness was probably the most conservative of the pictorial weeklies it provided an important outlet for New Zealand writers by regularly publishing poetry and short stories.

Like the other New Zealand weekly newspapers the Witness was adversely affected by the increasing development of rural land as well as competition from broadcasting. The paper stopped publication in 1932.

He tino tauira te Otago Witness o ngā nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua, he tūmomo whakaputanga nui, i paingia hoki i Aotearoa i te rau tau 1800-1899 me te tīmatanga o te rau tau 1900-1999. He mea tino pai i ngā wāhi taratahi nā te koretake o ngā rori i kore ai e taea te tuku ia rā. Ko ēnei nūpepa te mea nui mō te whakaputa pikitia, whakaahua hoki. Ko ētahi atu tauira ko te Weekly News (ākarana) me te New Zealand Free Lance (Pōneke).

Ka tīmata te Witness i te tau 1851, e whā ōna whārangi, he nūpepa o ia rua wiki, ā, ka tīmata te whakaputa ia wiki i te marama o Here-turi-kōkā i taua tau. Nō te Edinburgh Witness tōna ingoa, he nūpepa i paingia i Kotirana. I ōna tau tīmatanga, he tūnga whanonga tika teitei rawa atu tōna. Heoi, he whakaiti, he mauāhara, he kino nō te rītaha ki te tautoko i a William Cargill (te kaihautū o te Otago Association, arā, te peka o te Kamupene o Niu Tīreni nāna te whakanohonoho tuatahi o te Pākehā i ōtākou) me tāna whakataetae ki ōna hoariri tōrangapū. Nāwai rā ka tau te puehu, ka huri hei nūpepa ngāwari i whakaputaina whānui, ki te Waipounamu rā anō.

I te tīmatanga he uaua te utu a te Otago Witness i āna nama. I te tau 1855, e 210 noa iho ana kaiutu, engari i te tau 1864 e 4,500 ngā kape kei te tāngia i ia wiki. Ka mau i te tekau tau mai i 1860 nā te urutanga mai o Hōpara i ngā pānuitangata ki ōtākou ki te kimi kōura. He putanga ake anō tā te Witness mā ngā whīra kōura.

I taua wā i kaha ake te paingia o te nūpepa i te whakauru whakaahua. I te tīmatanga he mea āhua whakairo, ēngari i te tau 1900 pea, ka tīmata te whakauru whārangi whakaahua. Nāwai rā ka kaha haere ake ngā whakaahua.

He ahakoa ko te Witness te nūpepa tino whakatūpato o ngā nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua, i a ia tonu tētahi wāhi nui mō ngā kaituhi o Aotearoa i tāna whakaputa whiti me te pitopito kōrero.

I āhua raruraru anō te Witness, pērā me ētahi atu o ngā nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua i Aotearoa, i te kaha ake o te ahuwhenua me te whakataetae mai a te whakapāho irirangi. Ka mutu tana whakaputa i te tau 1932.

Publication.Title: Progress
Publication.Title-alternate: Progress : with which is incorporated the scientific New Zealander, N.Z. Building Progress
Publication.Description: N.Z. Building Progress was New Zealand’s first architectural periodical. Published in Wellington from 1905 to 1924 and heavily illustrated with photos, drawings and plans, it is an essential resource for the study of architecture and building in New Zealand in the early twentieth century.

Ko te N.Z. Building Progress te hautaka hoahoanga whare tuatahi o Niu Tireni. He mea pānui i Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara mai i te tau 1905 ki te tau 1924, he mea whakaahua nui hoki ki te whakaahua, ki te hoahoa me te mahere, koia tonu tētahi rauemi tino waiwai hei ako i te hoahoanga me te hanganga whare i Niu Tireni i ngā tau tīmata o te rautau rua tekau.
Publication.Essay:
N.Z. Building Progress was New Zealand’s first architectural periodical. Published in Wellington from 1905 to 1924 and heavily illustrated with photos, drawings and plans, it is an essential resource for the study of architecture and building in New Zealand in the early twentieth century.

It was initially published by Wellington patent attorneys, Baldwin & Rayward under the title of Progress. Its first issue in 1905 promised to "treat of progress in engineering, processes, inventions, industrial work and economics as applied to any of these subjects."

In 1910 the magazine was taken over by Harry Tombs (1874-1966). Tombs, son of Whitcombe & Tombs founder George Tombs, was a well-known printer, patron of the arts and publisher of fine arts periodicals. Progress was the first of his magazines; the best known was probably Art in New Zealand (1928-44).

Under Tombs Progress focused on architecture and building; this was signalled by a change of title in 1914 to N.Z.Building Progress. This specialisation was identified by the publishers in the final issue (April 1924) as one of the reasons why they were suspending publication. It was intimated that publication would resume when "conditions become more favourable". However Progress was not restarted. Instead, in 1926, Tombs published another architectural magazine, New Zealand Architectural and Building Review. This lasted until Tombs started Art in New Zealand two years later.

Ko te N.Z. Building Progress te hautaka hoahoanga whare tuatahi o Niu Tireni. He mea pānui i Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara mai i te tau 1905 ki te tau 1924, he mea whakaahua nui hoki ki te whakaahua, ki te hoahoa me te mahere, koia tonu tētahi rauemi tino waiwai hei ako i te hoahoanga me te hanganga whare i Niu Tireni i ngā tau tīmata o te rautau rua tekau.

I whakaputaina tuatahitia e ngā rōia whakamana ārai o Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara, e Baldwin & Rayward mā, i raro i te ingoa Progress. I oati te tānga tuatahi o 1905 ki te "whāki i te nekenga whakamua o te pūkahatanga, te tukanga, te tenenga, ngā mahi ahumahi, me te ohaoha e hāngai ana ki tētahi o ēnei take".

I te tau 1910 ka taumanutia te NZ Building Progress e Harry Tombs (1874-1966). Ko Tombs (te tama o te kaiwhakaū o Whitcombe & Tombs, a George Tombs), tētahi kaiwhakatā rongonui, he kaitautoko o ngā mahi toi, he kaiwhakaputa hoki i ngā hautaka toi. Ko Progress te tuatahi o āna hautaka; ko te mea tino rongonui pea ko Art in New Zealand (1928-44).

I raro i a Tombs ko te hoahoanga me te hanganga whare te arotahi o Progress, otirā i tohua hoki tēnei mā te whakawhitinga o te ingoa ki NZ Building Progress i te tau 1914. I roto i te tānga whakamutunga (o Paenga-whāwhā 1924), i tūtohutia e ngā kaiwhakaputa ko tēnei whakawhāititanga tētahi take i te whakatārewatia e rātou te hautaka. I whakaatu noa ka tīmata anō te pānuitanga ina "pai haere anō ngā āhuatanga". Heoi, kīhai te Progress i tīmata anō. Engari, i te tau 1926, ka whakaputaina e Tombs tētahi atu hautaka hoahoanga whare, New Zealand Architectural and Building Review. I whakaputaina tonutia tēnei tae noa ki te tīmatanga a Tombs i te Art in New Zealand e rua tau i muri mai.

Publication.Title: Poverty Bay Herald
Publication.Title-alternate: Poverty Bay Herald and East Coast News Letter, Gisborne Herald
Publication.Description: The Poverty Bay Herald was first published in Gisborne on 5 January 1874. It is still published today, under the name Gisborne Herald, and is one of the last remaining privately operated daily newspapers in New Zealand.

I whakaputaina tuatahitia te Poverty Bay Herald i Tūranga i te rā 5 o Kohitātea 1874. Kei te whakaputaina tonu i tēnei rā, ko te ingoa ko te Gisborne Herald, ā, koia tētahi o ngā nūpepa mōrehu o Aotearoa kei te whakahaeretia motuhake.
Publication.Essay:
The owners of Napier's Hawke's Bay Herald, in partnership with others, set up the Poverty Bay Herald. The first issue of this bi-weekly morning paper was published in Gisborne on 5 January 1874. When the paper started publication Gisborne already had a newspaper, the Poverty Bay Standard (1872-1883).

Like most New Zealand newspapers in the 19th century, it took the Herald some time to get established. In 1879 the paper nearly went into liquidation when the City of Glasgow Bank failed. However the Herald started to flourish in the 1880s. It proved too strong for its competitor, the Standard, which folded in 1883.

The outright acquisition of the paper in 1884 by Allan Ramsay Muir gave it stability. Muir's father had worked on the earliest New Zealand newspaper, the New Zealand Gazette as well as being one of the founders of the Wellington Independent (one of the country's most distinctive papers). Muir started working at the Herald in 1880 as a printer. He became a partner in 1883 and sole owner the year after. His descendants are still involved in the management of the paper today.

There were a number of other papers published in Gisborne before 1940. The most noteworthy is the Gisborne Times (1896-1938) but none of them were able to compete with the Herald. In 1938 the Herald absorbed the Times and the following year the paper changed its name to the Gisborne Herald.

The paper is still published and is one of the last privately operated daily newspapers in New Zealand.

Nā ngā rangatira o te Hawke's Bay Herald o Ahuriri, me ētahi atu, te Poverty Bay Herald i whakatū. Ka whakaputaina te tukunga tuatahi o tēnei nūpepa o te ata, e rua Hōpara i ngā pānuitanga i ia wiki, i Tūranga i te 5 o Kohitātea 1874. I tana tīmatanga ki te puta, i a Tūranga kē tētahi nūpepa, ko te Poverty Bay Standard (1872-1883).

Pērā me te nuinga o ngā nūpepa o Aotearoa i te rau tau 1800-1899, ka āhua roa te mau pai o te Herald. I te tau 1879, ka tata toremi te pepa i te hinganga o te pēke City of Glasgow Bank. Heoi anō, ka tīmata te puāwai i te tekau tau mai i 1880. He kaha rawa ia mō tōna hoa whakataetae, te Standard, i katia i te tau 1883.

Nā te rironga tonu atu o te pepa i a Allan Ramsay Muir i te tau 1884 i pūmau ai. I te mahi te pāpā o Muir mā tētahi o ngā nūpepa tuatahi o Aotearoa, te New Zealand Gazette, koia hoki tētahi o ngā kaiwhakaū o te Wellington Independent (tētahi o ngā nūpepa tino kōhure o te motu). Ka tīmata te mahi a Muir i te Herald i te tau 1880 hei kaitā. Ka huri hei hoa kaipakihi ia i te tau 1883, ā, i te tau o muri mai koia anahe te rangatira. E mahi tonu ana ōna uri i roto i ngā whakahaere o te nūpepa i tēnei rā.

He pepa anō i whakaputaina i Tūranga i mua i te tau 1940. Ko te mea nui o ēnei ko te Gisborne Times (1896-1938) engari kāore i taea te whakataetae ki te Herald. I te tau 1938 ka tōia mai te Times i raro i a ia, ā, nō te tau o muri mai ka hurihia te ingoa ki te Gisborne Herald.

E whakaputa tonutia ana te nūpepa nei, koia hoki tētahi o ngā nūpepa o ia rā i Aotearoa kei te whakahaeretia motuhaketia.

Publication.Title: Pukekohe & Waiuku Times
Publication.Description: The Pukekohe & Waiuku Times (later known as the Franklin Times), one of South Auckland’s longest-lasting local newspapers, was published in Pukekohe from 1912 to 1971. On 8 March 1912 Pukekohe businessmen Richard Eames and William Cargill brought out the first issue of the Pukekohe & Waiuku Times. The new tabloid was just four pages long and came out once a week. As demand grew it increased in size and frequency, becoming bi-weekly from 1 October 1912 and tri-weekly from 5 July 1915.

I whakaputaina te Pukekohe & Waiuku Times (i mōhiotia i muri mai nei ko te Franklin Times), tētahi o ngā nūpepa ā-rohe roa rawa tōna puta ki te ao o ngā pepa o Tāmaki-ki-te-tonga, i Pukekohe mai i 1912 ki 1971. I te 8 Māehe 1912 nā ēnei tāngata kaipakihi o Pukekohe nā Richard Eames rāua ko William Cargill i whakaputa te putanga tuatahi o te Pukekohe & Waiuku Times. Ko te niupepa iti i puta e whā whārangi noa iho te roa, ā, kotahi te putanga i te wiki. Ka piki haere te hiakai o te tangata ki te nūpepa, ka mātotoru haere te pepa, ka auau kē atu ngā putanga, arā, e rua putanga i te wiki mai i te 1 o Oketopa 1912, ā, e toru putanga i te wiki mai i te 5 Hūrae 1915.
Publication.Essay:
The Pukekohe & Waiuku Times (later known as the Franklin Times), one of South Auckland’s longest-lasting local newspapers, was published in Pukekohe from 1912 to 1971.

On 8 March 1912 Pukekohe businessmen Richard Eames and William Cargill brought out the first issue of the Pukekohe & Waiuku Times. The new tabloid was just four pages long and came out once a week. As demand grew it increased in size and frequency, becoming bi-weekly from 1 October 1912 and tri-weekly from 5 July 1915.

The Franklin Printing & Publishing Company acquired the Pukekohe & Waiuku Times in November 1914. The new owners changed the title to the Franklin & Pukekohe Times on 2 September 1919, then to the Franklin Times on 1 February 1921.

Despite the changes of title, the volume numbering remained consistent throughout.

The changes of title in part reflected broadening coverage. The original masthead shows the paper aimed to include Pukekohe, Waiuku, Mercer, Tuakau, Drury, Papakura and Bombay news. It then sought to reach into all parts of Franklin County. For some years it included a Papakura section on the back page, and sometimes also included Otahuhu and Manurewa news. In later years coverage reached southward across the Waikato River to include news from the northern parts of Raglan County.

A short-lived companion title, the Pukekohe & Otahuhu Times came out between 13 April 1917 and 28 December 1917. A later companion title, the Tuakau and District Times, lasted from 10 March 1932 to 14 September 1939. In November 1964 the Franklin Times absorbed its almost equally long-lived small-town rival, the Waiuku News. (The 1965 masthead read: 'The Franklin Times, incorporating the Waiuku News. Circulating in the whole of Franklin County and parts of Raglan and Manukau Counties').

The last issue of the Franklin Times came out on 19 January 1971. It was then merged with the South Auckland News Advertiser to form the Franklin Times Advertiser. However, after a subsequent merger with the South Auckland Courier, the Franklin Times was revived as a stand-alone title between April 1974 and July 1979.

I whakaputaina te Pukekohe & Waiuku Times (i mōhiotia i muri mai nei ko te Franklin Times), tētahi o ngā nūpepa ā-rohe roa rawa tōna puta ki te ao o ngā pepa o Tāmaki-ki-te-tonga, i Pukekohe mai i 1912 ki 1971.

I te 8 Māehe 1912 nā ēnei tāngata kaipakihi o Pukekohe nā Richard Eames rāua ko William Cargill i whakaputa te putanga tuatahi o te Pukekohe & Waiuku Times. Ko te niupepa iti i puta e whā whārangi noa iho te roa, ā, kotahi te putanga i te wiki. Ka piki haere te hiakai o te tangata ki te nūpepa, ka mātotoru haere te pepa, ka auau kē atu ngā putanga, arā, e rua putanga i te wiki mai i te 1 o Oketopa 1912, ā, e toru putanga i te wiki mai i te 5 Hūrae 1915.

Nā te Franklin Printing & Publishing Company i hoko te Pukekohe & Waiuku Times i te marama o Nōema 1914. I hurihia te taitara e ngā rangatira hou ki te Franklin & Pukekohe Times i te 2 Hepetema 1919, ā, i muri ki te Franklin Times i te 1 Pēpuere 1921.

Ahakoa ēnei hurihanga o te taitara, kāore i whati te rere whakatepe o ngā tātai o tēnā pukapuka, o tēnā pukapuka, mai rā anō.

Ko ēnei hurihanga o te taitara i whakaata i te whānui haeretanga o ngā purongo. E ai ki te panekōrero tuatahi o te pepa ko tāna whāinga kia kapi katoa ngā rongo kōrero o Pukekohe, o Waiuku, o Mercer, o Tuakau, o Drury, o Papakura me Bombay. I muri mai, i whai te pepa kia whātoro ia ki ngā wāhi katoa o Franklin County. Mō ētahi tau i uru mai tētahi wāhanga kōrero mō Papakura i te whārangi o muri, ā, i ētahi wā anō i uru hoki ko ngā rongo o Otahuhu me Manurewa. I ngā tau o muri mai i toro whaka-te-tonga ngā pūrongo ki te Awa o Waikato kia uru mai ko ngā pitopito kōrero mai i ngā rohe whaka-te-raki o Raglan County.

I puta mai hoki tētahi nūpepa whakahoa, te Pukekohe & Otahuhu Times he nupepa i puta i waenga i te 13 Aperira 1917 me te 28 Tīhema 1917. Tērā hoki tētahi taitara whakahoa o muri mai, te Tuakau and District Times, mai i te 10 Māehe 1932 ki te 14 o Hepetema 1939. I te marama o Nōema 1964 i horomia e Franklin Times tōna hoa tauwhāinga ā-tāone iti, he rite tonu ki a ia te roa i puta ai, te Waiuku News. (Tērā te kōrero a te Panekōrero o 1965: ‘The Franklin Times, incorporating the Waiuku News. Circulating in the whole of Franklin County and parts of Raglan and Manukau Counties’).

I puta mai te putanga whakamutunga o te Franklin Times i te 19 Hānuere 1971. Kātahi ka whakahanumitia ki roto i te South Auckland News Advertiser kia tū mai te Franklin Times Advertiser. Ahakoa rā, i muri i tētahi whakahanumitanga ki te South Auckland Courier, i whakaorangia mai te Franklin Times hei taitara tū motuhake i waenga i te marama o Āperira 1974 me te marama o Hūrae 1979.

Publication.Essay:
Australian Charles de La Roche began the newspaper in 1901. After his first foray into newspaper ownership with the short-lived Tauranga Herald in 1899, he moved to Warkworth and quickly established a successful real estate business. He also bought a poorly performing paper, the Gazette, ostensibly serving the Waitemata and Kaipara areas, and used its press to launch Warkworth’s first newspaper. The masthead read Rodney and Otamatea Times, but the secondary heading, Waitemata and Kaipara Gazette, suggested de La Roche had hopes of retaining some readership there. It did not help his cause that the first issue made no mention of either area.

The weekly Rodney and Otamatea Times, a four-page broadsheet, was printed on a Furnival flat-bed press. Two casual workers shared the job of turning the large wheel by hand while the printer fed sheets of newsprint to the rollers. The newspaper, published on Fridays, sold for 3d a copy, and the annual subscription was eight shillings. The Times soon acquired a reputation for its reporting and comment on local politics, but sporting enthusiasts found coverage disappointing.

After de La Roche sold the newspaper to A H Mason late in 1903, his real estate and property activities thrived. He later edited the Manukau Gazette in Onehunga where he retired, dying in 1938.

The Times had a number of other owners before Wairarapa printer William Cook bought the paper in 1917, the beginning of a three generation publishing dynasty that was to last 88 years. William Cook was editor until his death in 1942. His son Elsley, a former banker and World War One veteran, succeeded him in the editor’s chair and in running the company. Following his unexpected death in 1955, aged 62, his wife Marjorie headed the company until 1976, buying two opposition papers and withstanding a takeover bid from Wilson and Horton. Their son, Tony Cook, took over as managing director and, converting to web-offset, significantly developed the company’s commercial printing activities. The Times shifted from a paid subscription to free distribution model.

In 2005 the Cook family sold the twice-weekly Rodney Times to Fairfax New Zealand.

Nā tētahi tangata nō Ahitereiria nā Charles de La Roche te niupepa i tīmata i te tau 1901. I muri i tāna hounga tuatahi ki ngā mahi pupuri niupepa, arā i te Tauranga Herald i ora mō te wā poto noa iho i te tau 1899, ka nuku ia ki Warkworth, ā, he tere tonu tana whakatū umanga hoko whenua, hoko kāinga whai painga. Ka hokona e ia tētahi niupepa āhua korekaha, e kīia nei te Gazette, tōna tikanga hei niupepa mō ngā rohe o Waitemata me Kaipara, ā, ka whakamahia e ia tāna mīhini tā hei whakarewa i te niupepa tuatahi o Warkworth. Ko te taitara ko te Rodney and Otamatea Times, engari ko te taitara o raro ko te Waitemata and Kaipara Gazette, e whakaaro ai pea te tangata i te wawata a de La Roche kia kitea he kaipānui i taua takiwā. Hei whakararu pea i tāna mahi, kāore he kupu kotahi i te putanga tuatahi mō tētahi o aua rohe e rua.

He rau whānui, he whā whārangi hoki te niupepa ā-wiki Rodney and Otamatea Times, i tāia ki tētahi mīhini pāraharaha Furnival. Tokorua ngā kaimahi mahi harangotengote i kawe ngā mahi hurihuri ā-ringa i te wīra nui, i te kaitā e whāngai ana i ngā pepa niupepa pātea ki roto i ngā rango. Puta ai te niupepa ia Paraire, ko te utu he 3d (toru kapa) mō te kape kotahi, ko te utu ā-tau e waru herengi. Ka piki te ingoa o te Times mō ana mahi kawe kōrero me āna whakaputanga kupu mō ngā take o te rohe, engari kāore i tino nui ngā kōrero mō ngā mahi hākinakina mā te hunga ngākaunui ki ēnā mahi.

I muri i te hokonga a de La Roche i te niupepa ki A H Mason i ngā marama whakamutunga o 1903, ka tupu tuawhiti tonu āna mahi hoko whenua, hoko rawa. Nō muri ka noho ia hei ētita mō te Manukau Gazette i Onehunga i tuku ai ia i tana tūranga, ka mate rawa i te tau 1938.

Arā atu anō ngā rangatira o te Times i mua i te hokonga o te pepa e tētahi kaitā nō Wairarapa e William Cook i te tau 1917, i tīmata ai tētahi umanga tā niupepa tuku iho i toitū tonu mō te 88 tau. I noho tonu ko William Cook te ētita taea noatia tōna matenga i te tau 1942. Ka piki tana tama a Elsley, he kaimahi pēke i mua, he toa tū taua i te Pakanga Tuatahi o Te Ao, ki tōna tūru ētita, kaiwhakahaere hoki i te kamupene. Nō muri i tana matenga ohorere i te tau 1955, e 62 ōna tau, ka eke tāna wahine a Marjorie ki te tūnga kaiwhakahaere i te kamupene tae noa ki 1976. I huri ia ki te hoko i ētahi pepa tauwhāinga e rua, ā, i tū pakari hoki ia ki te ārai i tētahi kōkiri hoko i te umanga nā Wilson and Horton. I riro nā tā rāua tama, Tony Cook, i whakahaere te kamupene hei kaihautū whakahaere, ā, ka hurihia e ia ki te tikanga web-offset, nā ana mahi i tino whanake nui ai ngā mahi tā arumoni o te kamupene. I huri te Times mai i te tētahi niupepa utu ā-tau ki tētahi niupepa tuari utu-kore.

Nō te tau 2005 ka hokona e te whānau Cook te niupepa rua-wiki o te Rodney Times ki Fairfax New Zealand.
