Publication.Title: Southland Times
Publication.Description: The Times was established to oppose the Southern News (later the Southland Daily News), another Invercargill newspaper. The Southern News had begun publication the year before and was regarded as a liberal paper. The Times represented more conservative opinions. 1862 also was a good time to start a newspaper in Invercargill because the town was prospering due to the discovery of gold in the Wakatipu that year. Invercargill was the main supply base for the goldfield.

I whakaū ai te Times hei tautohe ki te Southern News (nō muri mai ko te Southland Daily News), arā, tētahi atu nūpepa i Waihopai. Kua tīmata hoki te tānga o te Southern News i te tau i mua atu, ā, i tirohia hoki hei nūpepa whakaaro whānui. I tū te Times hei māngai mō ngā whakaaro tūpato. He wā pai tonu te tau 1862 hei tīmata i tētahi nūpepa i Waihopai, nōtemea i te tōnui haere te tāone i te kitenga o te kōura i Wakatipu i taua tau anō. Ko Waihopai te pokapū matua o ngā putunga mō te pārae kōura.
Publication.Essay:
The Southland Times has been published in Invercargill since 1862. Since 1968 it has been Invercargill’s only daily newspaper.

The Times was set up by Gerard George Fitzgerald, John T. Downes and Charles Reynolds and published its first issue on 12 November 1862 under the title of the Invercargill Times.

The Times was established to oppose the Southern News (later the Southland Daily News), another Invercargill newspaper. The Southern News had begun publication the year before and was regarded as a liberal paper. The Times represented more conservative opinions. 1862 also was a good time to start a newspaper in Invercargill because the town was prospering due to the discovery of gold in the Wakatipu that year. Invercargill was the main supply base for the goldfield.

The history of the paper in the 1860s and 70s is similar to that of other newspapers in New Zealand at the time. The paper experienced financial difficulties, frequent changes of owner and the loss of plant and offices due to fire. The Times ceased publication for several months in 1864 after a fire destroyed its office. When it resumed publication in June that year it was under the new title of the Southland Times.

In 1875 the Times became a daily. In 1878 fire destroyed the newspaper office again. As in 1864, the Times’ rival, the Southland News, helped the paper continue to publish by allowing the Times to use their presses. During this period the Times published a weekly edition for its rural readers; the Weekly Times ran from 1866 to 1933.

In the 1880s the Times achieved stability and prosperity. This was due in large part to the very capable management provided by the paper’s owner, Robert Gilmour. Gilmour, who had assumed control of the paper in 1879, had been involved with the press in Invercargill since 1864. He had briefly owned the Times in 1869, before taking over the Southland News. In the mid-1870s he had moved back to Scotland for several years. Upon returning to Invercargill in 1879 he acquired the Times for a second time.

The Gilmour family owned and managed the paper until 1984, when it was sold to Independent Newspapers Limited.

One of the features of the Times and one of the main reasons that it has endured is that it stayed abreast of developments in newspaper technology. In the 1900s it upgraded its plant twice with the introduction of linotypes and then rotary presses. It was the first newspaper in New Zealand outside of the main centres to employ rotary presses. In the 1970s and 80s the Times was one of the first papers in New Zealand to use computer-driven newspaper technology.

The Times approach to technological change is probably one of the main reasons that it eventually overtook its old rival the Southland Daily News. The Times acquired the News in 1967 and in 1968 replaced it with an evening edition of its own. The Times evening edition ceased in 1976.

Kua tāngia te Southland Times ki Waihopai (Invercargill) mai i te tau 1862. Koia anake tō Waihopai nūpepa ā-rangi mai i te tau 1968.

Nā Gerard George Fitzgerald rātou ko John T. Downes, ko Charles Reynolds te Times i whakaū, ā, i whakatā tōna tānga tuatahi i te 12 o Whiringa-ā-rangi 1862 i raro i te ingoa o te Invercargill Times.

I whakaū ai te Times hei tautohe ki te Southern News (nō muri mai ko te Southland Daily News), arā, tētahi atu nūpepa i Waihopai. Kua tīmata hoki te tānga o te Southern News i te tau i mua atu, ā, i tirohia hoki hei nūpepa whakaaro whānui. I tū te Times hei māngai mō ngā whakaaro tūpato. He wā pai tonu te tau 1862 hei tīmata i tētahi nūpepa i Waihopai, nōtemea i te tōnui haere te tāone i te kitenga o te kōura i Wakatipu i taua tau anō. Ko Waihopai te pokapū matua o ngā putunga mō te pārae kōura.

He rite tonu te hītori o te nūpepa, i roto i te huinga tau mai i 1860 ki te 1880, ki tō ētahi atu nūpepa o Aotearoa i taua wā. I mōhio te nūpepa ki ngā raruraru moni, ki ngā whakawhitinga rangatira, ki te ngaromanga o te taonga, o te tari hoki ki te ahi. I whakamutua te tānga o te Times ētahi marama maha i te tau 1864 i muri i te ngaromanga o tōna tari ki tētahi ahi. Nō ka tīmata anō tōna tānga i te marama o Pipiri o taua tau, i raro kē ia i te ingoa o te Southland Times.

I te tau 1875 ka meinga hei nūpepa ā-rangi te Times. I te tau 1878 ka kāia anō te tari o te nūpepa e te ahi. Pērā anō i taka i te tau 1864, nā te tāwhai o te Times, arā, nā te Southland News a ia i āwhina kia haere tonu tana tānga mā te tukunga kia whakamahia e te Times ō rātou perehi. I taua wā hoki, i tāngia e te Times tētahi tānga ā-wiki mā ōna kaipānui o te taiwhenua; rere ana te Weekly Times mai i te tau 1866 ki 1933.

I te tekau tau mai i 1880 i tino ū ai te Times i whiwhi hoki i te tōnuitanga. He huanga matua tēnei nā te whakahaere tino pai tonu a Ropata Gilmour, te tangata nāna nei te nūpepa. I whai wāhi hoki a Gilmour, nāna rā i tango i te whakahaerenga o te Times i te tau 1879, ki te mahi tā nūpepa i Waihopai mai te tau 1864. Nāna hoki te Times mō tētahi wā poto i te tau 1869, i mua i tana taumanu i te Southland News. Tae rawa a waenganui tonu o te tekau tau mai i 1870, kua hoki anō a ia ki Koterana mō ētahi tau. Nō tana hokinga ki Waihopai i te tau 1879 ka hoko tuarua mai ai ia i te Times.

Nā te whānau Gilmour te nūpepa, nā rātou hoki i whakahaere tae noa te tau 1984, nā ka hokona atu ki te kamupene Independent Newspapers Limited.

Ko tētahi āhuatanga o te Times, he take matua hoki tēnei i matatū ai ia, ko tana haere upane tahi ai me ngā whanaketanga o te hangarau tānga nūpepa. I ngā tau mai i 1900 e rua āna whakahoutanga i ōna mīhini, arā, mā te whakamahi i te perehi tā ā-rārangi (Linotype) i te tuatahi, i kō atu o te perehi hurihuri. Koia tonu te nūpepa tuatahi o Aotearoa, i waho tonu o ngā tāone matua, ki te whakamahi i te perehi hurihuri. I te rua tekau tau mai i 1970 ki te 1990, ko te Times tētahi o ngā nūpepa tuatahi o Aotearoa ki te whakamahi i te hangarau tānga nā te rorohiko i pana.

Ko tō te Times āro ki ngā whitinga hangarau tētahi take matua pea i mahue rawa i a ia tōna tāwhai tawhito, a te Southland Daily News. I riro te News i a te Times i te tau 1967, ā, i te tau 1968 i whakakapia te News i tētahi tānga ahiahi ōna ake. I whakamutua te tānga ahiahi o te Times i te tau 1976.

Publication.Title: Sun
Publication.Description: In 1912, Edward C Huie resigned from editorship of the Press Company’s Evening News in Christchurch, frustrated that the proprietors were not interested in the young Australian’s ideas about livelier journalism and layout. The Evening News’ primary role was to carry news and advertisements too late for that day’s Press. The 36-year-old Huie announced shortly afterwards his intention to launch a third evening paper, a competitor to the Evening News and the Lyttelton Times’ Star.

I te tau 1912, i tukua e Edward C Huie tāna tūranga etita mō te nūpepa o te Evening News a te Press Company o Ōtautahi, i runga i tana manawapā kāore ngā rangatira o te nūpepa i aronui ki ngā whakaaro o tēnei taitama nō Āhitereiria. Ko tana hiahia kia whakahoutia te nūpepa hei whakapiki i te pai me te hāngai o ngā pūrongo me te āhua o te nūpepa. Ko te mahi matua ia o te Evening News he kawe i ngā pitopito kōrero me ngā pānui kua tūreiti mō te Press o taua rā. Nā te tangata nei nā Huie, 36 ōna tau, i whakapuaki tana hiahia ki te kōkiri i tētahi nūpepa ā-ahiahi tuatoru, hei hoa tauwhāinga mō te Evening News me te Star a te Lyttelton Times.
Publication.Essay:
In 1912, Edward C Huie resigned from editorship of the Press Company’s Evening News in Christchurch, frustrated that the proprietors were not interested in the young Australian’s ideas about livelier journalism and layout. The Evening News’ primary role was to carry news and advertisements too late for that day’s Press.

The 36-year-old Huie announced shortly afterwards his intention to launch a third evening paper, a competitor to the Evening News and the Lyttelton Times’ Star. In October 1912 the NZPA reported that the Canterbury Publishing Company had been registered with a capital of £75,000 (about $11.75 million today). The report noted that Huie would be editor and the paper’s backers were ‘prominent supporters of the Reform [precursor to National] party’.

The Sun, modelled on London’s Daily Mail, without the British popular press’s sensationalism, was launched in February 1914. It was an immediate success with Christchurch readers and advertisers. Its reporting was energetic and there was much more illustration than common in New Zealand dailies of the time. It also gave considerable encouragement to poets, short story writers and essayists. The Evening News closed in 1917 and the Sun was soon outstripping the Star in circulation.

Buoyed by this success, Huie convinced his directors to enter the lucrative Auckland newspaper market. A new company, Sun Newspapers Ltd, acquired the property of the Canterbury Publishing Company, and in March 1927 Auckland’s Sun was launched. Its journalistic approach appealed as much to Aucklanders as it had to Christchurch newspaper readers but the establishment costs in a much larger market and the deepening Depression were complicating factors. In 1929, the Brett Company, publishers of the Auckland Star, took over the Lyttelton Times Company. The merged company, New Zealand Newspapers Ltd, now owned Huie’s Auckland and Christchurch evening competitors. The ensuing pressure was too much and the Auckland Sun’s short, colourful life ended late in 1930 when New Zealand Newspapers bought the paper for about £62,000 ($6 million today.)

The pressure intensified on Huie and the Sun in Christchurch, with the three newspaper companies discussing and rejecting a range of mergers and takeovers predicated on tacit agreement that four dailies were not sustainable, and one morning and one evening paper was desirable. In November 1934, both the Sun and Star halved their per copy price to one penny, with the Press following suit and picking up circulation that further weakened its evening competitors. With its losses mounting, the Sun directors – despite Huie’s desire to fight on – agreed to sell to New Zealand Newspapers in late May 1935. In early July the first issue of the Christchurch Star-Sun appeared. The evening daily retained this name until 1958 and was the Christchurch Star when it closed in 1991.

From 1936 to 1939, Edward Huie was London representative of The Press. In 1940, he purchased, on behalf of a private company, the Hawke’s Bay Daily Mail, then in receivership. He managed and edited the newspaper until daily publication ended in June 1941. He died in Sydney in 1967.

I te tau 1912, i tukua e Edward C Huie tāna tūranga etita mō te nūpepa o te Evening News a te Press Company o Ōtautahi, i runga i tana manawapā kāore ngā rangatira o te nūpepa i aronui ki ngā whakaaro o tēnei taitama nō Āhitereiria. Ko tana hiahia kia whakahoutia te nūpepa hei whakapiki i te pai me te hāngai o ngā pūrongo me te āhua o te nūpepa. Ko te mahi matua ia o te Evening News he kawe i ngā pitopito kōrero me ngā pānui kua tūreiti mō te Press o taua rā.

Nā te tangata nei nā Huie, 36 ōna tau, i whakapuaki tana hiahia ki te kōkiri i tētahi nūpepa ā-ahiahi tuatoru, hei hoa tauwhāinga mō te Evening News me te Star a te Lyttelton Times. Nō te marama o Oketopa 1912 ka whakapuaki te NZPA kua rēhitatia te Canterbury Publishing Company me ōna moni punga £75,000 (tata ki te $11.75 miriona i ēnei rā). E ai ki te pūrongo ka noho ko Huie hei etita, ā, ko ngā tino kaihautū o te nūpepa' ‘he kaitautoko hira nō te rōpū tōrangapū Reform [te matua tēnei o te rōpū Nāhinara]’.

I whakarewaina te Sun i te marama o Pēpuere 1914. He mea whakatauira mai ki runga i te Daily Mail o Rānana, engari kāore i pērā rawa tana wairua whakapātaritari. I tino rawe te nūpepa ki ngā kaipānui me ngā kaiwhakatairanga o Ōtautahi. He hihiri ana mahi kawe kōrero, ā, he nui noa atu ana pikitia i ō te nuinga o ngā nūpepa ā-rā o Aotearoa o aua wā. He kaha hoki te nūpepa ki te poipoi i ngā kaitito ruriruri, i ngā kaituhi pūrākau poto me ngā kaituhi tuhinga kaupapa. I kati te Evening News i te tau 1917 ā, kāore i roa i muri mai kei mua noa atu te nūpepa te Sun i te nūpepa o te Star mō te maha o ngā kaipānui.

I runga i ēnei hua tino pai, ka akiaki a Huie i ōna hoa kaihautū kia kuhu ki te mākete nūpepa moni nui o Tāmaki-makau-rau. Nā tētahi kamupene hou nā Sun Newspapers Ltd, i hoko ngā rawa o te Canterbury Publishing Company, ā, i te marama o Māehe 1927 ka whakarewaina te Sun o Tāmaki-makau-rau. Ko āna tikanga kawe kōrero i tino pai ki ngā kaipānui o Tāmaki-makau-rau, rite tonu ki ngā kaipānui i Ōtautahi, engari he mea uaua ngā utunga mō te whakatū i a ia i taua mākete nui kē atu, waihoki ngā taimahatanga o te Tūpuhi Nui o te Ao, i te mātotoru haere ōna whakawhiu i taua wā. I te tau 1929, nā te Brett Company, te kaiwhakaputa o te Auckland Star, i piki mai hei rangatira mō te Lyttelton Times Company. Ka noho ko te kamupene hanumi, New Zealand Newspapers , Ltd, hei rangatira mō ngā hoa tauwhāinga i Tāmaki me Ōtautahi ki ngā nūpepa ā-ahiahi o Huie. He kaha rawa te tāmitanga a aua hoa tauwhāinga, ā, ka mutu te oranga ngahau, te oranga poto o te Auckland Sun i ngā marama whakamutunga o 1930 i te hokonga a New Zealand Newspapers i te nūpepa mō te takiwā o te £62,000 ($6 miriona i ngā moni o nāianei.)

Ka piki rā te tāmitanga ki a Huie me te Sun i Ōtautahi, me te noho o ngā kamupene nūpepa e toru ki te whakawhiti kōrero me te whakakāhore i te huhua o ngā whakahanumitanga me ngā kōkiri hoko i runga i te kirimana ahuwhānui kāore e taea te whā nūpepa i te tāone kotahi, ā, kia hoki ki te nūpepa ā-ata kotahi me te nūpepa ā-ahiahi kotahi. Nō te marama o Nōema i te tau 1934, i hāwhengia e te Sun me te Star te utu o tā rātou utu mō te kape ki te kapa kotahi, me te whai mai a te Press i tērā huarahi, i piki ake ai ana tauanga hoko, me tana whakahoki tupu i ana hoa tauwhāinga o te ahiahi. Ka piki ngā rarunga, ka piki, ā, ka tau ngā whakaaro o ngā kaihautū o te Sun – ahakoa te hiahia o Huie kia whawhai tonu, kia hokona te pepa ki New Zealand Newspapers i ngā rā whakamutunga o Mei i te tau 1935. I ngā wiki tuatahi o Hūrae ka puta te putanga tuatahi o Christchurch Star-Sun. Ka mau tonu tēnei ingoa mō te nūpepa ā-rā taea noatia te tau 1958 ā, kua huri te ingoa hei Christchurch Star i te wā i kati ai i te tau 1991.

Mai i 1936 ki te tau 1939, i mahi a Edward Huie hei kanohi i Rānana ki Ingarangi mō The Press. I te tau 1940, i hokona e ia te Daily Mail o te Matau ā-Māui, mō tētahi kamupene tūmataiti. Ka whakahaere, ka ētita hoki ia i taua nūpepa tae rā anō ki mutunga o te pukapuka ā-rā i te marama o Hune 1941. I mate mai ia i Poihākena i te tau 1967.

Publication.Title: Te Aroha News
Publication.Title-alternate: Aroha and Ohinemuri News, Aroha and Ohinemuri News and Upper Thames Advocate, Aroha News and Upper Thames Advocate, Te Aroha and Ohinemuri News and Upper Thames Advocate
Publication.Description: The Te Aroha News was the first newspaper published in Te Aroha, in the Waikato. It was a weekly paper and the first issue came out, on 9 June 1883, under the title Te Aroha News and Upper Thames Advocate. The Te Aroha News continued to be published uninterrupted until 17 September 1982.

Koia tēnei te nūpepa tuatahi kia tāngia i Te Aroha, ki roto i te rohe o Waikato. I tāngia ai ia wīki, ā, ko te putanga tuatahi i te 9 o Pipiri 1883, ko tōna ingoa Te Aroha News and Upper Thames Advocate. Tāngia tonungia ai Te Aroha News tae noa ki te 17 o Mahuru 1982.
Publication.Essay:
The Te Aroha News was the first newspaper published in Te Aroha, in the Waikato. The town was relatively late in getting its own newspaper, as it was well served by papers published nearby in Thames.

The first issue was published by HE Whitaker, on 9 June 1883, under the title Te Aroha News and Upper Thames Advocate. The paper was issued weekly. In 1884 ownership passed to John Ilott and the name changed to the Te Aroha and Ohinemuri News.

Over the next 40 years various other newspapers were published in Te Aroha; however none posed a serious threat to the News. The paper absorbed its main competitor, the Te Aroha Mail (1907-1918), in 1918.

In 1913 the Te Aroha News Company acquired the News and continued to publish the paper until 1982. In July that year the company went into receivership and the last issue of the paper came out on 17 September 1982. However, at the end of that month, a new paper with the same name began publishing in Te Aroha. This newspaper merged with the Piako Post in 1986.

Ko Te Aroha News te nūpepa tuatahi kia whakaputaina i Te Aroha, ki roto i Waikato. He āhua akutō te whakawhiwhi i tēnei tāone ki tāna ake nūpepa, te take, he whakaratonga pai kē mai ngā nūpepa e whakaputaina ana i Pārāwai he pātata noa mai.

I whakaputaina te putanga tuatahi e H.E. Whitaker i te 9 o Pipiri 1883, ko tōna ingoa Te Aroha News and Upper Thames Advocate. Puta atu ai te nūpepa nei ia wiki. I te tau 1884, ka riro i a John Ilott, ā, ka whakaingoa kētia ki a Te Aroha and Ohinemuri News.

Mō ngā tau e 40 o muri mai ka tāngia ai ētahi atu nūpepa i Te Aroha, engari kāore he whakaōritenga ki te News. Horomia ai e ia tōna tino nūpepa whakataetae Te Aroha Mail (1907-1918) i te tau 1918.

I te tau 1913, ka riro te News i te Te Aroha News Company, ā, tāngia tonungia ana tae noa ki te tau 1982. Nō te marama o Hōngongoi o taua tau ka riro te kamupene ki roto i te tangohanga, ā, ko tōna putanga whakamutunga i te 17 o Mahuru 1982. Heoi anō nō te mutunga o taua marama rā ka tāngia ai tētahi nūpepa hou i Te Aroha, ko taua ingoa anō rā. Tūhonotia ana tērā ki te Piako Post i te tau 1986.

Publication.Title: Colonist
Publication.Description: The Colonist was founded in 1857 by a group of Nelson residents as a means to oppose the dominance of the large landowners of the district. At the time its only opposition was the Nelson Examiner, which the Colonist was largely established to challenge and to provide an alternative voice.

Nā ētahi o te hunga kāinga o Whakatū (Nelson) The Colonist i whakatū i te tau 1857, hei ātete ki te mana nui o ngā tāngata whai whenua o taua rohe. I taua wā ko te Nelson Examiner anake tōna hoa tauwhāinga. Ka whakatumatuma te Colonist i ngā kōrero a te Nelson Examiner, ka mutu he rerekē tōna reo, āna kōrero, tāna titiro hoki.
Publication.Essay:
The Colonist was founded in 1857 by a group of Nelson residents as a means to oppose the dominance of the large landowners of the district. At the time its only opposition was the Nelson Examiner, which the Colonist was largely established to challenge and to provide an alternative voice.

A committee of six including William Wilkie was the driving force behind the new venture, and it invited William Nation, a Sydney-based publisher with his own press, to move to Nelson to establish the newspaper. Nation and his family moved to Nelson the same year and the first issue of the Colonist was published from Wilkie’s store on 23 October 1857.

The Colonist was initially published twice-weekly, and in 1882 it became a daily. In 1866 another competitor appeared, the daily Nelson Evening Mail. For a period Nelson had three newspapers; two bi-weeklies and a daily. The Examiner ceased publication in 1874, leaving the field to the Colonist and Evening Mail. The Evening Mail became Nelson’s sole newspaper when it bought out the Colonist in 1920. The final edition of the Colonist appeared on 1 May 1920.

Nā ētahi o te hunga kāinga o Whakatū (Nelson) The Colonist i whakatū i te tau 1857, hei ātete ki te mana nui o ngā tāngata whai whenua o taua rohe. I taua wā ko te Nelson Examiner anake tōna hoa tauwhāinga. Ka whakatumatuma te Colonist i ngā kōrero a te Nelson Examiner, ka mutu he rerekē tōna reo, āna kōrero, tāna titiro hoki.

Tokoono rātou te hunga whakatū i te Colonist i raro i a William Wilkie. Ka tono rātou ki a William Nation, he kaiwhakaputa nūpepa o Poihākena (Sydney), kia neke ki Whakatū me tana perehi ki te whakatū nūpepa. I taua tau anō ka hūnuku a Nation rātou ko tōna whānau ki Whakatū, ā, nō te 23 o Whiringa-ā-nuku 1857 ka puta te nūpepa tuatahi i te toa a Wilkie.

I te tīmatanga e rua wā i te wiki ka puta te Colonist; heoi, i te tau 1882 ka whakaputaina te nūpepa nei ia rā, ia rā. I te tau 1866 ka hou mai ko te Nelson Evening Mail he nūpepa o ia rā hoki. Mō tētahi wā, e toru kē ngā nūpepa ki Whakatū – e rua ka whakaputangia e rua rā i te wiki, ko tētahi ka puta ia rā ia rā. Ka kati ngā tatau o te Examiner i te tau 1874, ka mahue iho ko te Colonist rāua ko te Evening Mail. I te tau 1920 ka hokona e te Evening Mail te Colonist, kia tū koia anake te nūpepa ki Whakatū. Nō te 1 o Haratua 1920 te putanga whakamutunga o te Colonist.

Publication.Title: Timaru Herald
Publication.Description: The Timaru Herald is the daily newspaper in Timaru. It has been published continuously since 1864, and was set up to promote the interests of Timaru and Gladstone districts against those of the Canterbury province to which they belonged. In the 1870s it was one of New Zealand's most important newspapers. Originally publication was weekly, and in 1866 the Herald became a bi-weekly. In the 1980s the Herald was sold to Independent Newspapers Limited (INL).

Ko te Timaru Herald te nūpepa ā-rangi ki Te Tihi-a-Maru. Kua rōnaki te pānuitanga mai i te tau 1864, ā, i whakatūria hei toko i ngā pānga o ngā takiwā o Te Tihi-a-Maru me Gladstone ki tua tonu o ērā o te rohe o Waitaha nāna nei rāua. I te tekau tau mai i 1870 koia anō tētahi o ngā nūpepa hira rawa o Aotearoa. Kotahi tonu te rā tānga ia wiki i te tīmatanga, ā, i te tau 1866 ka rua rā ia wiki ngā tānga o te Herald. I hokona te Herald ki te kamupene Independent Newspapers Limited (INL) i te tekau tau mai i 1980.
Publication.Essay:
The Timaru Herald is the daily newspaper in Timaru. It has been published continuously since 1864. In the 1870s it was one of New Zealand’s most important newspapers.

The Herald was founded by Alfred George Horton and Ingram Shrimpton. The first issue was printed on 11 June 1864. Originally publication was weekly.

The Herald was set up to promote the interests of Timaru and Gladstone districts against those of the Canterbury province to which they belonged. People in the Timaru area thought they were not getting a fair share of the revenues collected by the provincial government. Horton’s involvement in this issue is very clear; he helped promote a bill in parliament setting up the Timaru and Gladstone Board of Works. This gave Timaru more control of expenditure on public works in the area and seems to have satisfied the local desire for independence from Canterbury.

In 1866 the Herald became a bi-weekly, and in 1871 Horton sold to Herbert Belfield. Horton went on to become one of the most important newspaper publishers in New Zealand when, in 1876 he joined the Wilson family to create Wilson and Horton, the publishers of the New Zealand Herald for so many years.

In the 1870s the Timaru Herald developed into a significant newspaper with a national reputation. This was largely due to the editor Edward Wakefield. Wakefield, the nephew of Edward Gibbon Wakefield, was an able and hard-hitting writer who was active in both local and national affairs. He was a Member of the House of Representatives in the 1870s and 1880s. As editor of the Herald he led campaigns that gained Timaru a port and waterworks. In parliament he had a reputation as a fierce debater but also for fickleness, which probably prevented him from achieving high office. In 1876 he was summoned to appear before the House of Representatives on a charge of breach of privilege after he wrote an article in the Herald that impugned the integrity of the current Members. The charges were dropped after Wakefield apologised to the House. During Wakefield’s term the paper began daily publication. He left the Herald in 1885 when he moved to Wellington.

During the 1880s the Herald ran into financial difficulties. The Timaru Herald Company was formed to take over ownership with Herbert Belfield retained as the manager of the newspaper. In 1886 the paper was leased by its mortgagees to Joseph Ivess, an indefatigable founder and owner of newspapers in New Zealand in the 19th century. Ivess is reckoned to have started twenty-six newspapers; characteristically he did not stay with the Herald for long.

In 1887 the paper was sold to Edward George Kerr. Kerr already owned another Timaru newspaper, the South Canterbury Times. Kerr ran the Times and the Herald from the same building, with the Herald published in the morning and the Times in the evening. The Times was closed in 1901 as part of a deal Kerr made with the other morning paper, the Timaru Post. Kerr persuaded the Post to switch to evening publication, becoming in effect the evening edition of the Herald. In 1923 the Herald began to subsidise the Post to keep it going. The Post ceased in 1939.

The Kerr family owned and managed the Herald until the 1980s when it was sold to Independent Newspapers Limited (INL).

Ko te Timaru Herald te nūpepa-ā-rangi ki Te Tihi-a-Maru. Kua rōnaki te tānga mai i te tau 1864. I te tekau tau mai i 1870 koia anō tētahi o ngā nūpepa hira rawa o Aotearoa.

I whakaūhia te Herald e Alfred George Horton rāua ko Ingram Shrimpton. Nō te 11 o Pipiri 1864 te tānga tuatahi. Kotahi tonu te rā tānga i ia wiki i te tīmatanga.

I whakatūria te Herald hei toko atu i ngā pānga o ngā takiwā o Te Tihi-a-Maru me Gladstone ki ērā o te rohe o ngā Pākihi-whakatekateka-a-Waitaha nāna nei rāua. Pēnei ana te iwi i te takiwā o Te Tihi-a-Maru kāhore tonu i te riro i a rātou te wāhanga tōtika o ngā whiwhinga i kohikohia e te kāwanatanga porowini. Kei te mārama te whakaurutanga o Horton ki tēnei kaupapa; nāna te tautoko i tētahi pire i te Whare Pāremata e whakatū ana i te Poari o ngā Mahinga ki Te Tihi-a-Maru me Gladstone. Koia anō a Te Tihi-a-Maru i whai mana ai i ngā whakapaunga mō ngā mahi tūmatanui i tērā takiwā; koia anō i ngata ai te hiahia o te iwi kāinga kia noho wehe kē i te rohe o Waitaha.

I te tau 1866 ka rua ngā rā tānga o te Herald i ia wiki, ā, i te tau 1871 ka hokona e Horton ki a Herbert Belfield. Ka neke atu a Horton ka whanatu ko ia tētahi o ngā kaiwhakaputa nūpepa tino hira tonu o Aotearoa i tōna honotanga ki te whānau Wilson i te tau 1876, hei hanga i a Wilson and Horton, arā, te kamupene e whakaputa ana i te New Zealand Herald mō ētahi tau maha.

I te tekau tau mai i 1870 ka whanake te Timaru Herald hei nūpepa hira tonu, he rongo hoki tōna puta noa i te motu. Nā te ētita nā Edward Wakefield te tokonga ake o tēnei āhuatanga. Ko Wakefield, te irāmutu o Edward Gibbon Wakefield, ko tētahi kaituhi mātau, mārō hoki, he mātātoa ki ngā take ā-rohe, ki ngā take ā-motu hoki. He mema ia o te Whare Pāremata i waenganui i ngā tau 1870 me 1890. I a ia te ētita o te Herald, nāna tonu i ārahi ētahi whakamatāratanga i riro ai i a Te Tihi-a-Maru he poi, he pūnaha wai hoki. He kaitautohe muha tōna rongo ki te Whare Pāremata, otirā he matuarua, ā, nō konei pea te korenga nōna i eke ki te taumata. I te tau 1876 ka hāmenengia ia kia tū ki te aroaro o te Whare Pāremata i runga i te whakapae o ngā tikanga pāremata, i tana tuhinga i tētahi kōrero e uiui ana te ngākau tapatahi o ngā mema pāremata o te wā. I whakamakere ngā whakapae i te whakapāhatanga o Wakefield ki te Whare Pāremata. I tōna wā ka tīmata te tānga ā-rangi o te nūpepa. I mahue i a ia te Herald i te tau 1885 i tōna nekenga ki Pōneke.

I te tekau tau mai i 1880 ka pā ki te Herald ētahi raruraru ā-moni. Ka whakatūria te Timaru Herald Company hei taumanu i te rangatiratanga, ā, puritia ana a Herbert Belfield hei kaiwhakahaere mō te nūpepa. I te tau 1886 ka rīhingia te nūpepa e ōna kaitango mōkete ki a Joseph Ivess, he kaiwhakaū nakawhiti, he rangatira anō hoki o ētahi nūpepa ki Aotearoa i te rau tau mai i 1800. E tatauria ana nā Ivess tonu i whakatū ētahi nūpepa rua tekau mā ono; i tōna āhua tonu kāhore i roa tana noho ki te Herald.

I te tau 1887 ka hokona te nūpepa ki a Edward George Kerr. Ko Kerr tonu te rangatira o tētahi atu nūpepa i te Tihi-a-Maru, o te South Canterbury Times. I whakahaeretia e Kerr te Times me te Herald i te whare kotahi, ā, ko te Herald i tāngia i te ata, ko te Times i te ahiahi. I katia te Times i te tau 1901 he wāhi o tētahi whaihanga nāna ki tētahi atu nūpepa o te ata, arā, te Timaru Post. Whakawherea ana te Post e Kerr kia whakawhiti ki te tānga i te ahiahi, noho noa ana koia tonu te tānga ahiahi o te Herald. I te tau 1923 ka tīmata te Herald ki te tuku pūtea āwhina i te Post kia haere tonu tērā. I mutu tonu te Post i te tau 1939.

Ko te whānau Kerr ngā rangatira, ko rātou tonu te whakahaere i te Herald tae atu ki te tekau tau mai i 1980, i tōna hokotanga ki te kamupene Independent Newspapers Limited (INL).

Publication.Title: Taranaki Daily News
Publication.Description: The Taranaki Daily News began as a weekly publication, the Taranaki News, on 14 May 1857. Its genesis was closely related to provincial politics, with one of the principal persons behind its establishment being Charles Brown, former Superintendent of the Taranaki Province. The News was set up as a rival to the Taranaki Herald, after the Herald successfully supported a rival candidate to Brown. The two newspapers remained strong rivals for over a century, although this did not prevent the News coming to the Herald’s assistance on more than one occasion when its production was affected by fire.

I tīmata te Taranaki Daily News hei pānui ā-wiki i mōhiotia ai ko te Taranaki News, i te 14 Mei 1857. I takea mai i ngā mahi tōrangapū ā-rohe, nā te mea ko tētahi o ngā kaihautū matua o tōna whakatūranga ko Charles Brown, Hupiritene o mua o te Rohe o Taranaki. I whakatūria ai te News hei hoa tauwhāinga ki te Taranaki Herald, i muri i te tautoko a te Herald i tētahi kaitōrangapū tauwhāinga ki a Brown. I noho ngā niupepa e rua hei hoa tauwhāinga mō te rau tau, neke atu, ahakoa rā, i ētahi wā i tahuri te News ki te āwhina i te Herald i te weranga o ana mīhini whakaputa pepa i te ahi.
Publication.Essay:
The Taranaki Daily News began as a weekly publication, the Taranaki News, on 14 May 1857. Its genesis was closely related to provincial politics, with one of the principal persons behind its establishment being Charles Brown, former Superintendent of the Taranaki Province. The News was set up as a rival to the Taranaki Herald, after the Herald successfully supported a rival candidate to Brown. The two newspapers remained strong rivals for over a century, although this did not prevent the News coming to the Herald’s assistance on more than one occasion when its production was affected by fire.

During its early years the News suffered from a lack of funds; paper shortages also hampered production and on two occasions it had to print on dark blue packing paper. Frequent changes in ownership and management also hampered the development of the News and it did not really start to prosper until it was bought by Thomas List in 1905. List was a professional newspaper man, who had built up invaluable experience through his involvement with the Hutt and Petone Chronicle, the short-lived Wellington paper the Sun, and the Waimate Witness. Under List’s management, improvements to printing processes were made and branch offices were set up in Stratford and Hawera. When List took over the News he found that the newspaper was in the perilous position of having fewer than 200 regular paying subscribers. By the time of his death in 1934 circulation had expanded to such an extent that the News claimed it was the fifth largest morning newspaper in the country.

After the Second World War, the News took advantage of improved transport links to extend its circulation into the King Country and came to be regarded as the regional paper, while the Herald was seen as a city and provincial paper.

Ownership of the News and the Herald was merged in 1962 and much of their activity combined. However both papers retained their own editorial departments and competition between the old rivals continued to be keen. Eventually the Herald’s weaker circulation and advertising base, and its less favourable position as an evening paper, meant that it failed to outlast the News.

The News has had various name changes over the years, with the most recent change being in August 2004 when the title changed back from the Daily News to the Taranaki Daily News. At the same time a picture of the region’s most well-known landmark, Mount Taranaki, was added to the masthead.

The Taranaki Daily News became part of the Fairfax group in 2003 and was still published as of 2014, making it the second oldest newspaper in the country after the Wanganui Chronicle.

I tīmata te Taranaki Daily News hei pānui ā-wiki i mōhiotia ai ko te Taranaki News, i te 14 Mei 1857. I takea mai i ngā mahi tōrangapū ā-rohe, nā te mea ko tētahi o ngā kaihautū matua o tōna whakatūranga ko Charles Brown, Hupiritene o mua o te Rohe o Taranaki. I whakatūria ai te News hei hoa tauwhāinga ki te Taranaki Herald, i muri i te tautoko a te Herald i tētahi kaitōrangapū tauwhāinga ki a Brown. I noho ngā niupepa e rua hei hoa tauwhāinga mō te rau tau, neke atu, ahakoa rā, i ētahi wā i tahuri te News ki te āwhina i te Herald i te weranga o ana mīhini whakaputa pepa i te ahi.

I ngā tau tuatahi o te News ko tōna raruraru nui ko te iti o ngā pūtea whakahaere; i ētahi wā nā te kore pepa tonu i uaua ai te whakaputa i te pepa, ā, e rua ōna putanga i runga pepa takai taonga, he kikorangi uriuri te tae. Tētahi atu take i uaua ai te whanaketanga o te News ko ngā huringa o ngā kaipupuru hea me ngā kaiwhakahaere, ā, nō te hokonga o te niupepa e Thomas List i 1905 kātahi anō ka tino tupu ki tōna teitei. He kaimahi niupepa tūturu a List ā, i haria mai e ia ana tino mōhiotanga i ākona e ia i ana tau i te Hutt and Petone Chronicle, te niupepa rangitahi noa o Pōneke e mōhiotia nei ko te Sun, me te Waimate Witness. I raro i ngā whakahaere a List i piki te pai o ngā mahi o ngā tukanga tā niupepa, ā, i whakatūria he pekanga ā-rohe ki Stratford me Hawera. Nō te ekenga o List hei kaiwhakahaere mō te News i kite ia kua hē te noho o te niupepa nā te mea he iti iho i te 200 ngā kaihoko auau i te niupepa. Ka tae ki te wā o tōna matenga i te tau 1934 kua whakawhānuitia te rere o te niupepa, i āhei ai te News ki te kī koia te tuarima o ngā niupepa ā-ata i te motu katoa, mō te maha o ana kaipānui.

I muri i te Pakanga Tuarua o te Ao, ka huri te News ki te whakapiki i ana mahi i runga i tana whakamahi i ngā hononga ā-huarahi, ā-tereina ki roto i te Rohe Pōtae, nō muri ka whakaarotia koia te niupepa ā-rohe, ā, ka kīa ko te Herald he niupepa ā-tāone, ā-rohe hoki.

I whakahanumitia ngā hea o te News me te Herald i te tau 1962 me te kōtuitanga o te tini o ngā mahi a tētahi, a tētahi. Ahakoa ko tērā, i waiho motuhake tonu ngā tari tuhi kaupapa o tētahi, o tētahi, me te haere tonu o te whakataetae nui i waenga i ngā hoa tauwhāinga o tau kē. Ka taka te wā, ka heke haere te tokomaha o te hunga hoko kape, me te hunga hoko pānui o te Herald ā, nā tōna tū ngoikore hei niupepa ā-ahiahi, i kore ai ia e ora ki tua atu i te News.

He maha ngā huringa ingoa o te News i roto i ngā tau, ā, ko tētahi o ngā huringa o ngā tau tata ko tērā i te marama o Ākuhata i te tau 2004 i huri ai tana taitara mai i te Daily News ki te Taranaki Daily News. I taua wā anō, i tāpiritia he whakaahua o te maunga tupua o Taranaki ki te whārangi o mua o te niupepa.

Ka uru te Taranaki Daily News hei wāhanga o te rōpū Fairfax i te tau 2003 ā, e whakaputaina tonutia ana i te tau 2014, nō reira koinei te niupepa tuarua te tawhito o ngā niupepa katoa o te motu, i muri i te Wanganui Chronicle.

Publication.Title: Taranaki Herald
Publication.Description: The Taranaki Herald was the first newspaper published in Taranaki, with New Plymouth being the last of the early European settlements to get its own newspaper. The paper survived a number of controversies in its early years but the 1970s and 1980s were difficult times for evening newspapers and the Herald ceased publication in 1989.

Ko te Taranaki Herald te nūpepa tuatahi kia tāngia i Taranaki, ana, ko Nū Pāremata (New Plymouth) te whakamutunga o ngā nohanga Pākehā o aua wā ki te whiwhi i tōna nūpepa ake. I ora mai te nūpepa he ahakoa ngā tūmomo tautohetohe i ngā tau tīmatanga, engari he uaua rawa ngā tau mai i 1970 ki te tau 1990 mō ngā nūpepa ahiahi, ā, ka katia te Herald i te tau 1989.
Publication.Essay:
The Taranaki Herald was the first newspaper published in Taranaki, with New Plymouth being the last of the early European settlements to get its own newspaper. The paper survived a number of controversies in its early years but the 1970s and 1980s were difficult times for evening newspapers and the Herald ceased publication in 1989.

The Herald was started by William Collins and Garland William Woon. The first issue was published on 4 August 1852. In 1867 the paper was sold to Henry Weston. He was the sole owner till 1920. Various members of the Weston family were associated with the paper for most of its existence.

The Herald, like other newspapers in New Zealand in the mid 19th century, was involved in various controversies. In 1854 William Crompton, the subeditor, resigned after opinions he expressed in the paper, including the denouncing of marriages between Māori and Pakeha, aroused hostile criticism. In the provincial elections in 1857 the Herald transferred its support from the incumbent Superintendent Charles Brown to his rival George Cutfield. Cutfield won the election and Brown responded by setting up the Taranaki News to compete with the Herald. The editor of the Taranaki News was the former editor of the Herald, Richard Pheney. Pheney had resigned over the Herald withdrawing their support for Brown.

In 1875 the Herald began publishing the Budget and Taranaki Weekly Herald. The Budget provided a synopsis of the news carried by the Herald each week and was intended mainly for rural readers who couldn't get the paper each day. The Budget lasted till 1932. In 1877 the Herald became a daily newspaper; the Taranaki News had become one two years before.

The Herald became the oldest newspaper in New Zealand after the Lyttleton Times ceased publication in 1935. In 1962 it amalgamated with its old rival, the Taranaki News (now the Daily News). The papers retained separate editorial teams but shared everything else. The News was issued in the morning and the Herald in the evening.

In the 1970s and 1980s it became increasingly difficult to maintain evening newspapers in New Zealand. The Herald was one of those affected and ceased publication in 1989.

Ko te Taranaki Herald te nūpepa tuatahi kia tāngia i Taranaki. Ko Nū Pāremata te whakamutunga o ngā nohanga Pākehā o aua wā ki te whiwhi i tōna nūpepa ake.

Nā William Collins rāua ko Garland William Woon te Herald i tīmata. Ko te putanga tuatahi i tāngia i te 4 o Ākuhata o te tau 1852. Nō te tau 1867 ka hokona ai ki a Henry Weston. Ko ia anahe te rangatira tae noa ki te tau 1920. He pānga o te maha o ngā mema o te whānau Weston ki te nūpepa mō te roanga ake o tōna wā.

He rite te Herald ki ētahi atu o ngā nūpepa o waenga o te rautau mai i 1800, i tōna urunga ki ngā tūmomo tautohetohe. Nō te tau 1854, ka tukua ai e William Crompton tōna tūnga ētita tuarua nō te kaha o te whakapae ki ana whakaaro i tuhia ki te nūpepa, pērā me tana whakahē i te moenga o te Māori ki te Pākehā. I ngā pōti porowini o te tau 1857 ka nukuhia te tautoko a te Herald mai i te Kaiwhakahaere o te wā, Charles Brown, ki tōna tāwhainga ki a George Cutfield. Ka riro i a Cutfield te pōti, ko te whakaūtunga i te Taranaki News hei tāwhainga i te Herald te whakautu a Brown. Ko te ētita o te Taranaki News te ētita o mua o te Herald, Richard Pheney. Ko te take i puta atu ai a Pheney i te Herald, nō te katinga o te tautoko i a Brown.

Nō te tau 1875 ka tīmata ai te Herald ki te tā i te Budget and Taranaki Weekly Herald. Ko tā te Budget he whakarato i tētahi whakarāpopotonga ia wiki i ngā kōrero i kawea e te Herald, ā, ko ōna kaipānui ngā mea noho matara e kore ai e taea te nūpepa ia rā. Ka tāngia ai te Budget tae noa ki te tau 1932. Nō te tau 1877 ka puta ai te Herald ia rā, nō ngā tau e rua o mua i pērātia ai te Taranaki News.

Nō te katinga o te Lyttelton Times i te tau 1935, ko te Herald te nūpepa kaumātua o te motu. Nō te tau 1962 ka honoa ai ki tōna tāwhainga tūroa te Taranaki News (ko te Daily News ki tēnei wā). He mahitahi i te katoa o ngā rauemi engari he tīma motuhake o ia nūpepa mō te mahi ētita. Puta atu ai te News ia ata, te Herald ia ahiahi.

I ngā tau mai i 1970 ki te 1990, ka kaha atu te uaua o te whakaputa nūpepa ahiahi i Aotearoa. Ko te Herald tētahi i pērātia, ka katia ai i te tau 1989.

Publication.Title: Thames Advertiser
Publication.Description: Following the first major discovery of gold in the Thames area in August 1867, William Wilkinson and Claude Corlett decided to try their luck as newspaper proprietors in the embryonic Thames settlement. Born in Derbyshire, England, Wilkinson arrived in Auckland on the Nimroud in 1863. He joined the Southern Cross newspaper, acting as a ‘war correspondent’ during the New Zealand Wars, notably at the battle of Gate Pa, Tauranga, in late April 1864. Corlett, from Manchester in England, a compositor by training, also worked at the Southern Cross. The first issue of the tri-weekly Thames Advertiser and Miners’ News appeared in April 1868.

Nō muri i te kitenga matua tuatahi o te koura ki te rohe o Hauraki i te marama o Ākuhata 1867, ka tahuri a William Wilkinson rāua ko Claude Corlett ki te whai i te mahi whakaputa niupepa i te tāone tino hou o Thames. I whānau mai a Wilkinson i Derbyshire, i Ingarangi, ā, ka tae mai ki Tāmaki-makau-rau i te kaipuke Nimroud i te tau 1863. Ka uru ki te niupepa o te Southern Cross hei kaikawe kōrero, ā, ko tōna tūranga rongonui pea hei ‘kaikawe kōrero mō te pakanga’ i te pakanga o Pukehinahina (Gate Pā), i Tauranga, i te mutunga o te marama o Āperira 1864. Nō Manchester, i Ingarangi a Corlett, kua whakangungua ia ki ngā mahi whakarārangi tā, ā, i mahi hoki ia i te Southern Cross. I puta te rerenga tuatahi o te niupepa toru-rā-i-te-wiki, o te Thames Advertiser and Miners’ News i te marama o Āperira 1868. Nā te nui o ngā kaikeri koura e tatari ana ki ngā rongo kōrero me ngā pakipaki o te wā, ka tino horapa tōna ingoa pai.
Publication.Essay:
Following the first major discovery of gold in the Thames area in August 1867, William Wilkinson and Claude Corlett decided to try their luck as newspaper proprietors in the embryonic Thames settlement.

Born in Derbyshire, England, Wilkinson arrived in Auckland on the Nimroud in 1863. He joined the Southern Cross newspaper, acting as a ‘war correspondent’ during the New Zealand Wars, notably at the battle of Gate Pa, Tauranga, in late April 1864. Corlett, from Manchester in England, a compositor by training, also worked at the Southern Cross. The first issue of the tri-weekly Thames Advertiser and Miners’ News appeared in April 1868.

With the large influx of miners anxious for the latest goldfields news and gossip, the tri-weekly was an immediate success. Within the first year it became a daily and was the major newspaper in the Thames district during the main gold rush era. The bonanza years for the region were from 1868-1871, with impressive gold yields recorded. Gold production topped one million pounds sterling at its peak. The population of Thames built rapidly to 18,000 and it was, at the time, one of the largest towns in New Zealand. Commercial activity mushroomed and there were over 100 hotels vying for business. The Thames Advertiser thrived in terms of circulation, and advertising was particularly buoyant with hundreds of new businesses needing to promote their presence. There was also a similarly high demand for job printing. As in other gold-mining towns there was a demand for printing ‘scrip’ for mining companies.

Corlett withdrew from the partnership after a couple of years, briefly running a competing, short-lived daily, the Thames Guardian and Mining Record (1871-1872), before spending many years as manager of the Christchurch Press.

In 1872, Wilkinson was joined by Alfred Horton who had previously begun the Timaru Herald. Horton, who was to become the principal owner of Auckland’s New Zealand Herald, was a very experienced newspaper man and evidence of this was soon seen in the Thames Advertiser. However, Horton moved to Auckland in 1876 following a clash of editorial views. There was a succession of owners after Wilkinson sold the newspaper in the mid-1880s. William McCullough, who was associated with the rival newspaper, the Thames Evening Star (formerly Evening Mail) , purchased the Thames Advertiser in 1912 – and absorbed it into the Evening Star which, in due course, became the Thames Star.

Nō muri i te kitenga matua tuatahi o te koura ki te rohe o Hauraki i te marama o Ākuhata 1867, ka tahuri a William Wilkinson rāua ko Claude Corlett ki te whai i te mahi whakaputa niupepa i te tāone tino hou o Thames.

I whānau mai a Wilkinson i Derbyshire, i Ingarangi, ā, ka tae mai ki Tāmaki-makau-rau i te kaipuke Nimroud i te tau 1863. Ka uru ki te niupepa o te Southern Cross hei kaikawe kōrero, ā, ko tōna tūranga rongonui pea hei ‘kaikawe kōrero mō te pakanga’ i te pakanga o Pukehinahina (Gate Pā), i Tauranga, i te mutunga o te marama o Āperira 1864. Nō Manchester, i Ingarangi a Corlett, kua whakangungua ia ki ngā mahi whakarārangi tā, ā, i mahi hoki ia i te Southern Cross. I puta te rerenga tuatahi o te niupepa toru-rā-i-te-wiki, o te Thames Advertiser and Miners’ News i te marama o Āperira 1868. Nā te nui o ngā kaikeri koura e tatari ana ki ngā rongo kōrero me ngā pakipaki o te wā, ka tino horapa tōna ingoa pai.

Heoi anō, i roto i taua tau tuatahi ka eke te niupepa hei niupepa ā-rā, ā, koia hoki te niupepa matua tuatahi o te takiwā o Hauraki i te wā o te rerenga ki te keri koura. Ko ngā tino tau mō te hua o te moni i aua wā mō te rohe, ko ngā tau mai i te 1868-1871, me te tiketike o ngā keringa koura. Ka piki te hua o te keri koura ki te kotahi miriona pauna tāringi, i tōna teiteinga rawatanga. Hohoro tonu te pikinga te tokomaha o te hunga noho i Thames ki te 18,000, ā, koia hoki tētahi o ngā tāone rahi rawa o Aotearoa mō tētahi wā. Ka tino piki ngā mahi arumoni, ā, neke atu i te 100 ngā hōtēra i te whakataetae i te tāone. Ka tino nui haere te Thames Advertiser, te taha tohanga rā, ā, ka tino kake tana umanga hoko whakatairanga ki te hia rau o ngā umanga hou kua tae mai, me te hiahia kia pānuitia ā rātou ratonga. Waihoki te mahi tā pukapuka. Rite tonu ki ērā atu tāone keri koura, inā noa ake te karanga mō ngā ratonga tā’scrip’ mō ngā kamupene keri koura.

Ka kōunu a Corlett i te tokorua mō ētahi tau ruarua noa, ā, ka huri ki te whakahaere i tētahi niupepa ā-rā whakataetae, te Thames Guardian and Mining Record (1871-1872), kātahi ka haere hei kaiwhakahaere mō Christchurch Press mō ngā tau maha.

Nō te tau 1872, ka tae mai a Alfred Horton ki te mahi tahi ki a Wilkinson, ko Horton hoki te kaitīmata i te Timaru Herald. He tino kaiwhakahaere niupepa tautōhito a Horton, ā, ka kitea wawetia tōna tohungatanga i roto i te whanaketanga o te Thames Advertiser. Nāwai, ā, ka eke a Horton hei rangatira matua mō te New Zealand Herald o Tāmaki-makau-rau. Ahakoa rā, ka nuku a Horton ki Tamaki-makau-rau i te tau 1876 i muri i te taupatupatunga whakaaro o ngā etita. Tērā anō te huri o ngā rangatira i muri i te hoko a Wilkinson i te niupepa i te ngahuru tau mai i 1880. Nā William McCullough, he tangata piri ki te niupepa tauwhāinga te Thames Evening Star (te Evening Mail i mua), i hoko te Thames Advertiser i te tau 1912 – ka whakahanumitia e ia ki roto i te Evening Star, ka noho i roto i te wā hei Thames Star.

Publication.Title: Thames Star
Publication.Description: The first major gold discovery in the Thames area took place in 1867. In the same year William Shaw arrived in Thames and started up the Times and Thames Miners’ Advocate along with Jeremiah Harnett.

I kitea tuatahitia mai te kōura, kia nui tonu, i te rohe o Waihou i te tau 1867. I taua tau anō ka tae mai a William Shaw ki roto i Thames, ā, ka tīmataria e ia te Times and Thames Miners’ Advocate i te taha o Jeremiah Harnett.
Publication.Essay:
The first major gold discovery in the Thames area took place in 1867. In the same year William Shaw arrived in Thames and started up the Times and Thames Miners’ Advocate along with Jeremiah Harnett.

Amongst other newspapers, Shaw also started the Thames Evening Star in 1869 (it first appeared as the Evening Mail). By this stage, there were 18,000 inhabitants in the town. After his bankruptcy it was taken over by James Hopcraft (editor until his death in 1879) and William McCullough, amongst others.

One innovation of the time was the use of messages sent by pigeon to deliver news reports, known as ‘pigeongrams’.

In 1893 the daily paper became known as the Thames Star.

Rival paper the Thames Advertiser was purchased by McCullough and incorporated into the Star in 1912. Further changes of ownership followed.

The Thames Star merged with the Paeroa Gazette in 1998 to become the Thames Valley Gazette, but the new publication lasted less than a year.

I kitea tuatahitia mai te kōura, kia nui tonu, i te rohe o Waihou i te tau 1867. I taua tau anō ka tae mai a William Shaw ki roto i Thames, ā, ka tīmataria e ia te Times and Thames Miners’ Advocate i te taha o Jeremiah Harnett.

I te taha o ētahi atu nūpepa, nā Shaw i tīmata te Thames Evening Star i te tau 1869 (ko tōna putanga tuatahi i raro i te ingoa o te Evening Mail). Nō te taenga mai ki tēnei wā, 18,000 ngā tāngata noho i te tāone. I muri i tōna pēkeraputanga, ka hokona e James Hopcraft (koia hoki te ētita taea noatia tōna matenga i te tau 1879) rātou ko William McCullough, ko ētahi atu.

Ko tētahi o ngā mahi hou i taua wā he tono karere mā te kūkupa, hei tiritiri i ngā rongo o te wā, ā, ka kīia ēnei he ‘pigeongram’.

Nō te tau 1893 ka tapā te nūpepa ki te ingoa o te Thames Star.

I hokona mai te pepa tauwhāinga a te Thames Advertiser e McCullough, ā, ka haumitia ki roto i te Star i te tau 1912. Arā atu hoki ngā tāngata nāna i hoko te nūpepa i muri mai.

Ka haumitia te Thames Star ki roto i te Paeroa Gazette i te tau 1998, ka hurihia te ingoa ki te Thames Valley Gazette, engari kāore i eke ki te tau te oranga o te nūpepa hou.

Publication.Title: Observer
Publication.Title-alternate: The New Zealand Observer and Free lance, An Illustrated Journal of Interesting and Amusing Literature; N.Z. Observer and Free Lance; Observer and Free Lance
Publication.Description: The New Zealand Observer was one of a number of illustrated weekly newspapers popular in the 19th and early 20th centuries. It was first published in Auckland in 1880 and continued, with name changes, until November 1954.

Ko te New Zealand Observer tētahi o ngā nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua, i paingia i te rau tau 1800-1899 me te tīmatanga o te rau tau 1900-1999. I whakaputaina tuatahitia i ākarana i te tau 1880, ā, ka haere tonu, ahakoa ngā hurihanga i te ingoa, tae noa ki te marama o Whiringa-ā-rangi i te tau 1954.
Publication.Essay:
The New Zealand Observer was one of a number of illustrated weekly newspapers that were popular in the 19th and early 20th centuries. The Observer was probably not as popular or as well known as some of the other weeklies, e.g. the Weekly News, New Zealand Free Lance and the Otago Witness.

The Observer was first published in Auckland in 1880 by Alfred Stewart Rathbone, an English journalist who had been running the Bay of Plenty Times. The Observer's history is convoluted and closely interwoven with that of other Auckland newspapers of the 1870s and 1880s, particularly the Auckland Star.

The Auckland Star started publishing in 1870. It was a liberal paper and set out to challenge the more conservative Evening News. One of the Star's owners, Henry Brett, was an important figure in the development of the press in New Zealand. He had worked for the Southern Cross and the New Zealand Herald as well as publishing a number of popular and influential periodicals besides the Star. He was also a director and chairman of the Press Association and an original member of the Newspaper Proprietors Association.

The Star was popular and successful from its inception, despite having a number of rivals in the 1870s and 1880s. In addition to the Observer these also included the Free Lance, set up by John Dickson Wickham in 1879.

In 1884 the Observer's publishers put out the Evening Telephone to compete with the Star. However this paper soon proved a financial drain and in 1885 John Wickham acquired both the Telephone and the Observer merging them with the Free Lance and retaining the Observer name.

With the demise of the Telephone came the Evening Bell (first published on 12 May 1885), which lasted three years before Brett bought it and the Observer. Having incorporated the Bell, Brett sold the Observer in 1889.

In the 1890s the paper was called the New Zealand Observer and Free Lance. It became well established in the 1890s and similar publications were started in Christchurch (the Spectator) and Wellington (the New Zealand Free Lance).

Like the other pictorial weeklies, the paper went into decline in the first half of the 20th century and stopped publishing in November 1954.

Ko te New Zealand Observer tētahi o ngā nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua, i paingia i te rau tau 1800-1899 me te tīmatatanga o te rau tau 1900-1999. Kāore rā pea i ōrite te paingia, te rongonui rānei ki ō ētahi atu nūpepa ā-wiki pērā me te Weekly News, New Zealand Free Lance, me te Otago Witness.

I whakaputaina tuatahitia i ākarana i te tau 1880 e Alfred Stewart Rathbone, he kairīpoata Pākehā nāna te Bay of Plenty Times i whakahaere. He tino whīwhiwhi te hītori o te Observer, ā, he whakakapiti ki ētahi atu o ngā nūpepa o ngā tau mai i 1870 ki 1890 i ākarana, ērangi rawa ia ki te Auckland Star.

I tīmata te puta a te Auckland Star i te tau 1870. He nūpepa whakaaro atawhai, ko tāna, he whakataetae i te whakaaro whakatūpato ake o te Evening News. Ko tētahi o ōna kaiwhaipānga, a Henry Brett, tētahi tangata nui i te whakawhanaketanga o ngā nūpepa i Aotearoa. He kaimahi ia i mua mā te Southern Cross me te New Zealand Herald, he kaiwhakaputa i ētahi nūpepa-hautaka whaimana i tua o te Star. He kaiwhakahaere, he tiamana hoki ia nō te rōpū pārongo e kīia ana te New Zealand Press Association, he kaiwhakaū anō hoki nō te rōpū o ngā rangatira o ngā nūpepa (Newspaper Proprietors Association).

I paingia, i whaihua te Star mai i tana putanga mai, ahakoa ngā nūpepa whakataetae i ngā tau mai i 1870 ki 1890. Hāunga te Observer, kei reira te Free Lance nā John Dickson Wickham i whakatū i te tau 1879.

Nō te tau 1884 ka whakaputaina ai te Evening Telephone e ngā kaiwhakaputa o te Observer hei nūpepa whakataetae i te Star. Heoi anō kāore i roa ka kitea te mimiti o te pūtea, ā, i te tau 1885 ka riro i a John Wickham te Telephone me te Observer, ka tūhonotia ki te Free Lance, mau tonungia ana te ingoa Observer.

Nō te ngaromanga o te Telephone, ka puta ko te Evening Bell (i whakaputaina tuatahitia i te 12 o Haratua i te tau 1885), ka toru ōna tau ka hokona tahitia me te Observer e Brett. Nō te tūhonotanga o te Bell ka hokona e Brett te Observer i te tau 1889.

I te tekau tau mai i 1890 ka whakaingoatia te nūpepa ko te New Zealand Observer and Free Lance. Ka mau pai i te tekau tau mai i 1890, ā, ka tīmata ētahi atu nūpepa i ōtautahi (Spectator) me Pōneke (New Zealand Free Lance).

Pērā ki ētahi atu nūpepa ā-wiki whai whakaahua, ka kore haere te pepa i te hāwhe tuatahi o te rau tau 1900-1999, ā, ka mutu te whakaputaina i te marama o Whiringa-ā-rangi i te tau 1954.

Publication.Title: Te Puke Times
Publication.Description: The first issue of the Te Puke Times was published on February 6 1912. A week later Wellington’s Evening Post reported that ‘the first issue of the Te Puke Times is to hand, and is a creditable production’. The paper was owned and edited by Thomas H Wilsone, born in Masterton and a journalist on the Wairarapa Star before a period farming with a brother. He moved north to become part owner and editor of the Waikato Independent in Cambridge in 1910. A year later the paper was sold to the Waikato Publishing Co and Wilsone relocated his newspaper ambitions to Te Puke.

I whānau mai te putanga tuatahi o te Te Puke Times i te 6 Pēpuere 1912. Kotahi wiki i muri mai ka puta ngā kupu whakamihi a te Evening Post o Pōneke, kua ‘puta mai ki te ao, ki nga ringaringa o te tangata te rerenga tuatahi o te Te Puke Times, ā, he niupepa whai take’. Ko tēnei niupepa he pepa nā Thomas H Wilsone, he tangata i whānau mai i Māhitaone, he kaituhi hoki i te Wairarapa Star i mua i tana haere ki te pāmu whenua me tana teina. Ka nuku whaka-te-raki ia kia eke hei kaipupuri i tētahi wāhi o te Waikato Independent hei etita hoki, i Kēmureti i te tau 1910. Kotahi tau i muri mai ka hokona te niupepa ki te Waikato Publishing Co ā, ka whakahokia e Wilsone ana moemoeā mō tētahi niupepa ki Te Puke.
Publication.Essay:
The first Europeans began to settle the Te Puke Block in 1879. Flax milling started up in the area in the 1870s and was a major industry until the early 1940s. Saw milling began in 1905 and has remained a major industry. After the swamps in the area were drained the land was found to be very suitable for crops, and maize and wheat were grown extensively. Pastoral farming was less successful until the use of cobalt, in the 1930s, cured animals’ ‘bush sickness’.

The first issue of the Te Puke Times was published on February 6 1912. A week later Wellington’s Evening Post reported that ‘the first issue of the Te Puke Times is to hand, and is a creditable production’. The paper was owned and edited by Thomas H Wilsone, born in Masterton and a journalist on the Wairarapa Star before a period farming with a brother. He moved north to become part owner and editor of the Waikato Independent in Cambridge in 1910. A year later the paper was sold to the Waikato Publishing Co and Wilsone relocated his newspaper ambitions to Te Puke.

In the first issue of the Te Puke Times, Wilsone wrote: ‘We have been encouraged to take this step recognising the manifold signs of future progress which are everywhere apparent .... We hold that a well conducted journal must always exercise a certain influence for good in a community, not only in a material but in a moral sense, that its duty is not only to expose abuses but to give every encouragement to all projects initiated for the elevation of the social life of a community.’

The one penny paper appeared twice weekly and lived up to its promise, in common with many small-town publications of the time, of providing local news in great detail. There were lengthy articles about weddings, debutante balls and farewells, with detailed descriptions of gifts given and dresses worn. Overseas trips by local identities were given extensive coverage; visitors to the area were interviewed. There was extensive coverage of sporting events, A & P Shows and, in later years, the activities of the Women’s Institute and Women’s Division.

Thomas Wilsone continued as proprietor and editor until his death in 1936, when his wife, Edith Wilsone, promoted Frederick Gemming, employed since 1919, to run the paper. Gemming leased the paper in 1939 until 1941. After ill health forced his retirement, Edith Wilsone took control for less than a year before selling the Te Puke Times to Philip Basham.

Basham served a six year printing apprenticeship at the Waikato Independent in Cambridge before joining the Hot Lakes Chronicle in Rotorua. Later, he moved to Auckland, where he ran an Otahuhu weekly, and then in 1934, to Taranaki, becoming managing director of the bi-weekly Inglewood Times. Newsprint shortages were common during the Second World War and, when a critical paper delivery by train failed to arrive, the 27 November 1942 edition of the Te Puke Times was a single 17cm x 6cm sheet – possibly the country’s smallest ever newspaper – to inform readers of an important farewell function the next night.

After Philip Basham died in 1963 his son David continued to run the paper. In 1978 Basham and two colleagues purchased the Bay Sun, with a free Tauranga area circulation, incorporating it with the Te Puke Times. The Tuesday edition of the combined paper included Te Puke news, but this satisfied neither readers or advertisers and, in 1982, the Te Puke Times masthead and full local content were restored.

In 1983 the company was sold to John Wood and, in 1985, to NZ News Ltd. In 1989, Independent News Ltd (INL) bought part of NZ News, including the Te Puke Times and a number of other community newspapers. In 2002 Wilson and Horton, now APN NZ Ltd, purchased the paper from Independent Community Newspapers (INL). The free weekly is now published by the Bay of Plenty Times and is one of the APN News & Media stable of community newspapers.

I tīmata te noho mai o te iwi Pākehā ki te poraka o Te Puke i te tau 1879. Ka tīmata te mahi tapahi harakeke i tēnei rohe i te ngahuru tau mai i 1870, ā, ka noho tērā hei ahumahi tino nui taea noatia mai te ngahuru tau mai i 1940.I tīmata te kani rākau i te tau 1905, ka noho hoki hei ahumahi tino nui tae mai ki nāianei. Nō muri i te whakamaroketanga o ngā repo o te rohe ka kitea he rawe te whenua mō ngā tupu, mō te kānga me te witi, ā, he kaha tonu te whakatupu i ēnei. Kāore i pērā rawa te pai o te whāngai kau, hipi, kia tīmata ra anō te whakamahi i te konukurahina (cobalt), i ora ake ai ngā kararehe i te ‘mate ngahere’ arā, te ‘bush sickness’, i te ngahuru tau mai i 1930.

I whānau mai te putanga tuatahi o te Te Puke Times i te 6 Pēpuere 1912. Kotahi wiki i muri mai ka puta ngā kupu whakamihi a te Evening Post o Pōneke, kua ‘puta mai ki te ao, ki nga ringaringa o te tangata te rerenga tuatahi o te Te Puke Times, ā, he niupepa whai take’. Ko tēnei niupepa he pepa nā Thomas H Wilsone, he tangata i whānau mai i Māhitaone, he kaituhi hoki i te Wairarapa Star i mua i tana haere ki te pāmu whenua me tana teina. Ka nuku whaka-te-raki ia kia eke hei kaipupuri i tētahi wāhi o te Waikato Independent hei etita hoki, i Kēmureti i te tau 1910. Kotahi tau i muri mai ka hokona te niupepa ki te Waikato Publishing Co ā, ka whakahokia e Wilsone ana moemoeā mō tētahi niupepa ki Te Puke.

I te rerenga tuatahi o te Te Puke Times ka tuhi a Wilsone: “I hīkaka ai mātou ki te whakatutuki i tēnei moemoeā i runga i tā mātou titiro ki te ahunga whakamua o te ao he mārama ki te titiro a te kanohi, i ngā wāhi katoa.... E mea ana mātou ko tēnei mea te niupepa whai take me kawe ngā whakaaro ki te pai, i tōna takiwā, kaua ki te pai kikokiko anake, engari ki te pai wairua, otirā ko te pīkauranga nui o tēnei mea te niupepa kia kaua e mutu noa i te hura i ngā mahi hē anake, engari kia hāpainga ngā kaupapa katoa e whāia ana hei whakapiki i te pai o te noho o te katoa.”

E rua ngā putanga o tēnei niupepa kotahi kapa ia wiki, ā, i tutuki katoa ngā tūmanako, rite tonu ki te nuinga noa iho o ngā niupepa tāone iti o taua wā, i horaina ai te tini o ngā pitopito kōrero ā-rohe, me te pai o ngā tuhinga. He roa tonu ngā tuhinga mō ngā mārena, mō ngā pō kanikani nui, mō ngā whakaputanga puhi o te rohe, ngā poroporoaki, me ngā whakamārama roa tonu o ngā perehana i takoto, me ngā panekoti i mauria. He roa tonu ngā pūrongo whakamārama mō ngā haerenga ki tāwāhi a ngā tāngata o te rohe; he hōhonu tonu anō hoki ngā uiuinga ki ngā manuhiri ki te takiwā. He maha ngā pūrongo mō ngā taumāhekeheke, mā ngā Whakakitenga A & P, ā, i ngā tau o muri, ngā mahi a te Women’s Institute me te Women’s Division.

I noho tonu a Thomas Wilsone hei rangatira, hei etita hoki taea noatia tōna matenga i te tau 1936, i reira ka whakapikia a Frederick Gemming, e te pouaru e Edith Wilsone hei kaiwhakahaere mō te niupepa. He kaimahi ia mai o te tau 1919. Ka rīhitia te pepa e Gemming i te tau 1939 tae noa ki te tau 1941. Ka pāngia e te mate, ka tukua e ia tana tūranga, ā, ka whakahaeretia e Edith Wilsone mō te wā, kāore i eke ki te tau, kātahi ka hokona te Te Puke Times ki a Philip Basham.

I noho a Basham hei pia mō ngā mahi tā pukapuka mō te ono tau i te Waikato Independent i Kēmureti i mua i tana hononga ki te Hot Lakes Chronicle i Rotorua, mahi ai. Nō muri mai ka nuku ki Tāmaki-makau-rau, i whakahaeretia e ia tētahi wīkiri ki Ōtāhuhu, ā, i te tau 1934, ka nuku ki Taranaki, ka noho hei kaiwhakahaere matua mō te Inglewood Times, e rua ōna putanga i te wiki. He maha ngā korekorenga pepa niupepa i te wā o Te Pakanga Tuarua o Te Ao, ā, i te korenga o te tino tereina me ngā pūkei pepa hei tānga e tae mai, he hīti kotahi noa te putanga o te 27 o ngā rā o Nōema 1942 o te Te Puke Times, e 17cm x 6cm te rahi. Koinei pea te niupepa iti rawa kia puta i Aotearoa, - hei whakamōhio i ngā kaipānui mō tētahi poroporoaki nui ka tū i te aonga ake.

I muri i te matenga o Philip Basham i te tau 1963 nā tana tama nā David i kawe whakamua te niupepa. Nō te tau 1978 nā Basham me ētahi o ana hoa tokorua i hoko te Bay Sun, he tohanga noa tōna ki te takiwā o Tauranga, ā, ka whakahanumitia ki te Te Puke Times. I roto i te putanga o ia Tūrei ngā pitopito kōrero o Te Puke, engari kāore ngā kaipānui me ngā kaituku pānui i rata ki tēnei āhua, ā, nō te tau 1982 ka whakarewaina anō te ingoa me ngā kai katoa o te rohe o te Te Puke Times.

Nō te tau 1983 ka hokona te kamupene ki a John Wood ā, i te tau 1985, ki NZ News Ltd. I te tau 1989, nā Independent News Ltd (INL) i hoko tētahi wāhi o NZ News, tae atu ki te Te Puke Times me ētahi atu niupepa ā-rohe. Nō te tau 2002 nā Wilson and Horton, e mōhiotia nei ko APN NZ Ltd ināianei, i hoko te niupepa mai i Independent Community Newspapers (INL). He mea whakaputa te wikiri hoatu noa e te Bay of Plenty Times koia hoki tētahi o te kāhui niupepa ā-rohe a APN News & Media.

Publication.Title: Star
Publication.Title-alternate: The Star, Sun, Christchurch Times; Christchurch Star-Sun
Publication.Description: The Star began publication as the evening edition of the Lyttelton Times on 14 May 1868. Although subject to intense competition during the early decades of the last century the Star survived and continues to be published today as a bi-weekly community newspaper.

Ko te tīmatanga o te Star hei putanga ahiahi o te Lyttelton Times kē nō te 14 o Mei o te tau 1868. He ahakoa te kaha o te whakataetae i ngā tekau tau tuatahi o tērā rautau, ka ora tonu mai te Star ki tēnei rā hei nūpepa ā-hapori, e rua tānga ia wiki.
Publication.Essay:
The Star began publication as the evening edition of the Lyttelton Times on 14 May 1868.

The Star established itself as a reliable but unremarkable newspaper. Probably the most noteworthy thing the Star did in its early years was to bring out a Saturday night sports edition which immediately became popular. Things livened up for the Star in 1914 with the publication of a rival evening paper, the Sun. The Sun was a new type of newspaper in New Zealand. Modelled on the London Daily Mail it had a bright layout, heavy use of illustrations and an independent attitude. It was immediately popular with the public. Christchurch was now overburdened with newspapers - there were three evening, two morning and two weekly newspapers.

The first casualty was the Evening News which ceased in 1917. The depression brought further need for rationalisation and competition intensified. In November 1934 the Star dropped its price from 2d to 1d. The other dailies in Christchurch soon followed. As a result there was demand for Christchurch papers outside Canterbury and eventually most South Island papers reduced their price. The price cutting proved unsustainable and, in June 1935, the Christchurch morning papers agreed to raise the price back to 2d. However the struggle continued between the Sun and the Star. The conflict was settled with help from the Newspaper Proprieters Association. New Zealand Newspapers Ltd, the owners of the Star and the Lyttelton Times (now called the Christchurch Times), purchased the Sun and agreed to cease publication of the Times. The Press Co. purchased the goodwill of the Times. In June 1935 the Sun was incorporated into the Star and became a new newspaper called the Christchurch Star-Sun. In the same month the Christchurch Times ceased, leaving Christchurch with one morning paper, the Press and one evening paper, the Star-Sun.

The Star-Sun changed title several times and was called the Christchurch Star when it ceased daily publication in 1991. The Star continues to be published as a bi-weekly community newspaper.

Ko te tīmatanga o te Star hei putanga ahiahi o te Lyttelton Times kē nō te 14 o Mei o te tau 1868.

Ka tū te Star hei nūpepa pono, he ahakoa tana kore hautupua. Tērā pea ko te mea rongonui o ōna tau tuatahi te tānga i tētahi wāhanga hākinakina, i tōna putanga mai tonu, i pai wawe ki te iwi. Nō te tau 1914, nō te putanga o te tāwhainga pepa ahiahi te Sun ka whakaohongia ake ai te Star. Ko te Sun he tūmomo nūpepa hou ki Niu Tīreni. Ko tōna tauira ko te London Daily Mail, he whakatakotoranga kānapanapa, kikī ana i te whakaahua, me te waiaro wehe kē. He tere pai ki te iwi whānui i tana putanga. Ka maha rawa ngā nūpepa o Ōtautahi i taua wā - e toru mō te ahiahi, e rua mō te ata, e rua ia wiki.

Ko te aituā tuatahi ko te Evening News i mutu i te tau 1917. He pūtake whakawhāiti mai i te pōuritanga, ā, ka kaha ake te tāwhainga. Nō te marama o Noema o te tau 1934 ka whakahekea te utu o te Star mai i 2d ki te 1d. Kātahi ka whāia e ērā o ngā nūpepa ia rā o Ōtautahi. Te mutunga iho he hiahia i waho o Ngā Pākihi-whakatekateka-a-Waitaha (Canterbury) ki ngā nūpepa o Ōtautahi, kātahi ka iti ake te utu o te nuinga o ngā nūpepa o Te Waipounamu. Kāore i taea te mauroa i te itinga iho o te utu, ā, nō te marama o Hune o te tau 1935, ka whakaaea e ngā nūpepa ata o Ōtautahi te whakahoki i te utu ki te 2d. Heoi anō, ka haere tonu te tāwhainga i waenga i te Sun me te Star. I tau te puehu i te āwhina mai a te Rōpū o ngā Rangatira Nūpepa (Newspaper Proprietors' Association). Nā New Zealand Newspapers Ltd, ngā rangatira o te Star me te Lyttelton Times (ko te Christchurch Times tōna ingoa hou), te Sun i hoko, ā, ka whakaaea te katinga o te Times. Nā te Press Co. te kaingākaunui o te Times i hoko. Nō te marama o Hune o te tau 1935 ka whakakotahitia te Sun me te Star hei nūpepa hou, te Christchurch Star-Sun. Nō taua marama anō, ka katia ai te Christchurch Times ka noho kia kotahi noa te nūpepa ata o Ōtautahi, te Press, me tētahi mea ahiahi, te Star-Sun.

He maha ngā ingoa o te Star-Sun, ā, koia te Christchurch Star i tōna mutunga hei nūpepa ia-rā i te tau 1991. Kei te haere tonu te Star hei nūpepa hapori e rua tānga ki te wiki.

Publication.Title: Tuapeka Times
Publication.Description: The Tuapeka Times expired quietly in November 1941. The only hint that it was about to cease publication was an editorial in the last issue exhorting the public to support local newspapers in general. The paper probably succumbed to shortages of paper and labour due to the War and the death, three years before, of its long-serving manager, John Norrie. In this the Times wasn’t alone: many other country newspapers in New Zealand shut up shop at this time for want of resources. It is likely that the paper had struggled for years to remain open. It had only published bi-weekly since 1873 and with usually no more than four pages to an issue.

I mate puku atu te Tuapeka Times i a Whiringa-ā-rangi o te tau 1941. Ko tētahi kupu whakapuaki i roto i te tānga whakamutunga, e aki ana i te iwi whānui kia tautokona whānuitia ngā nūpepa kāinga o te motu, koia anake te tohu iti e mutu ai ana mahi tā. I hemo tonu pea te nūpepa i ngā kōpaka pepa, kōpaka kaimahi hoki i puta i te Pakanga o te Ao, i te matenga anō hoki, e toru tau ki mua, o tōna kaiwhakahaere tūroa, o John Norrie. I tēnei āhuatanga kāore te Times i tū ko tōna kotahi: he maha noa atu ngā nūpepa taiwhenua o Niu Tireni i kati ai i ō rātou kūwaha i taua wā i te kōpaka rauemi. Kei te tika tonu pea i maha ngā tau i whawhai te nūpepa ki te noho puare tonu. Mai i te tau 1873 e rua noa āna tānga ia wiki, ā, te nuinga o te wā kāore i hipa ake ia tānga i te whā whārangi.
Publication.Essay:
The Tuapeka Times was published in Lawrence, in Central Otago from 1868 to 1941. The Times was started by Andrew Ferguson, Andrew Burns and John Ludford.

In 1869 they took over their rival, the Tuapeka Press (1866-69). In 1881 the Times was bought by Thomas and Richard Pilling. They published it till 1896 when it was sold to the Tuapeka Times Company, managed by John Norrie. Norrie remained in charge of the paper until his death in 1938.

The Tuapeka Times expired quietly in November 1941. The only hint that it was about to cease publication was an editorial in the last issue exhorting the public to support local newspapers in general. The paper probably succumbed to shortages of paper and labour due to the War and the death, three years before, of its long-serving manager, John Norrie. In this the Times wasn’t alone: many other country newspapers in New Zealand shut up shop at this time for want of resources. It is likely that the paper had struggled for years to remain open. It had only published bi-weekly since 1873 and with usually no more than four pages to an issue.

The nature of the Times’ demise contrasts with its early years when the paper was at the centre of the gold boom in Central Otago. Gabriel’s Gully, the site of New Zealand’s most significant gold find, was nearby. The Times was a product of the boom and the issues from this time are an essential resource for the study of New Zealand’s history in the mid nineteenth century, when the gold from this area made Otago the leading province in the colony.

I whakaputaina te Tuapeka Times i te tāone o Lawrence, i Otākou o Waenganui mai i te tau 1868 ki te tau 1941. Nā Andrew Ferguson, rātou ko Andrew Burns, ko John Ludford te Times i tīmata.

I te tau 1869 i taumanutia e rātou tō rātou tāwhainga, te Tuapeka Press (1866-69). I te tau 1881 nā Thomas rāua ko Richard Pilling te Times i hoko. Ka whakaputaina e rāua tae noa ki te tau 1896, i hokona atu ai ki te Kamupene o te Tuapeka Times, nā John Norrie i whakahaere. Ka noho ko Norrie te rangatira o te nūpepa tae noa ki tōna matenga i te tau 1938.

I mate puku atu te Tuapeka Times i a Whiringa-ā-rangi o te tau 1941. Ko tētahi kupu whakapuaki i roto i te tānga whakamutunga, e aki ana i te iwi whānui kia tautokona whānuitia ngā nūpepa kāinga o te motu, koia anake te tohu iti e mutu ai ana mahi tā. I hemo tonu pea te nūpepa i ngā kōpaka pepa, kōpaka kaimahi hoki i puta i te Pakanga o te Ao, i te matenga anō hoki, e toru tau ki mua, o tōna kaiwhakahaere tūroa, o John Norrie. I tēnei āhuatanga kāore te Times i tū ko tōna kotahi: he maha noa atu ngā nūpepa taiwhenua o Niu Tireni i kati ai i ō rātou kūwaha i taua wā i te kōpaka rauemi. Kei te tika tonu pea i maha ngā tau i whawhai te nūpepa ki te noho puare tonu. Mai i te tau 1873 e rua noa āna tānga ia wiki, ā, te nuinga o te wā kāore i hipa ake ia tānga i te whā whārangi.

He rerekē te āhua o te matenga o te Times ina whakaritea ki ōna tau tīmata i noho ai te nūpepa ki waenganui tonu i te wā e tino reia ana te koura e ngā kairapu koura i Otākou o Waenganui. I pātata hoki a Gabriel’s Gully ki te wāhi i kitea ai tō Niu Tireni kitenga tino hiranga tonu o te koura. He whakaputanga te Times nō taua wā rapu koura, nā reira ka noho āna tānga o tērā wā hei rauemi tino waiwai tonu o te ako i te hītori o Niu Tireni i waenganui o te rautau tekau mā iwa, te wā i mea ai e te koura ko Otākou te porowini o mua tonu o te taiwhenua.

Publication.Title: Upper Hutt Weekly Review
Publication.Description: The Upper Hutt Weekly Review was the predecessor to the Upper Hutt Leader. It was started in 1935 by Ralph Ashford, a British immigrant with a printing background. During the production of the Weekly Review, he started the Upper Hutt Printing Company, which was considered by some to be more significant than the newspaper.

Ko te Upper Hutt Weekly Review te āhuatanga tuatahi o te Upper Hutt Leader. I tīmataria i te tau 1935 e Ralph Ashford, he tangata i tae mai ki Aotearoa i Ingarangi, he mōhio ki ngā mahi tā. I roto i ngā tau o te putanga o te Weekly Review, nāna i tīmata te Upper Hutt Printing Company. Ki ētahi he hira ake taua kamupene tā i te niupepa nāna i tīmata.
Publication.Essay:
The Upper Hutt Weekly Review was the predecessor to the Upper Hutt Leader. It was started in 1935 by Ralph Ashford, a British immigrant with a printing background. During the production of the Weekly Review, he started the Upper Hutt Printing Company, which was considered by some to be more significant than the newspaper.

The Weekly Review was the only active newspaper in Upper Hutt at the time, and was printed in Wellington. It holds a wealth of information about historical Upper Hutt, a significant contribution being letters to the editor regarding the ‘old days’, personal stories about living in Upper Hutt at the turn of the twentieth century.

Ko te Upper Hutt Weekly Review te āhuatanga tuatahi o te Upper Hutt Leader. I tīmataria i te tau 1935 e Ralph Ashford, he tangata i tae mai ki Aotearoa i Ingarangi, he mōhio ki ngā mahi tā. I roto i ngā tau o te putanga o te Weekly Review, nāna i tīmata te Upper Hutt Printing Company. Ki ētahi he hira ake taua kamupene tā i te niupepa nāna i tīmata.

Ko te Weekly Review anake te niupepa ora o Whakatiki i taua wā, ā, i tāngia ki Pōneke. He tini ngā kōrero ātaahua kei te niupepa nei mō Whakatiki i ngā rā o mua. Tētahi wāhanga nui ko ngā reta ki te etita mō 'ngā rā o nehe' arā, he kōrero nā ngā pakeke mō te noho i Whakatiki i te hurihanga o te rau tau rua tekau.
