E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki nga Upper Hutt City Library , nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Victoria Times
Publication.Description: The Victoria Times was only published once but is noteworthy for several reasons; it was Wellington's second earliest paper, it was lithographed rather than letter-pressed and it contains a plan of Wellington on the back page. The plan was hand-coloured in some issues although not the one presented here.

Kotahi noa te tānga o te Victoria Times, ēngari he mea nui tonu; ko ia te tuarua o ngā pepa moata o Te Whanganui-a-Tara; he mea perehi ā-waituhi ēngari mō te perehi ā-reta, he mahere hoki o Te Whanganui-a-Tara kei tōna whārangi whakamutunga. He mea peita ā-ringa ki ētahi putanga, ēngari he rerekē tēnei nā.
Publication.Essay:
The Victoria Times was only published once but is noteworthy for several reasons; it was Wellington's second earliest paper, it was lithographed rather than letter-pressed and it contains a plan of Wellington on the back page. The plan was hand-coloured in some issues although not the one presented here.

The Victoria Times was published by Thomas Bluett and Jacob Jones. They had previously produced lithographs for the New Zealand Company, including a chart of Port Nicholson that's now recognized as New Zealand's first lithograph. Given that the Company had a strong interest in Wellington’s other newspaper, the New Zealand Gazette, the decision to publish a rival paper seems reckless. And is presumably one of the reasons why the paper failed to appear again. Another possible reason for the paper’s brief life was that the partnership of Bluett and Jones did not endure. Jones announced its dissolution in the Gazette in late 1841.

Bluett moved to Tasmania. Records show him operating a lithographic firm in Hobart in 1842. Examples of his work are held in various archives in Australia. He died in England in 1846.

Kotahi noa te tānga o te Victoria Times, ēngari he mea nui tonu; ko ia te tuarua o ngā pepa moata o Te Whanganui-a-Tara; he mea perehi ā-waituhi ēngari mō te perehi ā-reta, he mahere hoki o Te Whanganui-a-Tara kei tōna whārangi whakamutunga. He mea peita ā-ringa ki ētahi putanga, ēngari he rerekē tēnei nā.

Nā Thomas Bluett rāua ko Jacob Jones te Victoria Times i tā. Nā rāua rā i mua te tā perehi ā-waituhi mō te Nū Tīreni Kamupene, tae atu ana ki tētahi mahere o Pōneke e rongonuitia ana ko ia te perehi -waituhi tuatahi o Aotearoa. He whai pānga anō te Kamupene ki tērā atu o ngā nūpepa o Te Whanganui-ā-Tara, te New Zealand Gazette, he āhua mōrearea kē pea nō te whakataunga kia tāngia tētahi pepa anō. Ko ia pea te take i kore ai tēnei nūpepa e kitea anō. Ko tētahi take anō pea mō te oranga rangi tahi o te nūpepa nei, kāore i mau roa te hoatanga o Bluett rāua ko Jones. Nā Jones tōna whakakorenga i pānui ki te Kāhiti i te whakamutunga o te 1841.

Ka nuku a Bluett ki Tahimēnia. Mai i ngā pūrongo o te wā, ko tāna he whakahaere i tētahi kamupene perehi ā-waituhi i Hobart i te 1842. Kei ētahi pūranga puta noa i Ahitereiria ētahi tauira o āna mahi. Ka mate ia i Ingarangi i te 1846.

Publication.Title: Waiapu Church Gazette
Publication.Description: From 1 July 1910, the Diocese of Waiapu Parish magazine was incorporated into the new Church Gazette. The cost of the new paper was raised to 3 shillings per annum, from two shillings. For this subscribers would received a much larger paper.

Mai i te 1 Hūrae 1910, i whakakotahitia mai te moheni o te Diocese of Waiapu Parish ki roto i te Church Gazette hou. I whakapikia te utu mō te nūpepa hōu ki te 3 herengi ia tau, i te 2 herengi. Tērā noa ake te rahi o te nūpepa hou i tae atu ki te hunga hoko, i tō te nūpepa tawhito.
Publication.Copyright: The Diocese of Waiapu is the copyright owner for the Waiapu Church Gazette. You will need to get their consent to reproduce in-copyright material from this newspaper. For advice on reproduction of out-of-copyright material from this newspaper, please refer to the Copyright guide .

Ko te Pīhopatanga o Waiapu te kaipupuri i te manatārua mō te Waiapu Church Gazette. Me mātua kimi tō rātou whakaae kia tāruatia ngā rawa whai-manatārua i tēnei nūpepa. Mō ētahi tohutohu mō ngā rawa kua puta i te manatārua mai i tēnei nūpepa, tēnā titiro ki te Puka mō te Manatārua .
Publication.Essay:
From 1 July 1910, the Diocese of Waiapu Parish magazine was incorporated into the new Church Gazette. The cost of the new paper was raised to 3 shillings per annum, from two shillings. For this subscribers would received a much larger paper. The Rev. Canon Tuke requested that ‘…all who owe anything for last year’s magazine will promptly remit it to the Vicar, who is considerably out of pocket in his attempt to give the Parish a good Church Paper.’ In fact, only personal financial support from the Bishop of Waiapu, Alfred Averill, ensured its early survival.

Not surprisingly, there was a break in publication for several months after the 3 February 1931 earthquake. The 1 May 1931 issue begins with a letter from the Bishop, outlining the impact of the earthquake on Diocesan property, including the complete destruction of the Cathedral.

The article ‘Synod scuttles ‘Gazette’’ in the issue of 1 November 1945 announced the impending end to publication of the Waiapu Church Gazette. The Gazette was to be amalgamated with the Church and People from Wellington and the Gazette from Auckland. This decision did not meet with the agreement of the author. This was made even clearer in the following and final issue of the Waiapu Church Gazette, 1 December 1945. Particular objection was expressed to the new focus on advertising and making a profit.

Mai i te 1 Hūrae 1910, i whakakotahitia mai te moheni o te Diocese of Waiapu Parish ki roto i te Church Gazette hou. I whakapikia te utu mō te nūpepa hōu ki te 3 herengi ia tau, i te 2 herengi. Tērā noa ake te rahi o te nūpepa hou i tae atu ki te hunga hoko, i tō te nūpepa tawhito. I puta te inoi a Kānona Tuke ‘…ko nga tāngata katoa kei te noho nama tonu mō te moheni o tērā tau me tuku tonu mai te moni ki te Minita, nā te mea ka nui ngā raruraru i utua e ia i runga i tōna māia ki te whakaputa nūpepa tōtika mā te Pāriha.’ Me kī, nā ngā āwhina ā-pūtea anake a te Pīhopa o Waiapu, a Alfred Averill, i puta ai tōna ihu.

I mutu te puta o te nūpepa mō ētahi marama i muri i te rū nui o te 3 o Pēpuere 1931, mārama tonu te take i pērā ai. I te tīmatanga o te putanga o te 1 o Mei 1931 tētahi reta nā te Pīhopa, e whakatau ana i te pānga o te rū ki ngā rawa o te Rohe Pīhopa, taea atu ki te horonga katoa o te Cathedral.

I roto i te tuhinga ‘Synod scuttles ‘Gazette’’ i te putanga o te 1 Noema 1945 ka puta ngā kōrero mō te mutunga, meāke ka mana, o te Waiapu Church Gazette. Ko te whakaaro kia whakakotahitia mai te Gazette ki roto i te Church and People i Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara me te Gazette i Tāmaki-makau-rau. Kāore tēnei whakaaro i whakaaetia e te kaituhi. I tino mārama tēnei whakahē i te putanga whakamutunga o te Waiapu Church Gazette, i te 1 o Tīhema 1945. Ko te mea i tino whakahētia nuitia ko te aronga atu hou ki te putanga o ngā pānui hokohoko me te arumoni.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank the Diocese of Waiapu and the John Kinder Theological Library for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
Kei te whakamoemiti te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Diocese of Waiapu me te John Kinder Theological Library mō ēnei tari i āwhina i te whakamamatitanga o tēnei taitara.

Publication.Title: Waiapu Church Times
Publication.Description: The first issue of this monthly newspaper was published in Napier on 1 July 1907 by the Diocese of Waiapu. The joint editors were the Rev. Canon Mayne and the Rev. Canon Tuke, supported by fellow committee members Mr F.W. Williams, Mr C.H. Edwards and Mr. J.B. Fielder. It was available at the price of one penny.

I puta tuatahi mai tēnei nūpepa ā-marama i Ahuriri i te 1 o ngā rā o Hūrae 1907, ā, nā te Diocese of Waiapu i whakaputa. Ko ngā ētita ko Kānona Mayne rāua ko Kānona Tuke, ā, ko ngā mema komiti tautoko ko F.W. Williams, ko C.H. Edwards me J.B. Fielder. Ko te utu mō te nūpepa, kotahi kapa.
Publication.Essay:
The first issue of this monthly newspaper was published in Napier on 1 July 1907 by the Diocese of Waiapu. The joint editors were the Rev. Canon Mayne and the Rev. Canon Tuke, supported by fellow committee members Mr F.W. Williams, Mr C.H. Edwards and Mr. J.B. Fielder. It was available at the price of one penny.

Issued ‘at the express wish of the Synod’, fellow clergy were asked for their co-operation in sending their Parish news regularly every month. This Parish news remained a feature of the Waiapu Church Times, along with Church news from around the world and occasional advertisements.

Only twelve issues were produced; the last issue, dated June 1908, featured a call for support on the front page: ‘The editors would impress upon the clergy and church people of the diocese the urgent necessity of greater support if the paper is to continue.’ One can only conclude that this support was not forthcoming. The Waiapu Church Times was reported as being discontinued in the 1908 Waiapu Synod proceedings.

I puta tuatahi mai tēnei nūpepa ā-marama i Ahuriri i te 1 o ngā rā o Hūrae 1907, ā, nā te Diocese of Waiapu i whakaputa. Ko ngā ētita ko Kānona Mayne rāua ko Kānona Tuke, ā, ko ngā mema komiti tautoko ko F.W. Williams, ko C.H. Edwards me J.B. Fielder. Ko te utu mō te nūpepa, kotahi kapa.

He mea whakaputa tēnei ‘i runga i te karanga a te Hīnota kia puta he nūpepa pēnei’ ā, i tonoa ngā hoa minita kia āwhina, mā te tono mai i ā rātou pitopito kōrero ā-Pāriha ia marama, ia marama. Ko ngā rongo ā-Pāriha nei tētahi wāhi nui o te Waiapu Church Times, tae atu ki ngā rongo kōrero ā-Hāhi o te ao katoa, me ngā pānui hokohoko i ētahi wā.

Tekau mā rua noa iho ngā putanga i tāia, ā, ko te mea whakamutunga i tāia ki te rā 12 o Hune 1908, me tōna karanga āwhina i te whārangi o mua: ‘Tēnei ngā ētita te akiaki nei i ngā hoa minita me ngā tāngata katoa o te hāhi, kia tino huri mai koutou ki te āwhina i te nūpepa, me pēnei anake e puta tonu mai ai te nūpepa nei ki te ao.’ Heoi anō te kōrero, kāore pea he āwhina pērā rawa te nui i tae mai. I puta te pūrongo, kua whakamutua te Waiapu Church Times i roto i ngā tuhinga mō te Waiapu Synod o te tau 1908.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank the Diocese of Waiapu and the John Kinder Theological Library for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
Kei te whakamoemiti te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Diocese of Waiapu me te John Kinder Theological Library mō ēnei tari i āwhina i te whakamamatitanga o tēnei taitara.

Publication.Title: Wairarapa Daily Times
Publication.Description: The first Wairarapa newspapers were published in Greytown. Joseph Payton, a school teacher, was a partner with his father-in-law Richard Wakelin in one of them, the bi-weekly Wairarapa Standard which began publication in 1872. However, when Payton decided Masterton was destined to be the largest town in the valley, he convened a meeting in the more northerly town to discuss beginning a newspaper there. There were several short-lived attempts from the end of 1874, not helped by the premises of two papers being burned to the ground. Subsequently, Joseph Payton, now in partnership with W F Roydhouse and Edward Samuel began, in November 1878, the region’s first daily, the Wairarapa Daily. It absorbed one of the town’s struggling papers.

I whakaputaina ngā niupepa tuatahi o te Wairarapa ki Hūpēnui (Greytown). Ko Joseph Payton, he kaiwhakaako kura, he hoa pakihi hoki a ia ki a Richard Wakelin tōna hungarei i tētahi o ngā niupepa, te Wairarapa Standard he mea whakaputa ia rua wiki, i tīmataria i te tau 1872. Heoi anō, i te whakataunga a Payton ka tipu a Whakaoriori (Masterton) hei taone nui o te riu, ka whakatūria e ia he hui ki taua taone rā ki te raki, ki te whakawhitiwhiti kōrero mō te tīmata i tētahi niupepa ki reira. E rua ngā whakamātautau poto noa iho mai i te mutunga o 1874, i raru anō hoki i runga i te mea ko ngā whare o ngā niupepa e rua i kainga e te ahi. I muri iho i tīmataria e Joseph Payton, e mahi ā-hoa pakihi ana i te taha o W F Roydhouse rāua ko Edward Samuel, i te Nōema o te tau 1878, te niupepa tuatahi o te rohe, arā, te Wairarapa Daily. I whakawhenumitia e ia tētahi o ngā niupepa e raru ana o te taone.
Publication.Essay:
The first Wairarapa newspapers were published in Greytown. Joseph Payton, a school teacher, was a partner with his father-in-law Richard Wakelin in one of them, the bi-weekly Wairarapa Standard which began publication in 1872. However, when Payton decided Masterton was destined to be the largest town in the valley, he convened a meeting in the more northerly town to discuss beginning a newspaper there. There were several short-lived attempts from the end of 1874, not helped by the premises of two papers being burned to the ground. Subsequently, Joseph Payton, now in partnership with W F Roydhouse and Edward Samuel began, in November 1878, the region’s first daily, the Wairarapa Daily. It absorbed one of the town’s struggling papers.

Initially, Payton was editor, sub-editor and business manager on the four-page evening paper, Roydhouse was general reporter and Samuel supplied articles on a more casual basis. Edward Samuel retired from the enterprise when he was appointed headmaster of the Carterton School in 1880, leaving Messrs Payton and Roydhouse as partners. By 1878 the railway had reached only as far as Featherston, so for the next two years William Roydhouse spent considerable time in the saddle covering events in the lower valley. The railway reached Masterton in 1880, simplifying distribution, previously by relays of horses, and the town grew as Payton had foreseen. The 1878 population of 1,673 had nearly doubled to 3,160 by 1886.

The first printing machine consisted of a large non-stop drum, with one employee feeding in the paper at the top and a boy at the back taking off the printed sheets which were then folded by hand. The power was generated by a flywheel turned by two more boys. About 1903, an Elliott printing press was installed, first driven by a gas engine and later converted to electricity.

In 1892, the paper, now well-established, changed its name to the Wairarapa Daily Times. There was evening competition from the Wairarapa Star for a number of years, one of its editors being Alexander W Hogg, later MP for Masterton and a cabinet minister in 1909. Following changes in ownership, the Star was reborn as a morning daily, the Wairarapa Age, in 1902. Later editors included A H Vile and Guy H Scholefield, who became Parliamentary Librarian in 1926.

Joseph Payton, who kept plant and type up-to-date, ran one of the country’s best produced provincial newspapers until his death in 1910. It also had a reputation for the quality and depth of its local coverage. A private Payton family company then ran the Wairarapa Daily Times until it merged with the Wairarapa Times-Age in 1938. In 2002 the newspaper was bought by Wilson & Horton which was subsequently acquired by APN News & Media.

I whakaputaina ngā niupepa tuatahi o te Wairarapa ki Hūpēnui (Greytown). Ko Joseph Payton, he kaiwhakaako kura, he hoa pakihi hoki a ia ki a Richard Wakelin tōna hungarei i tētahi o ngā niupepa, te Wairarapa Standard he mea whakaputa ia rua wiki, i tīmataria i te tau 1872. Heoi anō, i te whakataunga a Payton ka tipu a Whakaoriori (Masterton) hei taone nui o te riu, ka whakatūria e ia he hui ki taua taone rā ki te raki, ki te whakawhitiwhiti kōrero mō te tīmata i tētahi niupepa ki reira. E rua ngā whakamātautau poto noa iho mai i te mutunga o 1874, i raru anō hoki i runga i te mea ko ngā whare o ngā niupepa e rua i kainga e te ahi. I muri iho i tīmataria e Joseph Payton, e mahi ā-hoa pakihi ana i te taha o W F Roydhouse rāua ko Edward Samuel, i te Nōema o te tau 1878, te niupepa tuatahi o te rohe, arā, te Wairarapa Daily. I whakawhenumitia e ia tētahi o ngā niupepa e raru ana o te taone.

I te tīmatanga ko Payton te ētita, te ētita tuarua me te kaiwhakahaere pakihi ki te pepa o te ahiahi e whā ngā whārangi, ko Roydhouse te kairīpoata whānui, ā, nā Samuel ētahi tuhi pānui i tuku poka noa nei. I te whakatūnga a Edward Samuel ki te tūranga o te tumuaki o te kura o Carterton i te tau 1880 i puta a ia i te umanga, ka waiho ko Payton rāua ko Roydhouse hei hoa pakihi ki a rāua anō. Nō te tau 1878 kua tae noa iho te rerewhenua (te tereina) ki Kaiwaewae (Featherston), nō reira mō ngā tau e rua he eke hoiho te mahi a William Roydhouse e hopu ana i ngā rongo kōrero o te riu i raro. I tae te rerewhenua ki Whakaoriori i te tau 1880, hei whakamāmā i te tuaritanga, arā, te mahi a ngā tānga hōiho i mua, ā, i tipu te taone pērā i te matapae a Payton. Nō te tau 1878 kua tata taurua te taupori mai i te 1,673 ki te 3,160 i te tau 1886.

Ko te āhua o te perehi tā tuatahi he taramu kore mutunga nui, he whāngai pepa i mua te mahi a tētahi kaimahi, ko te mahi a tētahi tama i muri he tango i ngā rau kua oti te tā, kātahi ka pōkai ā-ringa aua rau. I ahu mai te kaha i tētahi wīra rere ka hurihia e ētahi tama e rua anō. I te tau āhua 1903, i whakaurua he perehi tā Elliott, nā tētahi pūkaha hau te kaha i te tuatahi, nō muri i hurihia ai ki te hiko.

I te tau 1892 i hurihia te ingoa o te pepa, kua roa e haere ana ināianei, ki te Wairarapa Daily Times. I whakaritea tētahi whakataetae mai i te Wairarapa Star mō ētahi tau, ko tētahi o ana ētita ko Alexander W Hogg, i muri i tērā ko ia te Mema Pāremata mā Whakaoriori, he minita o te rūnanga o te kāwanatanga hoki i te tau 1909. Nō muri mai i te hokotanga mai a tētahi atu ka whānau mai anō te Star hei pepa o te ata, ā, ka tapaina ko te Wairarapa Age i te tau 1902. Ko ētahi o ngā ētita i muri atu ko A H Vile, ko Guy H Scholefield hoki, i riro i a ia te tūranga a te Kaitiaki Pukapuka Whare Pāremata i te tau 1926.

Nā Joseph Payton, he tangata kaha ki te whakahou i āna rawa, i āna momotuhi hoki, nāna i whakahaere tētahi o ngā tino pepa ā-rohe o te whenua tae noa ki tōna matenga i te tau 1910. He rongonui hoki taua pepa mō te kounga me te hōhonu o āna rongo kōrero o te rohe paetata. I whakahaeretia te Wairarapa Daily Times e tētahi kamupene ā-whānau Payton tae atu ki te wā i hanumi atu ki te Wairarapa Times-Age i 1938. I 2002 i hokona te niupepa e Wilson & Horton, ā, i muri mai e APN News & Media.

Publication.Title: West Coast Times
Publication.Title-alternate: Hokitika Guardian, Guardian and Evening Star
Publication.Description: The West Coast Times started in May 1865, only two months after the Provincial Government in Canterbury had proclaimed the goldfield on the West Coast. The paper prospered on the back of the gold boom and rival newspapers were established in opposition. In 1917 the West Coast Times was absorbed into the Hokitika Guardian and Star, which ceased publication in 1988.

I tīmata te West Coast Times i te marama o Haratua 1865, e rua marama noa i muri o te pānuitanga o te pārae kōura i te Tai Poutini i a te Kāwanatanga Porowini i ngā Pākihi-whakatekateka-a-Waitaha. Whaihua ana te nūpepa i runga i te tōnuitanga o ngā kaikeri kōura, ā, whakaūhia ana ētahi nūpepa tauwhāinga hei mautohenga. I te tau 1917 ka hanumi te West Coast Times ki te Hokitika Guardian and Star, mutu ana te tānga o tēnei nūpepa i te tau 1988.
Publication.Essay:
The West Coast Times owes its existence to the gold rush on the West Coast in 1865. Before the gold rush there were few European settlers on the West Coast, certainly not enough to sustain a newspaper.

The West Coast Times was the first of many papers to start up in the Hokitika area after the rush began. The Times started in May 1865, only two months after the Provincial Government in Canterbury had proclaimed the goldfield on the West Coast. The paper was founded by John Tyrrell but soon sold to William Shaw, a local politician. Shaw was Mayor of Hokitika in 1867.

That the Times prospered on the back of the gold boom can be seen by its publishing activities. In 1865 a weekly edition for rural readers called the Leader was issued, in January 1866 the Times became a daily, and later that year they published a daily evening paper, the Despatch.

The boom in Hokitika and opposition to Shaw’s political activities encouraged others to set up newspapers in the town. The Times’ most serious rival was the Evening Star, founded by Joseph Klein and James Snyder Browne in 1867 mostly to oppose Shaw. The competition between these papers peaked in 1868 when Klein and Browne provided the financial backing and management for a new morning paper, the Westland Observer. Shaw responded by reviving the Despatch, his evening paper that had gone into abeyance the year before.

However the situation was soon resolved when Shaw decided to leave Hokitika. Klein and Browne bought the Times from him and immediately stopped publishing the Despatch and the Observer. From then to its demise in 1917 the Times’ history was much less eventful. Ownership changed several more times. In 1874 Robert Caldwell Reid took over. Reid was a prominent politician active in both provincial and national government. In the 1880s the paper was sold to Leonard Northcroft and Harry Snow and in 1917 it was sold to Dawes, Nightingale and Co. Later that year it was absorbed into the Hokitika Guardian and Star.

Nā te rerenga ki te kōura i te Tai Poutini i te tau 1865 i ora ai te West Coast Times. I mua o te rerenga kōura he ruarua noa iho ngā tāngata whai Pākehā i te Tai Poutini, he iti rawa hei ukauka i tētahi nūpepa.

Ko te West Coast Times te tuatahi o ngā nūpepa maha ki te tīmata i te takiwā o Hokitika i muri o te tīmatanga o te rerenga ki te kōura. I tīmata te West Coast Times i te marama o Haratua 1865, e rua marama noa i muri o te pānuitanga o te pārae kōura i te Tai Poutini i a te Kāwanatanga Porowini i ngā Pākihi-whakatekateka-a-Waitaha. I whakaūhia te nūpepa e John Tyrell, otirā taro tonu te hokonga ki a William Shaw, he kaitōrangapū o te rohe. Ko Shaw te Mea o Hokitika i te tau 1867.

Ko te angitu o te West Coast Times i takea mai i te tōnuitanga o te mahi kimi kōura, ka kitea i āna mahi pānui. I te tau 1865 ka puta tētahi tānga ā-wiki i huaina te Leader mō te hunga taiwhenua. Ka tīmata te tānga ia rā o te Times i te marama o Kohi-tātea 1866, ā, nō muri mai i taua tau anō ka perēhitia e rātou tētahi nūpepa ā-ahiahi ia rā, arā, te Despatch.

Nā te tōnuitanga i Hokitika me te mautohenga ki ngā mahi tōrangapū a Shaw i whakahau i ētahi atu kia whakaūhia he nūpepa i te tāone. Ko te Evening Star te tino tāwhai o te Times, nā Joseph Klein rāua ko James Snyder Browne i whakaū i te tau 1867, he mautohe ki a Shaw te tino take. I tae rawa te whakataetae i waenganui i ngā nūpepa ki tōna tihi i te tau 1868, i te whakaratonga o Klein rāua ko Browne i te pūtea tautoko, i te whakahaerenga hoki mō tētahi nūpepa ā-ata, arā, te Westland Observer. Ko te whakautu a Shaw ko te whakaoratanga i te Despatch, tana nūpepa ā-ahiahi i whakamutua i te tau i mua.

Heoi i whakatau tonu tēnei āhuatanga i te whakaritenga o Shaw ki te wehe atu i Hokitika. Ka hokona i a ia te Times e Klein rāua ko Browne, ā, whakamutua wawetia ana e rāua te tānga o te Despatch me te Observer. Mai i tērā wā tae noa ki tōna mutunga i 1917 he āhua hira kore te hītori o te Times. He maha tonu ngā whakawhitinga rangatiratanga. I te tau 1874 ka taumanu a Robert Caldwell Reid. He kaitōrangapū whakarae a Reid, he mātātoa ki ngā kāwanatanga ā-rohe, ā-motu hoki. I hokona te nūpepa ki a Leonard Northcroft rāua ko Harry Snow i te tekau tau mai i 1880, ā, i te tau 1917 ka hokona ki te kamupene o Dawes, Nightingale & Co. Nō muri mai i taua tau anō ka hanumi ki te Hokitika Guardian and Star.

I mutu te tānga o te Hokitika Guardian i te tau 1988.

Publication.Title: Wanganui Chronicle
Publication.Description: Wanganui was the first town in the wider Wellington region to have its own newspaper, the Wanganui Record, which was published for a few weeks in 1853. The Wanganui Chronicle began publication on 18 September 1856 and came out tri-weekly in 1867. Under competitive pressure it became a daily in 1871. The Chronicle continues today as Wanganui's only daily newspaper.

Ko Wanganui te tāone tuatahi o te rohe whānui o Te Upoko o te Ika i riro i te taone tana ake nūpepa. Ko taua nūpepa ko te Wanganui Record, ā, he rite tonu te puta mai mō ētahi wiki noa iho i te tau 1853. Ko te Wanganui Chronicle ka tīmata i te 18 o Mahuru i te tau 1856, ā, ka puta mai i ngā wā e toru i te wiki. Nō te kaha o te puta mai o ētahi ake nūpepa, ka tīmata te puta mai o te Wanganui Chronicle ia rā i te tau 1871. I pēnei nā rā, ko te Wanganui Chronicle te nūpepa o ia rā anake kei Wanganui.
Publication.Essay:
Wanganui was the first town in the wider Wellington region to have its own newspaper, the Wanganui Record which was published for a few weeks in 1853.

The Wanganui Chronicle was the next newspaper attempted in Wanganui. Henry Stokes first proposed the paper in 1856 but initially publication was held back by lack of equipment. The first issue was produced on 18 September 1856 on a makeshift press, made by staff and pupils at the local industrial school. Shortly after this Stokes imported a press from Sydney.

However in the 1860s the paper had competition from the Wanganui Times and the Evening Herald (later called the Wanganui Herald). The Times didn't survive the decade but the Herald, under John Ballance, established itself as a serious rival to the Chronicle. The Chronicle responded by publishing three times a week in 1867 (publication frequency had been erratic up till then) and then daily in 1871.

The two papers competed against each other strongly for the next 100 years or more. The Chronicle tended to represent conservative opinion while the Herald was more liberal. However, the rivalry was often friendly. In 1888 Ballance let the Chronicle use his equipment to produce their paper after the Chronicle office burnt down.

Like many 19th century New Zealand newspapers, the Chronicle changed hands a number of times. One of the most noteworthy owners and editors was Gilbert Carson who took over in 1875. Carson was Mayor of Wanganui from 1881 to 1884 and a member of the House of Representatives and the Legislative Council. He proved to be an effective opponent of John Ballance and the Wanganui Herald.

In the 1970s the ownership and the editorship of the Chronicle and the Herald merged and the two papers continued to come out separately (the Chronicle in the morning and the Herald in the evening). While it may have been intended to keep the papers distinct, in reality they became like two editions of the same paper. In 1986 the Herald was replaced with a community newspaper of the same name and the Chronicle continued on as Wanganui's daily newspaper.

Ko Wanganui te tāone tuatahi o te rohe whānui o Te Upoko o te Ika i riro i te taone tana ake nūpepa. Ko taua nūpepa ko te Wanganui Record, ā, he rite tonu te puta mai mō ētahi wiki noa iho i te tau 1853.

Ko te Wanganui Chronicle te nūpepa tuarua i puta mai i Wanganui I marohitia e Henry Stokes i te tau 1856. I te tīmatanga i uaua te mahi whakatā nō te mea kāhore he mīhini perehi. Ko te tānga tuatahi ka whakaputaina ki runga i tētahi mīhini perehi whakakapi i te 18 o Mahuru 1856. Nā ngā kaiako me ngā tauira o te kura hangarau pātata i hanga. I muri tata i tēnei nā, ka hokona mai e Stokes tētahi mīhini perehi mai i Poihākena (Sydney).

Engari, i te tekau tau mai i 1860, ka tīmata mai te nūpepa ko te Wanganui Times me te Evening Herald (ka karangahia ā muri ake ko te Wanganui Herald). Kāhore te Wanganui Times i tū mō te tekau tau ki muri. Engari ka tino ora te Herald i raro i Te Paranihi (John Ballance), ā, ka tipu ake he tino nūpepa kaha ki te tū i te taha o te Chronicle. I tēnei nā, ka tīmata te Chronicle ki te puta mai i ngā rā e toru i ia wiki, ā, i te tau 1871 ka puta mai ia rā. Mō ngā tau ki mua i taua rā, he kōtītiti nei te āhua o te puta mai o te nūpepa.

Mō te rau tau i muri mai ka rite tonu te whakataetae o ngā nūpepa nei. Ko te Chronicle ka whai i ngā kaupapa whakatūpato. Ko te Herald, ka whai ake i ngā kaupapa atawhai. Ahakoa ngā taukumekume, he whakataetae ratarata nei. I te tau 1888, ka tukuna e Te Paranihi kia tāngia te Chronicle i runga ake i āna mīhini nō te mea i tahuna tā rātou tari ki te ahi.

I runga i ngā āhuatanga o ngā nūpepa o Aotearoa i tērā rau tau, ka rite tonu te whakawhiti i ngā kaipupuri o te Chronicle. Ko tētahi o ngā rangatira, ētita tino rongonui ko Gilbert Carson, ā, i uru mai ia i te tau 1875. Ko ia te Mea o te tāone o Wanganui mai i te tau 1881 ki te 1884, ā, ko ia hoki he mema mo te Whare Pāremata me te Kaunihera Ture. He tino kaitohetohe ia mō Te Paranihi me te Wanganui Herald.

I te tekau tau mai i 1970 ka tūhono ngā nūpepa e rua i raro i te rōpū kaipupuri, ētita kotahi, engari ka rite tonu te puta wehe mai (ko te Chronicle i te ata, ā, ko te Herald i te ahiahi). Ko te wawata kia noho wehe ngā nūpepa e rua nei, engari koa ka puta rāua i runga i te āhuatanga he ōrite ai ngā kōrero o tētahi ki tētahi. I te tau 1986 ka uru kē mai he nūpepa hapori e mau ana i te ingoa o te Herald. Engari ko te Chronicle kei te noho tonu ko te nūpepa o ia rā anake kei Wanganui.
Publication.Acknowledgement: The National Library would like to thank the Whanganui Regional Museum and Wanganui District Library for their assistance in the digitisation of this title.
E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Whanganui Regional Museum me te Wanganui District Library, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Waimate Daily Advertiser
Publication.Description: The Waimate Daily Advertiser began life as the Waimate Advertiser, a four-page weekly publication, on 28 May 1898. Editorially it aimed to be politically independent and described itself as taking an active interest in the social affairs of Waimate (in South Canterbury) and the surrounding district. The paper started publishing daily in 1914 and changed its name to the Waimate Daily Advertiser in 1916.

Ko te ingoa tuatahi o te Waimate Daily Advertiser ko te Waimate Advertiser, he whakaputanga whārangi-tokowhā i tāngia tuatahitia i te 28 o Haratua 1898. I whai kē i te āhuatanga tōrangapū motuhake mā ōna kaupapa ētita, ā, kātahi kē ka huri ki te kī he kawenga whai pānga ki ngā take ā-iwi o Waimate i te rohe o Ngā Pākihi-whakatekateka-a-Waitaha ki te Tonga (South Canterbury) me ōna takiwā tāpiri. I tīmata te nūpepa ki te whakaputa ia rā i te tau 1914 kātahi ka huri i tōna ingoa ki te Waimate Daily Advertiser i te tau 1916.
Publication.Essay:
The Waimate Advertiser started on the 28 May 1898 as a four-page weekly, and was published free for the first three months. It was founded by Charles Augustus and Harold Wilson, two brothers aged nineteen and seventeen, who were joined a year later by their younger brother George Wilson.

After six months the paper doubled in size and was issued as a weekly penny paper. By twelve months it came out three times a week to match its rival, the Waimate Times. Editorially the paper aimed to be politically independent and described itself as taking an active interest in the social affairs of Waimate and the surrounding district.

In 1908 the paper was taken over by S H Wilson (no relation to the original owners) with Robert Joseph Logan as editor. In 1914 it became a daily and in 1916 it was transferred to Logan and Mrs A K Sargent, who changed the name to the Waimate Daily Advertiser to reflect the earlier change in publication frequency.

In 1921 the paper was sold to the Waimate Advertiser Company, although Mrs Sargent retained the majority interest. The change in ownership again brought about a name change and the paper became the Daily Advertiser. In 1922 the company purchased the rival Waimate Times, leaving the Daily Advertiser as the town's sole newspaper.

The Waimate Publishing Company took over the business in 1939. In 1972 the paper changed back to its former title of Waimate Daily Advertiser, and from 1980 reverted to its original title of Waimate Advertiser. This last change coincided with a change back to being published three times a week.

I tīmata te Waimate Advertiser, he whakaputanga whārangi-tokowhā i te 28 o Haratua 1898, ā, i whakaputa kore utuhia mō ngā marama e toru ki te tuatahi. I tīmatahia e Charles Augustus me tana teina a Harold Wilson, tekau mā iwa me te tekau mā whitu ō rāua pakeke, ā, i uru atu tō rāua teina a George Wilson kotahi tau i muri mai.

Muri iho i ngā marama e ono kā tāruahia ake te nui o te nūpepa nei, ā, ka whakaputahia hei nūpepa ā-wiki tahi kapa. I muri mai i te tekau mā rua marama e toru kē ōna whakaputanga ia wiki kia ōrite atu ai ki tōna nūpepa whakataetae, ki te Waimate Times. I whai kē i te āhuatanga tōrangapū motuhake mā ōna kaupapa ētita, ā, kātahi kē ka huri ki te kī he kawenga whai pānga ki ngā take ā-iwi o Waimate me ōna takiwā tāpiri.

I te tau 1908 i riro i a S H Wilson (ēhara i te whanaunga ki ngā rangatira i tīmatahia ai) te mana whakahaere mō te nūpepa, ā, ko Robert Joseph Logan te ētita. I te tau 1914 ka huri kia puta ia rā, ā, i te tau 1916 i riro i a Logan rāua ko Mrs A K Sargent te mana whakahaere ka hurihia hoki te ingoa ki te Waimate Daily Advertiser kia hāngai ai ki te huringa o te whakaputanga o mua atu.

I te tau 1921 i hokona ai te nūpepa ki te kamupene ko te Waimate Advertiser Company, ēngari i mau tonu i a Mrs Sargent te nuinga o ngā hea. Nā te huringa o te mana whakahaere i hurihia anō te ingoa ki te Daily Advertiser. I te tau 1922 i hokona e taua kamupene te nūpepa whakataetae ko te Waimate Times kia riro ai te Daily Advertiser anake te nūpepa o taua tāone.

I riro i te kamupene kaiwhakaputa pukapuka, ko te Waimate Publishing Company, te pakihi nei i te tau 1939. I te tau 1972 i hoki anō te nūpepa ki tōna ingoa o mua ki te Waimate Daily Advertiser, ā, mai i te tau 1980 i hoki anō ki tōna ingoa tīmatanga ki te Waimate Advertiser. Mai i tēnei huringa whakamutunga ka hoki anō ki ngā whakaputanga e toru i te wiki.

E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Waimate Advertiser Office ki roto i Waimate, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Westport Times
Publication.Description: In keeping with the times, Westport, at the northern end of the Westland goldfields, had a colourful and often changing newspaper history. Near the mouth of the Buller River, and on its eastern bank, Westport’s early growth was principally due to the gold rush at Charlestown, 26 kms to the south. From 1866 to the end of the decade, the population in and around Charleston ballooned to about 10,000. At the peak of this gold rush in 1867, Westport’s population was about 1,500 but growth over subsequent decades was slow and sporadic.

E whai ana i te ia o te wā, i Westport, i te pito whakateraki o ngā papa koura o Westland, he whakamere, he nui hoki ngā piki me ngā heke o tōna hītori niupepa. Tata ki te wahapū o te Awa Buller, kei tōna ākau whakaterāwhiti, i tīmata ai te tupu o Westport i runga i ngā mahi rerenga koura i Charlestown, 26 km ki te Tonga. Mai i 1866 ki te mutunga o taua tekau tau i tere piki te taupori i Charleston, huri noa hoki ki te āhua 10,000 ngā tāngata. I te taumata o tēnei rerenga koura i 1867, he āhua 1,500 te taupori o Westport, engari he pōturi, he pokapoka hoki te pikinga i ngā tekau tau whai muri mai.
Publication.Essay:
In keeping with the times, Westport, at the northern end of the Westland goldfields, had a colourful and often changing newspaper history. Near the mouth of the Buller River, and on its eastern bank, Westport’s early growth was principally due to the gold rush at Charlestown, 26 kms to the south. From 1866 to the end of the decade, the population in and around Charleston ballooned to about 10,000. At the peak of this gold rush in 1867, Westport’s population was about 1,500 but growth over subsequent decades was slow and sporadic.

The first Westport newspaper was quickly on the scene. John Tyrrell, who learnt the printing trade in Dublin, arrived in New Zealand via Australia and a stint with the Melbourne Chronicle, Australia’s first, if short-lived, evening paper. He started the West Coast Times in Hokitika in 1865, launched the daily Waimea Chronicle in early 1866, and then the Westport Times in December that year. He began it as the Westport Times and Buller Express in partnership with Job Munson, an American-born printer, who began in the trade as a 11-year-old. Munson sold his holding several years before becoming a shareholder in the rival Westport News.

With Charleston booming, in 1867 the paper’s plant was moved there briefly and, also temporarily, its name changed to Westport Times and Charleston Argus. The name was shortened to Westport Times in 1869. It usually appeared twice weekly but, according to the Union List of NZ Newspapers Before 1940, there may have been periods when it came out three times a week or even daily.

In 1871, Irishman Eugene O’Connor, later a prominent South Island politician, briefly owned the paper before setting up the rival Westport News. Tyrrell, owner again, countered by producing the Westport Times as a daily for a period. In the early 1880s Tyrrell bought the Westport Evening Star, which had begun in 1867. In 1883, he was found guilty of libelling Charles Wright, in an ‘Open Column’ letter in the Star in relation to his conduct as borough valuer. Wright was also proprietor of the Buller News. Tyrrell was fined £50. In 1892, when Tyrrell died, the two papers merged to become the Westport Times and Evening Star. Later, probably in 1898, the then-daily became the Westport Times and Star.

Following John Tyrrell’s death, Thomas Patrick Williams became the managing proprietor. Born in Auckland, he joined the staff of the Westport Times as printer’s devil in 1872 and had become manager by 1885. The Cyclopedia of New Zealand (Nelson, Marlborough and Westland Provincial Districts), published in 1906, listed William Gothard as editor. An Australian, he had been apprenticed to Tyrrell in 1874, having worked in the Post Office previously and then ‘served through all branches of the newspaper and printing business’.

The newspaper continued as a daily until 1937 and a change of ownership and name. A new private company in Hokitika, with a capital of £300 in £1 shares, took over the Westport Times and Star and called it the Buller Times. It ceased publication on November 1, 1941.

E whai ana i te ia o te wā, i Westport, i te pito whakateraki o ngā papa koura o Westland, he whakamere, he nui hoki ngā piki me ngā heke o tōna hītori niupepa. Tata ki te wahapū o te Awa Buller, kei tōna ākau whakaterāwhiti, i tīmata ai te tupu o Westport i runga i ngā mahi rerenga koura i Charlestown, 26 km ki te Tonga. Mai i 1866 ki te mutunga o taua tekau tau i tere piki te taupori i Charleston, huri noa hoki ki te āhua 10,000 ngā tāngata. I te taumata o tēnei rerenga koura i 1867 , he āhua 1,500 te taupori o Westport, engari he pōturi, he pokapoka hoki te pikinga i ngā tekau tau whai muri mai.

Kāore i roa i puta mai te niupepa tuatahi o Westport. I ako a John Tyrrell i ngā mahi tā i ako i Dublin, ā, ka tae mai ki Aotearoa mā Ahitereiria, i tētahi mahi poto i te Melbourne Chronicle, te pepa ahiahi tuatahi o Ahitereiria mō te wā poto noa iho. Ka whakarewa ia i te West Coast Times i Hokitika i 1865, nāna hoki te Waimea Chronicle i whakatere i te tīmatanga o 1866, me te Westport Times i Hakihea i taua tau. Ko te Westport Times and Buller Express tōna ingoa i te tuatahi, ā, he mea tīmata i te taha o Job Munson, he kaitā i whānau mai i Amerika, i tīmata hoki ana mahi i a ia ka 11 noa iho ōna tau. I hokona atu e Munson ana hea ētahi tau i mua i tana hokonga mai i ngā hea o te niupepa tāwhai te Westport News.

Nā te nui o ngā mahi e tīmata ana i Charleston, i nuku te wheketere o te niupepa ki reira i te tau 1867, i huri hoki tōna ingoa mō te wā poto ki te Westport Times me te Charleston Argus. I whakarāpopotongia tōna ingoa ki te Westport Times i 1869. E rua ana putanga ia wiki engari e ai ki te Union List of NZ Newspapers before 1940, he wā tōna pea i whakaputaina e toru ngā wā ia wiki, ia rā rānei.

I 1871 i hokona e tētahi Airihi, a Eugene O'Conner, he kaitōrangapū rongonui ki te Waipounamu, te niupepa i mua te tana whakatū i te Westport Times hei niupepa tāwhai. I ātetetia ai e Tyrrell, mā te whakaputanga mō tētahi wā o te Westport Times hei putanga ā-rā. I te tīmatatanga o ngā tau 1880 i hokona e Tyrrell te Westport Evening Star, he mea i tīmata i te tau 1867. I 1883 i mau tangetange a ia mō te kupu whakakino i a Charles Wright i tētahi reta ‘Tīwae Tuwhera’ i te Star e pā ana ki ana whanonga hei kaiwhakatauuara mō te tāone. Ko Wright hoki te kaipupuri o te Buller News. I whuia a Tyrrell ki te £50. I 1892, i te matenga o Tyrrell, i hanumi ngā niupepa e rua, i hurihia te ingoa ki Westport Times and Evening Star. Nō muri mai, i te āhua 1898, i hurihia te ingoa ki te Westport Times and Star.

I muri i te matenga o John Tyrrell, ka riro i a Thomas Patrick Williams te tūranga a te kaiwhakahaere matua. I whānau mai a ia i Tāmaki makaurau, nō te tau 1872 i tīmata a ia ki te Westport Times hei pia kaitā, ā, nō te tau 1885 ka riro i a ia te tūranga a te kaiwhakahaere. I kīia i te Cyclopedia of New Zealand (Nelson, Marlborough and Westland Provincial Districts), he mea whakaputa i te tau 1906, ko William Gothard te ētita. Nō Ahitereiria ia, he pia ia ki a Tyrrell i 1874, he kaimahi i te Post Office i mua, katahi ka ‘mahi ia i ngā wāhanga katoa o te pakihi niupepa me te tā hoki'.

I haere tonu te mahi a te niupepa tae noa mai ki te tau 1937, i hokona, i hurihia hoki te ingoa. Ka riro i tētahi kamupene tūmataiti, hou hoki i Hokitika, me te moni punga o £300 i ngā hea £1 uara, te Westport Times and Star, ka hurihia te ingoa ki te Buller Times. Nō te 1 o Noema, 1941 i mutu te whakaputanga.

E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki nga Westport Genealogy & History Group, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Wanganui Herald
Publication.Description: The Wanganui Herald (originally the Evening Herald) was first published by John Ballance as a daily newspaper on 4 June 1867. Ballance was prominent in local and national politics. He was leader of the first Liberal government and premier of New Zealand from 1891 until he died in 1893. The paper continued to be published until 1986 when a community newspaper with the same name replaced it.

Ko te Wanganui Herald (i te tīmatanga, ko te Evening Herald) i tīmataia e Te Paranihi (John Ballance) hei nūpepa o ia rā i te 4 o Pipiri 1867. He tangata rongonui ia i roto i ngā āhuatanga tōrangapū ā-rohe, ā-motu hoki. Ko ia hoki te Kaiārahi o te Kāwanatanga Rīpera (Liberal) tuatahi, ā, ko ia hoki te Pirimia o Niu Tīreni mai i te tau 1891 tae noa ki te tau i mate ia, arā, 1893. Ka rite tonu te puta mai o taua nūpepa tae noa ki te tau 1986, arā, te tau ka puta kē mai tētahi nūpepa hapori ka mau i taua ingoa tonu. Ko tēnei te nūpepa i whakakapi i te nūpepa tuatahi.
Publication.Essay:
John Ballance established the Wanganui Herald in 1867. He was prominent in local and national politics and was leader of the first Liberal government and premier of New Zealand from 1891 until he died in 1893.

Ballance arrived in Wanganui in 1865 where he set up a shop. He was soon drawn into journalism through his interest in local issues. He wrote occasionally for the Wanganui Times, which at that time was the rival of the established newspaper the Wanganui Chronicle.

In 1867 Ballance bought a press and started a daily newspaper called the Evening Herald, using the paper to express his strong political opinions. He was a member of the Wanganui cavalry troop but was particularly critical of the way military campaigns were conducted against the Māori in the Wanganui area. For this he was arrested and threatened with court martial. Ballance also used the Herald to attack the Chronicle who responded equally strongly. This spirited competition continued until the papers merged in the 1970s.

Despite losing money in its early years, the Wanganui Herald established itself as a viable concern. Between 1869 and 1906 it also published the Weekly Herald (later called the Yeoman). From 1926 it published a children's newspaper as an insert, which was a first for a New Zealand newspaper.

In 1971 the ownership of the Herald and the Chronicle merged. Wanganui, like other New Zealand towns and cities, was unable to sustain two daily newspapers although it managed this for longer than most other places in New Zealand.

The Herald was replaced in 1986 by a community newspaper with the same name leaving its great rival, the Chronicle, to continue as Wanganui's only daily newspaper.

I tīmataia e Te Paranihi (John Ballance) te Wanganui Herald i te tau 1867. He tangata rongonui ia i roto i ngā āhuatanga tōrangapū ā-rohe, ā-motu hoki. Ko ia hoki te Kaiārahi o te Kāwanatanga Rīpera (Liberal) tuatahi, ā, ko ia hoki te Pirimia o Niu Tīreni mai i te tau 1891 tae noa ki te tau i mate ia, arā, 1893.

I tae mai a Te Paranihi ki Wanganui i te tau 1865, ā, ka whakatuwheratia e ia he toa. I muri tata i tēnā, ka tīmata tana tuhituhi i runga i te mea he kaingākau ia ki ngā take ā-rohe. I ētahi wā ka tuhi kōrero ia mō te nūpepa ko te Wanganui Times. Koinei hoki te nūpepa tāwhai ki te nūpepa rongonui o taua wā nā, ko te Wanganui Chronicle.

I te tau 1867 ka hokona e Te Paranihi tētahi mīhini perehi, ā, ka tīmataia e ia te nūpepa o ia rā, arā, te Evening Herald, ā, i roto i taua nūpepa ka whakapuakina e ia āna whakaaro tōrangapu. Ahakoa he hōia ia i roto i te ope eke hōiho o Wanganui, ka rite tonu tana whakahē i ngā whakahau pakanga ki ngā Māori o te rohe o Wanganui. Mō tēnei mahi, ka hopukina ia, ā, ka whakawehia ia kia whakawākia i te aroaro o te kōti taua. I tua i tēnā, ka rite tonu a Te Paranihi ki te tuhituhi i roto i te Herald āna korero whakahē i te Chronicle. Tino pukuriri hoki ngā kōrero whakautu a te Chronicle. Ka pēnei tonu te mahi o aua nūpepa tae noa ki te tekau tau mai i 1970, i reira ka hanumia aua nūpepa nā.

Ahakoa ka rite tonu te pakaru o te pēke o te Wanganui Herald i te tīmatanga, ka pakari haere i ngā tau o muri tae anō ki te wā ka tino kaha ake. Mai i te tau 1869 ki te tau 1906, ka tāngia hoki te Weekly Herald (i ngā tau o muri ka tapaina ko te Yeoman). Mai i te tau 1926, ka tāngia he nūpepa mō ngā tamariki ka whakaurua ki roto i te Herald. Koinā te tīmatanga o tēnā momo wāhanga nūpepa ki Aotearoa.

I te tau 1971 ka tūhonohono ngā nūpepa e rua, arā, te Herald me te Chronicle. I pēnei hoki nō te mea kāhore e taea e te tāone o Wanganui te tautoko i ngā nūpepa e rua. Ahakoa i pēnei ai, ko Wanganui tētahi o ngā tāone o Aotearoa i tino kaha ki te tautoko i ngā nūpepa e rua mō te wā roa.

I te tau 1986 ka uru mai he nūpepa hapori e kīia nei ko te Wanganui Herald. I tēnei nā ka mahue ko te Wanganui Chronicle te nūpepa o ia rā anake i Wanganui.

E mihi nui ana Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa ki te Whanganui Regional Museum me te Wanganui District Library, nā tōna āwhina ki te whakarorohiko i te rauemi nei.

Publication.Title: Waihi Daily Telegraph
Publication.Description: By the mid-1890s, Waihi had a sufficiently settled population to encourage Messrs Galbraith and Vercker-Bindon to start a bi-weekly, the Waihi Miner and Hauraki Goldfields Gazette. The Waihi Chronicle, part-owned by William Wallnutt, later long-time Waihi mayor, sharebroker and contributor to other papers, became a daily competitor in 1900, forcing the Waihi Miner to follow suit. The unprofitable impasse was soon to be resolved.

Nō te taenga ki waenga i ngā tau 1890-1900, he maha tonu te taupori āta noho i Waihi, koia i huri ai a Galbraith rāua ko Vercker-Bindon ki te tīmata i te niupepa rua putanga i te wiki, ko te ingoa ko te Waihi Miner and Hauraki Goldfields Gazette. Ka whai i muri ko te Waihi Chronicle, ā, ka eke hei tino hoa tauwhāinga ia rā i te tau 1900, i huri ai te Waihi Miner kia pērā anō ana putanga. Ko te rangatira o tētahi wāhi o ngā hea o taua niupepa o te Chronicle ko William Wallnutt, he koromatua nō te tāone o Waihi mō te wā roa, he kaipupuru hea, he kaiāwhina hoki i ētahi atu pepa. Nō muri tata mai i kitea he rongoā mō tēnei raruraru hua kore.
Publication.Essay:
Gold was first discovered at Waihi, to the south of the Coromandel Peninsula, in 1878. In 1882 the first battery was breaking gold-bearing rock at the Martha Mine which was later one of the world’s most significant gold and silver mines.

By the mid-1890s, Waihi had a sufficiently settled population to encourage Messrs Galbraith and Vercker-Bindon to start a bi-weekly, the Waihi Miner and Hauraki Goldfields Gazette. The Waihi Chronicle, part-owned by William Wallnutt, later long-time Waihi mayor, sharebroker and contributor to other papers, became a daily competitor in 1900, forcing the Waihi Miner to follow suit. The unprofitable impasse was soon to be resolved.

It is likely that William Geddis, co-owner of Auckland’s New Zealand Observer, with William Blomfield, was interested in Waihi because he was chairman of directors of the Rising Sun Gold Mining Company which operated a mine at Owharoa between Paeroa and Waihi. In the event, with some financial assistance from the Auckland Star’s Henry Brett, Geddis purchased the Waihi Miner. In 1901, the Geddis-Blomfield partnership renamed the paper the Waihi Daily Telegraph. The last issue of the Waihi Chronicle was on 1 March 1901; the first issue of the Waihi Daily Telegraph, billed as an up-to-date, one penny evening daily, appeared three days later. It printed a wide range of overseas cables as well as local news and was a steadfast supporter of the mining industry.

One typical editorial, in March 1905, was highly critical of the Hon James McGowan, Minister of Mines, who had made his portfolio ‘.... a comfortable means to a comfortable end’ and ‘has displayed parsimony towards the industry that he ought to have fostered, but it is reassuring to learn on such high authority [Prime Minister Seddon] that the era of parsimony is at an end, and that the goldfields industry is to receive the encouragement that its importance warrants ....’

Despite his Auckland newspaper interests, Geddis settled in Waihi for a number of years. As well as securing the newspaper’s future, Geddis was elected to the first Waihi Borough Council in 1902. He left Waihi in 1908 to edit and manage the Napier Daily Telegraph, bought in partnership with Henry Brett and T W Leys.

The Waihi Daily Telegraph was subsequently run by Nisbet McRobie, formerly manager of the New Zealand Times in Wellington and later president of the Auckland Master Printers Association. At this time Waihi had three times the population of Hamilton and was the Auckland province’s fastest-growing town. There was competition from the Waihi Times for a period from 1906, but more serious economically to both the town and newspaper was the 1912 miners’ strike.

When McRobie left in 1915, the Waihi Daily Telegraph reverted to Geddis and Blomfield for a period. From 1919, W H Toy, previously on the literary staff of the New Zealand Herald, became owner and editor. Like William Geddis, he served on the Waihi Borough Council. From the 1920s the newspaper was published two or three times a week. After Toy’s death in 1936, his son, W A Toy, ran the paper until 1951. Then a weekly, it stopped publication shortly after the Waihi Gazette set up in opposition.

I kitea tuatahitia te kōura i Waihi, i te pito tonga o te Tara o te Ika a Māui, i te tau 1878. Nō te tau 1882 ka tīmata te kuru tuatahi hei wāwāhi i ngā toka pupuru kōura i te keringa o Martha, ka huri i roto i te wā hei keringa hira rawa atu i te ao katoa mō te kōura me te hiriwa.

Nō te taenga ki waenga i ngā tau 1890-1900, he maha tonu te taupori āta noho i Waihi, koia i huri ai a Galbraith rāua ko Vercker-Bindon ki te tīmata i te niupepa rua putanga i te wiki, ko te ingoa ko te Waihi Miner and Hauraki Goldfields Gazette. Ka whai i muri ko te Waihi Chronicle, ā, ka eke hei tino hoa tauwhāinga ia rā i te tau 1900, i huri ai te Waihi Miner kia pērā anō ana putanga. Ko te rangatira o tētahi wāhi o ngā hea o taua niupepa o te Chronicle ko William Wallnutt, he koromatua nō te tāone o Waihi mō te wā roa, he kaipupuru hea, he kaiāwhina hoki i ētahi atu pepa. Nō muri tata mai i kitea he rongoā mō tēnei raruraru hua kore.

Ko te take i huri ai a William Geddis tētahi kaipupuru ngātahi o te New Zealand Observer, i Tāmaki-makau-rau, me tana hoa a William Blomfield. Te āhua nei ko te take i huri ai a Geddis ki te whaiwhai i ngā āhuatanga o Waihi nā te mea koia te heamana kaitohutohu o te Rising Sun Gold Mining Company nāna i whakahaere tētahi keringa i Owharoa i waenga i Paeroa meWaihi. I te tukunga iho, ka hokona e Geddis te Waihi Miner, ko Henry Brett o te Auckland Star te kaiāwhina mō te taha moni. Nō te tau 1901, nā te tokorua nei nā Geddis-Blomfield i whakaingoa te niupepa ko te Waihi Daily Telegraph. Ko te putanga whakamutunga o te Waihi Chronicle i te 1 March 1901; ā, e toru rā i muri mai ka hokona te putanga tuatahi o te Waihi Daily Telegraph, i kīa e ōna rangatira he niupepa whai pūrongo mohoa, he niupepa mō ia rā, kotahi kapa te utu. Ka tāngia e te pepa te huhuatanga o ngā waea mai i tāwāhi, tae atu ki ngā pūrongo o te wā kāinga, ā, he tino kaitautoko ia mō te ahumahi keri whenua.

Ka whakaputaina e ia tētahi tuhinga etita i te marama o Poutūterangi 1905, i ātete atu ki te Honore James McGowan, te Minita mō ngā Keringa, e mōhio ana tātou ko tāna mahi matua i tana tūnga 'he whaiwhai noa iho i te moni kia rangatira ai tana noho', ā, 'i matapiko rā ki te ahumahi e tika ana kia taurimatia e ia. Engari he pai ki te rongo i ngā kupu a te tino tohunga [a Te Pirimia a Seddon] kua mutu ngā wā o te matapiko, kua huri ia ki te atawhai me te tiaki i te ahumahi keringa, kia eke ai ki tōna tūnga teitei, kia rite ki tōna hiranga...'

Ahakoa ana hea i ngā niupepa o Tāmaki-makau-rau, ka noho a Geddis ki Waihi mō ētahi tau. I tua atu i te whakaū i te noho o te niupepa, ka pōtitia a Geddis ki te Kaunihera tuatahi o te rohe o Waihi i te tau 1902. Ka wehe atu i Waihi i te tau 1908 ki te whakatika ki te whakahaere hoki i te Daily Telegraph o Ahuriri, he mea hoko ngātahi me Henry Brett rāua ko T W Leys.

Nō muri mai ka whakahaeretia te Waihi Daily Telegraph e Nisbet McRobie, koia te kaiwhakahaere o mua o te New Zealand Times i Te Whanga-nui-a-Tara, koia hoki te tumuaki o te Auckland Master Printers Association. I taua wā e toru ngā tāngata o te taupori o Waihi ki te tangata kotahi o te taupori o Kirikiriroa, koia hoki te tāone tere rawa te tupu o te takiwā o Tāmaki-makau-rau. I noho anō te Waihi Times hei hoa tauwhāinga mō te wā mai i 1906, engari ko te tino raruraru nui i pā ki te tāone me te niupepa i te taha ōhanga ko te tū-te-ihu a ngā kaikeri o te tau 1912.

Nō te wehenga atu o McRobie i te tau 1915, ka hoki te Waihi Daily Telegraph ki a Geddis rāua ko Blomfield mō tētahi wā. Mai i 1919, ka noho a W H Toy hei rangatira, hei etita hoki. He kaimahi ia i te taha tuhituhi o te New Zealand Herald i mua. He rite tonu ki a William Geddis, arā, ka uru ia ki te Kaunihera o te rohe o Waihi. Mai i ngā tau mai i 1920 e rua, e toru rānei ngā putanga o te niupepa i te wiki. I muri i te matenga o Toy i te tau 1936, ka huri tana tama a W A Toy ki te whakahaere i te pepa taea noatia te tau 1951. He niupepa ā-wiki ia i taua wā, ā, ka mutu tana puta ki ao i muri tata tonu iho i te whakatūnga o te Waihi Gazette hei hoa tauwhāinga.

Publication.Title: Wellington Independent
Publication.Description: The first issue of the Wellington Independent was published on 2 April 1845. For a time it was considered one of the best newspapers in New Zealand and it had considerable influence. However, it failed to grow in the 1860s and early 1870s and, despite changing from bi-weekly to tri-weekly publication, was replaced by the New Zealand Times in 1874.

I whakaputaina te putanga tuatahi o te Wellington Independent i te 2 o Paenga-whāwhā 1845. Mō tētahi wā i kīia ko tētahi o ngā tino nūpepa o Aotearoa, ā, ka nui anō tōna whai mana. ēngari, kīhai i tino pakari ake i te tekau tau mai i 1860 me ngā tau tīmatanga o te tekau tau mai i 1870, ā, ahakoa atu te huringa kia whakaputaina i ngā rā e toru ki te wiki mai i ngā rā e rua katahi ka tū kē mai ko te New Zealand Times i te tau 1874.
Publication.Essay:
The history of the Wellington Independent is interwoven with that of other early newspapers in the Capital, particularly the New Zealand Spectator and Cook's Strait Guardian (1844-1865) and the New Zealand Gazette and Britannia Spectator (1839-1844).

The New Zealand Spectator began in Wellington in 1844 immediately after the demise of the Gazette (which was New Zealand's first newspaper). In 1845 the Spectator's owners sacked the printers of the paper after they ran a provocative advertisement. As a result the printers decided to set up a rival paper - the Wellington Independent.

The first issue of the Independent came out on 2 April 1845 but publication stopped four months later when the paper's equipment was sold to the Spectator to pay off its owner's debts. The owner of the equipment, Samuel Revans, had previously edited the Gazette and had also supplied the provocative advertisement to the Spectator that led to the printers being sacked. By November that year the Independent got another press and soon established itself as the more popular paper. It went on to outlive the Spectator by nine years.

The Independent was more popular because it advocated for representative government against the Spectator, which supported Governor George Grey's preference for continuing with colonial rule.

According to GH Scholefield (Newspapers in New Zealand, 1958) the Independent was one of the best newspapers in New Zealand. It had considerable influence, which can be seen from the contributors who included James Edward Wakefield, William Fox, Edward Stafford and Dillon Bell.

The paper failed to expand in the 1860s and 1870s but was still a going concern when it was replaced by the New Zealand Times in 1874. In 1873 it was sold to Julius Vogel's New Zealand Times Company. Vogel planned to publish a national newspaper from Wellington to be used to further his political ambitions. In 1874 he replaced the Independent with his new paper the New Zealand Times which continued the serial numbering from the Independent. The Times didn't become a national paper but it did continue until 1927, when it was absorbed by the Dominion.

Kō ngā kōrero tawhito o te Wellington Independent e kī ana i ngā kōrero mai i ētahi atu o ngā nūpepa tōmua o te tāone matua pērā i te New Zealand Spectator me te Cook's Straits Guardian (1844-1865) tae atu ana te New Zealand Gazette me te Britannia Spectator (1839-1844).

I tīmata te New Zealand Spectator i Pōneke i te tau 1844 i muri tonu i te ngaromanga o te Gazette (te nūpepa tuatahi o Aotearoa). I te tau 1845 ka whakamutua e ngā rangatira o te Spectator ngā kaitā o te nūpepa mō tā rātou whakaputa i tētahi pānui taki. Mai i tērā kātahi ka huri aua kaitā ki te hanga i tētahi atu nūpepa kē, ko te Wellington Independent.

I tāngia tuatahitia te Wellington Independent i te 2 o Paenga-whāwhā 1845, ēngari i mutu noa i ngā marama e whā i muri mai i te hokonga o ngā taputapu o taua nūpepa ki te Spectator hei utu i ngā nama a ōna rangatira. Ko te kaipupuri o aua taputapu a Samuel Revans, i tū hei ētita mō te Gazette i mua atu, ā, nāna hoki te mahi ki te whakaputa i te pānui taki ki te Spectator i whakamutua ai ngā kaitā. I Whiringa-ā-rangi o taua tau ka whiwhi te Independent i tētahi atu mīhini perehi, ā, kīhai i roa ka tū kē mai hei nūpepa i paingia e te nuinga. I tū kē mai mō ngā tau e iwa i muri mai i te mutunga o te Spectator.

I piki ake ai te painga o te Independent nā tōna tautoko kia whakatūria he kāwanatanga tā te nuinga e whakatau ai me tohu kia rerekē atu ai ki tā te Spectator me tana tautoko i te kawe a Kāwana Hōri Kerei kia ū tonu ki te kāwanatanga koroni.

Ki tā GH Scholefield (Newspapers in New Zealand, 1958) ko te Independent tētahi o ngā tino nūpepa o Aotearoa. Ka nui anō te whai mana meina ka tirohia ake ngā kaituku kōrero pērā i James Edward Wakefield, Te Pōkiha (William Fox), Edward Stafford me Dillon Bell.

Kīhai i whakawhānui ake te nūpepa nei i te tekau tau mai i 1860 me te tekau tau mai i 1870, ēngari e haere tonu ana i te wā i riro ai ia te New Zealand Times i te tau 1874.

I hokona atu ki te kamupene a Julius Vogel, ko te New Zealand Times Company, i te tau 1873. Ko te whakaaro a Vogel kia hangāia he nūpepa ā-motu hei kawe i ōna ake wawata tōrangapū. I te tau 1874 ka hurihia e ia te Independent ki tana nūpepa hōu, ko te New Zealand Times, i kawea tonu hoki ngā rārangi tatau mai i te Independent. Kīhai te Times i tū hei nūpepa ā-motu ēngari i tū tae noa ki te tau 1927, arā, te tau i riro ai ki raro i te maru o te Dominion.

Publication.Title: Waikato Times
Publication.Description: The Waikato Times began life as the tri-weekly Waikato Times and Thames Valley Gazette on 2 May 1872. It was first published in Ngaruawahia but moved to Hamilton in 1875. The paper succeeded against all competitors and continues as a daily to the present day.

Nō te 2 o Haratua 1872 i tīmata ai te Waikato Times hei Waikato Times and Thames Valley Gazette, e toru ngā putanga ia wiki. I tā tuatahitia i Ngāruawāhia, ā, i nukuhia anō ki Kirikiriroa i te tau 1875. I whaikaha, ahakoa ngā tauwhāinga katoa, me te aha e tū tonu nei i tēnei wā hei nūpepa o ia rā.
Publication.Essay:
The Waikato Times began life as the tri-weekly Waikato Times and Thames Valley Gazette, on 2 May 1872.

The owner was the enthusiastic newspaperman George Jones and the editor Henry Holloway, who had considerable experience in New Zealand newspapers. The paper was first published in Ngaruawahia but moved to Hamilton in 1875. At this time Jones sold out of the paper (now the Waikato Times) and the Bank of New Zealand and Auckland lawyer Frederick Whitaker bought a controlling influence.

From 1878 George Edgecumbe, local body politician and real estate agent, became the paper's business manager. In 1896 the Bank cancelled Edgecumbe's lease and sold the Times to James Shiner Bond. Edgecumbe left to start the Waikato Argus and took with him the editor, Henry Holloway, as well as the files, advertising contacts and goodwill.

After initially contemplating legal action, Bond focussed on the task of rebuilding the paper, merging his Cambridge newspaper, the Waikato Advocate, with the Times. He converted it to a daily (evening) publication. The new editor was Sydney Greville Smith.

The Times and the Argus competed for 20 years, in business and politics, until merging in 1915. The new Waikato Times was now politically independent, but became a powerful voice for promoting the region's development. During the 1920s new linotype and then stereotype presses enabled the paper to significantly increase its the print run in order to meet an increasing circulation demand from a growing population.

From 1968 to 1976 the paper was known simply as the Times. No new competitors emerged and it continues as a daily to the present day.

Nō te 2 o Haratua 1872 i tīmata ai te Waikato Times hei Waikato Times and Thames Valley Gazette, e toru ngā putanga ia wiki.

Ko George Jones tōna rangatira, he kaingākaunui ki te mahi nūpepa. Ko Henry Holloway tōna ētita, he tautōhito i ngā āhuatanga o ngā nūpepa o Niu Tīreni. I tā tuatahitia i Ngāruawāhia, ēngari ka nukuhia ki Kirikiriroa i te tau 1875. I taua wā ka hokona te nūpepa (i taua wā ko te ingoa ko te Waikato Times) e Jones, ka riro te mana whakahaere i te Pēke o Niu Tīreni rāua ko Frederick Whitaker, he rōia i ākarana.

Mai i te tau 1878, ko te kaiwhakahaere pakihi ko George Edgecumbe, he kaitōrangapū o te rohe, he kaihoko rawa whenua hoki. I te tau 1896 ka whakakorea te rīhi a Edgecumbe e te Pēke, ka hokona ai ki a James Shiner Bond. Ka wehe atu a Edgecumbe me te ētita, a Henry Holloway, ngā kōnae kōrero, ngā kirimana pānuitanga, me te kaingākaunui a te iwi, kia whakatū tētahi nūpepa kē, arā, te Waikato Argus.

Ka mutu te whakaaro ki te hāmene, ka whakapau a Bond i ōna kaha ki te whakahou i te nūpepa, me te hono i te Times ki tāna nūpepa i Horotiu (Cambridge), ko te Waikato Advocate. Ka hurihia hei putanga o ia rā e whakaputaina ana i te ahiahi. Ko Sydney Greville Smith te ētita hou.

Mō ngā tau e 20 ka tauwhāinga te Times me te Argus, ā-pakihi ā-tōrangapū hoki, tae noa ki te hononga i te tau 1915. Kāore he kōaro tōrangapū o te Waikato Times hou, ēngari he tino reo mō te whakatairanga i ngā whanaketanga o te rohe. I te tekau tau mai i 1920, nā te perehi whakarārangi (Linotype), kātahi ko te perehi tīwharawhara (stereotype), i āhei ai te nūpepa kia maha ake āna kape ki te whakangata i ngā hiahia a te tupu o te tokomaha kē ake o te taupori.

Mai i te tau 1968 ki te tau 1976 i mōhiotia whānuitia ko te Times. Kāore he nūpepa whakataetae hou i puta mai, ā, e haere tonu nei i tēnei wā hei nūpepa e tāngia ana ia rā, ia rā.
